description:
This truly is as good as it gets.

Don't let the name deceive you. I've had lots of sushi in my life and, to this day, Sushi Zone is consistently my favorite. 

Yes, you'll need to wait if you get there past 7 and yes it's a small/hole in the wall type place (so don't go with more than 4 people). But it will be better/cheaper than any Michelin start restaurant out there. 

I've been here over 30 times since 2010 and have always had a consistently amazing experience. The people that work here are so genuinely nice and take great pride in their work. 

I recommend getting the Salmon and Tuna Nigiri. Some of the freshest fish you can get in SF, it melts in your mouth. Their rolls are amazing too, try the Hawaiin Role #1 & 2 (with Macademia nuts!).

It's one of the last SF establishments that still exists, support them!
author: Eric K.

description:
A solid, no-nonsense venue for authentic sushi from real Japanese chefs.

Nothing will be cheap here, but nothing will be terribly expensive either. I actually found the sashimi combo plate quite a decent deal despite the high initial price tag as it came with 14 decent cuts of fish. Ordering nigiri sushi runs you $7-8 per order, at two pieces per order. The rolls are also quite decently priced at about $10-11 each; I enjoyed the king California roll (real crab, avocado, cucumber, fish eggs). They also have goopy apps that will delight gringo tastes, in particular the baked mussels, which come drenched with spicy mayo. 

Service is matter-of-fact and to the point, while the venue feels like a former diner. All in all, it's about the food here, and it doesn't disappoint. A nice find thanks to all you Yelpers out there!
author: Vincent L.

description:
"This place is literally a hole in the wall!" remarked my visiting friend as we stood in front of the doorway, still studying our phones to see if Google Maps had brought us to the correct place.

While this shop is very small and probably seats only 20 people max (1 bar + 2 tables), it still provides a nice dining experience. Just make sure you're not running on a tight schedule since you will probably be waiting a long while to sit, and a long while longer for your food (there is only one sushi chef). I think we actually waited close to an hour before we were able to eat.

However, my friend and I were both very impressed by how fresh the fish was. This is no doubt some great quality sushi. I'd recommend the sashimi or Chef's choice combo platters if you have the money to spend, but it seems like the most popular items to order are the maki rolls. My friend and I ordered a tuna and yellowtail maki, Alaskan roll, Rainbow roll, and Hawaiian Roll #2. They were each very delicious, but I think the Rainbow roll and the Hawaiian Roll #2 were the most substantial.

Prices are reasonable for sushi in San Francisco--anticipate spending $25-50 depending on what you choose to order and how hungry you are. Overall, it's a nice hidden gem of a sushi restaurant with great quality fish for the price point.
author: Wendy W.

description:
Loved coming here for my first time! Recommended by a friend. Don't let the simple name deter you as the sushi is spectacular. Service is amazing and the owner is the person serving you! We ordered the Sashimi Combination (chef choice), Uni, Hirame, and Spicy Hamachi Hand Rolls. YUM!
We love Hideko and that SHE is the owner! You Go Girl! See you again Hideko!
Heather and Tracey.
author: Heather W.

description:
I love this place. It's no-nonsense. You get in and you eat great sushi. That's it. Very few seats so if you don't get there right when it opens, it's almost worth just waiting an hour and then coming back. I wish they would take your name and number so you can walk away and come back, cause the waiting area is small. We usually get there 15 minutes before opening and there is already a line but with just 2 people, we always can get in.

The sushi chef doesn't seem to be chatty, so I just give him his space. He'll break up your order just so he can give something to everyone so customers seated are not waiting too long. 

Because it's small, it also means few staff. There is only 1 waitress to take everyone's orders. I would recommend placing your order all at once, cause it'll be a while if you add to it. Everything I've had there, I've liked. Even the sliced ginger, and I don't like ginger.
author: Josephine C.

description:
Real deal kind of sushi joint. A real hole in the wall that has bar seating and two tables. Wouldn't have checked this place out until our SF friend told us it was the good stuff. They only open from 5-10 Wednesdays-Saturdays so the window for sushi is small. There was a wait before doors opened. 

We waited maybe 30-40 minutes and ordered baked mussel, Hawaiian #2 and Rock-and-Roll. I liked the mango in the Hawaiian #2, and all of their fish seemed fresh. It was not too over-powering and I've never had fruit in my sushi like that. Baked mussel was a win. Read some reviews how everyone was raving about so of course we had to try it. It was good. If you're with people who have never tried this before, this is a good place to let them try it. It was flavorful, not too fishy, and generous. It was diced up instead of the usual whole piece. 

Great people and great food is really all you need for a great time. If you plan on coming, keep your party small and your appetite hungry.
author: Rae A.

description:
Group of four. Were quickly seated in a half empty restaurant, quickly had our order taken (which was nothing excessive or complicated). Then we waited. and waited. and waited. and waited. It took over an hour to get our food. No one ever checked in on timing. We hadn't ordered much and were still hungry when we finished but didn't have it in us to wait anymore. Went to a different restaurant.

The food was good for what it was. Nothing truly standout. Just a decent sushi spot. They have some more interesting vegetable options than the average place. No real non sushi items - chicken, tempura, etc so if someone isn't done for sushi (fish or vegetable) this is the wrong spot for them.
author: Ryan B.

description:
I've been dreaming of coming here for years. Friends have talked it up and even after living in SF, I never made it. But FINALLY, after a recent trip to The City, I was able to indulge in the glory of Sushi Zone. 

We arrived on a Wednesday evening around 6pm, we waiting for about 30 minutes for a table for 3. Friendly staff, but you have to know where the sign in sheet is. ;)

The baked mussels are a must have. They're the best part of the menu, flavorful, creamy, and my personal favorite- no slurping like oysters. 

We ordered 5 rolls to share amongst the 3 of us, and it was perfect. We left feeling full but not over the top stuffed stuffed. 

Highly recommended. But only if you order the mussels. :)
author: Suzy G.

description:
This is a cool hole in the wall local sushi joint! and one of my favorites in the city.

That's a loaded sentence, so let me explain why.
1. Its a 3 person operation with its own unique atmosphere and quality. Fish is cut thick and is super fresh. Flavor profile has a good Hawaiian influence. Rolls and pieces are messy looking, but very delicious.

2. Bring cash. They don't take plastic. 

3. Expect to wait. Come early or come late. And sign in. The place only has ~16 seats (8 bar, and 2 tables), so it fills up, and then theres a line. Important to note that people take about an hour to eat. So if you come 30min after they open, expect to wait 1 hour for the people seated to cycle through, which means you might wait 2 hours. 

4. Only come if you are in the area. It's not a destination restaurant, and you won't be wowed if you drove 30 min to wait 1 hour.

Overall a solid 5 stars once you understand what kind of food and restaurant you are getting yourself into.
author: James S.

description:
This hole-in-the-wall sushi spot is a gem for a few reasons:

1) limited seating. There's something special when there's a staff of 3-4 waiting on 10-12 people. The service feels more personal and the ambiance, more intimate.

2) sushi bar seating. I love watching the chefs prepare, there's some magic behind the knife work for each fish.

3) off the beaten path. Sure, you can easily stay on Market St. or go to a more high foot traffic area, but I like the feel of being away from the city madness.

4) Japanese operated. Everything feels more authentic when you hear the staff speak in Japanese.

5) fresh fish. You can't go wrong with that!

A few things to note:

1) super long wait. So make sure you bring good company! You'll likely do most of your chatting up while waiting for your seat.

2) cash only. The nearest ATM is pretty far away. Be ready with at least $40 in your wallet.
author: Nitar L.

description:
Rockstar and must visit place for sushi lovers who don't wish or have ton of $$$ to burn. 

Serious place with equally serious sushi curator. This is a must try place for sushi in SFO
author: Umesh P.

description:
SHOW UP EARLY AND PUT YOUR NAME DOWN to ensure a seat asap.

Parking: street, meter, muni

Food: 
FRESH & DELICIOUS. After a year, I finally found a good time to try this place out. The Alaskan Roll was super delicious, as well as the Hawaiian roll #1, spicy salmon roll, etc. Basically anything on the menu. (it is a bit pricy here, so the bill can add up, but come with friends and split and share!)

i'm definitely coming back
author: Cheri C.

description:
We came here on a Friday night on a recommendation by a friend. The wait for a party of three was roughly 30 minutes. While we were initially seated by the bar, we were later moved to one of the two table booths in this small but rather cute restaurant. Ambiance was simple and quant - ideal for a casual date/hang out with friends. Service was slow, but expected in this 3-4 staff run joint. It is cash-only so come prepared. 

Presentation for the food was spot on. I would've however appreciated that the nigiri sushi was plated separately from the maki rolls as the Smoked Salmon Roll came with sauce that did seep onto the nigiri fish.

Sake (Salmon) Sashimi: My favourite. The sashimi pieces were just fatty enough to melt in my mouth. Paired with the lemon, it brings out the flavour so perfectly. Serving was small (4 pieces for $14) but considering how rich it is in taste, you wouldn't want too much of it. 

Hamachi Nigiri: While it was $8 for two pieces, the fish serving was generous. Tasted fresh and neutral. The rice went very well with the fish. Seasoning was on point; texture was glutinous without it being too wet. Would have appreciated if the Hamachi came out first before the Salmon, but that's out of personal preference. 

Smoked Salmon Roll: I was rather disappointed by this Roll just because it didn't live up to what I imagined it would be. For $9.50, it was quite expensive (although subjective as I come from Vancouver where sushi is inexpensive and good tasting). The microgreens, a tab bit overpowering along with the inadequately baked salmon skin made for a mediocre tasting smoked salmon roll. Would skip this and try other maki rolls.

Altogether, I spent just north of $30 (tax+tip incl). I would recommend it for those who haven't been, but it wouldn't become my go-to-neighbourhood sushi restaurant . It is definitely on the higher end of the pricing spectrum so expect to to pay $30-$40 for its authenticity and quality of food but not for its overall dining experience.
author: Raymond D.

description: This place was awesome! I'm not sure it gets anymore authentic.  The sushi was fantastic and the portions were great.  The wait was ok, I think we waited about a 1.5 hrs.  There are only two booths and about 7 seats at the bar.  So you definitely need to get there early or else you wont get a chance to eat.  I wouldn't make this a regular stop if I lived in San Fran, but I might eat there on occasion.  My sushi pallet is not refined enough to notice too big a difference from other places, but they did have some unique rolls and everything was really fresh.
author: Derek S.

description: Ehh, this place is so-so. I've had great sushi at many different restaurants, and this sushi was pretty mediocre at best. Not at all worth 1.5 hr wait. For the price it's alright, but for waiting so long just to get a table and then another 40 mins for the sushi was not worth it at all.
author: Divya M.

description:
Great authentic Sushi spot. They are real Japanese chefs and servers. The food was delicious, fresh, and meticulously prepared. 

This place is a little small, and there usually is a wait (about 40 mins - 1 hour) but it's well worth the wait. The ambiance is cool. Simple and quant little spot. This place is cash only so come prepared. 

We ordered the baked mussel appetizer, 2 pieces come in one order - $7 well worth it! Definitely a must try. It was one of my favorite dishes of the night. Next we got the King California roll (not slathered in mayo and made with real Alaskan crab vs the imitation crab meat like usual spots) $9, Hawaiian 2 Roll, Hamachi and macadamia nuts roll - $9, and lastly the Rainbow roll. It was packed with a fresh assortment of sashimi on top (hamachi, albacore, red tuna, red snapper, and delicious eel) inside was wrapped with shisito leaves, avocado, and some cucumbers for crunch. Totally a great date spot or a spot to hang with friends! Would definitely be back!
author: Jamie C.

description:
My friends and I was craving for sushi in the hot day, so we decided to try Sushi zone. Seems like we're not welcome because we're not regular. She would give seats at the bar to regular couple who came 20 mins later than us if I didn't say anything. Then attitude showed on her face and her voice every time we need to communicate. Service went very slow but I had a hope that food will be fantastic according to yelp review. 

They give you a big pice of fish and fresh. Rolls are just ok. Sake Kama was very salty. 

In short; Long wait, slow service and hospitality is only for regular customer, food is mediocre, reasonable price. Disappointed.
author: Gin C.

description: One sushiman. One waiter. Two tables, a bar. Top notch sushi, Japan level. No frills, it's all invested in the technique of the sushiman and the quality of the ingredients. Seriously delicious. I left the place 30 minutes ago and I'm still drooling. We had nigiris: tamago, masago, Yellowtail, tuna, salmon. Also tuna makis. They gave us a scoop of green tea ice cream because it was my birthday. 150% recommended!
author: Tomás F.

description: This is the best, clean, amazing sushi. The wait can be long since the space is intimate and small, but you sit with strangers and become food friends. Love it!
author: Tyler D.

description: Best sushi I've ever had. My girlfriend and I were lucky enough to get there just as two spots opened up. Very limited seating so you'll likely have to wait but IT IS WORTH IT!
author: Taylor H.

description:
This is a very special place: the only restaurant I've found in SF that feels like a "real" izakaya. I don't mean to say that they serve much standard izakaya fare (this is definitely a sushi-first sushi bar kind of place), but rather that the atmosphere and set-up are exactly like what you'd find at your local neighborhood izakaya in Japan. There kitchen area is tiny and right out in the open, where you can see the one chef preparing all the food, plus one person washing dishes. It's amazing to me that there is such a place in the states at all (especially given its less-than-authentic-sounding name).

Oh, and of course, the quality of the food is spectacular! You won't find many of the rarer types of fish (kohada, kinmedai, etc) but the ones they have are incredibly fresh, and they certainly have all the classics plus some. If you're lucky, you might get to watch the chef masterfully fillet a hamachi. :)
author: Blake A.

description:
Still here twice a month. At least yelp reminds me how many years it's been. 

Hawaiian Roll #2
Papaya Unagi
Spicy Hamachi
Baked mussels
Baked Bass
And an assortment of the sizable nigiri.
Hamachi Kama is one of the best around.
Start with a large hot sake...
...finish with the Oshinko w/ Shiso.

Check out Pisco around the corner if there's a wait.

Don't give up and go to Roku next door. Not even close on its best day.

Look for parking on the north side of market, due to street directions and no turn lanes, it's the last to fill up.
author: Mike V.

description:
This place is super small and can accommodate about `12 -15 people. The prices are also pretty pricey, but their fish is pretty good...for the most part. The wait is really long and it is cash only. Most of the dishes average $12

Got sashimi platter + extra salmon and hamachi sashimi- not bad. Fish did not melt in the mouth but was yummy. No weird aftertaste. 
Hamachi roll- not bad
Mussel roll- did not like it. mussel tasted weird
Mango salmon roll [something like that] - ok

The rolls were a bit too warm and mushy imo. Got a nice amount of fish but some of them had either too much rice or sauce :(

uni nigiri- very small and expensive. not worth it at all and some of it was bitter :( I feel for the price I paid for this, I could go to another place and get yummier. 

Again, this place is just average, nothing too special, but they are pretty generous with their fish proportions.
author: Eva L.

description:
Best sushi in SF. Mussel appetizer is amazing and the service is exceptional.
Come early and put your name in the list.
author: Monica R.

description:
Dinner review. 

Mango hamachi roll - 3/5
Spicy scallop roll - 3/5
Unagi papaya roll - 5/5
Rainbow roll - 4/5
Tekka maki - 4/5
Baked sea bass - 5/5 - Perfect. 

Overall, this is now my favorite sushi place in SF. Good quality and very generous portions. The baked sea bass is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
I have such mixed feelings about writing this Sushi Zone review when I think about past vs. recent experiences.  I remember when I first tried this place and being really impressed with the flavor and quality of their sushi rolls.  However, I don't know if it is just the loss of novelty or if the quality has fallen off, but on my most recent visits, I thought the sushi was good but not mind-blowing.  I also noticed that the rolls were not very well-constructed, with several pieces falling apart.

It's a small restaurant that usually has a long wait, and I think the female server deserves kudos for managing the various customers and never seeming bothered or frazzled.  However, during my recent visit, I noticed that the chef making the sushi rolls ate something off of his hands before going right back to making sushi!  Although I've never seen this type of chef behavior before at Sushi Zone, I don't think I can go back if a chef considers that appropriate hand hygiene.  However, if I aggregate my review and include my past, more positive experiences, I will give it an overall middle rating.  Just keep an eye out on the chef's hands during dinner!
author: Keith H.

description: Put the lime in the sushi! Such a cute little hole in the wall that a tourist would walk by if they did not know about it. Make sure you have cash, it's CASH ONLY!  We are all really pleased with our entrees. Come early the line gets long. P.S. The spicy hamachi was our favorite.
author: Toni C.

description:
Want to eat dinner by yourself or just one other friend? This is the right place. For large groups, not so much. The ambience is a little quirky but service is great. And there's almost always a wait so be prepared. There's only two tables equipped for four people a piece and the bar which can fit about 8 people.

Food is yummy though but a bit pricey. Mango hamachi roll was delicious but couldn't tell the difference between 1 and 2 that much.

Cash only.
author: Mimi T.

description: The food is great but don't come unless you're patient. It's a small place where friendliness to the patrons eating is prioritized over speed.
author: Michael L.

description: Sushi zone is tiny, and can probably only seat about 20 people. However the sushi is super fresh and authentic. It is a three man show, one sushi chef, one waitress, and one dishwasher. With that said, they actually do get to your order fairly quick. The wait time can be pretty long, and the orders are relatively small. Don't come here starving or you will rack up a huge check. With that being said, some of the best sushi I have had in SF, and will definitely be going back.
author: Ross S.

description: Fantastic sushi!  It's a very small restaurant but there was an opening at the bar when we arrived so we were able to sit without waiting. While not a talkative chef I always enjoy watching my rolls made. The quality and experience were really amazing, I'll definitely be back.
author: Justin C.

description: Seriously the best sushi I have had in years.  Spicy isn't too spicy, and the combinations with mango are marvelous.  There is no need for wasabi or soy sauce...It's that good.  Seriously that good!!
author: Eric M.

description:
WORTH THE WAIT! The thickest, freshest sashimi ever. If you go here you have to order the mixed sashimi platter. It's the best I've ever had by far. 

I'm not really into crazy fancy rolls. I like simple fresh raw fish, so this is my perfect spot. If you prefer intricate rolls, it may not be for you.
author: Sara M.

description: Simply excellent. The baked mango striped bass in mussel shells is to die for. Fresh and so tasty especially the Papaya unagi roll and mango anything roll. It's worth the wait! (And there is usually a good 30+ minute wait, but if you are inside you can order beer, sake and edamame while you drool in anticipation!)
author: Joanna G.

description:
A friend of mine recommended me this place so that I tried it out recently.
I found that this restaurant has lots of interesting items such as Spicy Mango Salmon Roll, which was very good, although the restaurant is small and nothing fancy.
Their sashimi looked very thick! I've never seen such thick cuts before.
Their cooked items such as Baked Mussels looked yummy, too!
Will come back although they take cash only!
author: Nick O.

description: Never really had sushi before i went here. It was okay some things worked really well like the california rolls but wasnt really my thing i would say.
author: Anastasia D.

description: This place is tiny, accepts only cash and the sushi sometimes comes out messy looking. None of it matters. The fish is fresh, flavorful and truly fantastic. Everything that could be made in house is including the wasabi. They take no reservations and, unless you arrive at opening time, you will almost certainly need to wait. Certainly its an American style sushi joint that even has a Philadelphia roll on the menu but I suspect it would be considered pretty good just about anywhere. Only 16 or so seats and two tables (the other eight are at the bar) so hard for groups of more than two. Still, all-around excellent.
author: Eli L.

description:
Tiny, cash only, sushi bar in on the border of mission/soma. It seats about 12 ppl at counter and has two 4 seat tables. They keep a white board waiting list inside but don't tell you a wait time so if it's long use your best judgement and go to a bar near by or wait outside. I got there pretty early (6pm) an hour after they open and so there wasn't a crazy wait time. I was starving, so I was excited to order right away, but ended up waiting quite a bit once we were seated. It's less intense and crowded than Ryoko for sure 

I'm a firm believer to not expect amazing service at small hole in the wall places which sushi zone totally is. I won't deduct stars for that reason, although I don't think it's impossible those type of places to odder extraordinary service.

What we ordered: 
2 orders of the spicy hamachi - probably one of the best tasting rolls I've had in a while. The lime on this had me wanting more and more. 
1 order spicy mango- I love mango in sushi, so this one was a winner to me.
1 spider roll- eh it was okay I'm not fan of fried stuff in sushi.
1 salmon asparagus- was one of their specials, wasn't anything amazing , but it was simple which I like. 
1 order of the stuffed jalepeno- first time trying this at a sushi restaurant but I love my spice and this was def good! It was warm and spicy and creamy. Not something you can eat more than one of prob.  I was excited to try this as a starter before we got our rolls but our rolls all came out and we even ordered a second of the hamachi before we were brought this, I had almost forgot we ordered it. 

One thing that I really loved about the mango and hamachi rolls is they added a biter green (not sure what) it was different and tasted so fresh! 

I usually don't go to sushi often and only have tried a few places in the city so I hope to find some other gems. I'll prob be back or get take out from here again!
author: Hetal P.

description:
A real gem. One of my favorite sushi spots in the city.

Be prepared to wait, but it's worth it. And don't forget to bring cash.
author: Julie B.

description: Amazing sushi! This place reminded me of the sushi at this small joint in the middle of Dotonbori, Osaka. Fish is fresh, place is so homey and cozy. Owners are Japanese friendly people. We ordered the Hawaiian #2 with albacore, spicy mayo and some mayo topped with some yummy macadamia! So good! We also ordered the baked bass. That's is definitely a must order! Delicious bass with some cream baked on an mussel shell. Omg! This was new and so good! Will definitely come back!
author: Ibelig V.

description:
Guess it's about time to update my review!

Sushi Zone is still one of my go to sushi spots in SF.  It helps that I live super close too so I can make it early when they open since if you don't do that, you might have to wait a while.  They typically open at 5pm so if you get there about 5-10 minutes beforehand you can be in the first seating.  There's no reservations and it's cash only too.

I usually order just sushi although if I go with friends I'll also get the baked bass which is so good!!!  The fish is fresh and the portion sizes are solid so make it a point to hit up Sushi Zone if you can and enjoy one of the best hidden sushi gems in SF.
author: Gene X.

description:
I've been enjoying Ao's sushi here since '99.  His salmon (sake) nigiri is my favorite because he somehow adds the slightest hint of dill. The baked sea bass app is not to be missed. Your really aren't going to go wrong with any of the time-honored maki rolls, but I really just love the simple mango tuna or mango yellow tail. 
Always opt for at least one hand roll (Ao is sorta famous for these in the rock-and-roll world) and try something new every time. For me recently it was the uni, which I was informed was from Japan when Ao handed it to me. Expect long lines, but really, it's worth it. Try going on a rainy evening or when a big TV event is on to avoid some of the lines. Thanks again Ao for keeping it real all these years! You and the rest of the crew are awesome!
author: Brian J.

description: I love Sushi Zone!  They don't take reservation,but when I don't mind to wait a little bit, this is the place I go to feel cozy and enjoy chatting with staff. They serve good and fresh and trustable foods. My husband likes american style rolls,I like japanese style. It really hard to find a place we both can satisfy, but We both love this place. I can get happy belly and happy mind from here.
author: Keiko W.

description: Fresh, simple sushi with quality taste and freshness, reasonably priced. The staff is very friendly. The wait can be long though, so plan accordingly.
author: Maximus R.

description: Yes, it's small. Yes, it's cash only. However, it is high quality and fairly priced which is rare. The sushi is so flavorful, yet so simple. Not overly sauced or imitation anything.
author: Andrea P.

description: Great quality sashimi and big portions at an affordable price. The wait can be long if you don't get there before they open because its so small.
author: Dulce M.

description:
Been here a few times now, and the sushi is pretty phenomenal! It's all pretty high quality fish and full of flavor. I hate it when fish can be "high quality" but there is no flavor... What's the point!  

Anyways came here on a weekday night, and got lucky to be seated immediately! We ordered a few different rolls, but what was really impressive is how he'll always pair your salmon with dill, kinda his way of making fusion but subtly.  We also got a new rolls that were filled generously with fish and kept the rice to fish ratio in proportion.  

Would come back here!
author: Timothy S.

description: This is a great little gem; the food is stellar and the atmosphere is small and cute. They do magical things with mussels. Check out their hot appetizers. Really unique, one of a kind place!
author: Clarke P.

description:
I thought I had reviewed this before!

One of my favorite sushi spots in the city. It's a small place so expect to wait. And they can't seat parties larger than 6 people. 

You really can't go wrong with what you order but some personal favorites: baked sea bass, Hawaiian rolls, nigiris and Sashimis of any kind. The fish is really fresh so again, you can't go wrong. 

Service is great as well!
author: Laura D.

description:
I was really looking forward to enjoying this place. After all, I'd finally found a sushi spot in San Francisco that prepares baked mussels. After waiting an hour outside for a seat, my friend and I finally sat down at the sushi bar. Space is limited here - there are 2 tables that can accommodate up to 4, the bar can accommodate around 8. 

Service is friendly and quick. That should not be too difficult taking in to account the small space. We ordered the Sashimi Combo, which came with 14 pieces of the chefs choice. The platter included Salmon, Mackerel, Yellowtail, Octopus and other selections I was not familiar with. Though there were two slices each, we could cut each slice in half they were so big. You ever have one of those moments about an experience and say.. 'hmm that's a bad idea', then do it anyway? Well that is how I felt when I had my first bite of the salmon. It had a metallic taste to it. The tuna was meaty, though lacking any flavor whatsoever. I passed on the octopus, not my thing. The mackerel was about the same, not much flavor. 

When the baked mussels arrived I thought, okay those look amazing! The golden brown crust on the outside was deceiving. The inside tasted like mussels and scrambled eggs mixed with mayonnaise. No! Guess I better head back to LA if I want some proper baked mussels.  

After not enjoying this meal, we learned it was cash only. I had maybe $19.00 in my wallet and my friend have left her card in her other wallet. You know how women be changing purses. Anyway, I went to the liquor mart next door to withdraw cash. I was able to get cash, but not the amount requested because the machine ran out of bills. I returned to the restaurant and told them what happened and asked, do you not have Stripe or any device to accept payment? 'No we only have a cash register.' Okay, well 1 you need to jump into the 21st century and 2 where is the next nearest ATM? Walk number 2 consisted of crossing Market street at 9:30pm to a laundromat that had an ATM inside. Bill paid, tip left, we lyfted home. As you do. 

Ohh ho ho but the story does not end there. Around 3am my stomach was not feeling too good. Let's just say my dinner did not remain in my belly very long.... I did not throw it up. 

I most certainly will not be returning.
author: Jaylena P.

description: Now that I'm closer to Sushi Zone, I can't wait to come here all the time. I've been searching San Francisco for a sushi place that I can call my go-to, and I just haven't found it yet because my wallet won't allow for it. Well, no longer will I have that first world problem! A friend brought me and 2 others here, and we had to wait for about an hour and a half, which was no problem since we went to the bar next door and had a drink. We then waited inside Sushi Zone and had some sake and chatted while waiting for our table to clear. It's such a neighborhood gem and I had to practice self restraint from ordering everything on the menu. The spicy salmon with mango and the Hawaiian #2 were my favorites, and I really have to give Sushi Zone props on their spicy salmon. I usually refrain from getting spicy salmon or spicy tuna because of the way it comes minced up, but the salmon was unscathed, lovingly dressed with the spicy mayo, like a spicy roll deserves to be made! Lots of respect for (and lots of saliva while I reminisce about) this place!
author: Jenny L.

description: Best sushi I've had in a while. Make sure you try the baked sea bass- it's amazing. Also had the spicy albacore tuna roll, which was perfect. The place is small and they only have one chef who makes everything, so expect to wait over an hour to be seated. There usually is a line outside the door before they even open! Reasonably priced, too.  Just don't expect 5 star service.
author: Rob M.

description:
Went here for dinner on our first night in San Francisco. The wait was about 2 hours and at first we felt like it was worth it. The Hawaiian role #2 was okay. Other helpers suggested that. The uni and sake sushi really stood out. The sushi was probably a 9/10 but the wait really killed it for us. I know it's a 3 person team but maybe hire some help to move things along. 

I probably won't come back here unless there was a 15 minute wait or less.
author: Vu N.

description:
Easily some of the best nigiri I've ever had. Fish are extremely fresh and delicious. The sea urchin was particularly tasty. Miso soup was good as well. Overall, there is just nothing negative I can say about this place.

From miso soup appetizer to the main course, everything was top notch.
author: Alex P.

description: Great simple sushi. Funky hole in the wall, good vibes. Small, most likely long wait get there early. Good price for quality of fish. Japanese owner, always a plus.
author: W W.

description:
Incredible food,clean, small and cozy atmosphere, friendly service. The baked oysters were to die for. All the sushi was fresh and bar none the best I have had in the Bay Area. That is saying a lot because I used to be in food and wine PR.

I have been here twice and each time I have left wishing I lived closer. This is a great spot to come if you are not in a rush to get somewhere. Space is small so groups of more than six will have an issue unless they get there well in advance of the opening time.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I do recommend just bringing a plus one and no more than 3 others to this very small Japanese shop!  

The wait was worth the trying of their sushi rolls and sashimi!  I like how if you sit at the bar, you can see the chef hand crafting and making the rolls!  Their white rice was super soft and had a light taste of the rice vinegar in it.  

Their Melted Cheese Mussels, is a sure win as a a starter!  It was the perfect combination!  They cut up their sashimi in generous, thick portions.  

The waitress and hostess was courteous and accommodating!  

An above average spot.  I would go here only when I don't have to wait for about half hour for limited seating!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Anything with the word "zone" in it makes me think of Airplane! "Sushi Zone is for immediate loading and unloading of yummy fish only. There is no stopping in the white zone." Sushi Zone is certainly as delicious as Airplane! is hilarious.

I don't get to come to this miniscule spot as often as I would like (that whole pesky problem of living on the other side of the US), but if I were to live in San Francisco, I'd be occupying a stool at Sushi Zone regularly.

I'm old-fashioned with my sushi, so I order the sushi combo, and whoa, it's fantastical. Fair portion sizes, fresh from the sea, and very very tasty. The same can be said for the baked bass. Two women next to me ordered one of these appetizers for each of them which was actually a clever idea. Maybe I'll branch out next time, but for now, the baked bass and sushi combo make me as content as a giant clam.
author: Lisa H.

description: Yes, it's small. Yes, it's cash only. However, it is high quality and fairly priced which is rare. The sushi is so flavorful, yet so simple. Not overly sauced or imitation anything. We went on a Friday around 8'ish. We waited about 10 minutes to be seated and the food arrived timely. The rice to fish ratio was perfect. This lil gem will bring us back to SF sooner than normal. Definitely worth trying.
author: Maricela B.

description:
Cash only. Did I mention cash only? Tiny. Great if you're by yourself or with just one other person. I waited about 20 min before being seated (party of one) and waited another 30 min for my food. I was in no rush, and there was only one sushi chef for the entire place and he was working non-stop, so I didn't mind, but it's worth keeping in mind. Call ahead and ask what the wait is.

The portions were excellent. Not gigantic, but definitely larger than most sushi places and you don't feel like you're paying for more than you're getting. The sushi rice was on point, and the fish was above average to great. When you just need some sushi you can appreciate and you're not in a rush, this is the place to go.

The sushi was almost room temperature. This was good in helping the flavor, but a little colder might have been a nice compromise between taste and the appreciation of chilled fish.
author: Guy M.

description: Sushi Zone is by far the best sushi place in the city. Don't be fooled by the simple, understated down to earth decor, because the emphasis is on the freshness and quality of the food. Each piece of fish is lovingly prepared, mangos and avocados are hand selected for ripeness. Try green tea and sesame ice cream, the best in the city.
author: Nico M.

description:
I really enjoy Sushi Zone however I do feel that it's lost its luster over the years. My best advice to people who have never been is don't count on the traditional rolls or pieces to be the best sushi in SF, but rather go for some of the specials offered that day or week. For example, I just had a dish with baked sea bass, a light mayo and mango sauce served inside a clamshell and it was absolutely epic. It put the sushi to shame. 

Be willing to wait, upwards of an hour, though one can get incredibly lucky simply by showing up at the right time (like I did my last visit).
author: Meredith R.

description:
Spicy hamachi roll and spicy mango roll amazing 
Baked bass must must try..so delicious..
Yes everyone right he is sushi Einstein
author: saim g.

description: The best Sushi Place ever! A small and classic restaurant where the chef makes rolls specially prepared for you. Awesome! I love it
author: Gloria I.

description: My favorite sushi place in the Bay Area. Very fresh fish and a very passionate chef. Love this place!
author: mayank k.

description: This is the BEST place for sushi in the city. It never fails. The BF and I go so often we know everyone there! Hideko, Al, Yoshida, Rie, and Fatoshi are the best! Our regular rolls are spicy mango salmon and spicy hamachi. But their Indian roll is also yummy! They have the best shashimi! If I get sake...I dunno if it's the dill but it has such a great taste!!! Love it here. If it's your first time...don't forget to order their baked bass!! To DIE for. I LOVE sushi zone!!!
author: Cheryl V.

description:
Tiny place but worth the wait. Easy to put your name on then grab a drink at a bar that is close by such as Orbit Room. 

Have to have the baked mussels. So good!! I could eat 10 of these. Everything else is made fresh and right before your eyes. There is a reason there is a wait every night until close for this place even though there is another sushi place next door. 

Prices are reasonable as well. 

Warning, bring cash. You can eat for two reasonably with a small sake between the two of you for $50 with tip but if you want to totally gorge, its going to cost more.
author: Michelle K.

description: Cute little place. Relatively long wait but totally worth it. One of the best sushi spots in the city.
author: Ural C.

description: My husband and I have been coming here for 6+ years (and him before we met). We only make it every other month or so but they always seem to recognize us (even with a very drastic haircut on my part). In the last month we tried two other sushi places in noe, paid the same and ate either much lower quality (think ugly nigiri cuts) or way less (delicious but trendy rolls sans rice). Sushi Zone always leaves a HUGE smile on our faces. Be prepared to wait on weekend but trust me worth it (grab a drink at orbit room for cocktails or zeitgeist for beers). We've had good luck on weeknights. We always get the bake mussels, sake nigiri and hamachi nigiri. We usually get the spicy mango salmon rolls and tuna-masa rolls (both vary a little bit depending upon the level of deliciousness of the mango and avocado). Also don't come with more than 4 (even that is hard because there are two booths and they seat by next available spot which I totally support). I can't rave enough about Sushi Zone.
author: Emily H.

description:
I was thrown off when I walked in (after not waiting in line.... Don't wait in line)

This is very low brow sushi. That being said, if you're looking for affordable sushi at a lower end sushi bar, this is the spot for you. Giving it 3.5 stars since I don't think any other sushi joint in this price point is as good. Rounding down because I probably won't be back.
author: Jeff F.

description:
I'm in the zone. I'm psyched. I'm pumped up. I'm ready to chow down.

The lines around the corner, but I don't care. The wait is over an hour, but it's worth the wait.

My mouth is watering just thinking about their spicy tuna roll and baked mussels. I'm drooling like a vampire. I'm howling like a werewolf. I'm ready to chow down on their sushi.

I've had many spicy tuna rolls and baked mussels from upscale restaurants to mom and pop places, but there's something about how Sushi Zone does their sauces that keep me coming back.

Like a fish on a hook, they keep reeling me in with their spicy mayo deliciousness, and their finely chopped baked mussels. I see them stirring the mayo with the hot sauce, but it tastes unlike any other mayo I've had before. Their secret sauce tastes magical. 

Like wizards and unicorns magical.

Yes, their sashimi is fresh, but you can get fresh sashimi anywhere else. It's the rolls that I come for.

There tables are small, and sometimes when it gets super crowded they make you share tables with strangers. And yes, they only take cash. And yes, sometimes they rush you (hence the minus one star). And yes, it's hard to get a refill on tea or water.

But this is the only place I'd endure that for to get their spicy rolls. Tuna. Hamachi. Unicorns. Whatever, just give it to me with your spicy mayo.
author: Jack R.

description: Definitely my favorite sushi roll place in SF. Every dish I've ordered here since 2012 has been great. My favorites are the spicy salmon/mango roll, the Hawaiian roll #2, and the baked muscles
author: B L.

description:
worst name for a sushi place since sushi raw
annoying wait, but wait for it.. 
this place is absolutely legit.
inventive rolls without being trendy I believe this is the kind of cuisine this chef would make in his home town of Osaka 

To try

* baked hamachi and mango in mussel shell
*exquisite nigiri
*any of the specials on the board / be adventurous it'll be worth it
*shiro maguru belly
author: Ann Oyed ..

description:
This place is among the very few that serve authentic tradition rolls. Very simple yet tasty.  I order:

- baked seabass with mango = creamy texture and fluffy

- baked mussels = mayo sauce does the trick

- spicy tuna rolls = simple and delicious spicy tuna

- spicy scallop rolls = a bit slimy for me and felt a little bland

- Hawaiian rolls = love the crunchy nut topping

The service was friendly and the food was good. No complaining about that, but the parking is a bit of a problem. Street parking is a sure thing in SF but it does not help with this place tuck in a small street with barely any parking. Must come early if you want a parking spot.
author: Owie N.

description:
Very good spot for sushi. We came on a weekday a little after 5pm and there was no wait. Ordered three different rolls - all fresh and I could tell the chef put a lot of care into making each one (we were sitting right in front of him). 

Definitely try the mango sea bass appetizer! Fresh, warm, and sweet! 

It's a very small restaurant with a staff of 3 people and seats for only 16. The menu is pretty simple, but the quality is good. Cash only.
author: Josh L.

description:
Sushi Zone, you got me...

The vast stellar ratings, the hype, and the anticipation of going to the "BEST" sushi restaurant in San Francisco had me giddy with excitement only to leave with a "THAT'S IT?!?!" Talk about getting Sushi blue balls (ok, maybe not but you get the jest--NO foodgasm here). 

Sushi Zone is a tiny, hole-in-the-wall serving authentic sushi with an Americanized flair as you will see spicy mayo, mango, and/or lime in some of their rolls.  Don't get me wrong, Sushi Zone was good but NOT spectacular (the cooked food overshadowed the raw food). I'm not sure if it's worthy of a 2-hour wait and another 1-hour wait for food like most Yelpers experienced. My friend and I arrived on a Thursday night at 5:30 PM and got lucky as we were seated immediately; hence the 4 STARS. 

(Please note: If you come after 5:30 PM-5:45 PM expect at least an hour wait until the first wave of diners leave. When we left at 7 PM, there were 14 names on the waiting list.)

F O O D
*BAKED MUSSELS w/ Spicy Mayo ($6) - 4.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=UOC3kSUsCUxBVqg1XN0BbA
A must order, the tender mussels were diced, mixed with a mayo mixture, placed back in the shell and then baked to a bubbly golden brown. Rich, creamy, and just plain, sinfully good the mussels were. 

*BAKED SEABASS w/ Mango ($6) - 4.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=o1nK3kFcvzqtTIWUJdMj1w
Another must order, the buttery flakes of seabass was mixed with the mayo mixture and bits of mango before getting baked and topped with roe. The pairing of the seabass and the mango was genius producing a luxurious exoticness on the palate. 

*AMAEBI NIGIRI ($6.25) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=DPV_lvLtaId70D8OdcVJBA
The silkiness and the profound sweetness of the sweet shrimp were sublime. The accompanying fried shrimp heads had a crunch sensation that made me weak in the knees. Seriously, if you haven't had fried shrimp heads, give it a try. SO GOOD.

*SASHIMI COMBO (14 pieces - $35) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=6FJNq1QsU8mYHfFdhjPSqQ
The Sake (Salmon), Saba (Mackerel), Hamachi (Yellowtail), Tai (Snapper), Maguro (Tuna), Kanpachi (Amberjack) and Tako (Octopus) were cut in HUGE, unmanageable chunks which severely compromised the taste and texture of the sashimi (had a mushy texture). The sashimi seemed fresh, however, not being able to taste/enjoy the smooth, silky, and buttery texture that a much thinner, more angle cut would have was sorely disappointing especially for the cost of the dish. 

*SAKE NIGIRI ($5.50) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=uFYuIPOWpYPKY9SKX3KQWA
My favorite fish from the ocean, the sake salmon did not disappoint with the melt-in-your mouth texture. 

*UNI w/ Quail Egg Nigiri ($6.75 + $1) - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=7wtAl8mwD_KwElsIfxkDrg
My measure for all sushi restaurants, the uni was a tad dry as it lacked the quintessential custardy texture that fresh, top-notch uni would have. The quail egg came to the rescue adding that layer of moisture and creamy decadence. 

*SPICY HAMACHI ROLL ($7.25) - 3.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=cSfo2ZDkM2-8MMLuwB-5cg
A lot larger than the typical sushi roll, there were huge chunks of buttery hamachi which made for the girth. It was lacking some heat to quantify it was "spicy" though. 

S E R V I C E
Friendly but very slow so don't bring any eager beavers. It was slow when we arrived but it still took about 45 minutes to get all our food.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Old school vibe with wooden furnishings with Tibetan and Buddhist posters and Asian tchotchkes. There's only two tables and 8 seats at the bar so don't come with more than 4 people. 

P A R K I N G
Easy street parking. 

I've noticed the older I get, the more impatient I get. Although Sushi Zone is just 3 blocks from my office, this burgeoning eager beaver prefers going to an authentic sushi restaurant that actually takes reservations like Ino, Koo, or Okina. Holla @ Washu!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Very small place -  bar seating + a couple of booths.  Wait times can easily surpass 45 mins.  The selection is pretty basic, but their sashimi is good and portions are on the large side.

Go sign-in, ask the approximate wait time and grab a drink or two nearby.
author: Leland H.

description:
This is perhaps my favorite sushi bar in the US. Whenever my wife and I travel to San Francisco this is the first place we eat. 

The place is very small and busy so we have learned that showing up about 30 minutes prior to opening is the best bet.

The sushi has always been delicious and the use of macadamia nuts and other unique flavors is intriguing. 

I can't wait to return someday soon with our kids who have grown to love sushi as much as we do.
author: Tim B.

description:
I wasn't too impressed. The wait was far too long, even for one person. They only have 8 bar seats and two booths where they place 2 to a 4-seater often. That's it. No more space. It took an hour from when I arrived to eat two sushi rolls at 9.00 each and was only given 6, not 8, pieces. It was okay, but a bit over-priced. I've had better elsewhere so I'm not sure why this place is so hyped up. The food isn't that great to justify the wait time.

Another reason why there is such a long wait is that there is only one person cooking all of the food and one hostess/waitress for everyone.
author: John B.

description:
Excellent sushi. 

We got there right at 5 and did not have to wait at all. Very happy with everything we tried. Highlights include the baked bass, spicy hamachi roll and the King California roll. We also tried the spicy tuna, Hawaiian #1 and the hamachi nigiri. They were all excellent and I wish we were staying here longer so we could go back! All the fish/produce was super fresh and all the rolls were made right in front of us. Would definitely recommend this to any sushi lover out there!! Is a must visit for sure!
author: Gage B.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city for sushi! Always great service and fresh fish! The baked mussels, mango hamachi, and uni are all a must! 

Get there when it opens if you don't want to wait! It is also cash only.
author: Alison H.

description: Coming in here we ordered the sashimi combo plate, two rolls, and amaebi. Amaebi actually wasn't on the menu, but we asked for it and got it. Please note, it's more expensive than the other nigiri. The actual shrimp itself was great and I enjoyed it. However, the head part (which is deep fried) had no batter. Being that it had no batter, I don't think it was cooked for as long and it wasn't cooked at a high enough heat. Normally when you eat the deep fried head, the head shatters when biting it, but here I couldn't bite into all the pieces and had to throw out some. That was pretty disappointing. The rolls...yea they aren't special. I would say you might get the best value there? That being said, wouldn't come back for the rolls. The sushi plate: we got mackereel, tuna, yellowtail, octopus, albacore, striped bass. Nothing here stood out. The chunks of fish were bigger than other places, but the quality just wasn't there. Some slices didn't even taste like fish. I enjoyed the yellowtail the most, but there wasn't much competition. Overall would not come here. Spent about 40 bucks a person, it's cash only, and wasn't really satisfied. If I spent 20 here I'd say that's very reasonable. I would go to v16 sushi which is also pretty close. You'll spend the same amount of money for much better quality.
author: Victor D.

description:
The fish here is amazing. The quality is top notch and the portions are huge.

If every seat is able to be occupied the max is 17, including the the 2 tables in the window. People, do the math. If there are 6 names ahead of you on the list that means you could wait a whole turn before you are seated. I usually put my name on the list and go for a walk instead of staring at people eating and counting the moments till its your turn to have a seat. You can also order beer and sake while you wait but that can get dangerous if the wait ends up being 2 hours. Basically, for every 10 guests ahead of you think of it at as a 45 minute wait for your table.

Once you do get seated it's best not to order all stuff from the sushi chef or you will wait for another 45 minutes since he's got 17 mouths to feed and yours was last to sit down. Order some appetizers and enjoy your night out with some sake and beer. I've seen too many people get super excited about being seated to super hangry for waiting for their sushi. Also. Order ASAP. If you don't put your order in when the server comes to you she will take another tables order first and that just added on another 20 minutes to your wait.

I love this place and know what I'm getting myself into every time. If you want to sit quickly and eat, sushi delight is down the street with no wait. I'm pregnant and have been eating here once a week for the past 4 months of my pregnancy. Never any issues with freshness and always satisfied. There are plenty of places to grab a cocktail while you wait and the neighborhood is cute enough for a stroll.
author: tinkerbell e.

description:
Sushi zone is one of my all time favorite japanese spots in SF. Having been born and raised in this city, I've had my fair share of japanese restaurant explorations and I must admit, I find myself always coming back to the zone. 

It's a small restaurant with 9 spots at the bar and three tables for 4 ppl each totaling max capacity at 22 seats in the restaurant. It's a small venue and there's only one sushi chef and server per night so be prepared to attend with patience. 

Due to the minimal seating, plan to either arrive before it opens at 5pm every day or come at the very end (930pm). Arriving anytime in between will result in a 2 hour wait, no doubt.

At most sushi places, I'll opt for the nigiri but the mango in the rolls here make it taste so fresh and it's not typically an option so I always maximize on the rolls! 

Here's my classics:
Spicy tuna roll add mango (a must!)
Hamachi mango
Spicy salmon with mango
Hama-masa 
Hawaiian#1
Spicy scallop handroll
Baked Mussels 
Unagi nigiri
author: Lauren Y.

description:
For the boy and my one month, he decided to take me out on a Thursday night to sushi zone.

First mistake was getting there at 8:30 because the wait is FOREVER. We didn't get seated until 11:30 - shoutout to the couple who shared their table with us. 

Seriously, if you are only a party of 2, be a rock star and share your table with another party of 2. It's not scary to eat with other people, in fact, you'd be getting 1,000 positive karma points!!! 

Anyways, aside from the super long wait, baked mussels, spider roll, and the Hawaiian #2 was bomb. While I suffered from an empty stomach and then going to sleep without digesting a thing, the plates were good and fresh. 

Serious shoutout to the sushi chef too. He goes at incredible speeds to make each dish top quality. 

TL;DR: go if you have time to spare, share a table, eat everything
author: Leslie L.

description:
I was so excited that I finally got to eat at Sushi Zone after several attempts of trying to get a table but did not want to wait for an hour plus. 

My partner and I got in around 445pm and there was already a line. Luckily when the restaurant opened at 5pm, we got the last table. No waiting! Well, not really. 

I understand that food is slow to come since there is only one sushi chef and the sous chef only does appetizers. However, getting our food after an hour of being seated, is OK if the food was crazy amazing. Unfortunately, it was not. 

The rolls we ordered (spicy tuna and spicy hamachi) were drenched with mayo mixture that just ruined the fish. The nigiris (unagi, salmon, hamachi, stripped bass) were ok, with the fish/rice combo just being too big for my liking. A good quality sushi is usually small enough to finish in one bite. These were not. The fish were fresh, but something with the slicing, texture and pairing that was off. The rice however was good. 

Bottom line: very slow service, server was nice, sushi chef had a "don't care" attitude, and the food was average, but decent price.

I will definitely not wait for one hour. Go somewhere else if you're expecting great sushi.
author: Anthony T.

description:
I can be a sushi snob sometimes. I generally teeter on the purist side but I can hang with the pseu-shi and jive ass rolls when need be.

Sushi Zone borders somewhere in between purist and jive, but leans further toward jive. (One of my favorite rolls here is topped with macadamia nuts, cmon now) Still, it doesn't mean Sushi Zone isn't good, in fact it's damn GREAT. 

While the fish is fresh and it is definitely worth it to order nigiri and sashimi here, the star of this joint is the baked sea bass with mango appetizer. One order is 2 pieces, so unless you're dining solo you better order another. I know damn well that I always want 2 for myself! It's basically sea bass that's diced up and placed into a New England mussel shell with diced up uber sweet mangoes. There's some sort of kewpie mayo mixture that has a slight kick to it. 

The thing I hate most about this place is the wait. I've gotten more patient when it comes to people these past couple of years but when it comes to food? I've lost it. I can't stand waiting anymore. Your wait here will range anywhere between 45 minutes to 2 hours, guaranteed. If by some how you are here and nobody else is, this place is either closed or JUST opened. Do yourself a favor and sit your ass down and grub.

Have patience because service can be slow.. One chef, one helper, one waitress.
author: Susy C.

description:
Fish is incredible. Great little hidden gem.

Small place, so make sure to plan around the wait :)
author: Noah B.

description:
Close to the Orpheum Theatre on Market St, hubby and I dined there before a show. We got there a little earlier (6pm on
A Fri) and were seated immediately, so the wait was definitely not an issue. Having said that, let me just say that there is a reason many reviews crib about the wait...because there's probably a reason to! The place is tiny. It only has two tables and a bar area which seats no more than 8-10.
As for the food, it was every bit raving about. The mussels with sea bass and mango: warm and melt in your mouth delicious. Out of the three rolls we got, try the papaya and BBQ Unagi one (unbelievably yum) and the hamachi one with jalapeño and lime was amazing too. The fish was fresh and portions ample.

The only reason I take one star off is that they only take cash! --- no checks either.
What an inconvenience this was because there's a single liquor store within walking distance where we had to unwillingly withdraw $ out of (with hiked fees of course).
An establishment this well known should really accept cards...at the least checks. It's down right inconvenient and expensive for customers to go across the street and withdraw money from an ATM.
author: Kinjal N.

description:
Great traditional place!
Pretty small but food and atmosphere are nice!
Not so many choice in the menu but the quality is pretty high.
Price: medium
author: Federica S.

description:
Sushi Zone is, so far, my favorite sushi-ya in San Francisco, both for the high quality and value of their food. However, don't get me wrong, it's also not the most convenient place to stop for dinner on a weekday or weekend night. The main reason being that the restaurant is an incredibly small, family own restaurant with two tables and a sushi bar. Therefore, there is almost always a wait here, regardless of the hour of the day. They also do not take reservations, so sitting is based on a first come (wait), first serve basis. If your party is greater than two people, I HIGHLY recommend arriving upon opening, which is at 5pm, and putting your name on the waiting list; and YES, there is a waiting list when they open. 

That said, Sushi Zone is a great place for authentically crafted sushi, that I wouldn't mind waiting an hour for. Their sushi chef is known for their sushi rolls, nigiri, specials and baked mussels. I have not tried their dinner entrees, although I would not go to Sushi Zone especially for it. 

Presentation is rustic, beautiful and homey. It reminds me of a plate of sushi you will get from a good sushi-ya in Japan. I arrived here at around 5:30pm with a friend for dinner. We put ourselves on the waiting list and walked/waited around Hayes Valley for about 30-50minutes before being sitted. My only complaint is that it was a bit of wait to order and receive our order. But it was fine because we could tell everyone was working hard for there is 1 waitress, 1 sushi chef and 1 assistant. 

After nearly 1.5hrs of waiting, our meal finally commenced. And it was SWEET!
We enjoyed each dish ordered and kept talking about the need to revist Sushi Zone. Despite their small menu, you can't go wrong with any choices. However, I suggest getting their AWESOME signature dishes:

First off, start with their Baked Mussel and Baked Stripped Sea Bass with Mango. Both are incredibly rich and tasty, unlike anything I have ever had!

Then proceed with: Spicy Hamachi Roll (these are HUGE), any sashimi or nigiri (specials are awesome too), and end in a sweet note with their Hawaiian rolls; we had #2 which was filled with albacore, mango and topped with freshly chopped macadamia nuts. We would have ordered more but decided to save our appetites for the next visit. Next time, we're definitely getting an order of UNI!

My mouth waters from simply revisiting my last dinner here! If you are a sushi-fanatics, you must make a trip to Sushi Zone! Come early with a ready appetite for delicious, sweet and fresh fish and rolls, you will not be disappointed!
author: Jenny Z.

description:
The sushi here was pretty good, but the ramen (which I ordered) was awful. I'll eat almost any ramen, so this was pretty disappointing. Mushy, strange tasting noodles. I ordered the sushi as an appetizer, so maybe if that was my main entree, I would've enjoyed the experience more. 

The restaurant itself was quite nice. Cool seating for larger groups in the back.
author: Cody M.

description:
Sushi Zone serves consistently fresh and delicious sushi at excellent, cash only, prices. I've enjoyed dining at this wonderfully tiny place for more than 10 years and it never disappoints. If it it weren't for having to time it right (or endure a long wait) to get a seat I would go there every week.

Masterful sushi chefs, pleasant and highly efficient staff, and great music always. 

Especially appreciative of their generous use of mangos and macadamia nuts in the Baked Sea Bass with Mango, Spicy Mango Salmon Maki, and Hawaiian Roll #2 with albacore, mangos and macadamia nuts. Also love the Seared Albacore and Spicy Tuna.
author: Lisa M.

description:
By far the best sushi I've ever had! The restaurant is tiny. It is literally just one room with two tables, some stools at the counter, one sushi chef, one waitress and one other worker behind the counter.  We waited two hours to get seated and it was TOTALLY WORTH IT! I would definitely go back here and wait two hours all over again for this place.  I went with my cousin and we just went next door to a bar and got drinks while we waited. You put your name on a white board and then you can leave and come back to check where you are in line. If you aren't there when they call your name, they'll go right back to you when you get back to the restaurant.

When we went in to put our name on the white board they were playing some Bob Marley and then it was all Beatles while we were eating. It was a great experience! We sat at the counter and got to watch the chef make all of the sushi. The lone waitress was super attentive and friendly. I don't know what else to say about the sushi besides how fresh and delicious it tasted. Again, this place was definitely the best sushi I've ever had. We also got the hot sake and baked mussels. I definitely recommend the baked mussels as an appetizer. It was great getting to watch the chef prepare our food and then hand it to us. You see all the steps in the preparation of your food.

Also, the prices are totally reasonable.

I can't wait to go back to San Francisco so that I can go back to Sushi Zone! I highly recommend this place!
author: Drew H.

description:
I have always wanted to try sushi zone, finally my day came this past weekend. It's tucked away on a side street visible from Market street. No reservations, limited seating, one server, one bar back(buser), and one sushi chef make it all happen. 

The sushi is worth the wait! Fresh to the max and you cannot miss the attention to detail that really enhances the flavors here. The nigiri is a little pricey at $6-7/ 2 pieces but they are huge pieces and amazingly fresh. The maguro and hamachi were particularly melt in your mouth delicious. Sushi Zone recommends trying their baked mussels or baked sea bass starter. You will not be disappointed! 

The rolls we had were also delicious, we tried the spicy mussel roll and the hama masa. 

We had 3 orders or Nigiri, 3 rolls, 1 starter and 2 beers and it came to $85/with tax and tip. Not cheap, but some of the best sushi I have had in SF!
author: Theresa T.

description: This is where you got to go for sushi in SF. Great people and awesome food. You will love it and the wait is totally worth it. We tried few sushi roles and sashimi. The salmon sashimi could have been definitely better but sushis were great and overal we loved it.
author: Yashar M.

description:
Came here for a girls night out.  Ordered cold house saki and Sapporo for sake bomb. - loved it 


Ordered spicy tuna, spicy hamachi and spicy scallop rolls (I know I love the spice .. I'm Indian ) Loved all of those rolls. 

I would def come back here.

Although there was a 45 min wait, but SO WORTH IT !  But the ambience here is very couply..mostly couples were here.
author: Reet R.

description:
Just a word of advice, these guys don't do take-out and it is cash only. I didn't get a chance to even eat since their scheduling system is beyond horrible, it is virtually non-existent. This confirms the experience of countless other Yelpers over the course of many years! 

You have to write your name on a small hidden 8x11 board (which nobody tells you when you walk in). Apparently this is innate knowledge which one is just born with! People come in and write their name on the board and leave and come back. I waited 15 minutes there and two dudes came in after me. When a seat finally became available at the bar, I naturally went for it believing that I was next in line. It was then that the chef elected to tell me that the two dudes who came in after me were ahead of me! I am sure the food is good, but I don't think I will be coming back due to my frustrating experience!
author: Coco C.

description: This place is a hidden gem (only because I'm usually not in the area)! We went here for an early dinner because we've read that the place is pretty small and there are long waits if you go later in the evening. We got seated at the sushi bar around 5:30pm and it was cool seeing the chef work his magic. Everything on the menu looked good; we had the baked mussels, amaebi nigiris, the sake and maguro sashimi and hamachi mango roll and spicy tuna roll. They were all fresh and tasted great without the fancy sauces to covering up the fish. We will definitely come back again! Just make sure you show up early for a table.
author: Jen C.

description: Very disappointing. Sashimi was not fresh. This place came strongly recommended from a colleague who is a food writer so I'm surprised the fish was not great. Overpriced, overhyped and another disappointing west coast sushi joint.
author: Steve I.

description: The best sashimi in San Francisco! Get the chef special sashimi and you won't regret. I also like the hamachi roll. The service was friendly, all smiles and thank you's. For two people, spend about $80-$100 if you're really hungry. I'm sure you can spend more if you order booze, but I was just here for the sashimi! Happy to have come here! I can't wait to come back again!
author: J C.

description: Came here on a Friday night during prime time. Prepare for a 45-60 minute wait. I have been meaning to try this place since moving to sf but read about long waits. The quality of fish is great and portions are generous. We ordered the sea bass which was a little disappointing since I think there was more mango than fish but tasty nonetheless. We also ordered salmon sashimi which melted in our mouths and 3 rolls- Hawaiian Roll #1, King California and the hamachi roll. I wouldn't reorder the hamachi roll just because it seemed quite bland but again it's rare to find a mid price sushi restaurant with great quality fish in sf. I'd come back again, but likely right at opening.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
What a bizarre experience. 

The food tasted great, service was fine, but man. The interior and ambiance... not awesome. 

I'll start with the food because it's a restaurant after all. I had miso soup, salmon sushi, and the spicy scallop roll. Everything tasted really, really excellent. Good mouthfeel on the fish and scallops, and it was very fresh tasting. The integrity of the scallop roll was disappointing though, it feel apart and was bursting at the seams, as though it was rolled too tightly. But whatever, it was delicious, not a big deal. 

As to the interior and ambiance: it's a very small and bare bones place. The kitchen and the food is right out in the open: the actual sushi bar, the grill, the sink, the dishwasher, and bowls with edamame stacked high on top of each other next to the microwave, where they are heated. The industrial refrigerators are in the dining area. And finally, the bathroom was the storage area for all their cleaning supplies which just felt... weird. And a little gross. 

Anyways, I will definitely come back for the food, now that I know what to expect. But let's just say that it won't be for a proper date night. 

Also, heads up, it's cash only and they don't have an ATM onsite. There is one in a little bodega just up Market street, before the Laguna intersection.
author: Allison S.

description: My favorite spot in the city. So yummy fresh and delicious but you will have to probably wait to get seated
author: Lolo P.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city. All the ingredients are incredibly fresh and combined in the most unique and intricate manner. I came with my sister around 6 pm on a random Monday evening (which is actually the ideal timing / day to come bc the place is tiny and they don't take reservations so it's essentially first come first serve). We ordered the following: 

- seaweed salad
- baked mussels 
- miso soup 
- spicy salmon with mango
- rock n roll
- hamachi roll
- Hawaiian special #2 

The baked mussels were phenomenal - chopped up mussels with flavorful sauce (literally tasted like creamy buttery deliciousness that just melted in your mouth). Nothing like I've tasted before. Each serving comes with 2 and I definitely wanted more after I downed my one mussel. Maybe order 2 servings so you can have 2 each with your friend / date. 

I thought the Hawaiian roll was unique but wasn't as amazing as the spicy salmon w mango and hamachi roll. All in all, the ingredients tasted super fresh and this place is definitely my favorites. The venue is a bit on the smaller side, so try to avoid coming on a popular evening at a popular time (i.e. Friday or sat night at 7.. As ull be waiting for awhile).
author: Heather Y.

description:
I feel like this is another case of "the emperor has no clothes". Why is this restaurant constantly touted as one of the best (if not the best) sushi restaurants in the Bay Area? Sure, everything was tasty, but I found nothing about the food to be different from the millions of other good, reasonably priced sushi restaurants in the area.

Baked bass: Creamy and rich with its combination of fish and mangoes. Delicious and a good example of the non-sushi part of Japanese cuisine that is often overlooked. However, I don't know that it's worth a repeat visit as it is a pretty simple dish that could easily be recreated at home.

Hama-mass roll, spicy mussel roll and spicy hamachi roll: Larger-than-average pieces, smaller-than-average portions. That translates to about 6 pieces per roll that are each difficult to eat in one bite. I would have much preferred the opposite. My friend and I are both hamachi lovers and we found the hamachi here to be less than fresh--way too soft (almost rubbery) and a little too warm. The mussels were okay, but they were cooked, so it was nothing special.

Amaebi shrimp: One of the specials of the day. Decent portion for the price. The raw body was nothing spectacular, but the battered and fried heads that were later served were fantastic. The best part of the meal, in my opinion. 

Unlike some other reviewers, I was actually most impressed with the service. There was only one Japanese woman manning the whole restaurant, but she was super friendly and attentive, always answering our requests with a smile and even teasing us at times when she had a free moment. 

For those concerned with the wait, my friend and I got there at around 6pm on a Friday evening. I was about 5 minutes earlier than her and there was only one other party of 2 ahead of us. The wait time between when my friend got there and when they called our names was roughly another 5 minutes. Perhaps we lucked out and came during a lull on a Friday evening, but both of us were expecting a far worse wait.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I'm fortunate enough to have lovely gentlemen friends who live within a block of this restaurant and therefore can place their names on the waiting list and wait at home which makes the wait much less of a big deal.

As previous reviewers have noted, this place is tiny and seats 2 booths (5 people each) and a bar that has about 10 seats.  For a decent sushi place in a trendy neighborhood, the wait of course will be long for most.

Definitely a family-run affair with just one chef and one waitress.  There is passion and care in what they do and it does reflect in the adventurousness in some of the very traditional food options.

****Miso soup - a slightly above average miso soup - the miso they use is good.
*****Baked Seabass with Mango - I was incredibly skeptical about this mix of baked fish, mango and Japanese mayo topped with roe, but it turned out to be my favorite of the night.  Very very good and a must order.
***Hawaiian Roll - Good, but the textures threw me a bit... really soft melty fish with crunchy macadamia nuts... not sure if I'm a fan.  The roll was falling apart a bit which was a sign that this was hastily put together.
**Spider Roll - I love soft shell crab, and I've had this roll at many places before... and this one didn't really cut it for me.  The rolls was sliced too thin and the whole thing was falling apart.  The taste wasn't memorable.
*Papaya Unagi Roll - Kinda weird!  I don't think I enjoyed the mix of a large chunk of papaya with unagi.  It's definitely not a roll for purists.  Papaya just isn't a strong enough fruit to counter the distinct flavor of unagi.
***Omakase sashimi platter (14 pc, around $40) - nothing special on this plate, but the quality of the fish was good and fresh.  Being a small restaurant, I wasn't expecting anything beyond the usual maguro, hamachi, sake, tako, etc.  But it would have been a nice surprise to see some katsuo or uni or something.  Not sure this plate is worth it... I can get a similar plate at Sushitomi in Mountain View for cheaper and with more variety.  The cuts were pretty thick, but the 2 pc each could easily have been 3.

You can have order beer and sake here which always makes sushi taste better.  I'm a fan, and I would come back.  Support small businesses!
author: Ruth C.

description:
I have been looking for a All you can eat Sushi place and tonight  found it. It is great. They don't rush you, the food was all amazing and the customer service was awesome. I like hearing the people who work there remember customers names and welcoming them back. 
It's an A all the way ..
author: Patsy M.

description:
Wait can be long (2 hours on a Friday night) and people can be crabby because of it (but there are nearby bars to pass the time) but worth it for the baked mango seabass! It was heaven in my mouth!

We also ordered the baked mussels, spicy hamachi roll, Rock n Roll  roll (just ok), and the mango/avocado roll. 

Would definitely come back for the baked mango sea bass!
author: Siv L.

description: A small place with great ambience. Perfect to dine alone or with a few friends. Baked mussel and hamachi are must have. Sushi roll is also decent but not among the best I ever have.
author: Sen F.

description: Favorite sushi place in the city. Even on a Tuesday you'll be waiting an hour or two, but completely worth it. tiny space, fresh product, good service. cash only. I crave the sushi here regularly. tried lots of other joints but this is the real deal. excellent quality and worth the money.
author: Zara S.

description:
Really long wait. 

* Great maki (really great spicy hamachi)
* Good nigiri
* Nice people 
* Tiny space
* Too much wasabi in nigiri

I should have taken up my friend, Doris C's suggestion and gone for sashimi. 

A lot of people here are not necessarily into sushi or know what's good about sushi.

There is nothing fancy about Sushi Zone and it doesn't try to be fancy; just serving up fresh fish and creamy makimono. There is no toro but we did have very tasty amaebi.

The great thing about my experience here is that the sushi here made my bf realize how much he loved Sushi Sam.

Boyfriend's thoughts: 
* Fish was out too long; was too warm for serving

Even I think that's crazy picky.
author: Margaret S.

description:
My rating is for the food!! Of course there's a wait there's only 2 tables, ur a fool if u think u won't wait. Just get there an hour and half earlier then u want to eat and hit up 1 if the amazing bars in the area checking the list every 30 min. 

MUST EAT HERE
author: Lisette P.

description:
Hawaii #2

Baked sea bass

Salmon

Unagi

I came an hour early to get a seat! Worth it.
author: Christina K.

description:
Urban Dictionary: Hidden Gem- picture: Sushi Zone, link: my yelp review.
