I love this place! I want to start off by thanking all of the beautiful people of SF for being too busy partying the night before pride and making my wait on a Saturday night only twenty minutes. 

Yes, the wait can be a real drag. This is were the hidden part comes in. The place is super tiny. Has two booths and about 10 seats at the Sushi Bar, the super limited seating makes it ideal for couples. You walk in put your name on a white board and wait. Stick around because they will skip you if your gone. Bring CA$H! This place is cash only. 

Now that we have that out of the way I can focus on telling you how amazing the sushi is. 

To start we had a Miso Soup. Followed by the must have Baked Mussels with spicy mayo and scallions and the even more to die for Baked Bass with mango, spicy mayo, & fish eggs. I dream about that Baked Bass!!! If I had enough discipline to cut back on the sushi here I would order the Baked Bass for dessert. 

Okay, next we had the Spicy Tuna Roll, Spicy Tuna Hand Roll, and some very fresh Sashimi Sake. The couple next to us were regulars and highly recommended the Hawaiian Rolls. We ordered them and once again I fell in love. They were so fresh and delicious. 

The freshness and price point make Sushi Zone worth the wait. It is definitely my favorite casual sushi spots in SF.
author: Caro S.

description:
Unique Hawaiian style sushi rolls.
Great price. The restaurant is small and you have to wait quite long.
Service is slow...
But I will come back to try more dishes.
author: JK C.

description:
Very rarely is an excellent place just as excellent on my 2nd visit.  Two years later finally made it back here.  Pathetic to say, Sushi Zone was part of our reason for visiting San Fran again as a side trip to LA visit.
No wait as we got there right at 5pm on a Wed.. then the line started.  But if you have a wait, it is worth it.  This place is as good or even better than the top sushi places in NYC at half the price.
Best damn sushi I have ever had still..and the rolls.   5 ++++ stars!
author: Alexandra C.

description: Oh man, I feel bad writing this review.  It's a mom and pop place, and as non-commercial as you can get.  They have a big following and tons of reviews, so go ahead and go if you believe what you write.  As much as I'd love to support a local gem, honestly the sushi was average at best.  The tuna jalapeno pepper app was rubbery and flavorless, the spicy hamachi was sour and boycotted by the sidekick, spicy salmon was good, real crab something roll was fine.  Nothing to rave about esp with the ratings seen here.  My guess is the family vibe makes you want to support it like the paralympics, even though you don't really watch the paralympics.  My faves in and around this city: Zushi Puzzle (a place where the Yelp ratings actually match the hype), Domo, Sushi Time, Sushi Bistro, and Yuzu/Sakae (burlingame...i know, gross).  Even without those place in the running, this isn't holding a match.
author: A A.

description:
I'm not even sure I need to write a review, because there are so many good ones, but really it's more for me so I remember what I ordered and how amazing it was for the next time we go. We tried to go earlyish on a Friday night, but there are about 2 tables and 10 seats at the sushi bar, so we gave up and went somewhere else.  On our way back to the car, it was about 10 minutes before they closed and we decided to have a sushi night cap. It was well worth it.  

We ordered the stuff jalapeno with ahi. This was amazing, creamy deliciousness that I keep having dreams about. Imagine a baked (in a toaster oven, mind you) jalapeno stuffed with ahi and some kind of delicious sauce (probably mayo) with a nice golden brown top. Sooooo freaking good. For my roll I chose the hama-negi = yellowtail with scallions. It was really fresh and delicious. Um, how many times have I said delicious in this review?  Does it matter? It was! Can't wait to go again.
author: Sara R.

description:
Did you eat a super big lunch but still want/need to go out for dinner? Is it 5 pm and you don't have anything else to do before dinner? Lyft to Sushi Zone, put your name on the list, walk a few blocks to Safeway to withdraw cash, wait to be seated. By the time it's your turn to eat, you'll finally have digested your huge lunch. 

Sushi Zone has good sushi. However, I hesitantly say that the food was worth the wait (about 2 hours on Friday night) and I doubt I would actually wait again. 

Food: 
Baked bass: served with the spicy mayo and mangos in a mussel shell. The mixture tasted really interesting and I enjoyed the contrast between the tangy sweetness of the mango with the creaminess of the sauce over the bass
Baked mussels: as good as everyone says. The mussels are mixed in the spicy mayo and put back onto the shell to bake 
Spicy tuna roll and spicy hamachi rolls: I'd recommend the spicy hamachi roll over the spicy tuna and to get another non-spicy roll as your second. Not that the spicy tuna wasn't good but because both rolls use fish that is mixed into the spicy mayo. I didn't realize this and would have liked a roll where you could taste the fish more
Hawaiian roll #1: good but the macadamia nuts were a little overpowering 

Service: I'm amazed at how hard everyone works here. The two chefs and one server work nonstop. We had ordered and started devouring our two appetizers and two rolls when we realized we needed more food. We asked for a third roll and the server put our order in the front and we got it in a matter of minutes! We hurried to scarf it down, leave a sizeable tip for the fast turnaround, and rushed out of there. 

3 rolls + 2 appetizers + large beer + edamame + tip = ~$70 not bad!
author: Diana N.

description:
If you can get in before the line starts, you won't regret it. This place seats around 15-16 people, and is cash only. 

We loved the incredibly fresh sushi and amazing appetizers. You will not go wrong with the baked sea bass, Hawaiian roll #2 and spicy hamachi. Be sure to order something for your dinner guest too. Wash it all down with a Sapporo or some saki.
author: S K.

description:
TLDR: Not worth the ridiculous wait. Good sushi.

I can only imagine the people who reviewed this place highly were either 1) In a stroke of luck got seated and served right away 2) Too obsessed with being part of a fad to not have much respect for their own time.

We all have a short time on this planet and everyone is trying to make the most of it and wasting precious hours at this place is NOT a recommended way to do so.

Weekday night we were next in line to get seated, took us almost an hour to get seated and another one hour to get our sushi. Yep two hours before we saw food. Service is extremely casual and the waitress spends more time chit chatting with patrons than worrying about the people who are half way into their graves waiting to get seated/being fed.

Quality of Sushi was good but not great. Honestly just walk to another joint in the neighbourhood and save some time for yourself.

Not coming back.
author: Nadeem K.

description: Very good sushi in a very small place which gets crowded because it's really good. We love getting into places like this which become gems for our next trips
author: Stephanie D.

description: One of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city. Baked bass, Hawaiian rolls are a must. Also the roll with papaya in it is amazing. Small locations with 10-15 seats so there's always a wait if you don't get there around opening time.
author: Tina W.

description:
I must be one of the few customers of Sushi Zone underwhelmed by the food. It's likely due to the fact that everyone had been hyping up SZ for years -- quality of food, prices, etc. I'll agree that prices are affordable and reasonable for the type of food and quality of fish. I wasn't as impressed with the flavor or execution, however. This is what we ordered:

baked mussels
sunomono with octopus
tamago nigiri
uni nigiri
ikura nigiri
hawaiian roll #2

I would likely return for some normal fanfare (nigiri and some cooked dishes), but if there's a long wait, I'd head elsewhere or go to Roku for something entirely different.
author: Johanna L.

description: Wait took forever and the place is kinda cramped. But the food was really really good. You don't even realize that the place is two dollar signs with the quality of food that you get.
author: Mark Y.

description:
I haven't come here in a year but it's just as good as I remember it being. Always make sure to come here early right before they open or you may end up waiting anywhere from an hour to two. 
The place itself is very small, maybe being able to serve 20 people, if that. This place is also cash only so make sure to come prepared!
Things I always suggest to get here: 
baked mussel appetizer
Spicy mango salmon roll
Hawaiian roll #2
You seriously can't go wrong with those three and the rolls themselves are very decently priced at $8.50 a roll. 
I decided to be adventurous and try some nigiri as well. The slices of fish may as well be sashimi they're sliced so thick! Definitely no complaints from me there. My absolute favorite part of what they do here at Sushi Zone is they flavor the sushi rice and flavor it deliciously. This is the only place I know of that does such a good job of seasoning their sushi rice. 
This place may be difficult to get to, park, and wait for. But it is definitely worth trying out at least once!
author: Joy S.

description:
First time I went here it was great.
Second time my wife and I definitely got food poisoning. 
Will give it one more shot before deciding whether it's worth ever going back to.
author: El D.

description: The sashimi was not good and the nigiri was not good either. The fish seemed to be from yesterday or the day before. This is unfortunate as Sushi Zone is very well reviewed. I'd look elsewhere if you are in SF and looking for good sushi/sashimi.
author: Andrew M.

description:
First things first, I love Sushi Zone, and have been the biggest fan and advocate of this place since I first found it in 2007. That said, we went in last night and it's just not the same. The older fella who is usually making the sushi was doing the prep work, and washing dishes. Fish and rice quality was wonderful, as usual - tako, sake, hamachi, albacore, tamago. We had all nigiri and 2 basic hand rolls. 

Here's my take away:

Bad cuts of fish
Rice ball for nigiri was oversized 
Nori wraps on nigiri didn't fully wrap around
Nori paper on hand roll was not toasted - it was soggy. 
Hand rolls were not tightly rolled and fell apart - messy. 


All in all, just poor skills by the chef. Prep and execution are everything in sushi, and this guy was just pushing volume food, not like love and dedication that old guy put into every piece. 

Can the switch back be made? SZ was the best sushi in the west, now it feels like just another volume sushi house with an undeserved following. 

Bring back the old chef, we miss him.
author: Sharon N.

description:
Came here with a party of 3 at 4:45 on a Thursday night and there was already a line.
I'm extremely glad that I came early, because there's only one chef, and we didn't get our food until about 6:45. Started off the night with a hot sake--very good.

The lady is extremely nice and helpful with ordering.

Garosaba
King California 
Hamamasa
Mango Hamachi 
Rainbow Roll: YES
Stuffed Shitake Mushroom
Baked Sea Bass: Amazing!!
Mackeral

There was nothing bad. This was probably the best rainbow roll I've ever had. The sushi was not traditional in taste, but the balance of rice and fish/vegetables was exactly how I've always imagined them to do it in Japan. Not filled on rice!!!

Damage? $100 (t&t included)--not bad! Super full, had a great time, satisfied.
author: Adorable T.

description:
This is such an amazing sushi place, but it is super tiny and there will be a wait! Trust me, the wait is worth it!

Just how small is it? There are only 2 tables here with group seating (4 people per table) and space at the sushi bar for up to about 6 people. So, it's probably best to only bring 1-2 friends here at a time. I would also recommend this as a good date spot.

I came here with a friend on a Tuesday night around 8:00 pm and waited an hour for a seat. The wait was fine because we just signed up on the list and went next door to Pisco Latin Lounge for drinks, which was the perfect way to kill time. 

At about 9 pm, we were seated at the bar. There was only one waitress there and she took our order quickly. There is also only one sushi chef there and our order came out in just a few minutes. 

We attempted to be adventurous and ordered the Hawaiian #2, which had mango, hamachi, and macadamia nuts on top. It was surprisingly good! We also ordered the Octopus roll, which was okay, but we thought it was a bit too chewy.

The couple next to us had the baked oysters which smelled amazing and looked delicious. It was highly recommended to us by the couple, but we were too full at that point to order them. I will have to try them next time!

We also had the unagi sushi and suzuki sushi. The rice in both were perfectly seasoned - slightly sweet and perfectly complemented the fish. 

Overall we had a great experience here. For good sushi that doesn't break the bank, this is the place to go!
author: Katherine Y.

description:
First of all, the food taste good here. The he knows that the sushi rice should put in a wood basin stir with vinegar. And he knows what is sushi cut. However, I give this place 2 star for reasons.
First of all, he is too slow. I don't know how can he make a California row for 20min. And probably my bad luck, there were two table were his or the waitress' friends that they spend so much time on chatting. It make those bitches hold the table for three hours after they finish eating. 
Secondly, this is not a cheap fast food. It is a fairly expensive restaurant. Why it is cash only??? Why??? I can't think of any reason that they don't take credit cards! My husband and I ordered $100 food, just two people. Many places even don't take a $100 bill.
Finally and the most importantly, I don't know how the 100 food safety score scored. My husband and I started to have upset stomach in two hours after eating. Then diarrhea. We didn't eat anything before this meal. 
We won't go their again, for people who are going to visit, think about it.
author: Cherlyn H.

description:
I've tried FIVE DIFFERENT TIMES to go here. FIVE. For awhile (at least the awful awful crap year that was 2011) it seemed like I wasn't going to ever get in. 

Tonight (2012) changed that. 
Plan of attack- arrive at 4:45pm. Wait. Second plan of attack- if this fails... THERE WILL BE NO FAILURE! 

So Dream Team went at 4:45pm... and... crickets. Well, actually, one Finnish dude and his 3 kids- one of whom was not wearing pants I GUESS THAT'S HOW THEY ROLL IN FINLAND. But seriously. Just us. *Crickets.* 

Dream Team then contemplated what could happen to make this go wrong. Surely, it can't be this easy. Turned away 5 separate times due to an excessive wait, and then once due to the fact there were closed for 2 weeks. But here they were. Open. Here we were, in line. Could they be out of mussels? "I don't care I will ask for whatever fish they have on rice please kthnx." What if there is a fire? "Grab the fish and run." 

Turns out, nothing went wrong. Nothing at all. I ordered salmon nigiri, salmon maki, tuna maki, and baked mussels. $23.50. Seated at 5, served at 5:30. 

Now I want to make something crystal clear, so pay attention. 

Are you focusing?

Really? Stop speed reading and focus on my words.

This is the best sushi I have had outside of Japan. In fact this beat places IN Japan. This fish left me speechless. 

I had to take the salmon off the rice because I felt the rice was compromising the beauty of the fish. It was, without a doubt, not even kidding, I swear I felt like I was eating a stick of butter if you had blind-folded me and told me it was I'd have believed you: 

THE.
BEST.
SALMON.
IN.
AMERICA.  

So if you don't want to wait, if you don't want to order anything other than some fruity-nutty-cream cheese and eel roll, if you just want a "California roll,"

Thank you. You have just made my wait shorter AND it means more of the best stuff on EARTH for me.
author: Emily D.

description:
When we first came in, we were surprised at how tiny the place was. In totally they can only sit around 16 people (including the counter and two tables). Luckily others on the waiting list weren't there when a table was empty so we didn't have to wait for more than five minutes for a counter.

Between the two of us, we got the baked sea bass, rainbow roll, Hawaiian #2 and the mango. The prices are insane - approximately $7 for a roll (except the rainbow roll which has more fish and is larger).

We've never had fusion Hawaiian Japanese food before so we didn't know what to expect. First came the sea bass - I looked uncertainty at the two shells that looks nothing like the sea bass I normally eat. Turns out it's a creamy concoction with a thin layer of sea bass at the very top, mixed in with some delicious spicy mayo. Yum. The Hawaiian roll is recommended! I love the crunch from the macadamia nuts sprinkled throughout the roll. The mango roll is also yummy as I'm a huge fan of mangos. We were still hungry after this so we continued on with the more expensive rainbow roll ($12) and weren't disappointed. The amount of fish on the top is very generous. Plus, it's so exciting to see the chef at work with our sushi the entire meal!

Tip: cash only
author: Genny C.

description: Don't be deterred if the wait is long, this place is well worth it! It's a tiny place and it is cash only so come prepared. The fish is always super fresh. The two sushi chefs that alternate days and the waitresses are all amazing. I personally love getting a Spicy Tuna Hand Roll and various nigiri but honestly you can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The Hawaiian Rolls and Baked Bass are both favorites, also. I almost don't want to share my love for this place because I don't want the wait to be even longer but it's awesome and I want them to be in business forever!
author: Katie B.

description:
If you're willing to endure the wait, there is some bomb-ass sushi to be had here.

Make sure to get there EARLY and make a bee-line for the mini-white-board list to put your name down. We got the name down for our group of four at 5pm on a Sat. evening, which was pretty much at opening time. 

Not good enough. 

There were three other groups of four in front of us, and we had to wait about an hour and fifteen minutes before we were seated at one of only two tables for four. After we were seated, it was about another 45-60min before we were served our main sushi. The wait is somewhat justified by the fact that there's only one sushi chef, and he obviously takes great attention to detail in his work, but just don't expect this to be an expedient affair. 

Now on to the actual food.

This fish is legit. After waiting for an eternity, you're going to want to get your monies worth, so make sure you don't leave this place hungry. I got the Sushi Combination Platter, which featured six pieces of nigiri and a California Roll, and supplemented that with a Hawaiian Roll #2. The cali roll was average, but the nigiri was very impressive, with the salmon and albacore tuna standing out in particular. Next time, I'd probably just get a bunch of salmon nigiri and would be pretty damn happy with just that. The Hawaiian Roll #2 combined albacore tuna and mango for a refreshing taste, topped with macadamia nuts for a sweet/salty taste profile. Different, but definitely tasty. 

It came out to about $30ish per person on just food, no drinks, which isn't that bad considering the quality of fish. Just make sure to go with people you can have a deep and serious conversation with, because you're going to have a lot of time on your hands before you're stuffing your face.
author: Greg L.

description: This is by far my favorite place! I love it here. I have had so many amazing dinners and experiences with friends and loved ones. Great for dates or business. I love the baked sea bass. I know the wait for some is to much - but for me it is part of the amazing dinning experience.
author: B M.

description:
8 seats at the sushi bar + 2 tables for four (YES, I counted :P) and that's the simple reason why you must wait. And of course, for the FISH!!!

Try to come early and once you get here, zoom your way through the waiting crowd and head straight to the mini-white-board-waiting-list by the counter on the right. It's usually at least an hour wait, but it goes by quickly. My friend and I entertained ourselves with a walk around Haye's Valley and before we knew it, it was dinnertime baby!

My friend and I both agreed, the sashimi is legit. We ordered a serving of my favorite hamachi and let me tell you, the chef was not conservative with the slicing at all. Even the fish in the Spicy Hamachi was thicker than what I had expected. It was so good!

We also ordered the Baked Mussel and Baked Sea Bass and they were simply delicioussss. What baked seafood isn't? But there's a not-so-secret-super-cool ingredient ... mangos! Interesting huh. Try it for yourself.

I would personally like to recommend the HAWAIIAN ROLL #2. I've never tasted anything like it before! Albacore tuna and mango topped with macadamia nuts. SAY WHAT?! Haha try it, it's truly unique!
author: Yolanda C.

description:
1. Baked Mango Sea Bass
- Order at least 2-3 orders a person. Each order only has 2 pieces os if you just order one you're just going to end up ordering 2 more so save yourself the hassle.

2. Sashimi
All the sashimi here is bomb - start with what you know, like the salmon, tuna, yellow tail - and  definitely add in some new additions - mackerel, octopus, uni - all are freaking amazing.

3, Sushi - Don't waste your time on sushi (although everything is super bomb) when you have sashimi this good.

I used to live 3 blocks away from this place and if rent didn't take up half my income and mission riffraff didn't constantly pee on my doorstep, I'd gladly move back into the city to be within walking distance of this gem.
author: Michael N.

description: I absolutely love this place. I was introduced to it by my boyfriend and come back at least once a month now. It's a small hole in the wall restaurant with amazing food. That said, be prepared to wait. The restaurant seats about 15-20 people and only has 1 sushi chef, 1 waitress, and 1 person who washes dishes. I would advise coming right at opening (5pm) if you want to be served quickly. Otherwise expect a 1 hour wait for a table. The nigiri and rolls are great and very reasonably priced. I usually come out full and only paying $20.
author: Olga M.

description: Sushi Zone is a tiny place that takes CASH ONLY!  The wait can seem long, but I used this time to catch up with my friend, and we were ready for our rolls once we got seated.  My favorite thing was the stuffed mushroom appetizer.  So good!  Would totally come back, if I am not going some place after dinner.  The place is so small that I felt like I smelled like food after I left.
author: Sabrina T.

description: Small place with good fresh rolls with fair pricing. Sashimi on the expensive side but good. Wait is too too log... need to simplify that....
author: Ayaz L.

description:
Hard to beat this gem of restaurant as a neighborhood sushi spot. Their exotic yet home-style rolls are both fresh and interesting. Unagi papaya? Mango tuna? Also just plain delicious versions of your standard California, spider and yellowtail.

The reviews don't lie, this place seats like ten people (no really though) and the minimum wait seems to be 30 minutes and up to two or three hours most of the time. But, if you can show up early or are willing to kill some time at the wine bar next door, you'll be rewarded with some very good, very reasonably priced sushi.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
The appetizers were amazing (baked bass, mussels). Fresh and creative, mouth watering. 
Makis were fresh, delicious and reasonably priced. Nigiris were a bit pricy, but they are really generous with their portion of fish on top. 
I'd give the food 5 stars but the wait was just toooooo long (2 hours is ridiculous even for a Friday night). It's a tiny place but they should really get more staff because they are just too popular.
author: Rachel Z.

description:
OMG!! I miss this place. Been going here for years. OW we miss you! My dogs love this man, he used to make them special sushi rolls, hold the wasabi! Yes, best to get there @ 4:30. I know they don't open til 5. But trust me, there will be a line. 

You will never go anywhere else once you've experienced being in the Zone! 
Sushi Zone. P.S. this review is 14 years late but better late than never. Hope to see you again soon Ow!
author: Elisa B.

description:
This place rock...great mix with fish and tropical fruits....
Im an Italian Chef and I really loved it
author: Greg S.

description:
I would love to give five stars because, honestly, this is the second best sushi restaurant I have encountered, outside of Japan. I have lived there and traveled 30+ countries but the quality/size here is phenomenal. 

The cost-benefit ratio is excellent, meaning this place is, hands down, a steal. The nigiri are huuuge. They have Suzuki, Japanese sea bass, my favorite and hard to get. 

However, the waiting is a big minus. We waited 1h+ for our table and then another hour for our food and that while the place can only seat about 15 ppl. It is tiny. 

Normally, this would be a ruled-out for me because I go out to satisfy my hunger and not to wait 2 hours. But, as I said before, the food is exceptional. 

SO, if you have the time and want to wait, it is worth it. If you are hungry and want a sushi snack, go somewhere else. 

BE ADVISED: cash only!(next ATM is in a liquor store a block away).
author: René X.

description:
I'm disappointed. I was NOT amazed at all :(

I chose to come here for my birthday yesterday based on so  many great reviews. I was fooled. Yes, the baked bass was good. Yes, the fish were fresh. Those were about the only "good" things about this place. 

Their "spicy mayo" was NOT spicy at all, it was too tangy and they put waaaaay to much in their "spicy" rolls. Ordered their spicy: tuna, hamachi, salmon, and scallop. There was only one small piece of fish on each end of the roll and that was it. There were not enough fish IN the roll and too much of their "spicy" sauce. I had to dig out the tiny pieces of fish to avoid the sauce! I was not happy. I expected "phenomenal" sushi. Maybe I should've ordered strictly sashimi. 

The wait wasn't bad. We waited about 40 minutes to be seated on a Tuesday. We expected that. Not coming back.
author: L S.

description:
My friends and I decided to come here today due to the raving yelp reviews. Came here at 5:00pm on the dot with a line outside and thus the last to be seated in this first wave of customer. (It was 5:10 at this point, meals were distributed)

20 minutes later the lone waitress took our order. The wait began. Although we were lucky enough to be seated and not placed on the list (where a long wait would be understandable and expected). We had to wait for at least another good half an hour to 45 minutes to get the food.

Already annoyed but I was excited as the food arrives nonetheless. We had the Alaska Roll, Rock n' Rock, and the highly suggested Hawaiian roll #2. The sushi was good, wasn't the best sushi I've ever had or anything. which was fine, until I dived into one of my friend's Hawaiian roll #2. There as I was chewing I was poked by a piece of BONE, the half the length of my pinky! Honestly! I was quite surprised my gums weren't bleeding. I'm sure it was an accident and does not occur often but I don't think I'll be coming here ever again.

TL;DR: Extremely long wait (20 mins for menu, 40 for food), found a piece of bone in my sushi roll. Okay food. 

Tip: Cash Only.
author: Lilian C.

description:
Was it Sushi Zone's sushi that I loved? Or was it being seated before wiry, mustachioed Al, watching him expertly and lovingly halve avocados, slit albacore, and clean tuna? 

Who can say? SZ is instantly endearing. It seats about 12, it's frenetic and crowded, it's moderately priced, and Al's been making maki for "sixteen years, my-god-i'm-old". The baked sea bass appetizer ("cooked" in a toaster oven under some mango-mayonnaise miracle) was a must; the rolls were equal parts pretty and palatable. I didn't get to sample from the limited nigiri menu, but I'm very willing to return - if only the wait wasn't a couple of hours and change on a weeknight after 7!

Cash only. About a hundred bucks for a party of two, with sake.
author: Liz C.

description:
Loved it!  The restaurant is super slow so go veeeeerrry early to put your name in.  We stuffed ourselves on sushi and sake --the bill was only $37 pp with tip (cash only, PS).  

Definitely order the salmon sashimi -- the best I've ever had.  Oh, and be warned that the wasabi is super fresh (read: hot!).
author: Tami S.

description:
With all the world class dining in S.F., there are actually not many great sushi places.  Sushi Zone is probably one of the best casual sushi spots in the city.  Everything is dang fresh, dang pretty, and dang tasty.

1 star off: This place is tiiiiiiiny!  Get there early or get there patient.
author: Ally W.

description: I find my self wondering if this places if worth 3 or 4 stars. The food was decent, the prices were decent. This place is super small, do not come here with a party bigger than 4. I'm very conservative with my reviews, and I wish I could agree with other reviews about the quality of the food but this places didn't leave an impression on me.
author: Elba A.

description:
Straight up bomb.com this place is well worth the wait. 
Love the servers! Love the chefs! Love it all! 
Can't go wrong here.  
CASH ONLY
author: Jess K.

description:
Sushi Zone is my favorite sushi place in the city for the price and quality of the sushi/appetizers. 

It's a hole in the wall with minimal seating and usually an hour wait. Tip: come when it opens 5-5:30 to avoid the wait or go around the corner to a nearby bar for drinks.

My faves:
- baked mussel 
- hamachi or salmon kama
- rolls: Hawaiian #1, spider roll, Indian roll, spicy hamachi
- sashimi: salmon or hamachi
author: Minh P.

description:
Got a table at 5:30 with a friend who lives in the city and raved about this place. You've heard about amazing hole in the wall places, this is the kind of place they're referring to! It was amazing. So many people were waiting for a table though. I felt kind of bad sitting there with my delicious sushi dinner... but it didn't stop me from enjoying it. It was wonderful. I was introduced to mussels. So scrumptious they made my mouth water and I was sad when they were done. 

Don't forget to bring cash!!!
author: Eve D.

description: Got there 10:45am.  Window cover with Manila paper. Phone had a recording that said could find you another # of a open business   no signs of business out of business.
author: Kerry J.

description:
Wait really is long, but I think some people are really over exaggerating it. Me and my sister arrived around 6:30 and were served and outta there in before 8. Also, there are plenty of bars around, so waiting really isn't such a bad thing. Knock back a few cocktails, and 20 min will go by in a blink of an eye.

We got the baked seabass (awesome and not at all what you would expect.), the rainbow roll (portions are huge... Larger than I would have liked. Basically they were Sushi Maki with fat slabs of different sashimi on top of each. Portions were still huge though, so only half a star off for that one.), salmon skin roll (crispy shredded pieces of salmon skin. Beautifully presented, and not over done. Probably the best I've had) and uni and tako nigiri (both very fresh).

We had heard from another patron that the eggplant/Nasu Nigiri is supposed to be good, but we couldn't find it on the menu. Turned out it was on the Specials Board right by the entrance, and when we finally ordered it, they had already run out. Next time, I'll have to remember to order it.

Temperature wise, rainbow roll could have been served a little colder, but they were still good, so half a star off for that.
author: Francis R.

description: FINALLY!!! Food that "wowed" me!! WORTH THE WAIT (1:15 mins) Very fresh and quick! Try the appetizer baked bass . I split a few rollls with a friend!
author: Kara D.

description:
Baked sea bass and baked mussels are TO DIE FOR!!! Baked sea bass is quite possibly one of my favorite dishes ever! Totally bumps it to 5 stars for me.

Also ordered... 
- Spider Roll: Good, though not the best soft shell crab roll I've had before.
- Tuna Masa Roll: Good, though pretty standard.
- Sashimi Combination: 14 pieces in total. Large thick cuts of fish - 2 pieces, 7 kinds. Very fresh.
- Seaweed Salad: Good, though pretty standard. Nice portion - a rice bowl size. 

We got here around 5:30pm on a Friday night, and there were 2 seats left at the bar which we took. So no waiting - hooray! I would definitely come back if I can get here before 6pm. We found parking very close on Pearl - probably because it was still early in the eve.

Everything is very fresh. Uni was not available when we were here because apparently the Uni lady does not drop off the Uni until 7:30pm. Doh! Not sure if that is a regular thing or just that day - anyway, we didn't get to try the Uni. Also, next time, I would try a few other rolls, like the Hawaiian and Rainbow which both looked really good and was constantly being ordered. 

I liked sitting at the counter too because we could watch the sushi chef. Service was very nice. And remember, CASH ONLY!
author: Veronica H.

description: Honestly not too sure what's up with the rave reviews and constant line. I guess it's quite an established establishment. Yes, it's veryy small. The wait is generally ~30 mins and sometimes just as slow for the food to arrive. The menu is small (almost too small for me). The only real sashimi option seems to be the Chef's choice combo ($39) which was exactly the same several months later. The fish is usually quite fresh and worth the wait, though the cuts are a little big. The lemon they cut still had the sticker on it. Edamame is microwaved. Last time I went the tako didn't taste very fresh at all :/ I'd still come back here since it's in my neighborhood, but only if I was alone with time and a book in my hands.
author: Xue H.

description: Great quaint little place with a few tables and bar seating. Sushi is well made, and Nigori sake seems to be pretty good
author: Arjuna S.

description:
When I first saw this place I thought to myself, "What's the big deal?" because there were about ten parties on the waiting list in front of us. This restaurant literally seats about 16 people max and four people who work here: one waitress/hostess, one sushi chef, and one su-chef cook also washed all the dishes. 

After I put my name down I asked the waitress, "Excuse me, how long is the wait?" She replies, "two hours." LOL!! Was feeling patient so we waited, so glad we did! Went back a few times already. 

FOOD: 
* Baked Sea Bass Appetizer - fresh sea bass and mango baked in a creamy mayo sauce is to die for :D It's slap yo mama good (Do Not slap yo mama after eating these). :)
* Deluxe Sashimi Selection 14 pieces - freshest I've ever had, just wish butter fish was part of this selection. There was hamachi, taro, tako, maguro, salmon, albacore (?), and saba. 
* Spicy Hamachi Roll - nice chunks of fresh hamachi with slivers of jalapeno was perfect yum! (All rolls are $6.50). 
* Rock 'N Roll - BBQ eel, avocado, cucumber, and fish eggs was tasty. 
* Ama Ebi - best I've had. The body was so fresh and sweet, and the fried head was soo goood and not greasy at all. 
* Uni - was good, but I've had fresher. 

Service: 
The one waitress/hostess was on top of it! The whole time we waited she was clearing dishes and cleaning tables, seating people, taking orders, serving food and drinks, refiling water, taking drink orders for people who were waiting for tables. Waiting for a table here can make you thirsty! :) She rocked it! 

Great sushi at a well oiled establishment. 

GO GO GO!!!
author: Fried Rice B.

description:
Been going to this place for years on a weekly basis and sometimes a few times in the same week. The food is that good that it's worth the wait. Al, Hideko, Yoshi and Rie are all great people. 

Must haves:

1: baked bass (on my last meal list)
2: spicy hamachi
3:spicy mango salmon 
4: Hawaiian roll #2
5: sashimi plater

Being a sushi snob, this place is hands down the best not only in the city, but they can compete with the best of them outside of Japan (never been there). I've tried many top rated sushi spots and all have not come close to sushi zone that I find myself craving sushi zone after eating elsewhere just to get my sushi fix. 
Long wait but well worth the wait. 
*Cash only
author: Dixiee N.

description:
The hype is true. Sushi Zone is the best sushi joint in SF. The warnings about waiting in line are also true, so show up no later than 4:40 to be seated first when they open at 5:00. Couples make do with the eight seats at the sushi bar, while parties of 4-6 can use one of the two tables.

Start with a baked appetizer- baked bass is amazing, stuffed jalapeño is also very nice.

Sashimi and nigiri pieces are generously sized, but I always go for the makimono. Here you won't find the over-reliance on tempura or exotic goos that hide bad cuts of fish in lesser establishments. These rolls stand out because they masterfully combine simple ingredients that accentuate really fresh fish.

Most of the makimono are rolls of six pieces for $8. My favorites are the Hawaiian #2 (albacore tuna, mango, scallion, and mayo sauce, topped with Macadamia nuts) and the Spicy Mussel (with jalapeño, scallion, cilantro, sprouts, and lime). The Spider Roll is $12 but is larger. The $17 Rainbow Roll is larger still and truly a sight to behold- like the arm of a baby holding a piece of salmon.

Sushi Zone will make your clothes smell like fish, but you won't care. They're also cash-only, but if that keeps the rolls cheap, I couldn't care less.
author: Barry E.

description:
It's really good food. 
The sushi tastes fresh and the service is pleasant. 

However, there can be a long wait - we waited an hour and it's cash only.
author: Marina S.

description: If you are a sushi lover, you need to try this place. I am not exaggerating at all when I am saying that it is one of the best in San Francisco!
author: Vitalie S.

description:
Baked bass with mango app was delicious!

Rolls:
- Rock N Roll- Good but nothing special.
- Hawaiian #2- A unique combo of flavors and textures that worked, with buttery and flaky albacore, sweet mango, and slightly salty and crunchy macadamia nuts.
- Hama-masa- My favorite of the three. Simple, but fresh and tasty.

My bf and I arrived shortly after opening, but with limited seating and only one sushi chef, we ended up waiting a long time. Good sushi at a very reasonable price, but don't know if it's worth the wait.
author: Sophia B.

description:
The service at Sushi Zone can be spotty, but the sushi here is always top notch. Be prepared to wait 30+ mins for a table as it is a first come first serve joint with only enough to seat maybe 16 people tops.

Baked Bass is a must order here. The mango pairs well with the bass and creates a well balanced flavor.

I typically order the Sake sashimi and always love the buttery richness and the freshness of the fish.

My favorite roll is the Hawaii #2 roll. The macadamia nuts are an interesting and unexpected addition to a roll, but the texture and flavor is well received.

The sushi at Sushi Zone is some of the best in the city. I'd give it 5 stars, but the service can be hit or miss. The last few times we have dined there, the waitress has messed up orders, forgotten to bring our drinks and taken forever to get us a check. Small issues here, so nothing to worry about.

Sushi Zone gets the job done and is a great experience!
author: Justin O.

description: food was good, but took FOREVER to get seated and FOREVER to get our food. Tons of other sushi places with better sushi that have shorter waits and faster service. will not be returning.
author: Adrian A.

description: So fresh and simple. I absolutely love the no frills atmosphere paired with amazing fish. Doesn't take rocket science for great sushi, just quality Ingredients with a passion for food.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Long wait. Food wasn't amazing
Very overrated.

raw shrimp was mediocre
mango sea bass didn't pair well together. but the sea bass was pretty good
rolls were whatever's
never knew eel was packaged
sushi uni was pretty mouthwatering.

But definitely not the best I've ever had
author: Angela W.

description:
The sashimi was good, but it wasn't worth the wait.  The three of us came out smelling like BBQ even though they serve primarily sushi.  

We came at 7 p.m. and didn't get seated till an hour later.  I was prepared to wait and finally try this place, so no biggie.  

You get good sized cuts of fish and huge rolls.  Everything was pretty good.  Even though the fish was uber fresh, I didn't feel blown away.  Also bummed out that they were out of uni.  

It'll be hard to come back; hardly any food is worth waiting an hour for.  If I come back, I'll get the baked bass again and all sashimi, no rolls.
author: Erika C.

description:
S ushi Zone is amazing
U nbelievably affordable for the quality you get
S imply one of my favorites in San Francisco -- or anywhere
H ad waited an hour once just to get seated
I t's worth it, trust me

Z esty Spicy Hamachi roll...
O rgasmic, melt-in-your-mouth Spicy Mango Salmon roll... 
N o-words-can-explain-how-good-it-is Baked Bass...
E very bite is wonderful
author: Anthony N.

description:
Completely overrated. I was very excited to try this place and was terribly disappointed. It took forever to get in, forever to order, and another forever to get the food. 

When we finally received our order, it was very lackluster, mediocre and the presentation was below par. It was not in anyway extraordinary. I do not recommend this place. You can find better value elsewhere. 

The wait does not justify the product or the service. Try the Pisco place next door. That place was pretty awesome!
author: Mel C.

description: Adorable, chill, understated sushi restaurant with some of the best fish and rolls in the city. Other reviews cover the classic choices here, but you basically can't go wrong. Service is equally chill, and you may have to wait a long while (so get to know nearby bars and cafes for a while-you-wait beverage), but it's just worth it. Prices have risen as rents have, so it's not exactly a bargain; on the other hand, it's a great value. :)
author: adam b.

description:
Sushi Zone can be hit or miss depending on the night you go, sometimes the fish is fresh with healthy portions or sometimes it can be less than pleasant. 

First: Always have a plan, they do not take reservations and there are approximately 12 seats in the place, if there is a wait my recommendation is to put yourself down and go to pisco for a drink/appetizer.
Second: If you are here for rolls or mango sea bass, you are most likely in the wrong place. They do really great nigiri/sashimi, you can get that other stuff anywhere that makes mediocre sushi. Wait in line for the fish quality and the portions, not to drown it with japanese mayo.
Third: Be courteous, people are waiting. I've seen too many people just order drinks after they are done eating. This is a great place that a lot of people want to enjoy, plus, the drinks are cheaper around the corner.
author: Michael W.

description:
Good quality fish. Get there early. I got dropped off at 4:45 while the other half went and parked and there was a line already. Parking is not too bad if you know where to look. Like everyone mentions- it's small, and your basically sitting elbow to elbow with someone at the sushi bar.

What to order hmmm... baked muscles, and basically any sushi. It's fresh.
author: Crystal B.

description:
Not sure what I can say here that hasn't been said other than to emphasize how truly small this place is.  Other reviews caution that the restaurant only holds about 16 patrons at a time; I just want to paint a picture for y'all what that actually means.  It means there are two tables and a counter.  That's what it means.  Also, you write your own name on the white board when you walk in.  And keep an eye on that white board!

We stepped down the street to a Peruvian establishment to have some drinks while we waited.  I felt a bit bad because I'm sure their food was delicious as well, yet I was waiting to eat at another place.  But it soon became obvious that the bartender TOTES knew what we were about, and they seem to be totally used to it.  Because, dovetailing with my comments about how truly small this restaurant is, there is little space to wait therein.

Okay, so food-wise.  It was great.  I'll reiterate what everyone has said about the baked bass, it was legit.  The chef's sashimi platter was awesome too, each slice of fish was like 1/2 an inch thick, so it was a generous portion.

Here's the thing though (and why there's only 4 stars up yonder) is that I'm quite sure that there are sushi places that are pretty close to being just as good, with a fraction of the wait.  Just saying.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This place is beyond good! By far the best sushi I have had in SF.

We got there at 5:15 so there was plenty of room (BIG plus not to have to wait!) The place is small, but the flavors are BIG! I don't know what else to say, but that the fish is incredibly fresh and all of their rolls are excellent!
author: Em D.

description:
Yes yes! The sushi was
  JUst amazing so fresh! Loved it. The waitress was super attentive! I love how friendly everyone was
author: Weezy E.

description:
Really pretty and fresh tasting amazing edible works of art.  
I bet if I knew about quality sushi it would have justified the $$.
author: Stan H.

description: I love the size and location of this restaurant. It is simple and not fancy. Basically, a "whole in the wall." It is a little bit of a wait but it is well worth it. The food is awesome. It is not an overwhelming menu so you won't spend so much time figuring out what you want to order. I love both Hawaiian rolls. Btw, they're not shady with the size of the rolls. Only problem was probably looking outside the window and having people stare at what you & what you are eating.
author: Bermel L.

description:
This was my second time to come here.  My first time was about 5 years ago.   Surprisingly, the food was still as good as before.

Came here with a friend on a Friday at 5:30pm and the restaurant was already packed.  Luckily we were the first party on the waiting broad.  We got seated at 6pm.  

A lot of people complained about the wait for the food.  Yes, it was a pain because there was only one chef and he was doing one order at a time.  So you probably expect to wait another 30 minutes for your food.

We ordered:

Baked mussels:  I tried this in 5 years ago and the taste of the mussels were always in my mind.  After so many years, the taste was pretty much the same.  Delicious!  The sauce was flavorful and the portion was good.  Must order item!

We also ordered Hamachi Nigiri, White Tuna Nigiri, Hawaiian #1 roll, Mushroom roll and Mango Hamachi roll: All fish were so fresh and the slice of the fish was generous.  The portion of the rolls and sushi were good.  

The service was very friendly.  Even though there was only one waitress, she was still attentive; just kinda slow sometimes.  

Deducted one star?!?!?!  Definitely the wait..............too long ;-(
author: Liza T.

description:
I found my new favorite sushi place! This place is tiny. We got here around 5:05 (they open at 5:00pm) and got the last seats in the place. The people after us, who came in 2 or 3 minutes behind us,had to wait probably 30/45 mins to get food. There's 8 seats at the bar, and 2 tables by the windows...unless you get here right when it opens, be prepared to wait.

BUT it's well worth it. I generally don't get rolls out in the Bay anymore due to overseasoning (too much sauce, mayonnaise) that overpowers the taste of the fish. But Sushi Zone's rolls are delectable! 

I had the salmon with spciy mayonnaise and mango...it was too die for. The balance of salmon, sweet mango, and spicy mayonnaise sounds simple but tastes amazing. 

We also ordered an abundance of nigiri. The yellow-tail and albacore (white tuna) was especially fresh and literally melted in my mouth. The uni was really good too. The only nigiri that wasn't as fresh as the others was the salmon, which generally would ruin my experience, but the other stuff I ordered was so mind-blowingly good, I didn't mind the mediocre salmon nigiri. My recommendation is to ask the chef what's fresh for the day.

We also got a seabass with mango in the mussel shell appetizer which was the perfect way to start the meal.

I thought Sushi Time down the street was really good until I tried Sushi Zone. The atmosphere at Sushi Time is more romantic, but for a delicious sushi dinner, definitely try this place. Just be prepared to wait!

Also note that it's only open for dinner.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Best rolls in the city. Baked sea bass w/ mango is a must order. 

Don't come here for nigiri or sashimi. Though their fish is fresh, you won't be getting amazing cuts.

Don't ever expect to wait less than 1.5 hrs to get seated and have sushi served, but it's well worth the wait. Best chance to avoid lines is coming before they open or right when they close.
author: R C.

description:
I've probably eaten here 50 times over the last 5 years. I think this is the best sushi in SF. Everything is melt-in-your-mouth fresh. The service is basic and friendly, which is all you really need.  

The place is small and doesn't take reservations - yes - so plan accordingly.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Sushi was decent. Especially the sake nigiri was delicious and huge. Other than that mediocre experience. Super long wait ( arrived 10 mins before seven and started eating at 9), slow and indifferent service. 
Rolls were a bit blant- especially the soft shell crab one was over-fried.Fish selection for nigiri/sashimi was quite small. For the same prices there are plenty other places  with better sushi. Or maybe my expectations were pretty high. In any case, i wont be returning soon
author: Sarita V.

description: I found this wonderful place in yelp while visiting San Francisco with my family of four. We arrived 5 minutes before opening and where lucky enough to get one of the only two tables available. Within minutes the place was packed. Very happy with this place, a must try. :)
author: Mayelyn B.

description:
Worth the wait!
The excitement builds as you watch your food being created lovingly before your very eyes. The smells are intoxicating. The music is varied but just works. Great service amazing fresh food.
author: Neil G.

description:
For the longest time, I wanted to try this highly rated sushi bar, but I feared the long wait that everyone wrote about.  One day, I decided to face the fear head on.

LOCATION:  With a name like Sushi Zone, I expected a more Western style sushi place like Sushi-Go-Go, but I was pleasantly surprised to see a nice little neighborhood sushi bar.  There was no separate kitchen with refrigerator, stove, and sink all in the same space.  On the day I went, one Japanese chef made all the sushi, one young Japanese guy washed dishes and other kitchen tasks, and one young Japanese lady took the orders.

QUESTION: Best sushi in SF?

MY ANSWER:  Please read my linked opinion about Sushi Customers (http://www.yelp.com/biz/vSkY6bYFXN19f1eBXQXMNQ?hrid=KsBURNfxA2B0vjAgPiqnOg).  I believe that Japanese standards to judge sushi do not apply in the U.S.  In Castro area, there is a large population of customers, enough to form lines out the door, who seek the rolls at Sushi Zone.  To this population, Sushi Zone maybe the best sushi in SF.  If you apply the Japanese Standards, Sushi Zone may not even be considered an Edo (Tokyo) Style sushi bar.  It lacks the basic variety of fish choices.  With over 90% of orders being rolls, chef makes very few nigiri, which Tokyo Style Sushi is known for.  At a sushi bar, you should be able to order directly from the chef, one order at a time, but you cannot do that here with a long waitlist of orders.  Customers that seek sushi like Japan would be highly disappointed at Sushi Zone.

FOOD:  I enjoyed the rolls at Sushi Zone.  I especially liked the rolls with thin slices of lime and jalapenos.  I could not believe how well it went in a sushi roll.  As for mango and Macedonian nuts, it worked well with the rolls, but I did not become a big fan of them.  With a limited number of raw fish in stock, it allowed a fast turnover.  It allowed him to always have fresh fish.   

PROBLEMS:  Sushi chef works very hard and fast to make the rolls as quickly as possible.  However, with no helpers, he cannot get them out quickly enough.  Usually, the apprentice makes the rolls while the master makes nigiri.  Here, I don't think he considers the other guy his apprentice.  Chef didn't even allow the other guy to season the sushi rice.  Come here with plenty of time and don't expect to get your food immediately after ordering.  This will not seem like a big problem when you receive your check, which will be significantly lower than other premium sushi restaurants.  You can go home satisfied for $25/person.

Japanese style sushi fans:  This is more of a 2 Star sushi bar.  Not enough 'neta' selections.  I don't think the chef went through apprenticeship in Japan.  I would definitely encourage you to try this place as their rolls are very creative and good.  

--Useful notes for my next visit---
8 --- Counter seats
2 --- Tables for 4 adults

Wednesday night in January:
6:10 --- Two groups ahead of us
6:30 --- Seated
8:00 --- Leave restaurant

Parking:
Fairly easy on Valencia, just south of Market.
author: トモ T.

description:
Just had to say it again.

After moving back to San Diego Sushi Zone is still one of my favorite sushi place.

My boyfriend and I were back in San Francisco for a few days and we had to stop by Sushi Zone. We got there around 5:30pm and grabbed the last table. 

We ordered our usual:
- Spicy Mango Salmon Roll ($5.75)
- Spicy Scallop Roll ($5.50)
- Spicy Hamachi Roll ($5.75)
- Hawaiian #2 Roll ($5.75)
- Baked Stuffed Striped Bass with Mango ($5.00)
- Baked Stuffed Jalepeno with Albacore ($5.00)

As usual everything was amazing. 

I love you Sushi Zone: you never disappoint.
author: Eifeh S.

description:
Life-Changing.  Some of the best sushi I've ever had.  Well worth the wait.

Top Recommendations:

Baked Bass 
Hawaiian Roll #2 (the fish is like butter)

We went on a Monday around 5:45 and waited on the little bench inside for 25-30 minutes.  Can't wait to go back.
author: J L.

description:
Being out of the country for a month puts you into a sushi fix, and Lorna D. had just the place to take me to during a visit back to The City.  Arriving around nine in the evening, she's surprised to see it's so packed for a Tuesday night.  Sure, it's been a year since her last visit and we get on the long list of waiting hopefuls.  With only two tables for four and about 10 counter seats, our wait extends out for about an hour.

Diners are in no rush as they linger over sake and Sapporo.  With only one sushi chef, one waitress, and another assistant who manages the fryer and washes the dishes, the pace of food coming out is far from a hurried state.  We get seated a little after ten despite the CLOSED sign being put out a quarter to that hour.

The waitress takes our drink orders, which is simple with water and tea.  We also throw in some edamame since we're starving and we know the sushi is going to take awhile.  Their menu is brief, one laminated page and their specials board. 

The first item to arrive is the Spicy Tuna Roll (Tuna, avocado & scallion w/ a mayonnaise base $5.50) and I am reminded of why I first started enjoying the spicy tuna roll...the mayonnaise based spicy sauce.  (I hate it when they use that Sriracha sauce. Blah!)  It comes in six pieces and the roll isn't wrapped very tightly, so you definitely have to make it in one bite.

Number two is the Spider Roll (Softshell crab, avocado, and shiso $9.00), also cut into six pieces.  The crab is still very hot as it just emerged from the fryer.  The shiso adds a nice finish to this crunchy bite.

We look over at our neighbors and are tempted by their nigiri choices.  We also order one amaebi nigiri ($4.50) and its sweet plumpness is pleasant to our tastebuds.  The deep fried shrimp heads come out shortly.    

Lorna D. has an obsession with mango, and anytime she sees a roll with this sweet fruit, she had to get it.  The Mango Hamachi Roll (yellowtail, mango & scallion $5.50) comes out next.  

The Alaskan Roll (salmon, avocado, & scallion $5.00) is quite satisfying with its chunky salmon bits and I find myself smiling with glee on all this lovely sushi.

It's way past 11 and I tell Lorna this is our last chance for any additional rolls she may want.  (There's another party behind us that has yet to be served!)  We go for the Spicy Scallop Roll ($5.50) and learn they are out, so we opt for the Spicy Albacore Roll ($5.50) instead.  The spiciness proves a bit too much for Lorna D., but I really couldn't ask for more.

Service is what you can expect when there's such few staff.  The waitress will fill your water and tea glass when you ask, just don't expect her to come around and do it automatically.  She's too busy taking orders, bringing sushi platters back and forth, and clearing the dishes.  Patience is definitely a virtue here.

Sushi is fresh and good. No frills at all.  Next time I would love to pig out on their sashimi and nigiri since their fatty chunks of fish were making me drool.

At $42 with tip and tax, we left content and with very full bellies.  

Cash only.  Don't bother coming with anyone else besides your plus one, otherwise the wait will be even longer. 

(Pics of our sushi dinner can be found in the business profile.)
author: Teri C.

description: Delicious but requires Zen patience. Waited 1 hour for seating for 2, then almost another hour for the food to arrive. My favorite was the ume-shiso roll. Simple, but really you judge a good sushi place by how well they can make the simplest things. The uni was surprisingly good - perfect bites.
author: Taya V.

description:
Brace yourselves for the long wait. Or go early on a weekday!

BAKED SEA BASS = no regrets

SASHIMI - very fresh

Also, never in my life did I think I would be eating a sushi roll topped with macadamia nuts but hey, you only live once! (My bf does not like macadamia nuts whatsoever, but LOVES the #2)

Side note: I've never seen a sushi place incorporate so much mango, very nice accent!

Definitely need to go back for the sea bass!!
author: Anna H.

description:
This place when I first saw it I thought it was a "Hole in the Wall" since it is so small but the food itself made-up the wait and the setting. 

Funny enough I brought my girlfriend here on our first date and it was awesome we were amazed at how fresh the sushi was prepared "literally in front of you from fresh fish!!!"  

Let just say you can't go wrong on ordering here from any food you order from their menu & it's cheap if you compare their prices with other sushi places but remember considering they use everything from real crabmeat to fish!!!

I ordered the following:
Sea Bass appetizer 
Chef choice s
Hawaiian Roll#2

Let's just say overall is worth it.
author: Steven C.

description: With a name so dubiously generic as "sushi zone", I expected gimmicks: party trains, cheap thrills and otherwise; however ,what I encountered wasn't smoke and mirrors, but authentic and extraordinary sushi. I'll chalk the Hawaiian roll #2 up to sensationalism because the real show pony here is the nigiri. The yellowtail and salmon we're to die for. The seared tuna was decent. Was it worth the hour + wait? Certainly. Exclusivity has it's price.
author: Scott K.

description:
Another good restaurant ruined by being over hyped.  This is a 3.5 star place, but closer to 3 than it is to 4.  I went on a date here with a girl who loves to go to all the hyped up 2 hour wait places in SF (Zazzies, Burma Superstar, Outerlands).  We had a great time...but is it really worth the 60+ min wait?  

Got here around 7:30 on a Monday and only 2 groups were ahead of us.  We waited, and waited and finally were seated after 40 min (like other reviews, the waitress didn't even say hi or make eye contact with us for the whole time we were waiting, the only interaction we had was when she called our name, kinda rude but whatever, not docking anything for that).  Then you have to wait and wait and wait for all the orders in front of you to be made, and then FINALLY you get your first roll.  

The food was pretty good, not the best I have had but I would go back just for the food (not the line).  We got 4 rolls to split.  All $8 which is very reasonable for the quality.  The 2 specialty rolls, Hawaiian #2 and the spicy mussel were great.  Hands down some of the best rolls I have had.  The mussel one was cooked and had a great lime flavor which I'd never had in a sushi roll.  The Hawaiian #2 had mango in it which was also a first and pretty damn tasty.  I also appreciated how the specialty rolls were the same prices as the normal rolls, a lot of places will jack up the price on the special rolls but Sushi Zone didn't.  We got two basic Salmon rolls which were just OK, i wouldn't order them again.  We got free green tea with the meal which  hit the spot, and the waitress was pretty attentive with refills.  

Total bill came to $40 with tax and tip.  Well worth the price.  Was it worth the wait?  No chance in hell.  Are there other places where I can walk in and be eating in 15 min for the same quality of food?  Probably. I would go back again if it were only a 30 min wait, the food was good.  If you go, stick to the specialty rolls, they were awesome and are what probably give this place all the 4 star reviews.  If you go, eat a snack before, because from the time you walk in and put your name down to the time you get your first roll, it will easily be 90+ min (make sure you take a fun date, if he/she is boring you are in for a looooooong night).
author: Mark M.

description:
Sushi Zone has been bookmarked for places to try for over a year. As the near year began, I wanted to tackle as many places to try on my growing list of bookmarks. When the opportunity came up to get sushi, I went to my bookmarks and went with Sushi Zone. Reading the reviews of the long wait was somewhat of a deterrent but if I wanted to knock Sushi Zone off my list, I just had to SUCK IT UP!

Luckily, I didn't have to wait too long since Matt L. was waiting on a table while I got off work, drove to Sushi Zone and found parking.  It is street parking in the area so it's the luck of the draw you find good parking. Sushi Zone is SMALL...REALLY SMALL! It seats 8 people at the bar and 2 booths with 4 seats in each...for a grand whopping total of 16 seats for the patrons to fight over. I got there a little late so Matt L. had to give our seat away to the next people on the list since the whole party has to be present for them to seat you. We ended up waiting another 30 minutes before we got seated. 

We got seated in the booth that fits 4 so we got a couple of nasty glares when we sat down. I thought we had to communal with another party but we had the whole booth to ourselves. The waitress came over and got us started with drinks, we had a large Sapporo. That came quickly and we were ready to order when she came back. We ordered the, Baked Mussells, Baked Bass, Spicy Hamachi Roll, Hawaiian Roll #2, Papaya Unagi, Scallop Roll and Sake (Salmon) Nigiri. 

The appetizers, Baked Mussells and Baked Bass came first. The Baked Bass was good but not really really good. The bass was a little over cooked so it had the tough feeling. I enjoyed the mango in the bass though. The Baked Mussells was AMAZING! Perfectly cooked! It was buttery good, wished I got 2 more. These are both baked and served in a mussell shell. (See http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=YxYdjiGc86rz-YD0R9pF5w and here http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=CWM2-LObYAxV1k3OrUsp_Q).

It took a while for the rest of our rolls to come but we expected it since this place was PACKED and there is only one sushi chef behind the counter working his butt off. The rest of our rolls soon came in a big platter, Spicy Hamachi Roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=loGRPESSoT-C9r_YdCKgHA), Hawaiian Roll #2 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=W-jEgXnPgCUYZ7adawCleQ), and Papaya Unagi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=4ojs7fM0he8UaU0Mwboucg). Everything was super delicious and fresh. The Hawaiian Roll #2 was what I was looking forward to due to all the suggestions on Yelp and it did live up to the hype. The macadamia nuts on top added a great contrasting texture to the soft melt in your mouth goodness of the roll.

We took a quick break from the food and got another beer, this time an Asahi. We flagged down our waitress (there's only one working the entire restaurant) and ordered 2 more dishes. We waited 25 minutes for the rest of our food to come. The Sake Nigiri (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=id_zuZQ4rt460t5NMJc9qA) was melt in your mouth good. The Scallop Roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=74u6cOM8660XjhmmCR7u5g) was my least favorite dish of the night, the scallop was super slimy and the texture was just weird to me. 

All in all, the meal took around 2.5 hours with waiting and eating. Overall, I enjoyed the food and the service at Sushi Zone. The food was fresh and a little different from other Japanese restaurants (fruit in the dishes) and the service was attentive. Props to our waitress for working so hard. It's CASH ONLY. I will definitely be back the next time I don't mind waiting for some BOMB Japanese food.
author: Myron J.

description:
Went here with my buddy Yoshie K. last year. Very cozy sushi spot with extremely talented chefs. The quality is up there and the rolls are huge. And the prices really aren't too bad either.

Unless you arrive super early, you're gonna have to wait. My buddy and I waited almost 2 hours for a seat, but I have to tell you, it was definitely worth the wait.
author: James M.

description:
Delicious sushi in a mom and pop hole in the wall place. Go on an off time, or risk waiting hours for a seat. Both the sashimi and the rolls were excellent. 

Deducted one star because it is cash only.
author: Zach K.

description:
OMG!
The baked sea bass is to die for!
And the rolls just melt in your mouth!
Thank you chef!
author: Maryam M.

description:
I'm conflicted. 

Well, I guess I'm always conflicted, but moreso than usual. I came here with a friend to celebrate our birthdays and we had done our research. We were careful to come early, we were prepared to wait, we brought cash since it's CASH ONLY. 

Even though we got there early we waited a completely bogus amount of time. The waitress estimated an hour, we waited a little over two and half hours to be inexact. They have a white board that you write your name on and the waitress occasionally checks to see if you're there waiting and circles your name so she knows who to call next. If she calls your name and you're not there...well then, you're SOL and you're name is taken off the list. 

I can't describe the torment of sitting outside of a restaurant in the cold watching tables get their food and savor it slowly. On this particular day there was a lady eating by herself and she was leisurely reading a book. She then had a few drinks and became friends with the people seated at the bar and started up a conversation with the couple sitting next to her. They got more drinks and chatted away long after they were done eating. 

I understand that it's awesome to make friends over dinner, but I'm HUNGRY!!!

Anyways, after my little tantrum over book lady, she finally leaves along with the couple sitting next to her. Score! 

We had the opportunity to order while we were waiting so the wait for our food wasn't as long as I saw it take for other tables. We ordered both the mango sea bass and the baked mussels. They arrived at the table and looked almost exactly the same. I thought the sea bass would look more like a piece of fish, but it's placed over diced mango in a mussel shell and covered with sauce. The baked mussels were chopped up mussels mixed with sauce and baked into a mussel shell. They were both good, but come in a pair, so I felt like I wanted more.

The sashimi appetizer was super duper awesome as well as the rolls and nigiri that we got. They ran out of some fish, which made me sad because I saw other people ordering and eating it, but that's how it goes.

I think if I only had to wait 30 minutes, Sushi Zone would be a solid 4 stars. All the anticipation of food made my dinner seem not as good as it could have been, if that makes sense. I know it's not the restaurant's fault that they are popular, but it's honestly not worth such a long wait. 

If you pass by and the wait doesn't seem to bad, I'd say go for it!
author: Grace Y.

description:
Sushi was great, super fresh, yadda yadda, read the comments below.

All I wanna say is that they needa update the prices on their menu online on Yelp, 'cause those prices are HELLA inaccurate! It is not an average of $5-6 a roll but more lke $7-9. I was hoping to pay no more than $20 for my meal and well I got played!! 

The portions are unfortunately small too. I guess that's why all the rolls are under $10. 

Aside from that, food was good. It's just I was broke after.
author: Phillip S.

description:
**Cash only!!** And worth every penny!

Came here on a Monday night and it was already busy with about a 30 min wait for 2 people. While we waited we sat behind the sushi bar and enjoyed a Sapporo. 

Typically we order tons but that night we weren't sushi-hungry, loved everything we ordered:
Baked mussels 
Hiyayakko
Salmon
Hamachi
Unagi
Salmon skin cut roll

The hiyayakko was fresh, simple, and amazing! Not fried like agedashi but just pure tofu. The baked mussels were heaven in a shell. All of the sushi was prepared delicately and just fresh/delicious. Miso soup was excellent! Once you are seated, the wait isn't too long at all.

I noticed there was no fryer so there is no tempura of any kind (sorry folks!) But truly if you want just fresh sushi with no frills, but friendly, cozy atmosphere this is the place. That night we were there, the owner was eating at one of the tables with some friends on his night off so that tells me he is one dedicated owner! Hard working staff. 
Be patient, worth the wait.
author: Cindy A.

description:
This place is strictly sushi. Dragged our non-sushi loving friend along ("whaaat? just sushi??"), but he had a good time.

My friends and I ordered 6 different rolls:

Tekka
Hawaiian Roll #1
Hawaiian Roll #2
Rock n' Roll
Hama-masa (YUMMM we ordered two of these)
Spider Roll

They were all delicious! The Hawaiian Rolls were topped with macadamia nuts (what a great idea), but our favorite was the Hama-masa roll. The hamachi was like butter. I also really liked the mango in Hawaiian roll #2!

I heard this place usually gets packed because the restaurant is really small (they only have two booths and bar seating), but we (party of three) came on a Wednesday night at around 6:15 and we were seated right away! It took awhile for the sushi to come, but all of the rolls came out at once!

CASH ONLYYY!!!
author: Andrea F.

description:
This place is pretty great.  Little hole in the wall off Market, maybe seats 16 (two booths and then bar seating), plays blues music, etc.  One sushi chef and one waitress.

We went on a Monday around 6:30, 7:00 and were able to get a seat at the bar immediately, but after us everybody waited, although not that long.  

I had:

Uni - WOW.  Some of the best Uni I've had in a long, long time.  The highlight, hands down.
Kani - Fresh, real crab in the city?  No brainer.  Really nice portions here.
Hamachi - Beautiful, huge pieces of fish.  Served with some lemon juice and scallions on top, which was OK, would have just preferred the fish.
Spicy Tuna - Giant rolls, gooey, tons of fish, delicious.

My friend had some rolls which I didn't try, but they looked really big and she loved them.

What's keeping this from being a 5 for me are as follows.  I like sushi bars where there is more interaction with the sushi chef (ie, being able to order piece by piece, asking him what is especially fresh today, etc).  If this is doable at Sushi Zone it is certainly not the norm...the sushi chef did not interact with anybody, and you ordered through the waitress.  No big though, I understand that with only one sushi chef for the whole restaurant this is sort of an unreasonable request.  Also, I like places that serve one piece of Nigiri instead of two, simply because you can try more things.

My OCD nitpitcking aside, this is a super solid spot.  Definitely worth hitting up, although I'd shoot for earlier on a weeknight to avoid what I'm sure is a monster wait on the more prime nights.  Great portions, fresh fish, and reasonable prices for sushi.
author: James S.

description:
Seriously delicious! 
My boyfriend and I went there due to the great reviews and they didn't lie. Must try!
author: Esty G.

description: This little hidden treasure is one of my date night favorites. It is a very small location so wait time is a possibility even though we walked right in and foud a seat at the bar. They have authentic chefs and their food speaks for itself. Joining the rest of the Yelp reviews I will add that you MUST TRY THE BAKED SEA BASS. WARNING: it's hard to have just one order. Cheers!
author: Danielle L.

description: Best sushi I ever had. Had the New York roll and the Hawaiian roll #1. The macadamia nuts on top were delicious- I hadn't seen that before. Very small place and very delicious food.
author: Christy K.

description: Very small restaurant with only two tables, and a few sushi bar seats. Show up early, to put your name on a list and be prepared to wait. We waited for nearly two hours, and it was well worth it. The staff are super friendly and pleasant, and the sushi was the best I've ever had. Will gladly wait for this again. Treat it like a Disneyland ride!
author: Silje H.

description: You'll spend about $50 for a good dinner, but its traditional sushi and probably the best I've had outside of Japan. If you're a man you'll crush a tall can or two from the liquor store while you're waiting (they don't take reservations)
author: Aaron V.

description:
I moved to San Francisco from Hawaii about three years ago and this is *the best* sushi place I have been to so far! I feel so confident in giving it five stars! You can imagine that being from Hawaii, I have very high standards for fish and sushi in general. Very impressed. The wait for a table (about one hour for us) is insane but soooo worth it. The waitress is the sweetest and most helpful woman and the chefs seem pretty cool as well. 

Recommendations: 

Hawaiian Roll #2 (mango & mac nuts)
Stuffed Mushrooms (yum)
Baked Mussels (my favorite)
Mussel hand roll (never had anything like this)
Sake Nigiri (my staple nigiri, large pieces of fish)
Salmon roll (simple but really goood)

My friends and I weren't fans of the King Crab California Roll or the Spider roll. The California roll was kind of dry and plain and the Spider roll was nothing special... but those were our only complaints.
author: Shannon A.

description: Definitely believe the hype and GET HERE EARLY. My friends and I got here at 5 on a Monday, got a great table, and by the time we were done there was quite a long wait. The thing that makes this place just even better than great, because the sushi is super fresh and good, is that it's not overpriced! In fact, compared to most places I've been, it's UNDERpriced! Everything we ate was delicious, especially the Hawaiian Roll #2. I was pretty dubious about macadamia nuts on top of a sushi roll but it was AMAZING. Also for people who notice and care about this sort of thing-- they have excellent sushi rice. Eat here.
author: Lia H.

description:
I was probably expecting too much as I was told by friends for years that this is their favorite sushi place in SF and there's always a line. The first time I tried to eat here, it was 8pm when the wait was over an hour so I didn't wait. I came back today when it opened and was quickly seated at the bar. 

I ordered the spicy hamachi roll and hawaiian roll no. 2 (albacore tuna, mango, and macadamia nuts). The friendly Japanese sushi chef quickly made and handed my sushi to me. The spicy hamachi tasted like ceviche with the lime and wasn't very spicy. The mangoes were very sweet as I saw the chef toss out the bad mangoes from the batch. The rolls contained a lot of rice compared to minced fish, which might be why the rolls were only $6.50. However, the rice was mushy today making the sushi not very good. 

I also tried the baked mussels and baked sea bass with mango ($5.50 each). Considering that the appetizers were baked in a toaster oven, they were tasty, but I didn't expect the mussels and sea bass to be chopped up. I thought I would get a whole piece of mussel and a cut or small fillet of sea bass. Instead, the sea bass was chopped, mixed and baked with cheesy mayo and mangoes in a mussel shell; the resulting baked sea bass tasted more like mayo than fish.
author: Diana B.

description:
This place, Zushi puzzle, and tataki are my top 3 favorite sushi places in the city! So fresh and delicious and totally worth it to go. It's super small (probably only holds no more than 12-15 people in the entire restaurant) so I recommend getting there early. I went with two other people, and we got there right at 5:30 pm on a Friday. We had a 45 minute wait already by that point, but we were luckily seated by 6:00 pm. We ended up ordering seaweed salad, sea bass (2 orders for 3 of us), the chef's sashimi platter, and three rolls (spicy hamachi, spicy tuna, and another special roll I forgot which one). 

The chef's sashimi platter was a GREAT deal and totally filled us up before we even received the rolls. The sashimi platter gave a good variety of fish, even including octopus! It was 14 pieces and they were huge between the three of us. It was so delicious and the rolls were also to die for. I felt more than sufficiently full by the time we were done with our meal. 

The downfall of this place was that everything took forever. We were seated at 6:00pm like I said, and we didn't get the sashimi platter till 6:45 and the rolls till about 7:20. The rolls took more than an hour to arrive from the time we ordered which was annoying, but it worked out in terms of how we wanted to space out the food.
