However, if they were faster, then people would be able to come in and out of this restaurant way faster. People were waiting forever - the food makes it worth it, but I do think it could be sped up a bit. 

I'll definitely be coming back though! This place rocks. So yummy!
author: Priya G.

description:
Oishii.....delicious fresh fish!

It was Friday evening and we were at Pearl and Market St. looking lost.  The owner of a Chinese restaurant at the corner there, without saying a word, came outside and pointed a little ways down Pearl Street. 
So I guess we looked like sushi connoisseurs ;o)

...AND there it was...SUSHI ZONE behind bushy ficus trees.  

Put our name on the list and waited 45 minutes for seating.
  
The server takes all orders even if you're sitting at the sushi bar leaving the one sushi chef uninterrupted to make his creations for the whole restaurant.  There is a wait for your food, but it is part of the whole experience.  Order some edamame and a tall Sapporo to pass the time.

Ordered spicy tuna roll, Hawaiian Roll #2, unagi/papaya roll and masago.  All the sushi pieces were large--each took two bites to eat.  Along with the fresh fish, crunchy nori (seaweed), ripe avocado and papaya.  No messy rolls drenched in sauces.

Facts:  CASH ONLY / 9 sushi bar seats / 2 tables of four
author: Candace I.

description:
Great place. Awesome sushi rolls for great prices. It's so relieving to finally find a cheap sushi place that doesn't just smother their rolls with spicy tuna or mayo.

Some personal favorites, the Indian roll had freshest octopus I've had in a while. The Hawaiian rolls may sound tacky at first but the macadamia nuts add a great mild flavor without taking away from the natural flavor of the fish.

Now here's why I gave this place three stars. My friend and I ordered some Nigiri and we discovered that the restaurant had "hidden" some wasabi under the sushi. Since this isn't normal protocol I suspected the Nigiri was of lower quality and I immediately confirmed this.

I hate to end on a low note because I had a great time here and the fish used in the rolls is very very high quality but I just can't ignore the fact they tried to hide wasabi in the Nigiri. Seriously guys not cool, but the rest of your food is incredible!
author: Spencer M.

description:
I love this place.. 
Good quality fish.. excellent prep and handling.. good quality well cooked rice.. 
Not a lot of choices.. Large portions...
Just the basics for sushi, sashimi, and rolls 
properly handled very fresh Tuna, Salmon, Yellowtail, Sea Bass, etc..
very fresh avocado and mango used in the rolls
a Hawaiian #2 roll is a good place to start..
the wait can be quite long if you go at prime times. 
But, there are plenty of places in the neighborhood to wet your whistle while you wait
Very casual with a great atmosphere .. Chef/Owner supports local music... 
Hidden Gem is a pretty accurate description..
Cash only
author: Mike T.

description:
7.7.2012. We spent $98 dollars for two people for average Sushi. We arrived at 8PM on a Friday without reservations. There was one waitress who saw us but did NOT acknowledge our presence. AKA, meaning: she knows you are there but doesn't greet you nor ask your name to put on the waiting list. The restaurant had approximately 20 patrons -- sitting at the L-shaped  bar or socializing at two banquette seats.  There was a party of three people before our party of two; however, the waitress didn't acknowledge our presence for 20 minutes until I made a snark comment about terrible hipster customer service within her hearing range. 

In order of presentation: the Seaweed Salad was good.  The Baked Mussels were excellent.  The Baked (Striped) Bass and Mango had a rough texture inconsistent with the presentation which was, ultimately, unappetizing. The $36 chef's choice Sashimi Combo plater was of average quality fish; however, the Papaya and Unagi roll was tasty. We  had two large bottles of Sake and one large Sapporo. Overall, the whole experience was AVERAGE! VERY DISAPPOINTED BY THE YELP RATINGS ON THIS SITE.  The Sushi was worth $50 but we paid $100 for a lackluster experience. Never again! By the way, I have lived in the City for sixteen years -- ten of those years near 18th Street and Mission.
author: Benaminh L.

description:
I live around this place so I am here very often, but also because I really like the food. The sushi is fresh and they definitely don't skimp on the fish. I usually order the Lion King, which is not on the menu, but the chef is ALWAYS nice enough to make it for me. 

This place is next door to a Karaoke bar, and while you enjoy your sushi you can watch people sing and dance next door on the TV screen - which can be pretty entertaining. 

The restaurant is very clean, small but cozy. I have always had great service. They also offer these punch cards that give you deals if you earn enough punches, which for me is always a plus!

Most of all, the price is very reasonable for the quality of sushi you get - definitely worth the money.

P.s They also offer a GREAT happy hour!
author: Sarah D.

description: After living in SF for almost 5 years now I have eaten at many sushi spots and I think it is safe to say that Sushi Zone is my favorite sushi spot in the city.  I find the affordability and the quality of the fish unbeatable.  The salmon nigiri is uh-maze-ing!!!.......so flavorful and the portion is good.  The baked sea bass with mango on top is mouth watering.  That is a must-order every time.
author: Tara K.

description:
17 seats, 2 conventional ovens, 2 refrigerators, one electric gas stove and a sushi bar. This place is smaller than my garage when I lived back in Houston, Texas. But, admittedly, for their prices, I definitely cannot complain. Their selection is mediocre, but their quality and the passion that comes out of artful cooking certainly places this little sushi joint at 5 stars.  

We got the Salmon Kama -- it was really good, but I think we'll try the more traditional Hamachi Kama next time.  We also tried their popular Baked Bass with Mango -- highly recommend! I'm not a big fan of fruits in savory dishes, but I'll definitely break out of my norm for this one. Other dishes we ordered: Alaskan Roll, Salmon Skin Hand Roll (only because I get this at every sushi place I walk into) and the Papaya Unagi (I probably would never get this again). 

All in all, I would definitely frequent this place more often.  Can't wait until we meet again, Sushi Zone!
author: Patricia T.

description: Ordered an avocado mango roll, a spicy tuna roll & hamachi nigiri. Everything was absolutely divine. I didn't even use the soy sauce I poured.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Great, fresh, sushi. 

However, the venue is teeny tiny (large groups NOT recommended) + be prepared to wait! 

Outside! 

In the cold! 

It's worth it in the end :)
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
the best sushi ever?  NO WAY.  but...i have to say that the prices are amazing, serving sizes are generous, the service is friendly...your water and tea never reach remotely close to empty...and the sushi guy behind the counter is working his ass off!  

we got there around 5:30 this evening and the place was already full...they have 2 booths and 8 counter seats.  we were 2nd on the list and we waited about an hour.  there's only one guy making sushi...and all they really serve here is sushi...so put 2 and 2 together...and of course, the wait time stinks!  the wait list fills up super quick so if you want to eat here, you should probably get here at 5pm on the dot or else expect to wait.

we tried 3 different rolls:
1) spicy salmon and mango - the best roll out of the 3!  this one seriously lit up all of my taste buds...it was spicy, sweet, and salty.  i'm not usually into the foo foo stuff...but this one was pretty dang tasty.   
2) unagi and papaya - eh...not so great.  the papaya actually made the roll quite soggy.  
3) hama masa - nothing special...covered in tobiko, filled with hamachi and avocado.  the rice was a little mushy on this roll.

i also ordered albacore nigiri and hirame nigiri.  the fish on both of these were semi fresh...the size of the nigiri itself was good.   

if you're a serious sushi junkie like i am, then this place isn't for you.  but if you have some friends who are just starting out and want to try something foo foo, then sushi zone is the best place to explore.  remember, get here at 5 or else expect to wait!  a solid 3.49 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
This was a three phase talent show between the sushi chef, the nigiri pieces, and fellow Yelper Tom R, who took a colossal chunk of wasabi in the size of futomaki and swallowed the entirety without a flinch. These were my three points of fascination as I joined Maybelline C, her friend Wendy, and Tom R for a sushi dinner in the City. If not for my friends who arrived early to snag a table, I was told the wait could last up to two hours. 

May and Tom are among my most trusted Yelpers so it was nice to sit back as they took care of the ordering.  All together, we shared two appetizers, one roll, and they asked for the chef to bring the house with their freshest assortment of nigiri:

Stuffed Jalapenos: Four giant pieces of opened jalapenos smothered with a creamy spicy tuna rendition. The jalapeno was bulky like a bell pepper with a dull kick and the stuffing was too creamy for my taste. I'm a big fan of the concept but the taste and presentation was rugged when compared to the ones that were finesse and sharper tasting at U-Zen.

Baked Bass: Minced bass baked with cream cheese and mayo served in a shell, and sandwiched between small chunks of sweet mangos at the bottom and morsels of masago atop. The sweet mango did not have influence until the bottom was reached while the bass was even creamier than the stuff jalapenos. When it comes to these types of dishes I'm expecting craftiness so the cream laden bass was less than ideal for my taste.

Hawaiian Roll: Sushi roll with fresh albacore and more mangoes at the center covered with canned macadamia nuts. I like the fresh albacore but the mango and macadamia nuts were a mysterious combination as they looked and tasted out of place.
 
For those sushi eaters with discriminating palates, the best bet here are their nigiri and sashimi. There were some hits and misses as I liked the hamachi, sake, and albacore, but I also find the maguro decent and the hirame disastrous. I was tempted to try their uni but decided against it after faced with the inconsistencies previously mentioned. Otherwise, the fish was generously cut into equal sizes--an art form for which I deeply appreciate.

My plum wine was a bit medicinal in taste but it was still worth the experiment. The place is a tiny hole in the wall so the huge line of people waiting for a table brought an overwhelming atmosphere with  little elbow room to maneuver outside our immediate area. The noise level was high and the server was a one-person operation who amazingly brought us rounds of awesome tasting water without skipping a beat. Among the three forms of talents being displayed, I thought there were some bright spots about the nigiris but Tom's wasabi trick was the most newsworthy. Here is how Sushi Zone is rated with all considered:

1.) Quality and freshness: 3.5 stars. With the exception of hirame, other nigiris ranged from decent to good. The ones I enjoyed had good moisture and taste, but aside from this dish, the others were either too creamy or the ingredients simply didn't meshed well together.
2.) Creativity and presentation: 2.5 stars. Perhaps too creative on the appetizers and the only roll we got. The simple look and taste of the nigiris was much more favorable.
3.) Quantity and substance: 3 stars. We each got a decent piece from all the dishes and were full by the time the meal was completed.
4.) Accessibility and affordability: 4 stars. We double ordered all the dishes and the total still came out to be $30 per person. The price tag was excellent.
5.) Service and ambiance: 3 stars. The venue is very small so the overcrowded ambiance could be overwhelming at times. I thought service was decent considering the amount of people waiting to be served with a chaotic line that flooded onto the sidewalk. 

Their largest table can only seat four so the setting arrangement is not ideal for large groups or family friendly. Cash only.

3 stars for the overall experience. With so many great sushi places in San Francisco, this restaurant was worth the try but I will not be returning unless Tom is scheduled to reappear for another wasabi trick.
author: Daniel L.

description:
This place is incredible.  We decided to come here because we couldn't get reservations for Kiss.  Kind of glad it worked out that way.  Fiance and I showed up at 4:30 because we were sure there would be a wait.  Unsurprisingly, there were 8 people already lined up before us.  The entire restaurant seats about 16 people but you have enough elbow and leg room.  The service is a little slow but that's because everything is made to order with care and precision.  Fiance had the sushi combo and I had the papaya eel and mango hamachi rolls.  I was pretty skeptical of the papaya and eel but they went together so well.  Even Fiance, who hates eel, said it was delicious.  Everything we tried was delicious and the fish was so fresh.  The prices are a little higher than I'm used to but for the size and quality of the sushi, it was so worth it.

The only complaint I had was the parking, but it's San Francisco so it comes along with the territory.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Really cute little place in Hayes Valley. Definitely call ahead if you can (it seemed like the waitress was taking phone rezies), since otherwise, you'll end up waiting about an hour, even if you get there right when dinner starts cranking up. Nice date place if you want to just chitchat for a long time, haha.

It's fun watching the sushi chef and his apprentice slice up the fish since they do it so fast and so prettily. I think I got the Hawaiian #2 roll and another roll with unagi (it's dying out, but it's too frackin' tasty...). Somehow the sushi here was on another level than sushi I've had elsewhere. It might just be ambience + the longgg wait making me delusional, but I swear it's good.
author: Kevin L.

description:
We've all encountered at least one location, restaurant, boutique, or hair stylist that is so fabulous that we want to selfishly keep it all to ourselves. Well, that's exactly how I feel about Sushi Zone--I would like to keep it as one of San Francisco's best kept secrets of all time. Unfortunately, I am too impressed NOT to share it with the world.

My girlfriend from college willingly took me to this sushi joint under the single condition that I maintain its secrecy and authenticity as best I can. I remember walking up to this hole-in-the-wall restaurant immediately feeling a sense of joy within me. Anything THAT tiny (sits about 18 people MAX) with THAT many people squished inside either eating or patiently waiting to be seated...MUST be good.

Unfortunately the word "good" does not cut it. Sushi Zone's food is beyond good; in fact, think of it as one of the best one-night stands you can remember. The food is orgasmic and doesn't leave you feeling guilty at the end of the night! The menu consists of many rolls and appetizers for only 6 dollars ;).

What to order? Do yourself a favor and believe me when I say the Sea Bass with Mango, and the Mussels will blow your mind. Order more than one helping of each of those two appetizers and you will not be disappointed. Also make sure to order the spicy mussels roll; this is one of the freshest and most creative rolls I've had in a while.

Sushi Zone, thank you for the wonderfully authentic--not to mention delicious--meal I've had in a while.
author: Jasmin W.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for the first time, I couldn't understand the wait.  After something like an hour and a half we got seated.

OMFG.  The food here is off the hook.  It's my favorite sushi place ever.  Cash only though so be prepared.
author: Kristin G.

description:
Sushi Zone is probably the best sushi you can get in the city for a cheap price.  The only downside is you will probably have to wait an hour for it, but it is worth it!

As everyone says do not come here with a big group, we arrived at 6pm on a Wednesday and it was about an hour and a half wait.  Luckily we popped over next door to grab some drinks.  

We ordered baked clams, and mussels with 7 different kinds of nigir and 2 bottles of sake for 75 dollars.  Very reasonable.

I will definitely be back here and it is a great place to take someone to.
author: Ryan J.

description:
This place is overrated, literally. 

The experience was SO disappointing. I have been wanting to try this place for months. What happened: The average patron seems to range somewhere between Marina douche to tourist with a shifty gaze. Also, I'm assuming there's a rupture in the space time continuum somewhere under one of the tables because a quoted 30-miunute wait actually turned out to be between an hour and a half to two hours. The food took an additional hour to hour and a half. In what universe does raw fish take an hour to throw on top of rice?! And guess what? Our long-awaited sushi was mediocre at best. I left annoyed, unsatisfied and confused how this place stays in business. Bluh.
author: Micah H.

description:
Absolutely delicious! 

Great food. Great service. Great prices.

The fish is very fresh, and nothing disappointed the hype that this place gets.

It's a must-go!
author: Ana M.

description:
Surprise, surprise - the Yelp reviews for Sushi Zone did not disappoint.

We arrived at 4:30 and were the second group in line.  Planning for an early dinner and standing in line, meant that our party of four was seated immediately when Sushi Zone opened at 5.  The line had at least 6 or 7 parties in it 10 minutes before opening - looked like everyone was thinking the same thing: let's beat the wait.  

The restaurant is small; there are two booths that can seat four each, maybe five/six if you want to squeeze three people on each side (but I think that's pushing your comfort level). The rest of the seating is at the bar where you can watch the sushi master at work. 

As all the reviews are saying, the fish truly is amazing.  The cuts are fresh and the portions are big. Most rolls (all but two) are $8/roll. 

The Spicy Hamachi was by far my favorite -  for the first time in my life, I was hesitant to dip my roll in my soy sauce wasabi mixture.  I cherished the unique and very subtle flavors of the roll too much.  Lime and hint of jalapeño in each bite - I didn't think that combination would be good with raw fish - but it was unlike anything I could've imagined. 
The Spicy Tuna was also great.  They use the spicy mayo really well here-- it doesn't drown your roll and there isn't a fat dollop of it on top. Instead, the mayo is lightly mixed in - it's subtle, and brings out the flavors of the fish. 
I also had the Hama Masa roll which was good (fresh, quality ingredients) but in comparison to the previous two rolls not as unique. 

Minor setbacks, the tea was not particularly good nor flavorful and the sake was so so.  Definitely not deal-breakers by any stretch of the imagination - the rolls were phenomenal and I look forward to trying the rest of the menu on my next visit.
author: Kimya P.

description:
I think this place is suffering from over hype-itis

Food is tasty for sure. I was a fan of everything I got here. Seabass is great here. However, the wait was pretty lengthy esp on a weeknight. From other reviews, we knew it was going to be long but it just really sucks that it's that long. Good for Sushi Zone but not so good for us. 

The space itself is a little grimy feeling. A little overcrowded, gets too much sun which makes the place kind of warm, tables can be kind of sticky...just feels cramped in general.

Yeah I know it's nitpicky but when I'm waiting for an hour, it gives me a lot of time to look around and think. ha.
author: Young L.

description:
This place is SO SMALL. GEEZZE.

I had dinner here on a MONDAY night and still waited a good hour and fifteen minutes. good thing parking was an ease or I would've been pissed!

Ordered:
1. backed mango seabass
2. spicy hamachi roll
3. spicy salmon roll
3. two orders of Amaebi

Overall I can say i really liked the hamachi and salmon rolls. I like the sauce they put to make it "spicy" but it's a bit too over powering with that mayo base. 

baked mango seabass was pretty good i'd say. But i think i notice that they reuse the shells by just washing them ...

In the end, i dont think the food was worth that hour plus wait. I like the classic atmosphere where it feels genuine when you sit inside and eat slowly at a japanese restaurant rather than feeling rushed.

The fish was fresh, but i've definitely had better. Everything we had was reasonably priced and I wasn't overstuffed by the time our meal was over. I'd come back again, but it would probably if i didnt get to go to the places at the top of my list.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Simple enough: Go early, with no more than 2 people, chill out and enjoy. The sushi is delectable, very well priced and the chefs and server are sweet. Yum. The baked Oysters are so good and I hate oysters! I used to come here  eons and eons ago, and just went back recently. They haven't changed and I'm glad, the wait was longish then as well and no one cared. I'll be back again soon.

For all the other complaining big group, restaurant storming, spoiled, hand coddled reviewers: Get over it and go to Blowfish ( which is also tasty).
author: Uda W.

description:
Its totally my pleasure to perpetuate the hype about this joint. 2.5 hour wait time and all! This place is so legit. so clean. so egoless. just fresh, impeccable food with humble and efficient service (and its cheap...what?!)

Worth mentioning is the staff, the head chef always has a smile on his face and is down to chat it up and both of the two (incredibly hot) women who serve are helpful, friendly and chill.

I have yet to try the baked mussels or baked bass, but everytime I see people gnoming on them they are beaming huge with like big inflated eyebrows that say, "hell ya!".

I'm a big fan of the fish & tropical fruit combos, I think the textures and flavors are so complimentary and its a unique kick to a cuisine that can tend to be a bit repetitive after 25 years.

To die for:
Spicy Salmon & Mango
Unagi & Papaya
Tuna & Mango
Spicy Himachi (with thin sliced jalepeno, lime and scallions)

A previous review said that the salmon here was the best in North America, I'm not much of a fish guru, but I had the salmon nigiri tonight and I was licking my fingers. They season the salmon lightly with salt, pepper, vinegar, lemon and dill and...just get it.

Their miso is really balanced and nicely seasoned, a bit on the sour side which I like a lot.

I would say if you're trying to impress a date and be super cool, roll through at like quarter to nine, put your name on the list, hop up the block to Orbit Room at Market & Guerrero, grab one of their ridiculously clever and equally fresh cocktails and then skip merrily down the hill at like 9:30 to catch the lull before close. 

If, on the other hand, you wanna be a dumb ass date and prove you are one of those San Francisco folks who likes waiting in line all night, then go at 7:30 and sit around staring at the minimalist decor for 2 hours. Either way, the meal is certain to make you cream your mouth without breaking the bank.
author: Shannon H.

description: Wow talk about amazing sushi! If your in San Francisco and looking for Sushi this is the place to go! It's a total hole in the wall restaurant. Its appearance may scare you but don't be frightened, the service is great. And you walk out with a full tummy and full wallet, because the food is super affordable. I highly recommend starting with the stuffed jalapeños to start with!
author: Jesus B.

description: small place but AMAZING sushi! highly recommend, well worth the wait
author: Marc M.

description:
There is always a long wait, but the sushi is really good and very inexpensive.
I liked the maguro, unagi, hamachi, and rock and roll.
author: Chris H.

description: It's been a minute but since I was on a Japanese kick all day I figured why not round things off with some amazing sushi and those freakin' baked mussels!
author: Jade W.

description:
Best hamachi I've ever eaten!

In fact, probably some of the best sashimi I've eaten overall.   

The only issue with this great little place is that the wait times are so long.   So it's not quite as fun for a date or a big group meal.

I've found that the trick to getting in and trying this place is to arrive at around 445pm and getting online.  If it's just you, you could pop in at 5 or 515pm with no problem.  But if you want to get a table for four or five people, get there even earlier.
author: Melissa D.

description:
I've heard over and over that this is the best Sushi in SF.  That may be true, but sadly that is a more a reflection of how surprisingly mediocre the sushi is in San Francisco.  It's really kinda stunning as SF is otherwise a great city for Asian food.  I suspect it's because there isn't a very large Japanese population in SF relative to other Asian ethnicities and sushi has become very trendy in mainstream American culture.  So the sensibilities for what is "great" sushi by most SFers (a city of transplants) is relative to what they had "back home".

Sushi Zone has all the trappings of a "to-die for" hole in the wall: the place is TINY -  as in seats 16 total (8 at the bar, and 2 tables of 4), it's too warm to be sanitary for sushi, is in the middle of nowhere on Market Street, takes forever and a day to get a table (2 hours on a Friday night), and is CASH only.  The only problem is the sushi does not in any way live up to the hype.  It actually rates somewhere just above average.  Certainly not anywhere close to the best I've had.  I've had great sushi plenty of times and without the "charming" "annoyances" one is really only willing to tolerate when the food is exceptional.

If you're used to places like Ponzu or Blowfish, then this is certainly more authentic, but it's still highly Americanized.  The crowd is strictly gaijin - no Japanese at all (except staff) while we were there. The menu is English only (another subtle hint about the clientele), and it's dominated by Western style rolls - granted they were more "Japanese" than some of the ridiculous concoctions at rock'n roll sushi bars.  

Although I only give Sushi Zone 2-stars, It's not a condemnation of the owner/chef.  The food is 3-stars (maybe even 4 if you've never been to Japan).  It's the massive wait times (not his fault) which made it a 1-star experience for me.  He is Japanese and a very competent sushi chef who prepares respectable food.  But the place is too damn small and inconvenient, and he has certainly tailored the menu for his crowd.  Having had the real deal many times, Sushi Zone just doesn't do it for me.  But I guess if you live in SF, this is about as good as it gets.  If you really want to experience great sushi though and can't go to Japan, then visit the suburbs of LA.  There is a HUGE Japanese population around Torrance / Gardena and that's where you'll find the best sushi in America.
author: Michael T.

description:
Worth every minute of wait. 

Don't come here to impress someone; come here to relax and enjoy the green tea, sip the miso, talk to someone you love, and eat some sushi that's on par if not better than more expensive places like Sushi Ran. 

My happy place.
author: Soyan M.

description:
They knocked it out of the park with the spicy hamachi roll. No mayo-sriracha gloppy mess on this spicy roll. Just hamachi, jalapeno and thinly sliced lime slices. Greatest combo in sushi I've had in a while. 

The wait time to get seated is incidiously long, but you can go around the corner to Destino for a pisco cocktail and you won't even notice you've been waiting for 60 minutes for that made in heaven hamachi roll.
author: Lee H.

description:
I really like this place. I've only been here twice and it was an experience both times. Unfortunately, that experience gets old. The sushi is great. You've read about it on countless other reviews. It is tender, tasty and tactfully turned out. I get that it's good sushi and the space is limited. That helps with the buzz. I think nearly comparable sushi is available without having to rush out of work and then sit in line for dozens of minutes. 

 I'd like to enjoy my sushi without feeling the shadow of guilt creep over me if I decide to start a conversation with sushi buddy. I know that asking how his day went will keep the person behind me in line waiting another 12s. I'm sorry. If it makes you feel better, you sitting 4 inches behind me and staring at me almost dampens the orgasm of flavor this mango and thinly sliced lime served with fresh hamachi brings to me. The sushi is great, probably the best I've ever had. 

If you get there a few minutes before 5pm, you should have no problem being seated, even on a friday.
author: Mike D.

description:
Minus one star for the 2.5 hour wait on a friday night!!! ahhhhhhhh!!!! 

Baked mussels: big juicy and delicious. Must try.

Baked sea bass: my favorite. sea bass was baked perfectly...on top of the sweetness of mango and the mayo... nom. 

Spicy Hamachi: I was so hungry I just inhaled the rolls, didn't know which one was which

Mango something: waitress suggested this for us, this one got blurred with the spicy hamachi.

Hawaiian #1: The macadamia nuts on top of the tuna roll with avocados, I have to say, this one was worth the wait.   

Hamachi sashimi: decent, but not the best I've ever had (esp after kiss seafood...)

Great service, cheap booze, and "worth the wait" food.
author: Emily T.

description:
First off this is a small intimate restaurant as others have stated. That's part of its charm. There are two booths that seat 4 people each and the counter which seats 8. Maximum seating capacity is 16 if the booths are filled, most times there's just a couple occupying them. When you walk up to the place based on the size you should expect a wait if the tables/counter are full. For those who complain about having to wait, what would you rather have? 1) A wait and then a leisurely meal where you can savor it all at your pace. 2) No wait and a waitress who delivers indigestion as she encourages you to inhale your food and stands over you breathing down your neck to get you to gulp your tea and vacate your seat.

If you get there and the tables are full, add your name to the whiteboard (it's on the sideboard). There's a bench near the door and four chairs against the sideboard for waiting. I recommend grabbing one of the chairs against the buffet so that you can watch the Sushi chef. While you wait you can enjoy a Sapporo or sake or nibble on some Edamame. We've waited both times we've gone here - a little over an hour the first time and almost 2 hours the second time. There's a rhythm to the waiting - some people come in, list their names, and reappear just as the seats with their name open up. NOTE: If you wander and then come back to discover that your name has been passed, don't despair. The server will seat you when the next table comes open.

The first time I came here I didn't know to get the baked sea bass with mango. A friend told me we absolutely had to get it the next time and we'd forgotten about it until we were waiting we saw a baked concoction on mussel shells go by us. It was as good as we'd been told. If you're with another person, don't get just 1 order (2 pieces for each of you), get your own order! 

Also, if you have the choice between a booth or the counter, I'd recommend the counter. When we sat at the booth, the chef wasn't able to judge our pace and sent out the sushi at the same time. At the counter we were able to enjoy each plate on its own. Sushi is meant to be savored from the start as your eyes feast on the presentation to finish as your mouth experiences a symphony of balanced flavors.
author: Eden S.

description:
After reading all of the reviews citing 2.5 hour wait times and not complaining, we had to give Sushi Zone a try. We got here at 6:00 sharp and put our name on the list. For those of you who haven't been to Sushi Zone before, putting your name on the list means physically picking up an Expo marker and writing your name on a dorm room whiteboard. Pretty funny. Lucky for us, there were only two parties in front of us, and they both had gone around the corner for a drink, so we were seated within about ten minutes.

But this review isn't about the wait. It's about the food:

Appetizers (4/5): We ordered both the baked bass with mango and the baked mussels. Both came in mussel shells, so were a little hard to tell apart, until we ate them of course. If I had to choose one over the other, I might lean slightly towards the mussels, but they're pretty small, so go ahead and order both.

Rolls (3/5): We had the tuna mango roll and the yellowtail scallion roll. Fish portions seemed a little bigger than other places, but nothing special. We didn't see a lot of creative or unique rolls on the menu, which probably should have been a sign to focus on other things.

Nigiri (5/5): This is the shining point. Not only is the nigiri super-fresh, but the slices of fish are incredibly thick and generous. We had uni, maguro, salmon, hamachi, and albacore. We have had better uni elsewhere, but the four fish nigiri we ordered were right up there with some of our favorite sushi spots. I would say that the albacore and salmon were tied for the favorite spot, though the hamachi and maguro were strong contenders as well.

The next time we go to Sushi Zone, we'll probably order a little more nigiri and skip the rolls--not because the rolls are bad, but because the nigiri is so good.
author: Safford B.

description: Excellent sushi!  The fish was very fresh, and the portions were generous.  We had sashimi, and each piece was a big slab of fish!  We were seated quickly with 2 people, but larger parties waited a while longer.  Either way, it's worth the wait.
author: Lolo M.

description:
Although I vowed to never eat sushi on a Monday after reading Anthony Bourdain's Kitchen Confidential, I found myself at Sushi Zone on a Monday.  And after a longer than expected walk from my apartment, I was determined to wait out the 3 names before me to see what all the Sushi Zone hype was about.  It's sushi. It's raw. How long could the wait be?

1.5 hour later, I was ravenous. Maybe that's part of the allure of Sushi Zone? You wait so long to eat that you are really hungry and food tastes extraordinarily delicious. However, the sushi here is really good. And I'm confident that the sushi would taste this good even if I hadn't waited as long.

Everything we had was simple, fresh, and very good.  We started with a green salad topped with mango, avocado, and shrimp, served with a miso dressing.  We also ordered a yellowtail/scallion roll, salmon nigiri, and a spicy hamachi roll.  The spicy hamachi roll was our favorite roll.  

Although the sushi was very good, the standouts of the meal were the baked mussel and baked seabass.  The baked mussel is a concoction of mayo and chopped mussel, baked in a mussel shell.  The seabass is the same concoction, but with sweet chopped mango in it.  Both were sweet, creamy, and rich.  The seabass was so good that we ordered a second round.  

If you can get here before the rush or endure the wait, you'll be rewarded with really fresh sushi at unheard-of, cheap prices.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Generally when it comes to a life changing food experience, I wouldn't mind waiting awhile to devour it but Sushi Zone time limit burst in my stomach before I could really enjoy it.  Put our name down around 7:50 and didn't get seated til 9:45.  Which I was ok with since my friends and I were at a bar around the corner. 

The thing that I didn't like was how long it took for the food to get to us once we ordered.  Around 40-50 mins later, we finally got to try this "amazing sushi" which wasn't so mind blowing fresh but this may also be due to the fact that it took forever. 

All the rolls we ordered were great but was it great enough to wait that long for it?  Nah.  I think you can get just as great quality sushi elsewhere in SF like Tataki!  The good thing about Sushi Zone is that it wasn't expensive.  Hey, if I can get good quality sushi without breaking my bank, I'm a happy camper.  Now they just gotta figure out the traffic situation!  

Maybe I'll give it another shot next time with a brilliant time strategy to beat  the crowd.  Maybe.
author: Nho C.

description:
Absolutely awesome! The freshest sushi I have ever had. You can cut the fish with your chopstick with no effort, its just that fresh.  And it melts in your mouth. LOVE this little gem of a place.

Everything we had was amazing. I would definitely go there again, but just be warned, it's small so if you get there late, you will have to wait.  We didn't and got seated right away. 

Fantastic.
author: Candy T.

description:
Queue up early (20-30 mins before they open).
Sushi is fresh and service is great.  Kitchen a little slow, but I don't ding for that.  Definitely try the baked mussels.  Prices are super-cheap for the freshness, but you do pay for it by having to wait around.
author: Lisa S.

description: Sashimi and nigiri is delicious although the place is tiny.  Waited a while but it's worth the wait for the great dishes.
author: Uli G.

description:
O.M.G. Delicious!!! The baked mussels are to die for!!! My friend and I came here two months ago and I am still craving these baked mussels. We also had a couple rolls that I don't remember the name - one was a california roll with real crab and another one was a tuna (?) roll with lime - DELICIOUS! We hardly talked to each other while eating and just kept shaking our heads because it was so good! 

One caveat - the place is TINY. There are only two booths that fit comfortably 4 people - I think you can squeeze 6. The sushi bar fits about 10 or so. The wait will be long but definitely worth it! We got there half an hour after the restaurant opened and waited about 20 minutes.

Can't wait to visit SF again so we can eat here!
author: Rosanne A.

description: This is the best japanese resto in the city. It's worth the wait everything is delicious, specially the mushroom with salmon.. Bbq unagi with papaya is sooo good!!! The place is small so go there before they open.
author: Gladys D.

description:
Baked Mussels!!!

kinda hard to beat rolls at less than $10 apiece. the menu is small, but substantial. there aren't any fancy, exotic fish selections to choose from, but they've got the basics and they're good. the bf and i tried an interesting combo: papaya and unagi. i wasn't sure what to expect, but the outcome turned out to be a winner. must come early(by 6p) to secure first round seating.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Deliciously fresh sushi in a cute and cozy Japanese restaurant. The boyfriend and I ordered a nigiri platter and the salmon mango roll. Both were blissfully divine. Apparently we missed the memo that sea bass with mango was the way to go -- 3G wasn't working and couldn't access Yelp!! :( It's okay though, it just gives us a reason to come back.

But next time, we'll pack some patience and snack beforehand since there was quite a wait for our food because there was only one chef on deck. I am not a patient or pleasant girl - especially when I'm hungry!! [Minus 1 star for the long wait.]

Word to the wise: Don't come big groups, this place is tiny -- think it can only fit about 16 customers max. Improve your average wait time and come in two's.
author: Linda B.

description:
My favorite tasting sushi, fresh, simple and creative.

Get the mango sea bass thing everyone talks about, its delicious.
Order anything, you can't go wrong.
The prices are moderate, not a "fill-the-junk-out-of-yourself" sushi place.

Sushi Zone is my favorite sushi place, if I had more $ and didn't have to worry about the wait-time, I would come here waaay more often.

Sitting at the bar is really uncomfortable too, that's a drag.
but its your only choice unless you have 4 guests & get 1 of the 2 booths.

CASH ONLY
author: Grilled O.

description:
A true hole in the wall, where there are only 2 booths and a counter which seats about 8 people, this place serves amazing sushi. 

The operation is made up of four people. Sushi chef, appetizer chef, a dishwasher, and a server. The only person who really speaks english is the waitress. 

Appetizer chef prepares and cooks the appetizers - all of which are baked in a small oven. He cuts up fish, mangoes, mussels, and prepares the mayo concoctions as well. Otherwise, he will be politely standing with his hand behind his back.

We tried the baked bass, which was cut up mixed with mangoes and topped with mayo in mussel shells, and then baked. Same procedures apply to all the appetizers. Very yummy.

The sushi are super fresh and huge. Most rolls are only $6.50 except for the rainbow roll which is $14.50. The fish are soooo fresh and sweet. The last time I have such fresh fish was in Hawaii.

CASH ONLY is the only downside here, so make sure you visit the ATM before hand.
author: July N.

description: This place is worth getting in line early for. We usually get there about 30 minutes before they open and chill outside. Otherwise you might not get a table for 2-3 hours. Seriously my favorite sushi joint.
author: Jena C.

description: Pretty legit sushi, even their non sushi is good.  Worst part is there isn't any seating and long lines but that doesn't mean I'll rate it any lower.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This place has the best sushi I've had in San Francisco. There isn't one other place that comes close to my experience at Sushi Zone.

Disclaimer: If you want to eat here, you should have a place nearby to get drinks while you wait. Our wait was close to an hour and a half, maybe more. Pisco is around the corner, so that's what I do.

The place is owned and managed by one family, which gives it a homey feel. It is TINY, so in can only hold so many people at once.

However, the food is unbelievably good.

Even with the long wait, I would come every other week; not everybody is willing to wait that long for food though.

It;s not overpriced, but it is expensive.
author: Gerardo C.

description:
Service: 4
Taste: 5
Quality: 5
Variety: 4
Price: $15-30
Recommend to a friend: Yes!

Okay. So I'm going to say the not-so-good parts first and then end with the good.

The place seats about 16 people, so the max you can probably have is about 6 people in your group. We only had 4 people so it was okay. But, keep in mind that since the place is so small and we had a fairly large group, there was over an hour wait for our group. For this reason, they won't seat you unless your whole group is there -- keep that in mind. Also, because there's only one sushi chef, it takes a while for food to come out. We probably waited another half hour for food. Our water glasses were empty sometimes, but it might be because the cups are really small. Also, I found one fish scale in my tuna...

Those things being said, please note that I STILL gave Sushi Zone five stars. They don't use imitation pollack "crab meat" and have really fresh fish. I got the baked mussels appetizer, a Hawaiian #1 roll, and a Spicy Tuna roll. I've got to say, the baked mussels were REALLY good. The mussel itself is actually chopped up into small pieces and cooked with some sauce, then replaced into the shell and baked. Please order this appetizer. Only comes with 2 mussels, but worth it. I liked that the spicy tuna had bean sprouts in it and had fresh pieces of tuna with spicy mayo sauce instead of pureed tuna. I chose the rolls because I'm a sucker for tuna and avocado, but they have a pretty decent selection of other sushi rolls and nigiri.

Other things my friends got were the sushi combo, the Hawaiian #2, nigiri, and the mango-yellowtail(?) roll. Everyone was really happy and satisfied with their food, so I think it was a success for everyone. Definitely would come back again!
author: Julia N.

description: Prices on Yelp are old. Quality and prices do not match. Cramped quarters and very long wait for mediocre sushi.
author: Pat F.

description: The sushi here are great, lion king roll is popular here, a long with the Godzilla and sashimi. Love eating sushi with some Saki, it tastes really well together.
author: Krystal S.

description:
Likes: Baked mussels, salmon mango roll, salmon nigri, green tea ice cream and the reasonable prices. 

Dislikes: 90 minute wait on a Monday night at about 7 p.m. My boyfriend said he experienced every emotion during this duration; anticipation, excitement, hunger, anger, defeat and sadz. This 16 seat venue means you'll be waiting for awhile unless you arrive right as they open or before. While the sushi is good quality and tasty, I'm not sure it's necessarily always worth this very long wait.
author: Jessica S.

description:
One of the the best sushi places I've been to in the City. 

The cuts of maguro are so lean, I'd wish blood would still be oozing out a bit. 

The New Zealand baked green mussell. YUM!

Their rolls. Delish!

BUT

They don't have Ankimo. No Ankimo, no peace. You lost 1 star.
author: Christopher V.

description:
Shhhh. Rate this place lower so the lines will be shorter.  Starting to see Marina folks edge into this spot.  Not having anything against the fine neighbors to the north, but for once can't we just enjoy a good spot without it showing up on the trend radar?

Good? Everything on the menu.  Especially the baked mussels, spicy scallop roll and (something not on the menu) the Alaskan crab hand roll.

Bad?  The wait.  Really people, if you aren't prepared to wait 2 hours for good food, this is not the place for you.

PS:
Al loves you. That is all.
author: Josh N.

description:
Good quality, authentic and simple sushi...buuuut it did not blow me away.

The sashimi was overall really good but I felt that some types of fish were fresher than others. I also didn't really like how on our Sashimi Sampler platter, the salmon was touching some lemon wedges, and ended up having a strange fishy/lemony flavor. The chef is really generous with giving you thickly sliced pieces of sashimi though.

The hamachi sashimi was so incredibly fresh, buttery, and flavorful. Easily the best I've ever had.

The Baked Mussels (baked with spicy mayo)...you must! $5.50 a pair though.

The rolls are smaller than average...and they are pretty simple so you can actually taste the fish...except in our Saba Maki Roll. There was wayyyyyy too much ginger up in there!

Due to my ignorance, I didn't realize that this restaurant only has 2 tables that each seat 4, a bar that seats around 6, and one hardworking sushi chef, which means that it will most likely take at least 1.5 hours for them to accomodate you...and then at least another 30 minutes to get your sushi.

Spent around $60 for a 14-piece sashimi sampler, a saba maki, a pair of baked mussels, and a spicy hamachi roll. Worth the money? Yes. Worth the 2 hour wait? Probably not.
author: Jessica C.

description:
This place is one of my Worst nightmare as in the fish were not fresh and the sushi rice was not properly cooked.. The portion served was way too big... Even the mango used in vegetarian nigiri had alcohol smell.. Yet this place is very popular... For those who are used to authentic Japanese sushi, this is definitely NOT for you.

Plus the long wait and the street parking... We will not come back period. 

The only good part of this restaurant is their cooked items such as their baked mussels...
author: Simon J.

description:
I saw someone mark this place as a "one star" simply because they thought it might prevent people from going there. If there's any better recommendation for a restaurant, I can't think of it.

What can I say? The best sushi I've had, and I've been to a good number of sushi places across the US. I really can't say much else that the other reviewers haven't already said. The sushi is very fresh. Most of what is available is not too flashy, but still tastes amazing. The baked muscles are a must.
author: Joshua G.

description:
I caveat my 5-star rating with a warning... You will only enjoy this experience if you have a lot of time to devote to waiting patiently for a seat and if you have no where else to go after dinner.

Food: In an age of spicy tuna, spicy salmon, and other ground up sushi fillers that all taste the same, Sushi Zone delivers some of the best food at a reasonable price. This place has some of the nicest cuts of sashimi I've ever had... maybe rivaling even Nobu for the texture and weightiness of the meat. And I really mean that it is a fraction of the price. A bill for 4 stuffed to the gills came out to $120 all in.
This is my advice: go beyond the rolls. While they are very nice, they aren't a cut above the rest of the sushi restaurants around the world. For me, the baked mussels and the baked sea bass made the 2.5 hr wait worth it (this was on a TUESDAY night). These appetizers are served very much like baked scallops at dim sum restaurants... meat mixed with some variation of kewpie mayo and loaded onto a sea shell... then baked to a molten golden brown. These items are out of this world... don't miss them if you took the time to wait in line for a seat.

Space and Decor: The storefront is very unassuming and small. There are 2 tables for 4, and the rest is just areas around the bar. It has a homely, if a bit cramped, feel to it. But luckily, its never freezing cold in the Bay, and if you get a bit claustrophobic, you can step outside and wait.

PS don't come if you plan on going out later. You will smell. of delicious food, but you will smell. Just remember that before you start grinding up on some stranger at a club.
author: Joe L.

description:
I found this place on yelp while in San Fran on business. I can honestly say it was the BEST MEAL OF MY LIFE. I followed the lead of other yelpers (in terms of what to order):

1. Sea Bass/Mango App (get ready to die and go to heaven)
2. Hawaiin Roll #1
3. Spicy Hamachi Roll
4. Hawaiin Roll #2
(in this order). 

This was enough food for 2 people. I repeat, It was THE BEST MEAL OF MY LIFE. the whole meal including 2 large hot sakis was less than $50.  I dream of the day I can return to Sushi Zone.
author: Liz G.

description:
Ok, the fish is pretty good. But I don't know if it's the freshest fish I've had. And I guess it didn't help that I was starving my brains out when I arrived to wait 1.5 hrs for a table and continued to be starved for another 45 mins after being seated and ordering. The spicy tuna was good though, as was the uni. The salmon sashimi was nice too. And I really appreciate the prices even though it's cash only. Nonetheless we unsurprisingly left a little after 11pm (been there since 8pm) and were still hungry :(

My fav sushi place still is Minako. The fish is fresher, the rice is yummier, and the slow ass service is amusing at least, plus comes with a hug if you're awesome.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Probably some of the best sushi that I have ever had - super fresh, and at the best price ever (all rolls are around $6)!  This is a little hole in the wall restaurant, with 2 booths and a sushi bar.  It can probably seat 20 people max, but that didn't scare us away.  We got there around 6pm, and we probably waited about 30 - 45 minutes.  We did notice that it got much busier as the night progressed, but it is definitely worth the wait!

I highly recommend the baked sea bass... SO GOOD!  The bass is cooked perfectly in a little muscle shell, and hiding underneath it is a serving of some mango salsa.  delicious.  We also had one of the hawaiian rolls covered in macadamia nuts (I think #2), which was delicious.  I think we also had the spicy scallop roll, rock & roll, and I can't remember all the other stuff we ordered, but I do remember that it was all good!

In total, we got an appetizer, 5 rolls, 2 pieces of sake nigire, and green tea ice cream all for $50!! INSANE!
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Delicious!  The food is awesome here.  Loved the baked seabass and mushrooms.  Will try the baked mussels next time!  The rolls were all delicious, we had tried a variety of rolls, some raw, some cooked but everything was really good and fresh.  The rolls had a very well balanced flavor and their spicy mayo is yummy!  

I've been here twice and the wait is definitely long!  The place is tiny, they can fit about 8 people at the bar and they have 2 tables which fit about 4 each.  Get here before they open and you should be fine.  If not, be prepared to wait at least an hour to two to be seated! The first time we came here, we waited 2hours before we were seated and we were first on the waiting list.  On our second try, we were able to grab the last two seats at the bar.  There is only one sushi chef so it takes some time before your food arrives.  Once the food starts coming, the rest of your food will arrive at a good pace.  Once we finish one item, the chef will have your next item ready.  Besides the wait, this place is awesome!
author: Veronica N.

description: Amazing place! Have become quite the regular. Baked bass is unreal. Fresh fish, friendly service and great prices. In my opinion the best sushi spot in the bay.
author: Camilo V.

description: Sushi Zone is all about the baked seabass & mango appetizer and Hawaiian #2 roll. Well worth the wait. Never had anything this divine.
author: Latrice P.

description:
I think perhaps a 3.5 for not accepting credit cards and being 1.5 hr wait everytime I've come here. BRING CASH. Luckily, this place isn't too pricey.

I've been here twice, one with a party of 5 and another time party of 2. Both times 1hr+ wait. This place is super tiny so I suggest that you put your name down on the whiteboard and go do something for at least 45 min. Both times we arrived around 7:30-8 and the wait was just as long. Perhaps next time we'll come around opening time which is 5pm (who eats dinner that early). Parking isn't difficult, mostly all meters.

We ordered: 

Baked Bass: DELICIOUS! Chopped up bass meat mixed with some creamy mayo sauce with some ponzu and scallions. One order comes with two pieces.

Baked Mussels: JUST AS GOOD! Pretty much the same concept as bass but with chunks of mangoes added. Mouthwatering goodness! Each order also comes with two pieces.

Sashimi Combo: Comes with salmon, red tuna, mackerel, albacore, shrimp, and yellow tail I think? Not skimp on the pieces.

Hawaiian Roll #1: Tuna with avocado and a generous amount of chopped macadamia nuts sprinkled on top. YUM!

Hawaiian Roll #2: Yellowtail with mango and also with avocado I think, plus the mountain of macadamia nuts sprinkled on top. JUST AS GOOD AS #1.

Unagi papaya: Exactly what the name says, eel with papaya. I am not a fan of papaya so I did not try this but my cousins sure had no problem annihilating it within minutes. 

Mango Hamachi: The flavors really compliment each other and gives that tropical taste.

Hama Masa: One of the few rolls that didn't really leave a strong impression in my head, but nonetheless delicious.

Spicy Hamachi Roll: Exactly how it sounds too. Very fresh, very simple, very good!

Salmon & Albacore Nigiri: Very fresh and generous on the cut.

I like my sushi simple and fresh, because I find restaurants that like to mask the freshness of their fish with some kinda spicy mayo sauce or teriyaki sauce, kinda jive? Kinda overpriced and for no reason. The rolls here have the best of both. Simple yet with a touch of hawaiian influences. The best thing about it is that it won't break the bank. Each roll is about $5.50-$7 for a decent size too. Just remember not to come here hungry because it will be over an hr.
author: Elaine L.

description:
My star rating still stands. Although Al, the owner/sushi chef prior, is no longer behind the counter, my meal was as delicious & fresh as I remember.

New equation: 
Grilled hamachi kama special (cheek/collar) + in my mouth = food orgasm

p.s. The diners next to us ordered the "Amaebi sushi" special (raw sweet shrimp), and I kind of regret not ordering it. You get the shrimp nigiri, but then they ask you if you want the head. Say yes, 'cos they deep fry it and serve it to you hot & crispy. Don't knock it --fried shrimp head is fracken delicious!
author: Antoi C.

description: It's across the street from where I live. There was a wait, but it was good. I do think you could get just as good quality somewhere else that accepts credit cards, but it was yummy, so I'm not really complaining. That much.
author: M.E. F.

description:
I keep forgetting to write a review about this place!

This is the best sushi roll place in San Francisco! The rolls are all unique and fresh tasting! Everything on their white board menu is good! You can order everything and it'd all taste good. I'm serious because that was what I did lol! The Hawaiian roll is so good with the macadamia nuts on top, the Indian roll has octopus in it which goes really well with the sauce, all the fresh fish with mango rolls are good, and all their baked stuff is good. I highly recommend the baked sea bass with mango. I wanted seconds and thirds after that! Order all the rolls here that you can't get anywhere else.

Just letting you know there is only one sushi chef here and only one guy making the baked stuff. I thought I saw a third guy washing dishes and making the rice last time, but I'm not sure. Well anyways, the wait is between one to two hours here. Yes I've actually waited 2 hours here before but I don't care because I can wait for good food.
author: Shu L.

description: This place is amazing! I must say best sushi I've ever had next to Hawaii. The staff is very friendly & nice. The place is sort of a little hole on the wall and small so it can't seat very many people at once, but its well worth the wait! Reasonably priced and most important its the freshest sushi you'll get in the whole city.
author: Kaitlyn F.

description:
Man, this place is amazing. i always try to get there early around 4:45 before they open to get first seating. My family and friends still talk about this place on Facebook and I text them pictures of the food to tease them.  
Hawaiin #2 and Spicey Yellowtail is out of this world.  And the stuffed mushroom appetizer, What? Awesome.  
Go to this place but make sure you take into account the wait.  If I don't make first seating I usually go over to Orbit Room and kill an hour.  But it's well worth it.
author: Frank A.

description:
Warning! Spoiler Alert! 

This place is small. Like the size of my studio apartment. Don't come here with big groups. Shit coming here with 6 people was already too much. 

But! The food is fresh and delicious and relatively cheap for rolls. 

I would love to come back, maybe with just 2 people. 

We waited almost an hour for food. But it was super good.
author: Melissa T.

description:
The wait was an hour, which doesn't bother me as long as it is worthwhile.

Now comes the part where I'm nit-picky:
While the fish tasted fresh and the combinations were fun and yummy, my sushi was falling apart. The rice was too moist and didn't have the right amount of toothiness that I expect from a solid sushi place. And the saba was -eh- in my opinion. 

Maybe it was because the chef and others had been drinking all night, and their craftmanship was getting shoddy towards the end of the night. But presentation is a big part of the whole sushi experience for me. If you just want to stuff some fish and rice in your grill and don't care about that, then you will probably enjoy this place.
author: Yum Chompsky B.

description:
Whaaa?! 

Yelp has officially let me down. This place is no where near great. We waited about 30 - 45 minutes and it wasn't worth it, can't believe some people are saying they waited up to 2 hours! 

The nigiri sushi had so much wasabi on it you couldn't even taste the fish and the other rolls were equally bland. The one with macadamia nuts? Not good or tasty at all. Plus the service was pretty terrible. 

The only plus to this place is it's super cheap but I'd rather pay a little more and get great food & service.
author: Desa F.

description:
Not worth the wait. I don't just mean the time it takes to nab a table (about an hour), but the wait to actually get food once you are seated (about an hour from first dish to second). Which is even MORE tortuous, believe you me. Watching people eat while hungry is cruel and unusual punishment.

Yes, it's pretty cheap and fresh, but only the baked seabass + mango was truly memorable. Everything tasted just as they would at another decent sushi joint and the cost seemed to be slightly cheaper overall. 

But the sushi master is the only one making any sort of food for diners, and since everyone is starving when they sit down, each order consists of a billion things, which slows down things for the next diner. Plus, the sushi master tends to make the bulk of each order at a time, rather than making one thing for one table, one thing for another table, etc., which adds to the long lag (and stomach rumblings) between some dishes.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
Despite being located in no man's land, Sushi Zone is quite popular. It was a chance encounter for me one night as I passed by at 20 mph on the F Train and seeing activity within the restaurant in an otherwise very dead block. Though I'd seen the high Yelp rating before, it was the sight from that random night that triggered me to finally check it out.

Small, even for a sushi establishment, Sushi Zone's sushi and maki roll offerings are anything but small in portion and flavor. I find their prices very reasonable especially considering the generous cut of fish you get. What impressed me even more is the freshness of the fish I had. Their rainbow roll is a whopping $15, but it was a rainbow roll on steroids (in a good way).

I didn't care much for the one hour wait at eight o'clock on the Wednesday night I decided to stop by. I guess being rated as SF Weekly's Reader's Best Sushi makes it a highly sought after destination at any night of the week. Unfortunately there's really no place nearby to pleasantly kill time before you get to sit down, unless you fancy yourself a new tramp stamp from the parlor next door. Except for the mango in some of the maki rolls, there's nothing pretentious about this place. Their limited selection of basic fish nigiri sushi and rolls will not disappoint as soon as they enter your mouth. Practically a hole in the wall with bar seating and a couple of booths, your clothes will start to smell like the food if you stay long enough (though nothing was particularly offensive while I was there). In moderation, it's definitely worth your while.
author: Rina W.

description:
Baked Bass & Hawaii Roll #2 all the way!

I had a 3 hours wait once (2 outside, 1 after the order inside) but it was totally worth it.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Decent, but nothing that I would crave.

There are certainly much better places in the city.
author: Ankur V.

description: This might be the best sushi I've had. Certainly the best in SF. Definitely try the Baked Bass appetizer (two half oyster shells filled with mango and topped with delicious baked bass). I rounded my meal out with the spicy hamachi, spicy mango salmon, and the Hawaiian role #2, all of which was excellent (a good amount if you're alone and quite hungry -- was about $32 total). Note that it's cash only and you may have to wait a long time (but it's worth it!)
author: Jay G.

description:
The wind was at our backs this evening when we happened by Sushi Zone just as they were opening. We snagged two seats at the bar and settled in, ordering miso soup and edamame to stave off impending hunger. Being Sushi Zone novices we did not get any of the hot dishes and went straight for the sushi: spicy tuna roll, yellowtail with scallion and mango, unagi, saba and maguro.

My traditional companion was not a fan of the yellowtail with scallion and mango. As the more adventurous one in our pairing, and a lover of juicy, ripe mango, I thought it was delicious. However, my favorite by far was the spicy tuna roll which arrived studded with avocado - a nice surprise. 

On a misty, cold San Francisco night opt for some of Sushi Zone's hot specialties. From a modest toaster oven comes many delights: baked mussels, shiitake mushroom with salmon and jalapeno peppers stuffed with albacore. Both the salmon and tuna are spreads - chunks of fish in very rich, creamy sauces dolloped on either the shell of a jalapeno or the shiitake cap and allowed to brown. They're inspirational - what else might be possible with a toaster over? I long to know!

On a busy night, when the sushi chef is a little behind, get some of these hot dishes (made by a different chef). They go especially well with beer. We learned this after envying the orders of everyone around us and finally opting to get some of our own. In future, we'll get the hot stuff at the start of the meal.

Dinner for two tonight was potentially the best $70 (that's including tax, tip and beer) I spent on this visit to San Francisco. I don't know how, given the size and scope of Sushi Zone, the meal could have been any better.
author: Miriam W.

description:
In New York you have to wait for everything.  Resturants, delis, hardware stores, bars, clubs... so it doesn't necessarily mean the place will be great.

In San Francisco, on a Wednesday night, it's usually a really good indication that the place is good.  I also happened to go with a su-chef friend while I was in town, so that kinda put me a step ahead of the pack.

We waited 30 minutes or so, but had some really good beer while we were waiting.  Drinking on an empty stomach makes any wait pleasant.  

The food... gee do you wanna know about the food?  Yeah, it's damn good.  This place is a little tiny hole in the wall with some really really fresh fish, and phenomenal sushi gurus.  If a weekday night is this busy, I would say weekends are probably impossible.  Good thing they're open late (late as in SF late, not nyc late...)

Highly recommended... this is one of those memorable places you want to go to while in the bay area.  Close to the mission, and Hayes valley, and kinda across the street from the Civic Center...
author: Sean S.

description:
The Good
Flavors are above average

The Bad
Long wait to get a seat, long wait for food. My party waited for 30 minutes to get a seat (a short wait for this restaurant, I'm told), and after 40 minutes sitting at the seat, was told that our sushi order hadn't even started. After 15 minutes of waiting, our baked mussel arrived. After asking if our order had been started, we told them not to bother making the rest of the order and we just paid and left. We did not even get an apology.

The Ugly
Don't get me wrong, I appreciate good food that takes time. But take it from me. Sushi requires a lot of time and patience in fish selection and ingredient preparation, but these all happen before the actual making of the sushi. The actual making of the sushi, while requiring great skill, does not require great time.

Avoid this place at all costs, unless you have at least 2.5 hours to spend on food here or are a hipster who thinks that 2.5 hours to wait "totally gives the place character, man". There are many many places that serve sushi of equal or greater quality with better wait times, better service, and greater selection.

You have been warned.
author: Sam W.

description:
This is absolutely the best sushi I've had in my life. I've had all different kinds since I was a kid, from traditional rice+fish to super Americanized monster-roll-with-hot-sauce-and-deep-fried-stuff to gastronomic slice-of-whitefish-with-some-pleasant-aromatic. Sushi Zone is the best. We're not talking about romance, we're talking about sushi.

This little nook opens at 5 and fills up quickly-- no reservations in advance, you have to show up and write your name on a little white board they have inside the restaurant. The restaurant literally has only enough room for two comfy tables, the sushi bar, some bar stools, and many hungry, anxious patrons.

The ambiance is not the greatest and yes, it can get crowded if you're not sitting at one of the tables, but ambiance is not the point of this restaurant. The emphasis is clearly on the sushi, which is just stupid good. Little overhead otherwise means they can charge $3-7 for outrageously delicious rolls-- simple, and so fresh people are literally delivering fish throughout the evening. The chef, Yoshi, is a freaking master, never stops working, and seems to care as much about the sushi he makes as his own breath.

Bottom lines:
1. Fresh. Ridiculous fresh.
2. Delicious. Wonderful flavor combinations.
3. Beautiful. Colors and all.
4. Cheap. And even more cheap.
5. Authentic. They even make rice the old-fashioned way and pickle their own ginger.

Great dishes:
1. Spicy salmon mango roll
2. Baked stripped bass and mango in mussel half-shells
3. Salmon skin roll
author: Jen N.

description:
Best Sushi I've Ever Had. 

Came here with my two roommates and waited and hour and 40 mins for a table. We were so starved and annoyed with the wait that all of us were skeptic any restaurant would be worth it at that point. Obviously we were wrong - our very first bite of the grilled hamachi collarbone blew our minds. And then it was all ooooo's and ahhhh's from there.  We ordered a few pieces of nigiri, the baked mussles, and a roll. The Uni Nigiri was orgasmic. It was so good that I was told not to talk as roommate #1 needed her moment of silence to take it all in. I don't blame her. I usually like to break up my sushi and eat it, but the Nigiri here deserved the true authentic experience. I stuff the whole thing in my mouth and decided it had the perfect ratio of fish to rice - even if I had to puff up my cheeks to fit the whole thing in. 

Everything was SO GOOD. And even when I became super full, I still couldn't help it but eye the rolls on everyone else's plates. I wanted to tell the chef how awesome his restaurant was but too bad he was so busy. He had a cool mustache too. 

Price came out to be very reasonable - $66 + tip for 3 people (no drinks). My goal is to come here as often as possible.
author: Nattie X.

description:
First things first: Sushi Zone is cash only. Make sure before you walk in to have enough on hand. If not, there's a Bank of America about four blocks away (I'm not kidding - the Husband had to run down there after we ordered). 

Moving on to more important matters: I am the 670th person to review Sushi Zone! So like with so many of the delightful places in SF, Sushi Zone has more reviews than it knows what to do with so why am I adding my two cents? Because I want to ensure that by adding a positive review, SZ continues its good reputation online.

It's Saturday night and the Husband and I are meeting up with an old college friend of the Husband. We decide on sushi and although Umi tends to be my go-to place, we thought it would be good to try something new. Street parking wasn't as bad as we were expecting but the line at SZ was something else. We waited about an hour for the three of us but they will serve you a drink while you wait if you'd like. So we stood right outside the door drinking our large Sapporos, feeling a little naughty. 

Once we were seated, we were pleased to find that the prices were wallet-friendly. We decided on a sea bass appetizer (it's one of their most popular appetizers - two mussel shells with baked sea bass and mango), a spicy mango salmon maki and a mango hamachi maki along with a 14 piece sashimi combo. The total came out to about $95 without tip and the three of us left quite full and happy.

The baked sea bass mussel shell was fantastic. I highly recommend it! The sashimi was fresh and the maki were homemade-tasting. I've had more polished sushi but I like the homemade presentation and flavor at Sushi Zone. 

We were kind of squashed up against a group of three guys at the bar and when you're shoulder to shoulder with a stranger, you're bound to become friendly unless you're completely anti-social. The cute old Asian man making all of the sushi was preparing something delicious-looking and I asked the guy next to me what it was that smelled so good. It was apparently his order and the chef apparently overhead me because as he handed my neighbor the plate, he also handed him a small additional plate and nodded to me. It was a small taste for me and the Husband and the Friend! How nice! It was the Chef's Special and I think it was lightly seared tuna. Yum!

The wait time was pretty intense but with the large Sapporos, we did ok. Luckily the weather wasn't too bad otherwise I think we might have left. At the end of the meal, the three of us agreed that it was worth the wait. On a Saturday night, you have to expect that a well-run place like this is going to have a wait time.
author: Christine P.

description:
I don't usually have the patience for the long wait places like this require but this is one of the few restaurants that, when I'm in the right mood, I'll totally suffer through because it's worth it!

I've been to this place about five times now and their sushi is amazing. My favorites are the Hawaiian roll with mango and the ever-so-simple-yet-so-delicious sake nigiri. Oh, and lets not forget about the baked sea bass. Everyone raves about it for a reason!

I've only been seated here immediately once, and that's because we got there about a half hour before it opened and were about third in line. A wait is hard to avoid. I've seen a few lucky people stroll in at the right time and get right in, but it's best not to assume that will happen. The last couple of times we went, we simply put our names in and then had a drink or two at a nearby bar (but make sure to check back regularly!).

The service here is a bit slow but not too bad. I can totally understand people avoiding it because of the chance of a one-and-a-half-hour wait but, if you are prepared and in the right frame of mind, I highly recommend checking it out!
author: Fanny S.

description:
I highly recommend the baked muscles. This place is soo yummy but can seat very few. 2 booths and enough room at the counter for about 4 groups of 2. 

Get there early! But you'll probably still have to wait...

Might be the best sushi I've ever had!

Only reason for 4 stars is they really do need a bigger place..
author: Tom L.

description: This was really disappointing. Mushy rice that was too warm, tamago that was too cold, makis that fall apart and just no love whatsoever put into what they serve. It's a cute place but the flavors were muddy and the presentation was dismal.
author: Dave G.

description: One thing to keep in mind, don't come hungry.  By the time you are seated, order, and served, you will be.  Unless you show up 30 minutes before they close, then maybe you can get seated right away.  One person rolling the sushi, one person serving; it's gonna be awhile.  However, some amazing sushi comes from here.  So clear your schedule and give it a chance.
author: Patrick K.

description:
Sushi was fantastic but I was definitely over the horrendously long (2hr wait...we ended up getting a drink across the street and came back...and still waited another hour)

+5 stars for the sushi which was melt-in-your-mouth delicious
-1 star for the ambience, which seemed a little aggressively voyeuristic...because everyone waiting around the awkwardly small space of the restaurant is staring at everyone eating
-1 star for the wait time....i know it's not their fault for being amazing, but honestly it's not worth it
author: Ben T.

description:
The best sushi in San Francisco. Hands down. 

Just fresh, clean, skillfully prepared, no nonsense sushi. The place has been there forever--I actually popped my sushi cherry there with a boyfriend sometime in the late 90's. The boyfriend is long gone, but Sushi Zone has remained a consistent delight. There is no reason to go anywhere else for sushi people. 

And yes, I know it's f**king crazy busy and the line for a table is outrageous, so just do yourself a favor and go on a Monday night. Ok, that's all the insider secrets I'm giving up for now.
author: Jennifer J.

description: Great fresh sushi here would love to come back unfortunate like many other popular places in sf it is very small super crowded and therefore the wait can be horrendous. I believe we waited 1.5 hrs... Ouch! It was almost worth it if we hadn't been dying of hunger. We had the muscles, sashimi, special rolls all very yummy.
author: Dang L.

description:
I get the hype. I really do... the second I walked in the place I knew it was going to un-real. The fact that jazz was playing and the smell of baking green mussels was complimented by a wise old samurai sushi warrior doing work, was an immediate sign this place was legit. Well from there we all know the story: this place sits 20 max., the wait was crazy long, a 7 top was ahead of us, my date and I drank loads of nigori... it was all good. We knew what to expect and rolled with the wait and any hiccups.. Besides we drank and ate tapas down the street for most of the wait :)

So we finally sit, order 3 things: Rainbow roll, Spicy Salmon mango roll, Hamachi scallion roll. Meanwhile the place is full and a 7 top from hell was placing orders left and right, all ahead of ours. The one sushi chef was in the weeds, mainly because the 7 top were shouting loud vulgar comments and ordering and shit ton of food left and right. This place is a victim of their success, so naturally they were not well prepared to take on all the bullshit coming with trying to turnover more numbers than they should be. Me and my date were drunk and analyzing all of this go down. So we knew not to expect great detail or attention to our food... no biggie 

Bottom line the food is bomb. Quality fish and lots of it. And guess what... its really cheap. You can actually get FULL here and not break the bank. And the sake is very well priced ;) The only reason im giving a 4 star review is because it's a mistake for them to take anything more than a 5 top. On a busy night (which for them is all night every night) it just throws a fat stick in their spokes to take parties over 5, and then the attention to detail in the food suffers (which in sushi is a big NO NO).

I WILL BE BACK FOR MORE!  KAMPAI
author: Kevin D.

description: Hands-down the freshest and best sushi I've had in SF.  Don't come here if you're looking for fancy made-up rolls.  Everything I've had on the menu is great.  You must get the baked mussels.
author: Ravi R.

description:
Yup, after avoiding this place for literally *years* because of the fabled wait, I finally checked it out myself, and I can tell you folks, it's all true. 

It's teeny, and you'll wait.  And wait.  And wait.  (Even at 8:30 on a Tuesday.)  And the fish is great, the chef and staff are friendly, the atmosphere virtually non-existent, and the prices pretty good for what you get. 

The wait is daunting, but if you're up for it, it's definitely worth it.
author: Dana S.

description:
