I really want to give this place one star - just so that fewer people know about it and there is more room for me.  

The restaurant is incredibly small and it has taken me YEARS to actually get in - I'm not patient - but I made it.  There was a line even before they opened at 5PM!  

The baked mussels have got to be one of the best things i've tasted at a sushi restaurant EVER.  The salmon melts in your mouth like butter.  The Hawaiian roll (with macadamia nuts) was a little overwhelmed by the nuts, but there is plenty more to try.  I'm so exctied...
author: Jimmie L.

description:
Overall, a great meal. Everything tasted amazing, but I think they could fix a few details to make the experience great as well. We didn't have to wait at all like others have mentioned, but I think it's because we arrived at 6:00 on a Thursday.

To start, we had the stuffed shiitake mushrooms and the stuffed jalapeños. Both use the same filling, which was this deliciously cheesy, creamy fish mixture. However, the  jalapeños hadn't been seeded correctly and I got an intense punch of heat in my last bite that was very unexpected and sort of ruined that app for me.

For sushi, we had the spicy hamachi roll, the spicy tuna roll, and the hawaiian roll. The tuna and the hamachi came first. I wouldn't necessarily use the word spicy to describe them, but they were definitely sweet and creamy. The hamachi had this subtle lime flavor that was really surprising and delicious. The rolls on the end were huge though which made them hard to eat (I hate it when sushi places do this!). The hawaiian roll came later and was this incredible mix of sweet mango, avacado, herbs, and tuna. The macadamia nuts on top gave it a great crunch.

All things considered, I think the taste made up for everything else and I would definitely visit again!
author: Saad A.

description:
No one should come here! It is crowded enough as is and goddamn it, I want it to myself! I nearly die of anticipation when I put my name on the list and swallow the fact that I will most likely be in for a 45 minute wait. Waiting this long for sushi seems preposterous, I know, but Sushi Zone is SO. WORTH. IT. 

Everyone thinks of themselves as a sushi snob, but I, like, really am for real. And so, when I say this sushi is the best in the city, you know I speak the truth.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
While I didn't really mind our 1.5 hour wait to get in here (Pisco next door has excellent drinks and happy hour until 8pm) I wasn't really blown away our meal. Yes, the sushi was fresh and the prices were great, so I'd definitely say it is an excellent value for basic sushi. 

We ordered the sashimi platter and a few rolls. The pieces on the rainbow roll were pretty big. We also ordered a couple beers and some unfiltered Sake. Didn't break the bank, but didn't melt my mind like a transcending piece of salmon nigiri should either. I'd go back if I was in the area and had 2 hours to kill before dinner.
author: Kelly R.

description: Sushi was super fresh and delicious. Definitely going back. Can't say much for the decor but who cares, at this place it's all about the food.
author: Deena L.

description: I won't lie, this is some of the freshest sushi I've ever had but I might have to disagree with some of my fellow Yelpers, I don't think I would wait the 2 hours again. Got here around 5:10 and didn't get out of the restaurant until 8:30. I might try coming before they open next time. Food is pretty orgasmic, but same as sex, who wants to stand around for 2 hours with blue balls anticipating the main course?
author: Cindy A.

description: Another five stars to add to the list. This place is perfection. A shoe-box, yes, but simple, fresh, excellent sushi. Definitely would go back.
author: Catherine C.

description: I love sushi zone. It is a tiny hole in the wall restaurant on Market street that I did not know about until I serendipitously discovered it yesterday. The chef is so talented and prepares the sushi right in front of you. All the ingredients are fresh and the sushi is pretty mindblowingly good. My favorite roll: the hawaii #2 : albacore and mango topped with macadamia nut crumbles, unique and delicious. The service is slow but the food is worth it. Out of all of the sushi options in my radius this now is at the top of my list. Thank you sushi zone.
author: Christy D.

description: This place didn't really impress me after all those great reviews.  I haven't had phenomenal sushi in SF, but I have had extraordinary sushi elsewhere and I have to rate it based on the entirety of my sushi experience, right?  First of all, there's that "wow" factor of the dynamite mussels that are baked and everyone orders them, so they are wafting below your nose while you wait 1.5 hrs for your turn.  Don't buy into that.  Our mussel shells were basically hollowed out; there aren't mussels inside, and it had mostly chopped mango, a sliver of tuna, and a ton of mayonnaise, and it's baked.  Does it make sense to you  to eat that?  I ate it like a hungry hippo because I was starving from the long wait, but... ya know.  Could've done without it.  The baked eggplant sushi, the uni, and the spicy hamachi roll with avocado and scallions were definitely winners. The main thing was the huge chunks of fresh fish/uni they put inside.  The Hawaiian #2, which had mango, hamachi (?), avocado, and chopped macadamia nuts on top was interesting but not really special or flavorful.  The service is good, it has the typical hole-in-the-wall sushi ambiance kind of like Tekka sushi, and they serve alcohol.  Dunno if I'd wait for an hour + again, but if I were able to get seated right away, I'd go back.
author: Terry K.

description:
I finally got to try out Sushi Zone the other night with two others and many reviewers got it perfect.  The wait is long and the way the restaurant operates the service suffers but the menu and food are amazing.

It's the kind of sushi place where you just can't stop yourself from ordering too much.  It might of taken a good hour and a half from showing up to getting some food in front of us but we left very happy.

Will be back just maybe not at 7 PM on a Thursday...
author: Mitch M.

description:
We came prepared to wait and so we did.  Patiently.  We really wanted to see what all the fuss was about.  And I am glad that we did because now we can cross it off our list and not waste another moment of our time waiting there again.  

It's a hole in the wall and so I won't complain too loudly about the cleanliness of the place but if you prefer to eat your raw fish in a sanitary environment, this is probably not the place for you.

The quality of the fish was OK but the HUGE chunks of sashimi were poorly cut making the eating experience less "melt-in-your-mouth" and more "chew for ages before swallowing awkwardly".  It made me feel quite ill and I had to leave most of the tuna. 

The salmon and mango rolls were average: falling apart and pretty dry and tasteless.  The king crab rolls were slightly better but still nothing to write home about.

The surprize star was the baked mussel "appetizer" that came out at the end of the meal.  it was chopped up and served baked in its shell in a very tasty sauce. 

I left very confused as to why this place has so many rave reviews.  Have these people never tasted great sushi?  Or have the crowds and the long wait produced an Emperor's New Clothes effect?
author: Amanda F.

description:
This has become one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, and so far my favorite sushi restaurant in the city.

EVERYTIME I dine here, I order the baked bass appetizer. The bass is mixed in a spicy mayo sauce over pieces of ripe mango baked in a mussel shell. The outcome is extraordinary. I'm not embarrassed to lick the remains from the shell.

The sushi is very fresh and the price is right. After circling around for street parking and a long wait (be sure to sign it on the little whiteboard), the feast is well worth it. Be sure to keep your group to 4 people or less.
author: Maybelle M.

description:
Absolutely the tiniest place I have ever dined in.. with that said, I have never been so full from sushi in my life.  Baked mussels were insanely mouth watering, it is a must every time.  You can't go wrong, take a chance and order something you wouldn't normally!

Wait staff was willing and able to make your sometimes longer than 2 hour wait OK.. Well worth it.
author: Leann B.

description:
Best "little" sushi house I've been in the city.

Great little place for small groups or a casual date.

Me and my 3 friends got 7 rolls, 2 miso soups, and the baked bass, it only came out to 60 on the tab.

All of you definitely need to get the Baked Sea Bass w/ Mango.
author: Billy L.

description:
Please don't go here, it is not worth you waiting in line sometimes over an hour.  Or at least that is that i hope as it is my favorite sushi spot in the city and maybe the best sushi i have had in a long time.

I almost rated this fine establishment with only one star as i would like to keep this a neighborhood secret, but i have a feeling at it already has over 600+ reviews, that time is fleeting.  So, i guess after a couple of years, i must share this little piece of sunshine and tasty goodness.

Tips to ensure a happy experience:
1) Expect to wait 30 min if u arrive after 6pm
2) Try the Halibut starter
3) The salmon is simply amazing
4) Ask to try the scallop without the spicy sauce

oh so mummy to say the very least
author: Jai D.

description:
Good sushi. Great value. I suggest the baked mussels.

Ridiculous line/wait. Slightly understaffed. Modern payment methods (credit/debit) not accepted.
author: Ian S.

description:
I've been here a few times, all when I was unemployed. How else are you supposed to get here before 5PM to make sure you're one of the first 10 people to avoid a long wait? (2 or 3 tables and then sushi bar seats) If you're not in the first seating, expect to be seated sometime around 6:30. Maybe longer since it takes awhile to service the customers with the minimal staff (chef, 1 waitress, and 1 grunt guy . . . mostly doing menial tasks?!? come on. get this guy making more food!).

That said, I really enjoy eating here. Always good fish and always at the sushi bar. The chef is a funny guy who likes to chat with the customers. The last time I went, my friend and I were talking about jam bands and the show we were going to see at the Warfield later that night. We were regaled with a story about when he saw Phil Lesh at the Warfield and got to go back-stage to meet the band just a couple weeks earlier.

Maybe that's why the time between ordering and receiving your food is so long? Well, that and the  fact that the other dude doesn't seem to make any food except the simplest of rolls.

Solid 4 stars. Remember. First seating or go elsewhere . . . IMO, of course! :)
author: Andrew C.

description:
This is the best Sushi place i have visit, "sushi heaven" should be the name.
Owner make the sushi in the small simple restaurant(always que and wait for at least one hour)

Spicy hamachi and tuna is now taken to a new level.

Problem is the tiny space and not so many seats and its also a problem the one guy is making the sushi.

Last visit we had to wait an hour for table and then when we where seated an hour for food.

Prices great 8 dollar for a Roll.
author: Patrik D.

description:
3 simple reasons I frequent this [45 min - 1 hour wait] venue:
 
No one glances at my direction twice for being severely underdressed [I come after the gym] unlike some other Japanese restaurants *cough* Ozumo *cough*.
 
Their Amaebi Nigiri is among the best I've ever had. It comes freshly prepared with a perfect hint of natural sweetness that coats your tastebuds like a pleasant forgotten memory. In conjunction with the requisite amount of viscosity, it makes for the most delightful treat when ingested prior to the fried shrimp head. I'd gladly devour those shrimp [brain] guts anyday.
 
Don't even get me started on the mangoes. Luscious, golden food fitting only for gods, this tropical fruit ranges high on my must-eat-on-a-daily list. Sushi Zone has masterfully integrated this natural sugar infested fruit into many of their creatively fabricated rolls. Not being a huge fan of specialty rolls [crouching tiger hidden dragon roll, hot love roll, etc] or anything other than sashimi + nigiri, I surprisingly found myself thoroughly enjoying every bite and more. Unlike the other exceedingly posh Jap eateries, their rolls aren't doused in flavored mayonnaise. If I wanted spicy mayo overpowering my overcooked  rice, flavorless slivers of raw [think stale] fish and additional unnecessary condiments, I would have went to Sushi Bistro or another similar trendy "sushi" joint.
 
In a nutshell, Sushi Zone = no thrills, zero frills, just good sushi.
author: Lisa W.

description:
"Get in the Zone..... Sushi Zone!"

We waited about an hour and half to be seated. Based on what I hear and what I've seen regardless of when you go there will always be a wait. It's worth it.

Here's what we ordered:

Baked Sea Bass- a hit. Baked with Mangoes and cream sauce that wasn't too heavy or too salty.
Papaya Unagi- I'm a huge fan of eel, so I thought this would be my favorite, but either the taste of the unagi over powered the papaya or vice versa. I could taste the unagi, but something about the flavor combinations canceled each other out.
Hamachi Roll- Standard, but fresh fresh fish.
Hawaiian Roll (think that's what it's called. I don't remember and they don't have the menu online)- albacore tuna, mango, scallions, macadamia nuts. The best roll that we picked! The ingredients make it seem like an unlikely good combination, but the roll itself was delish. 

I like how they serve their patrons. They bring out each item ordered one at a time. Good because I feel that it gives diners time to enjoy the tastes of each dish/roll. They really are putting you in the "sushi zone" aren't they? Har har.

I should start a good things are worth the wait list. In honor of Sushi Zone, I think I will.
author: Geralyn Y.

description: Delicious sushi, great service, awesome tunes and cozy interior. Go for the baked mussels, salmon sashimi and spicy hamachi roll. Doesn't get much better than this.
author: J. A.

description:
i will make my review short and straight to the point since i go here all the time. 
this place never disappoints me for the quality for the sushi, and hands down, one of the good sushi in the city. yes, the wait sucks but i think it's worth the wait. price is reasonable for quality, what gets better than that?? compared to other cheap to overpriced sushi, this place, can't go wrong and can't compare to those that taste like crap. if you think their sushi is ok, there is something wrong with your tastebuds.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
show up at 4:45pm.  Fat Koreans show up at 4:38pm.   SZ opens @ 5pm and accommodates 8  at the sushi bar; 2  table tops that can seat 4 each.  If you are later than 4:45pm, you will wait an hour at the very least. 

A harmonious blend of hot tea, a few choices of good sake, and fantastically fresh fish.  There is one sushi chef working along side 1-2 assistants...no speaking...just smooth movements....almost like ninjas but they don't cut you.  

The mussel with mango...oh my God. 
The Himachi is the size of my ear.  I have big ears.
The rolls that use macadamia nuts...amazing
The prices?  Well, lets just say...you can pay with cash cause it is affordable.  NOT SF affordable, but like North Carolina affordable.  

My favorite SF sushi joint.  Period.  I can leave SF knowing that the entire city isn't about 50 dollar rotisserie chicken, 9 dollar scones, and 7 dollar coffee.   If i could afford it, I would eat this every day, die of mercury poisoning and pass away smiling.  The food is creative, generous, and well priced.  

5 stars cause if you don't try this...you will probably live your life thinking, "What if".
author: Sam K.

description:
NOTE: Either you come right when it opens or otherwise you will have to wait for at least 30 minutes! This place gets hella packed really fast! I waited  for like 30 minutes here even though i came only 20 minutes since the place opened. The place is really small, making the place really crowded. 
HOWEVER, 
-the sushi is really great!
-I had the sake, saba, inari, toro, ikura and Uni sushi, all of them are hella good! except the ikura sushi.....it tasted pretty weird. But overall i really like this place. The owners are a Japanese family and i think its really cute that they work together operating the business.
author: Cavin T.

description: It is tiny, uncomfortable, noisy and the service is non-existent, but after a few beers, you get into the zone and feel the rhythm of the hustle and bustle. In a way, sitting in sushi zone is pure performance art. The sushi is fresh and delish which helps. This is a great place for a 1st date because if it isn't going well, there's lots of other conversations to tune into. On the other hand,if it is going great, you don't mind raising your voice to be heard. Welcome to the Sushi Zone.....
author: S. G.

description:
It seemed like we would never please the mother with our celebratory dining choices. Year after year of birthday or Mother's Day dinners, it's usually a complaint or if it's pretty good - "Meh, it was only okay." 

This year, we took her to Sushi Zone. We ordered the baked bass, stuffed mushrooms, two orders of the 14-pc sashimi platter [thick generous slices of deliciousness], a spider roll, a King California roll [none of that imitation crap!], a sushi platter, and two large hot sakes. 

She thanked us for dinner, and that was that. I guess we finally picked a winner! 

*noted*

Cash only! Since they use REAL crab meat, you can order a California roll here without me pointing and laughing at you!
author: Tinna H.

description:
Gosh, this was so worth the wait!

Me and a friend went there on a Tuesday evening (around 8 pm). Waited for about an hour to get a table. No biggie, and was expected.

Very cozy place with a nice atmosphere.

The food was outstanding, some of the best sushi I've ever had to be honest! Amazing value. The service was really good as well. 

Highly recommended.
author: Joel C.

description:
This place is worth every minute of the wait! We ended up waiting 1 1/2 hours, which, looking at past reviews seems standard. But, I will recommend checking out the great bars in the area for a before-dinner cocktail, and the wait goes by fast. The service itself was also amazing. The waitress was extremely attentive despite the fact that she was the only one serving. 

As for the food: this was the best sushi I have ever had. We had a little bit of everything from the menu, and I didn't find myself being disappointed with a thing. Their soft shell crab was to die for. Yum!
author: Emily F.

description: We arrived, a party of two.  To be greeted with a board which you are to put your name down to wait for others to part.  So we did.  Then, a booth (one of two total) opened up and the hostess put the party of 3 in the booth which they arrived after us.  She offered no apology, or no explanation, not even a drink while we waited which I would have gladly paid for!  So, we waited some more, patiently, then we realized the note on the door said "No credit cards"  Well, that was the straw that broke my wallet.  So, we left.  Having not had the sushi, which did look good, but please.  SF Sushi world, dont pull your elitist cr@p here.  There are options a dime a dozen and we went to another and fully enjoyed as they received over a $100 from my wallet.  Thanks.
author: Nate B.

description:
It's no secret. The way to this girl's heart is raw seafood. It's also the way to my mom's heart too, so we came here to celebrate her bday.

To beat the rush, we arrived at 5:30PM for an earlier dinner, and it worked! We immediately scored one of the booth tables (seats max 5 or 6 if you all squeeze in real tight). The sushi bar seating is better for individuals or groups of 2-3. If you find yourself waiting, you can always order drinks to kill time.

Between 5 people, we ordered the baked bass, stuffed mushrooms, 2  orders of the 14 piece sashimi, a spider roll, a king california roll, a sashimi combination, and 2 large hot sakes. If you're not a raw seafood fan, you can find rolls or appetizers. There are no udon/soba/ramen or non-seafood items otherwise. It came to about $32 per person. 

The 14 piece sashimi was heavenly. *Le sigh* They were huge, fresh morsels of deliciousness. Usually, I'm not a fan of regular Tuna sashimi, but it was really good compared to other places I've tried before. They definitely don't skimp on the portions, so you feel okay about dropping almost $30 for the sashimi. 

The only drag was the wait between our appetizers and getting all the sashimi and rolls. There's one guy behind the counter, so a wait is expected. They also ran out of the specials really fast. I really wanted to try the Hamachi Kama (cheek) or the Salmon Kama. It was a little disappointing. Next time, hopefully, they will have Uni too. They were out and were waiting for a delivery that evening. I guess we got there a little too early. If we had gotten there later, it would've been super fresh too *SUPER SAD LOWER LIP POUT*. Oh, and that Scallop nigiri looks AMAZING. Putting that on my list as well. 4.5 stars till I get to try the Uni though! Until next time!!!!!
author: Donna H.

description:
Were there sushi bars in the USSR?  I have no idea.  But I think they would have been (were?) like Sushi Zone.

First, the costs would be low like they are at Sushi Zone.  Soviet sushi would be inexpensive because the government would subsidize the production of fish and rice.  I have no idea why Sushi Zone is inexpensive; it just is inexpensive.

Second, the wait would be long.  Like being in a bread line.  And that was what the wait at Sushi Zone is like.

Aside from that, Sushi Zone slings stunningly unmemorable versions of sushi bar favorites.
author: Suo L.

description:
The sushi here is so fresh! And cheap!

Spicy Hamachi, Hawaiian #2, and Baked Mussel, all excellent.
author: Barbie L.

description:
I've been here twice, and it is worth the wait. Do note that it is cash only. Most recently, I got the Hawaiian roll #2, the hamachi roll, bass nigiri and albacore nigiri. I'd get them all again though maybe just a second Hawaiian roll instead of the hamachi roll.

Great, small sushi spot.
author: C S.

description:
Authentic sushi restaurant.
Reasonably priced. 

I'd take my friends or family here, then you know how much I love the sushi here. 

Recommendation:
Hawaiian roll #2 
Spicy hamachi roll 
Mango hamachi roll
Baked sea mussel 
Baked sea bass
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Quick Tips:
- Baked Sea Bass appetizer, spicy hamachi roll, hawaiian #2 roll
- Wait is extremely long - for dinner expect at least an hour wait - you can't call beforehand, so instead you go to the restaurant, have the waitress put your name down on the whiteboard, and leave for an hour to do something else, then come back
- CASH ONLY 

A sushi bar with over 500 reviews and 4.5 stars in SF - there's no way anything could stop me from coming here, including a 2.5 hour wait. Yes, don't come in at 8pm on a Friday night.

Sat around waiting for a seat for what ended up being 2 and a half hours. Was the wait worth it? At that point, nothing is worth it, but if I could do it again, I would.

The wait gave me plenty of time to learn the finesse and art of making sushi (watching a single person making sushi for the whole restaurant - a management consultant's nightmare) and browse the various yelp reviews for food recommendations.

Once seated at 10:30pm, ordered the following for 2 people, which was perfectly sufficient for 2 people:

1. Baked Muscles with Spicy Mayo - nothing super special, the muscles were a bit chewy (maybe they over-cooked mine). I would get the Striped Bass over this one.

2. Striped Bass Mango in Mussel Shell - this was my favorite, REALLY REALLY good. You get the soft warm fresh sweet mango lining the inside of the shell and a warm baked sea bass with the consistency of warm pudding filling the rest of the cavity. The combination? Heavenly.  

3. Spicy Hamachi - amazingly fresh fish paired with amazingly soft avocado, just almost melts in your mouth

4. Hawaiian #2 - the ingredients, combinations, and executions are just impeccable. 

My only complaint, is just how incredibly inefficient and non-business savvy the restaurant is. You have the place seating about 16-20 people with only one guy making the sushi. if that's not frustrating enough, the people at their seats love to take their time and order a second round, a third round, or simply just sit in their seats sipping Japanese beer as other customers are crossing the 2 hour mark on their wait time. it's just a tremendous inefficiency that could really be changed for the benefit of the restaurant's profit and reputation and the customers. 

However, I will say that once sitting down at the sushi bar and the lone sushi maker hand delivered my sushi plate with a smile and a wink, all that frustration went away. That and also you really know that you're getting the consistency of food quality every time you go to this restaurant. I just can't imagine if this guy ever gets sick - hopefully he has trained a few others to deliver the type of quality sushi that he does.

Overall, the sushi was the best I ever had (6 out of 5 stars) which balances out the inefficiency piece (4 out of 5 stars). The best number to go is 2 people, and definitely no more than 4 or 5. Once you get there, expect to put your name on the list and go somewhere else nearby for an hour or so and coming back.
author: Derrick P.

description: My old favorite place to eat sushi.  Outside of Japan this is my favorite place.  We have to get back to Tokyo to do a sushi run soon! Al is kickass with the Unagi and people here are just friendly and nice.  Plus they have a perfect score from the Health Department.  This place is great.
author: Jim J.

description:
This place has really creative sushi and is definitely a really solid place, but be prepared to wait if you show up at 7. And I mean wait 2 hours!! I mean the sushi is great browse I don't know about waiting 2 hours. Next time I will go at 5pm or 9 pm. 
My recs for this spot at the sushi zone roll. Everything with lime and/or jalepeno is delicious. The flavor combos are awesome.
author: Komal B.

description:
Wait time: 1 hour. yes, it's a long wait, learn the master of zen if you want to eat here.
Restaurant capacity: 20
Restaurant location: hard to find, in the boon docks, definitely a neighborhood gem.
Ambiance: no frills sushi bar with a counter and 2 tables for guests. The kitchen is right there next to the sushi bar.
Authenticity: genuine Japanese chef preparing the rolls right in front of you. menu is relatively no frills but also has some unique Hawaiian influenced rolls.

Everything we ate was pretty delicious from the jalapeno stuffed tuna to the fresh pieces of yellowtail, salmon, and tuna. The albacore and salmon were definitely buttery and melt in your melt. The cuts were generous and tasted very fresh.  The rolls were the perfect size and the macadamia crusted Hawaiian roll had the perfect amount of crunch!

I don't know if we would want to wait so long again just to eat sushi but it was definitely fresh and deelish.
author: Betty C.

description: Long wait. Hardly any space. But all that doesn't matter because this is delicious. A strong feel of authenticity as the Japanese sushi chef carefully slices fish, avocado, mango, melons, etc. with a wickedly sharp cleaver, effortlessly. Dry Japanese beer adds to the authentic taste palate built at this restaurant.
author: Shan S.

description:
MUST EAT. I nearly died when I ate the sea bass because it was just that good. Their rolls are creative, but not in an overly done or overly sauced way. You can still taste the freshness of the fish. We ordered: 2 orders baked sea bass, hawaiian roll 2, hamachi mango roll, spicy tuna roll, ikura nigiri, and salmon kama. All of this came out to $48, which is quite a bargain for everything we got! 

We waited about and hour and a half to eat here, but took Muni around SF and did other things during the wait. You can just tell that the sushi chef enjoys what he does. The staff was excellent; although there was a wait, we never felt the need to eat faster nor did we feel rushed by the staff.
author: Ruth R.

description:
Years of impeccable sushi! It's cheap, and tasty, and oh so good. I dream about the Spicy Hamachi roll. Damn, I'm drooling now just thinking about it.

Note:  Get there early or arrive with patience. Its small and everyone wants to eat there. And if you are waiting for a spot, don't sit in the corner glaring at people eating. It's rude. Know you have to wait your turn or go somewhere else :-)
author: Natty C.

description:
This place is sooo good. The rolls are stuffed with big pieces of fresh fish and the baked sea bass with mango is amazing. The prices are surprisingly low for the quality of the food. There was only one waitress/hostess, but she was really friendly and definitely on top of things considering how busy she was. 

The only downside to this place is that it's super small. We were lucky that we only waited 20-25 min for two seats at the sushi bar, but some people that came in right behind us waited an hour and a half to get sat. You'd better be willing to wait. And when you do get seats, you'll have to ignore the jealous and hungry stares from everyone on the waiting list that are standing around the tiny room.
author: Kristin D.

description:
The sushi was very fresh. Yes, I too am now a fan of Hawaiian roll #2 and I don't usually like mango! This mango was sweet and the flavors go together so well and the subtle salty, sweet crunch of the macadamia nuts is unexpected. Delicious!
The sashimi were the strangest cuts- the maguro was cut so thick and the sake sashimi was also cut thick and long-never had sashimi like that and actually prefer a more traditional cut but it was oh so fresh! Didn't care for the flavor of the miso soup- tasted a little smoky. The spicy tuna rolls were phenomenal- the spicy mayo on it was one of the best I've had.
We went on a Wed around 6:30pm and waited about 30ish minutes. I notices the wait list got pretty long by about 7pm.
Love this sushi! It's definitely worth a 30+min wait, however I don't know that I would wait an hour or more. Hope people who come here all have the courtesy for each other and the restaurant and not "hang out" after they are done eating at this tiny joint.
author: Piper W.

description:
I 'll have to agree with the early review of Hank J. 

I have not tried the mixed rolls, maybe they are good .
I like the traditional raw fish , the basic simple sashimi well prepared and cut by a professional chef, that's what I go to sushi spots for.

Maybe it was the off night ,maybe I am bias because I am Japanese and used to good quality sushi (Try Ino sushi for instance or Sushi Time for slightly cheaper much better quality served by pro sushi chef- ) but this is by far the worst sashimi I had in San Francisco . 

Please take a look at the counter , where the chef stores the fish and you'll know how the sushi will taste , is gonna taste just as it looks like there.
author: Tam T.

description:
The best sushi I have ever had! 

I know this is quite a statement, but it is the truth. Not only is the fish extremely fresh, but the appetizers and rolls are very unique. Not to mention the owner is a great, friendly guy. 

My favorites:

Spicy Salmon with Mango 
Spicy Tuna
Stuffed Shiitake with Salmon
Stuffed Jalapeno with Albacore
Hawaiian #2 (tuna with mango and macadamia nuts)

They don't have any deep fried rolls, so if that is your thing this place might not be for you.

Warnings:

Sushi Zone is VERY popular and VERY small so the wait can be VERY long.  It is first come first serve so make sure to get there early or plan on waiting for over an hour sometimes two....

There are only two tables that seat 4 comfortably.  So not good for groups over 4 people. 

They are cash only, but there is a ATM (high fee) around the corner if need be.
author: Karen M.

description:
My #1 favorite food in SF.

Someone once wrote a review saying this is the perfect place to go on a first date - you'll find out if the person has patience and if they can appreciate truly amazing sushi.

You can always go at 5:00 before they open and wait to be the first, but thats always off my dinner schedule. Here's what i do:

My secrets to enjoying waiting for sushi zone:
1. Go by 7:30pm signup and gauge the wait - if it's full, and there are more than 4 names in front of you, perfect, you've got time, especially if you're waiting for a 4-person table!

2. You've got an hour, go to Martunis at Valencia and market, or up the street to the Orbit room or more fun, Kareoke @ The Mint! (but don't eat their sushi!)

3. come back to sushi zone a little buzzed and if your name was called, thats Ok, they'll put you up next if you're reeeeally nice. 

4. Enjoy some Saki while you wait, maybe put in your hot-order if they'll let you! =)

5. THE ORDER! (expect to wait anxiously for 30-40 minutes more)
- Hamachi kama & the muscles are a hot dish, usually served faster than the sushi itself. The kama is a perfect appetizer, flakey soft meat with a sweet tangy teriyaki sauce.
- Hawaiian #2 roll, albacore nigiri. Their albacore is the best!
- Spicy tuna or any eel dish my usual.

6. Offer the chef a cup of your saki! At the pace he's going, he needs it!

7. The bill - always $30-40 less what i would end up paying anywhere else for half the quality. Can not be beat!

ARIGATOU!!!
author: Pierre V.

description: Long wait, tiny venue, mediocre veggie options, CHEAP
author: Jamel I.

description:
We went to Sushi Zone on a Friday afternoon around 5. We were first on the waiting list and waited about 45 minutes. It was worth it. I'll never forget the first time I tried one of their baked mussels. It is something that will be with me for a long, long time. The rolls are well-priced at $6 for the amount of food that you get. I recommend the ones with macadamia nuts on them...amazing. We ordered way too much food, but didn't overpay really. The same meal at Zushi Puzzle would have been $100 where we spent around $65 at Sushi Zone. 

This is definitely one of those places that makes San Francisco special.
author: Jonathan G.

description: My favorite sushi place in SF. Their fish is always fresh. Definitely try their appetizers. Their baked seabass, baked mussels and hamachi kama are to die for.
author: Helen L.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city for sushi. Just amazing, no frills, fresh fish. The only downside is the size of the restaurant but I think that adds to its charm. If you don't want to wait, either come really early (5-530pm) or really late (9-930pm).

Recommendations:
-Baked mango sea bass: rich, creamy, melt-in-your-mouth goodness. Get this
-Hawaiian #2: albacore, mango, macadamia nuts (don't be turned off...it's good)
-Spicy Hamachi: a staple and must-try
-Yellowtail & Scallion
-Salmon sushi

Prices: 
On the cheaper side which is awesome. Not a ton of cheap sushi places that is also backed by quality.

Atmosphere/Service:
Friendly staff, only about 2 sushi chefs are outside at a time. Don't wear anything you don't want smelling like fried food

I have nothing bad to say about Sushi Zone..just that the negative reviews are all BS ;)
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Brilliant little place. My friend and I loved the Sushi and Sake. Yellowtail sushi just melted in my mouth.
author: Balu V.

description:
Get there early. Unless you're ok with waiting an hour at least for 2 people. 

Recos:
Hawaiian #1
sake nigiri
Everything hamachi
Baked muscle
papaya and eel roll
author: Thomas W.

description:
Food = 5+ stars
Service = 3 stars

I got some Miso Soup (could have been a bit hotter), and drank it.  Yup, no spoons here, folks.

The Hawaiian Roll #1. SO. DELICIOUS.  Perfect amount of soft sushi with a powerful tuna taste mixed with the nutty, salty top.  OMG.

Spicy Tuna was just so fresh and delicious...best I ever had.

Make sure when you go here, you wait around instead of going someplace else and getting drinks to pass the time.  Because you might have to wait over 1.5 hours to get seated (with a group of 4) rather than 45 minutes.  Just saying.
author: Emily G.

description:
Not sure what the hype was...

Wait was long, fish was decent, rolls were a bit intimidating due to their size, and it's cash only.  This place is small and service overwhelmed.  "Hole in the wall" describes it perfectly.
author: MTBer I.

description: So when people say some restaurants are small...this place takes the cake.  Bar seating, for about 6, and then 2 tables.  But it's okay cause the food and fish quality here is GREAT.  The fish was very good quality - I can never get good hamachi any where these days.  Noticed alot of people having the baked mussels so it must be good.  Amaebi was delicious here too.  If you're looking for crazy rolls this is not your place.  This place has pretty simple rolls.
author: Christine N.

description:
It was like 10pm and we still had to wait for 45 mins to sit down.  There is really just one sushi chef, and he does each order/table one by one. So we had to wait at least another 45 mins before we had our first dish. Its not like the chef was busting his ass either, he was fussing over the music, drinking some sake in between, etc.

The fish was definitely fresh and the sushi was delicious.  I am not a big fan of rolls in the first place, however they were pretty cheap here.  The selection of fish was also limited. 

Although the fish was good, I still can't justify for the long wait.
author: Ling Ling Z.

description: Sushi Zone -- in its tiny lil space -- lives up to the hype and then some, and there's a lot of hype we're talking about here. It's really darn good. Sure, we waited about 30 minutes and you shouldn't go with a party bigger than 2, but everything -- from the fish to the macademia nuts -- we ordered was fresh and perfect. The waitress was hella nice - we didn't feel rushed, food came out in a nice flow, lots of tea refills. The baked mussels and sea bass were savory, tasty, and just MMM. Then, the sake nigiri - was pure buttery bliss. You've gotta go!
author: Andrew K.

description:
The sushi was AMAZING. Great prices, fresh fish, the whole shebang. I came with two other people, and between the three of us, we seem to have tried pretty much everything on the menu, from the Asahi Japanese beer to the sake, and the spicy hamachi to the unagi and papaya (the mango and avocado rolls were a ridiculously awesome combination, and probably my favorite). 

The only thing that we didn't like was that this is one of those holes in the wall that was probably ruined by Yelp. Wait time was two hours... just to be seated, and another hour to be served. This is because this place is a closet, with two four-person booths and eight seats at the bar. Also, I'm not sure if this is every night, but only one guy made the sushi rolls; there were two guys working on the appetizers, but this place has definitely gotten too big for its current location. To be fair, we were warned by the several hundred reviews that the wait would be long, we just thought a two hour wait was an exaggeration. It's not folks.
author: Gloria J.

description:
This place is the best sushi I have ever had in the Bay Area. I've been twice now. The fish is so fresh and tasty. It seems to just melt in my mouth. I have tried all the rolls and the baked mussel appetizer. They are all very delicious, however, I didn't really care for the Hawaiian rolls with the macadamia nuts aren't that great because they don't go well together.

I wish this place were open more often rather than the Mon-Sat 5-10..

Love it!
author: Kevin H.

description:
No reservations. 1-2 hour long wait but it is worth it.  Like any restaurant, you have to order properly.  Here are the stars at Sushi Zone:

-striped bass mango
-seaweed salad
-jalapeño albacore
-stuffed shitake
-spicy hamachi
-spicy mango
-Hawaiian #2
-spider roll

The sushi and cooked appetizers are fresh, inventive and worth every minute of the wait.  This is a small place with 8 seats at the bar and two tabletops for groups of 4.  

No tempura, no noodles.  But the best hole in the wall sushi place in SF.
author: Thomas J.

description: pretty good food and options , and i am a sushi lover ! If you can get over the fact that they are located AND connected by a swinging door to the karaoke club then you'll be fine lol
author: Ashana D.

description:
Fantastic fantastic sushi. Nothing like the stuff I've tasted along the east coast.

I recommend everything others recommended:
Hawaiian roll #1
Hawaiian roll #1
Spicy Hamachi
Spicy Tuna
Baked mussels
Baked bass. 

+ try the amaebi nigiri if they have it. They fry the head for you and it is delciousness. 

The use of mango here is amazing. Boyfriend and I were in San Fran for a week and this was the only restaurant we went to TWICE. 

Price is right. We were out for 60 bucks max with 2 bottles of beer. The place has limited seating and does get crowded fast, but luckily we were always seated without much wait.  

The ambience is really authentic and it's quite a cozy place. There seems to be a couple of regulars and there's a friendly atmosphere. It seems to be quite the date spot for San Fran, so expect many couples. 

It opens at 5pm, so come close around that time. It will be so worth it.
author: Victoria A.

description:
I'm a sushi snob. This place was DELICIOUS.

Get the baked bass, I promise you won't regret it. We got the Hawaiian Roll #2, Artichoke avocado and sprouts roll, mango and avocado roll, and seaweed salad. I recommend them ALL (seaweed salad is hard to mess up, but still).

We did have to wait about 20 minutes for spots for 2 people, because it's a tiny place, but it was totally worth it. The food came out about 5-8 minutes after we ordered, the waitress was very sweet.

The restaurant is CASH ONLY, come prepared!
author: Brittany B.

description:
It smells like japan, it feels like japan, if the sushi didnt have mango and macadamias in it and was in japan, it would be japan.....

I love Sushi Zone.  It IS EXPENSIVE but the food makes me smile and makes my ladycakes smile which is all you really want from food.

The Mango whatever is a perfect complement to the salmon it is paired with and the macadamia maki is to die for.

The staff are so friendly and make you feel at home....

Let's Sushi Zone!
author: Nathan H.

description: I come here once a month with my smoking hot girlfriend. We love this place. The freshest, tastiest nicest preparations of fish in town. OH, and don't forget to get the baked bass app. IT IS THE MOST ORIGINAL AND AMAGING thing you will have at a sushi place. OH, and don't forget the KAMA. Hamachi or Salmon. I mean, jeeeez louise. I want some now. GO GET IT. Wait is worth it, and yes, there is usually a wait as this place is pinner. Who cares. Go drink Pisco drinks around the corner, and wait. You will not regret it.
author: F.f. Durst D.

description: We were seated in less than a half hour, which I was grateful for, but then it took well over an hour and a half between the time we got seated and the time we got anything to eat. I was so hungry I ate all the pickled ginger, because that's all there was available. I watched the chef make everybody's entire meal, piece by piece, before going on the the next person. Why not make some sushi for each person, so nobody sits there starving? At least a few appetizers or some edamame would have kept me from wanting to gnaw on the table, or steal fish off the plate of the woman next to me. When the food finally came, it was delicious, but I won't be going back.
author: Asha V.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had in SF so far. They do some great combinations, like eel and papaya, that are fresh and amazing. 
The line is always long since it's a small place, so get ready to have a few drinks while to wait for a seat.
author: Ariana L.

description:
Sushi Zone is more than a meal.  It's a dining experience.
Over the course of two hours, you will imbibe many Sapporos, discover how rolls taste with nuts in them (Hawaiian).  You will learn that the chef's name is Al, and that he loves to play the drums.
You will wonder about the Cuban music, but only until you meet Al.

I really liked this place.  Tiny, cozy, intimate.  Don't go if you're in a rush.
author: dan s.

description: Here for a conference and took a group here. NOT the place for that. Teeny tiny with two tables. We didn't get to stay unfortunately.
author: Heather D.

description:
Yes at 5:45 PM we snagged 2 out of the last 4 seats in the place on a Wednesday. 

Yes from start to beginning it was like and hour and a half (so yeah the wait will be long).

Yes, I can't wait to go back. 

The salmon sashimi was sooo fresh and unlike any other I've tasted. 

Get the baked mussels, get the baked bass. Hamachi cheek was great. 

The chef took great care with everything he was preparing and it all looked great, so I'm excited to go back and check out other items.
author: Nikke G.

description:
This is the best sushi I've ever had in my life. Seriously. I refuse to go anywhere else for sushi because it just doesn't compete. The regular hostess/ server is so sweet and accommodating, she will say "sorrysorrysorry" just for reaching to fill your water glass. 

I come here once a week, maybe twice if I'm lucky. Don't listen to the grouches who deducted points for the wait!! It is worth it, and you need to strategize--put your name on the list and go have a cocktail at the amazing Orbit Room 1 block up on Market. 

Some things on the menu may be a little better than others.
This is what we get (and you should get too)

Baked mussels
Hawaiian roll #2
Spicy hamachi roll
Spicy mango salmon
tataki albacore
unagi 
sake sashimi
author: Diane D.

description:
I guess either during the bottomless bloody mary brunch at Paul K or directly after I said something to Daniel L about how I'd heard from a couple of people that consider themselves sushi experts that this place was great. I don't remember this conversation, bottomless bloody marys have their consequences, but when I got a PM from Daniel a few days after it didn't matter that I forgot because I'd wanted to try this place for months.

Daniel got Maybeline C to come and she brought her friend Wendy. This place is tiny and popular, we were seated quickly but it wasn't long before the place got crowded with people staring at us like vultures.

I ordered the plum wine. Not because it's good but because I wanted to drink something, I hate sake and beer mixed with rice in my stomach is a gas factory.

I picked the place based on recommendations and even suggested some of the items because I'd heard good things about them but didn't like any of it, everyone has different tastes but all of the items we ordered based on recommendations were mediocre at best. I'd be a little more tactful and think maybe it's just my taste but all four of us had almost the same opinion of each item.

Appetizers

Stuffed Jalapeno: A half pepper stuffed with some kind of tuna concoction, it tasted like tuna salad made with canned Geisha.

Baked bass and mango in a mussel shell: I didn't like it; I didn't think the flavors complimented each other at all.

Roll

Hawaiian roll #2: Another overly quirky item. A roll with fish mango and avocado covered in macadamia nuts. 

By this time I was sick of off the wall sushi like items and was ready for some nigiri. Sorry to my friend that made these suggestions if you read this but everything you recommended bombed with the group.

Assorted Nigiri: The salmon was the best and everyone loved it! The albacore and the hamachi were pretty good. The maguro was a little rubbery but OK. It was cut against the grain which is fairly common. The hirame had turned and shouldn't have been served. It smelled off but I wanted to trust the chef and ate it anyway. It was very fishy and even tingled a little on the tongue. Wendy had to spit hers out.

I expected "the best sushi place in SF" to care a little more.

Other things that are a little troubling:

The table was sticky, the place has no décor, the people waiting to eat are all right they're staring at you to hurry up and finish, and it's cash only. Also for some reason they brought everything out one item at a time, which I wouldn't care about except, they didn't bring the nigiri out in the right order (light to dark).

I'm willing to try this place again but I want to sit at the bar and I'm only getting nigiri or sashimi.
author: Manny F.

description:
Come early or be prepared to wait as this place is super small. Their menu is not particularly large and they are known for a few of their more popular items such as the mango hamachi roll. If you're into that sort of thing (fusion sushi) then you might like it. It was just "meh" since I'm not a big fan of having any sort of fruits in my dinner or the sweet and savory combination. 
We started out with mussels on half shells. I forgot the exact name but we ordered two, one had mango in it and the other didn't. You can probably guess which one I preferred. Beware that one order only comes with two pieces which is a bit pricey. 
We also ordered the spicy tuna roll, spider roll, and the tekka roll. They were all pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary. 
Prices are slightly lower than elsewhere but due to the inconvenience of the long wait and difficult parking around the area I most likely will not be returning when there are similar to better places for sushi closer to home. A few of us in our party of 4 left with a half filled stomach.
author: Bunnie L.

description:
Superb!!  Super fun night with TOMO.  Great fish, great staff,  I lived in rural Japan for three years, so I think I have a decent conceptualization surrounding "fresh fish."

Sushi Zone had it.  Yum.

Hamachi kama anyone??
author: Stirling E.

description:
Could go on for years about this place, but I will make it short and sweet...

Before Sushi Zone there was only 1 place (in NYC) that I thought had amazing sushi...now there is 2.

Don't mind the wait and don't mind the small space.  Love everything about the service and sushi!!!  Love that it's not fancy and just down right good!!!  

So...generous portions, great price, good quality and friendly staff equals 5 stars!!!  

Can't wait to go there next week!! And the week after...and the week after that...and
author: Jessica P.

description:
Okay, I don't know what is going on... but everywhere on this restaurant's review I see the Happy Hour deal.  The pictures posted all have the menu saying Happy Hour everyday and 5-10PM... which I thought was odd... so i decided to make a call... the lady picked up and I asked nicely saying that I saw online that you guys have a Happy Hour.  She said that they have never had any Happy Hour... Umm okay thanks...I even double checked which restaurant I called.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=ENmzrVbHhIYt1wqKbLimUQ

Either the posts and pictures are COMPLETELY WRONG ... or she is... either way.. I find this to be really lame and unhelpful.  Luckily I was smart enough to call and check up on their status.  Thanks goodness I didn't waste the time to drive there and find out that it was all a let down.

Luckily there are more possibilities online and I am checking into it to find a decent sushi Happy Hour.  Just went to Sushi Ran last night, but my sister wants Happy Hour before Jardiniere tonight.  O=P Hey I am a serious foodie and this was just a waste of my time!
author: Kat L.

description:
Came to Sushi Zone on a Thursday evening with my friend Wendy and fellow yelpers Daniel L. and Tom R.  Luckily we got to the restaurant early enough to beat the crowd-word has it...the wait can be VERY long. 

Good prices at Sushi Zone with rolls ranging around $6.  Our order consisted of:

*Stuffed Jalapenos-no good.  This was an opened jalapeno that cradled some sort of mixture that tasted like tuna salad to me.
*Baked Bass-I expected something different.  Served on a shell with mangos.  I didn't see what the hype was about this one.
*Hawaiian Roll #2-this was ok.  But it's one of those rolls where you have so much going on...the fish is no longer the star of the show
*Assorted Nigiri-I felt better about this.  For the most part, fish was fresh and clean (except for one).  My favorite was the hamachi and salmon.  

Overall, Sushi Zone is not the best sushi I have had, but the prices are real good here.  If I ever come back to Sushi Zone, it will only be for nigiri or sashimi.  I will come early because I do not believe a 2 hour wait is worth it.  I will bring cash because that's all they take.  I will avoid most of the things on the front page of the menu.
author: Maybelline C.

description:
Wowza I am immmmmmpressed with Sushi Zone. This is probably the best sushi experience I've had to date. 

If you get nothing else here you MUST try the baked mango sea bass! It was unbelievable, simply divine. We started out ordering some standard stuff but the waitress put us in check ASAP and suggested a bunch of their signature items which is how we settled on the sea bass to start. 

We also ordered the papaya and eel roll which was ridiculously good. I loved the combination of the sweet and salty. It was a real treat. 

This place is incredibly compact and seats next to nobody. We didn't have to wait too long but from what I hear that's atypical. I would be prepared to wait but trust me when I say you won't be disappointed that you did.
author: Julia N.

description:
This place rocks, I think this has become my favorite sushi restaurant in the Castro/Mission/Noe Valley/Hayes Valley area

The Salmon was super fresh and I just wanted more. Their prices were affordable
author: Eric A.

description: This place is fucking awesome the food is good. the prices they're not too bad, and the place is very cozy.
author: Tony B.

description:
Absolutely amazing.  My fellow yelpers were spot on for their reviews on this place.

You MUST get the baked mussels.  I'm usually not a a fan of them, but they're chopped up and baked beneath some kind of amazing secret sauce.  I also got every single type of nigiri you can get here.  The hamachi was incredible...best I've tasted in a long time.  We ordered all the nigiri and the spicy scallop roll (which wasn't too spicy).  I will definitely be coming back again!  I love the up close and personal seats right next to the sushi bar.  This place is super duper small and popular, so get here early to write your name down on this list! 

A heads up- Cash only, a long wait sometimes, not good for large groups...but totally worth it.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
I FINALLY made it here after three years of wanting to come.  In the past, the wait has been brutal. But today, we found ourselves free around 7pm and there were only three names ahead of us.  

After about 20 min, we were seated at one of the two booths. and then the fun started...

What we had:
- Baked mussels - as good as advertised!  My favorite dish. Little chunks of mussel with spicy mayo sauce served on a half shell.
- Sea bass with mango - also served on a half mussel shell. Also good but not as much as the mussel. 
- Hawaiian #2 roll - overrated. Tasted bland and overpowered by the shaved macadamia topping.
- Spicy scallop roll - yummy! not really spicy, though.
- Spicy hamachi roll - very fresh, practically melted in my mouth.
- Amaebi special - delicious! They'll fry the sweet shrimp head if you want. I'll admit it takes someone adventurous to try that.

All in all, a really good meal. But after waiting three years, I will admit my expectations were probably unattainable.

Cash only.
author: F. P.

description:
This place is the BEST place ever!!!!! The people who rated 1 star or said nasty things about this place I have a few words for you : 
   1) Don't HATE!!!!!
   2) The only sushi you know and eat are the ones that are smothered with a bunch of crap 
   3) You wouldn't know what GOOD sushi is if it was in front of you
   4)  EVERYTHING THERE IS GOOD!!!!!!!
   5) Lastly, don't HATE once again!
author: Naner V.

description:
I wanted to give Sushi Zone 5 stars, but the place is majorly lacking in space, the wait is consistently too long (2 hours is normal) and they don't have a huge selection of fish.

BUT I have a lot of great things to say as well! Try coming on an off hour or not on a weekend, because this place gets wayyyy too busy and they do NOT take reservations. Their sushi was really tasty, however I wish there was a little more selection and variety. 

It can be really awkward when you're eating and less than 5 feet away are 30 hungry customers staring you down hoping to get your seat. 

Their prices are very reasonable - earning them another star in my book, but again, there isn't a great deal of frills in their ingredients.
author: Emmi B.

description: Wow. I just left what will be one of the worst dining experiences I have had in a long time. First of all, arrived at 8pm and didn't get seated until 10pm. So we get seated at their closing time and you could tell because instead of making our order, the chefs cleaned and the waitress counted her money. As wafts of bleach drafted through the air and we continued to be ignored, we decided to cancel our order. No apologies, nothing taken off our bill for the ridiculous wait, nothing. Unfortunately that will be my last visit. Their sushi just ain't worth it. So many other amazing places in SF that will actually treat you the way a paying customer should be treated. Don't waste your time.
author: Trisha A.

description:
Came here around 7:30pm on a Friday night with a friend.  Took us about 10 minutes to get seated at the bar, which was a surprisingly short wait for such a tiny place!

We shared:
*Baked Sea Bass w/ Mango appetizer: These are delightfully delicious!  They come in servings of 2 in mussel shells so you probably want one serving for yourself to satiate the intense craving for more that immediately follows after inhaling the first one.  The warm mango was a little strange at first, but you get used to the texture quickly.

*Baked Mussels appetizer: Reminds me of Dynamite, the Japanese appetizer.  I liked that the mussels were diced so they were easier to eat.  This appetizer is also served in mussel shells, which made the following process incredibly efficient: bring shell to mouth, tilt, slurp, and repeat.

*Yellow Tail Kama: Fresh, buttery, delicate fish with a rich, fatty flavor.  The collar was not out of this world, but it definitely exceeded my expectations in quality.

*Hawaiian roll #2 with white tuna, mango, and chopped macadamia nuts: What a unique roll!  This roll embodies the concept in which opposing forces, when thoughtfully combined, can elevate individual ingredients far beyond the levels they would reach if served alone.  The combinations of salty and sweet from the fish and mango and soft and crunchy from the rice and macadamia nuts made my mouth dance with joy!  Juxtaposition at its very best!

*Spicy Hamachi w/ Jalapeno roll: Delicious and fresh, but I wish it was spicier!

*Papaya and Unagi roll: Papaya and Unagi are two of the few things I dislike eating so when my friend suggested that we order this roll, I smiled politely, agreed to ordering it and silently grumbled to myself.  Shockingly, it was actually pretty good, although I will still never order it for myself.

Overall, Sushi Zone is great for its food, but not for its service or atmosphere.  The sushi chefs never once spoke to us even though we were sitting at the bar.  Come to think of it, they didn't speak to anyone at the bar during our meal!  Service is also slow as they are very understaffed, and the kitchen appliances, which can be seen from the bar as they have an open kitchen, desperately need to be replaced.  They are using TOASTER OVENS to cook fish and appetizers!
author: Jen Y.

description:
Awesome, awesome sushi experience. My friend took me here because she comes to this spot every time she comes to the city from the East Bay. I thought maybe she was in love with a mediocre sushi spot since there probably isn't good sushi in her area. Boy oh boy am I grateful she brought me here!!

We arrived around 7ish on a Friday and the placed was packed and the little white board already had two columns of names, and we were near the last of the list. Thankfully I wasn't too hungry at the time because we waited a total of nearly two hours. Good thing there is Orbit Room across the street and Destino Pisco Lounge nextdoor-ish because we worked up a good buzz and enjoyed the sushi even more.

Things you must order:
- Baked Mussels: not your average sushi boat baked mussels, these are truly something special baked in a rich, creamy, spicy sauce that isn't so thick that it makes you feel gross like other baked mussels you mighta had. Plenty of mussel meat. Baked Sea bass was just okay (disappointingly cuz I love Sea bass) because IMO there was too much mango, too little sea bass.
- Spicy Hamachi: jalapeno, sprout, citrusy goodness! Plus, I love hamachi.
- Hawaiian Roll #2: When I came back the second time, I thought my bf would love this roll and I was right. Perfectly ripe mango, nice pieces of tuna, and crunchy crumbly rich macadamia nuts. I usually dislike mango/macadamia nut rolls at other sushi places, but my oh my this was sooo good! Not too sweet because it didn't have a ridiculously sweet sauce drizzled all over it like most sushi places like to irresponsibly dress rolls with.
- And the roll with unagi and avocado (its names evades me at the moment, Rock and Roll?) Super simple and a staple roll at any sushi spot, but some how Sushi Zone master makes it taste so good.

I think this place is reasonably priced for such delicious sushi, but please come with plenty of cash because you will probably want to keep ordering more, and more and then more sake and more sake on repeat.

Final Words: Sushi Zone offers pretty basic rolls that you can find at any sushi spot... but they have selected a few and perfected each aspect of the roll. The rice, the seaweed, the fish, the flavors. Regular sushi rolls elevated to an extraordinary experience. The service is straightforward, be patient, and respect the sushi chef at work. They know what they're doing here.
author: Rachelle F.

description:
Literally a "hole-in-the-wall" restaurant off of Market Street. Delicious sushi and quick service. I had the combo plate with the baked sea bass and mango in an oyster shell (SO GOOD). Make sure you show up as soon as it opens so that you can grab a spot, or else you'll have to put your name down and wait for a table. The wait is worth it, though.

Best sushi I've had in San Francisco so far.  Maybe even the best I've had between here and Canada.  Definitely worth checking out if you're ever in town.
author: Michael S.

description:
Sea Bass was AMAZING.

Long wait times FYI.

Had to change my review to 5 starts... absolutely my favorite sushi place. Scallop roll with jalapenos is great too.
author: Sara M.

description:
One of the most amazing sushi places I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I enjoyed the atmosphere, although quite small it's interesting in the aspect that you almost have to talk to the person next to you (which isn't a bad thing). The wait can be a bit of a hindrance but the meal will definitely make up for it no question about it.

Try the Baked Bass and Mango, it's good enough to sell your soul for.
author: Cove C.

description:
The baked sea bass with mango is amazing.

Both the Hawaiian Rolls are a must try as well, they're super tasty.

The fish here is really fresh and they have pretty large cuts.

The prices are pretty decent unless you want to drink sake, in which case, the price really goes up really quick.

Since the place is super small, you can't come with a party of 4 or more and if you do come with that kind of a party, you've gotta come really early or expect a really long wait.  So be prepared.
author: Jason K.

description: Stumbled upon this place when we couldn't find parking near the restaurant we actually wanted to go to in SOMA, but wow this place was waaaay better. Had to wait an hour for two of the 10 seats in the house to open up, but we found a surprisingly chic little bar to wait at. The sushi chef there was like an SF version of the guy from "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" and his rolls were delicious works of art. This place is not cheap, but you definitely get what you pay for and the sushi is just amazing.
author: Courtney L.

description: Best sushi in SF! Not over-priced but there is a long wait. The spicy tuna roll is a must.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I finally came here again Sunday evening 12/28/08.  There was ample street parking and of course no need to feed the meter at all b/c it was Sunday.  

~4:45PM  Time of arrival
Sign on door: "We will open at 5:30PM"  =/  (They were having slight electrical problems - they probably need a new breaker box or to balance out the flow of electricity..)
~5:20PM  Time we were let through the door

I love the intimate setting at Sushi Zone.  
The one chef making the sushi and appetizers, the one assistant making the baked appetizers and the one waitress tending to the customers.  It gives me a cozy feeling and I love that the place is small and hole-in-the-wall-ish.

This time I got some of what I hadn't ordered on my last visit.

- Baked sea bass w/ mango 
soso SO good!  I should've gotten a couple orders of this one.

- Nigiri
Saba! (my favorite)
Sake
Maguro
Hamachi
Suzuki

- Hawaiian roll
A fun roll w/ tuna, creaminess of avocado+mayo, crunchiness of macadamia, mmm..

- Spicy albacore roll
Yum.

- Hot sake 
I'm not the biggest sake fan, but this one did not leave a gross aftertaste in my mouth, so not bad.

It was all very satisfying, and I love getting in early, eating as part of the first group in, and leaving at around 6:30PM, so I still have the rest of the night to do whatever floats my boat. 

Yay Sushi Zone  ^_^  Intimate, friendly, affordable and delicious.

(P.S. Check out several pics of the food I ate on Sushi Zone's business profile.)
author: Kay N.

description:
I found it! Finally, a neighborhood sushi joint that I LOVE (not just like). The wait is long and even after you sit down it will take some time but I'll basically do anything for delicious food. Sushi Zone really deserves a better name. It sounds so genetic which is why I stayed away for so long. What a mistake. The delicious rolls, sashimi, and nigiris have me kicking myself! 

I first tried Sushi Zone two weeks ago before I went on vacation in Florida. My bf and I always have to get our sushi fixes before trips because it's so hard to find a good sushi place when you're traveling. We almost ordered every roll but here were some of my favorites:

The Hawaiian #2 - is similar to the Hawaiian. It just depends on if you like albacore or tuna better. Huge macadamia nuts and mango pieces make this taste like you really are in Hawaii. So good.

Papaya Unagi - This was just mouthwatering. I never thought papaya and unagi together but I'm sure glad Sushi Zone did. I know I'm ordering this one every time I come here!

Spider Roll - The tempura was perfect. Sometimes it's battered too thickly or it's BREADED and fried (yuck!) but this one was light and crisp. The crab was so fresh, you could taste the guts and juices. I LOVE IT. 

Rainbow Roll - Each piece was wrapped with a beautiful piece of sashimi. That's awesome. Best rainbow roll ever!

Spicy Scallop - The sushi chef cut nigiri quality scallops to mix into the spicy mayo for this roll. It was sweet, fresh and had just a hint of spice. 

The Sashimi combo plate was a great value too at just $20.50. I also tried the famous baked sea bass with mango. It was good but I'd rather have ordered more rolls! I was actually sad to leave SF the next day since the night before I found such a great sushi joint. The whole time I was away, I dreamt of Sushi Zone. I rushed right back after I got off the plane!
author: Julia T.

description:
Waited about 1 1/2 hours to eat here tonight. it was friday, my wife warned me, so we put our name in and got a at the bar about a block away at market and laguna (nice little place) - the wait is insane, way longer than anyone should have to wait to get a table...this place would benefit from 1 more sushi chef (there is only one guy for the whole place), this would speed things up a bit, but also destroy the charm. 

That being said - this was perhaps the best sushi i've had to date. It's simple, the fish is pretty top quality (some of the best i've had), tastes like it should, i dont know who would say otherwise, i've been to many of the 'best' places in the state and this fish was far and away better than 95% of them. and those portions!!!! wow 

RAINBOW ROLL = $14, but its the size of a burrito - imagine two full orders of thick cut sashimi put over a solid crab/avo/tobiko roll - WOW! highly recommend, the rest of the rolls were pretty epic as well, 

and the setting - amazing, you feel like your in your sushi chef friend's living room. 


Only downfall - too small, too many people, DO NOT come here if you are impatiently hungry, you will be pissed, come ready to wait and you'll leave very very happy, and stuffed.
author: Ben B.

description:
This is my go-to place for sushi in SF!! The rolls are so unique and delicious! I always get....

Appetizer: Baked stripped bass (with mango and spicy mayo sauce served in a oyster shell)

Rolls: Hawaiian #2, papaya unagi, spicy hamachi...these are my top three!

I LOVE Sushi Zone!!! The wait is very long, so be prepared for that (sometimes 2-3 hrs)...well worth it. Rolls are usually around $6...SO cheap!!
author: S P.

description:
I love this place but not the wait.

I really wanted to give this place five stars but the wait was so ridiculously long! And I'm usually someone who doesn't mind waiting! My friend and I had to wait well over two hours to get seated but then again, I don't really blame them. The place is small and there was only one person preparing the sushi. The service was really good and so was the food. I absolutely LOVE the Spicy Mango Salmon roll! Can I say it was like an orgasm in my mouth? That sounds so gross but I can't think of a better analogy than that.

What we ordered:
Spicy Mango Salmon Roll
Spicy Scallop Roll
Hawaiian #1 Roll
Uni Nigiri
Tuna Roll
New York Roll
Spicy Tuna Roll

We ordered way too much but it was worth it. My only regret was not ordering the Baked Mussels  ;(
author: Simon L.

description: Small store with small booths, located in a busy area. Charming-all-the-way. Recommendation from a friend to visit. The rolls were creative, not traditional. The service was very slow, since they only have one server for the small space.  At the end of the meal, I felt that I had over paid for what I received (which is standard for sushi in general, but even more so at this place). Be sure to come early if you're a large party, because the 2 four-person booths fill up quickly.
author: Alexander R.

description: Hands down the most fresh and delicious sushi I have ever had in my life. Also the smallest joint. The place is so small they don't have a dishwasher. There's just one chef and two ladies helping him with the front end. In thirty years of enjoying sushi all over California I have never been surprised by any place until I came to eat here. Many unique dishes and I repeat: more delicious and fresh than I have ever experienced before. It seems they even pickle their own ginger.
author: You Best R.

description:
As good as sushi gets !  Fresh from the ocean, even taste like ocean.
YUMMY,I am going there tonight
author: David C.

description:
oh damn that was good.

LONG wait. bring sidewalk sodas.
author: Clover Dan ..

description:
With a movie/tv show shooting around the corner, staffed with men wearing fishing vests and cargo shorts, featuring police officer-looking cast, it was your typical Monday evening in the almost-castro, in the heart of genuine San Francisco.  How many cliches can you fit into 15 mins?  If I saw a drag queen running down the street, it would have rounded out the count.

We were not the first in line.  But we did get the last booth.  Nee-ner-nee-ner-nee-ner.  Nothing makes me feel more entitled than observing the groups of people who showed up after us with children in tow.  Young children.  People who were told that the wait was more than an hour.  Young children who are then forced to wait an hour for dinner becuase they have either sophisticated palates or dip-sheep as parents.  It calls for another bottle of hot sake.

We ordered the baked sea bass mango, hawaiian #2, spicy hamachi roll, spicy salmon mango roll, king california roll, uni, ama-ebi, and albacore nigiri.  The nigiri was delicious.  The portions were generous, the fish was buttery and melted upon contact.  The uni was caressed in a leaf of shiso and as golden as a solid gold ingot from the Aztec temples.  

The rolls ranged from good to weird.  Weird in a jive ass way.  The King California Roll was good, but the real crab was real dry.  It was either from a can or purchased in bulk and processed.  I've become such a snoooooob since I've learned how to efficiently rip the flesh from shellfish.  It's a skill that has been good on my wallet because I will no longer accept machine imitations.  Snob, I know.  Deal with it.

Spicy Hamachi had a lot of flavor.  The spicy mayo was creamy without being slimy and overpowering the already flavorful hamachi.  

Spicy Mango Salmon: I think my testate shriveled up and curled back inside my body when i ordered this.  No good will come of a name that includes both "Mango" and "Spicy."  The sushi purist inside of me committed seppuku and hung himself out to dry.  Whereas the dumb blond in me said, "oooooh, mango!"

Baked Sea Bass Mango - this was the worst thing I've ever had to sit in front of.  It beats out "foam" as the stupidest idea for food, style and taste.  You get two mussel shells (but no mussel) which have a layer of diced mango on the bottom, a small sliver of white fish (maybe it's sea bass, maybe it's halibut, maybe it's chicken!) and then frosted over with mayo.  Baked.  Sprinkled with Masago egss.  Not even tobiko.  It was masago.  I think.  For $6.  

The food would have earned a 4 star rating.  But the service was ridiculously slow.  It took an hour and a half to get our food.  I was late for class.  The sake was watered down and rather expensive for hot sake.  The miso soup had a strange smokey tangy flavor.  A scent you might call it.  I'm no Top Chef, but Padma might say "This doesn't smell right."
author: Christina C.

description: Rolls are big, delicious, and juicy. However, the place is small and the waiting is long if you get there after 6pm.
author: Richard C.

description:
very good, actually top sushi according to its price. You eat so much cool sushi and pay about 15-20$ per person. That is amazing...

Very negative side is that you have to wait quite long. It is very small, just two tables and bar. We waited 2hrs but this is not eventually their mistake...
author: Ali E.

description:
The wait isnt worth it. 
This place has fresh ingredients but thats it - there is nothing special about it. We came to the restaurant at 6:30pm, there were 7 people in front of us, 3 couples and 1 individual, it took 1.5 hrs before we sat down. There is one chef cooking and he was finishing the order for each group before moving to the next (to empty seats). So after we sat down we had to wait another 20 minutes before getting our food. The menu is small, which is fine if they had some specialties, but besides the muscles there is nothing extraordinary. I was really hoping that the wait was going to be worth it and we'd get a delicious meal but that wasn't the case. There are plenty of other sushi restaurants that have fresh ingredients and most have a much bigger fish selection as well. 

We ordered cold tofu which was not good - seemed like it was straight out of the box with fish flakes and soy sauce.
Stuffed jalapeños were ok but the muscles looked better.
Salmon and tuna nigiri fish pieces were bigger than usual and very tasty.
Sushi rolls were mediocre - fresh but nothing special.

Overall, I would not recommend going to this restaurant.
author: Natalie R.

description:
2.5 stars- went here last night w/a friend. Walked in to the little place.. its half full on a Tue night, which is not too bad. 

Waitress was incredibly nice and friendly. Its been a LONG time since I had sushi- maybe since my bday 7 months a go. For some reason I used to have a lot more sushi before moving up to the bay area. 

Anyway- it didnt quite hit the spot. I ordered the dragon rolls and it had ginger or wasabi and im not a huge fan... so that kinda destroyed my meal. also ordered a hot tea- and just not my thing.. not my taste. it tasted like fishy hot tea.. yuck. 

anyway.. staff is very nice and friendly and attentive. the food is probably ok. id recommend you going.. but just not my place...
author: Art A.

description:
To be honest, I was a little disappointed with the sushi scene in San Francisco. I almost feel like I found better sushi in NYC, Chicago and LA (in America anyway). I'm pretty certain that I was spoiled by the quality I would get in these other cities for 30% less than I would pay for in SF.

Then someone recommended me to try this place. It was nearby my place. It's small with usually one waitress, 1-2 other people who would prep ingredients, and one old Japanese man in a Hawaiian shirt who makes all the rolls and sushi. Expect a long wait if you get there after 6 pm, and possibly being turned away if you arrive too late.  The menu is simple, but the shock came in when I saw how cheap it was. For around 3 rolls and 2 orders of sushi, it came out to around $24 which was pretty amazing in SF.  The fish was fresh and definitely not skimped on.

I think I found my go-to sushi place if I crave rolls. Unfortunately, I docked a star because the wait is too long for both getting a table and service. (At that point, I would walk 20 minute in the opposite direction and pick up sushi to go from the Japanese markets in Japantown.)
author: Koh K.

description:
The other yelpers are right--don't come here.  And I mean that not because I "want the place to myself," but because I think the sushi is substandard, and you deserve better.  In fact, there *is* better sushi in this city, far better, and you don't have to wait an eternity to eat it.

They had that "I've been frozen one too many times" taste to it, and was cut into these strange, jagged chunks.  Taking a peek inside of the little area where the chef keeps the fish, you find slabs of fish strewn about at random, no finesse involved here at all.  

Sushi is about fresh fish, and this place ain't got it.  If you're a fan of long waits, mayo, rolls, and mushy sloppily cut sushi, this place is all yours.  Sorry, SZ, I honestly wish you were as good as your reputation.
author: Michael J.

description:
They have my favorite love story ever told: : : 'Mango meets Sushi' : : :
