My 'NEW' favorite love story: : : "Mango meets Seabass' : : :


Specially: : : 'Baked Mango Seabass' : : :
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/M175LTlKPJjAWREIUPyMGg?select=ceMsUPfttwp5Uly2sVnYaA 




Oh, and P.S...
the Amaebi Special is a must-try as well.
author: Sue Y.

description:
Never have I been able to confidently declare one establishment as the best sushi I've ever had.  Finally!! 
At Sushi Zone, the style is very simple.  3 people run the place- a front of house (server/busser/hostess), a guy making rolls/cutting sashimi, and an in-between baking apps (like the baked mussels and bass- both fantastic).  The sake sashimi (salmon) is amazing.  The spicy hamachi roll is wonderful.  The rainbow roll is overwhelming.  Playing its simple roll, the menu is relatively limited.  Quite sufficient if you're not high maintenance when it comes to your sushi.  Seemingly boring rolls spring to life in your mouth- tremendous flavor/freshness.
I have tried 3 times to dine in this shoebox, twice successfully.  This place is all about patience.  If you don't have it, don't bother patronizing this place.  
The quality of fish and the cleanliness of the establishment (their health inspection card is on display) are the major reasons for the high ranking.  The wait list doesn't tell the story- see how many people are actually waiting in/around the restaurant.  When dining at Sushi Zone, remember to bring your necessary virtues and appreciate the process as it was intended.  
Cash only- though it's not as expensive as most sushi dinners of lower quality.
author: c d.

description:
Finally went here after months of hearing so many good things about this neighborhood sushi gem! Ace and I found parking literally across the street on Market, of course had to jaywalk but it was certainly worth it, if a cop busted us. 

We sat right infront of the bar, two corner seats. Ordered a large Sapporo to share and a large hot sake for starters. This place seats 18 people and we were lucky enough to arrive early before the dinner crowd started to trickle in. 

This cozy hole in the wall served to be the most best kept secret in SF and I kid you not, the food speaks for itself. Be aware of the long wait for food, from what I was told...it's actually the same kind of long wait if you were in Japan. 

We had the baked mussels. These are mouth watering! I could eat six of these! 
We also had the two hawaiian rolls with salmon and hamachi (with mango and generous amount of crushed mac nuts), the unagi with papaya, the salmon skin roll, etc. I absolutely loved the unagi with papaya roll -- this was refreshing and delicious. 

I would recommend this place to anyone and definitely coming back next month!
author: Mika D.

description:
HEY ASSHATS!!!!!!!!!!
stop complaining about the wait, we get it, you had to wait for hours, boho poor you!!!
Spoiled butbellys take your onestar and head over to TACOBELL it's just around the corner!
author: cecilia k.

description:
One comes to this place to contemplate the passing of time.  The wait is truly a test of patience.  You wait for a seat.  You wait for food to come.  If you are seated at the bar, you must resist the temptation to look at the food that arrived for the person next to you.  For many minutes, you ponder if your sushi will look something like the sushi in front of another person down the bar.

Now, is it worth the wait?  Not so much for me.  The place does sushi rice right and the fish is fresh.  The saba has a unique texture as if there was some sort of ever-so-slight steaming.  No fishy taste, no watery flesh, and a density approaching chicken breastesses.  It's quite wonderful.  The cucumbers are the crunchiest I've ever had.

I would recommend it for the sushi traditionalist, but traditionalists might find the sight of baked mussels and macadamian nut coated rolls too much.  I do and I eat rolls with some crazy made-up names.

Take a girl camping to see what she's like in the rough.  Then, take her here to see how she handles an excrutiatingly long wait for food.  If she can get through those experiences graciously, then you have no more excuses.
author: jeffrey k.

description: Yes, there will be a long wait but it's worth it. There are places around the area to have drinks while you wait like Pisco next door or the Orbit Room across the way. I've been having dinner here for many years and the sushi is divine. If you have the patience go, it is worth the wait.
author: Sheila T.

description: I haven't been to sushi zone in AGES, but I used to go at least twice a month. While the sashimi/nigiri is not too great, the maki and the cooked sea-bass mango thing are great, casual, easy to eat food.
author: Maïa Cybelle C.

description:
I've been here a few times now, most recently on a holiday monday (MLK). We were seated promptly, but a line soon formed out the door. In the past, I've had to wait up to 2 hours, so be careful about when you go!

The sushi is good, and consistently fresh. The key term here though, is sushi VALUE., It's not the best sushi I've ever had, but it's some of the best sushi I've ever had for the price I had it at. At $5-6 for a decently ornate roll (I'm not talking california roll here), it's hard to beat. In mathematical terms, where deliciousness is measured in yums and price measured in dollars, the yums per dollar ratio is perhaps greater then any other sushi restaurant I've been to in SF.

Recommend: anything with Mango, such as the hawaiian rolls. Mango roll for 6 bucks? Sushi Zone is making Hawaiian's cry that they don't live in San Francisco. Tropical tears. 

Also, the spicy rolls were done well. I'm forgetting the name of the roll right now, but I'm pretty sure it was a spicy roll and had lime in it. Their technique: they slice a lime into an impossibly thin piece, and it brings just the right amount of sour/fruity taste to make it a unique sushi creation.
author: James W.

description: Demoted.  Raw fish is a B- and wait at table is fundamentally unacceptable (1hrs+ post order).
author: N K.

description: This is my favorite restaurant.  Please stop coming here, the wait is just getting worse.
author: Ahab R.

description:
For years I've heard about this restaurant. Awesome sushi. Long lines. Authentic. Hole-in-the-wall. I finally got to see what this place was all about and I must admit, I was quite happy with the experience. First off, it is small. Lines are long. And yes, the sushi was good. Our group of 3 got there at 8:30pm and were sat maybe 25 min later. I think wait time is really dependent on timing since when we got there, several tables were wrapping up with only one name on the list ahead of us. Yes folks, look for the list to jot your name down.

The baked mussels were AWESOME! Mango on anything does me right. The rolls were great but I don't even remember what I got. Fish was fresh though and in the end, I walked out stuffed with a $35 tab (beer included).
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: By far the best sushi that I have had in San Francisco.  In the world, only Blue Ribbon in NYC and Sushi Sam's in San Mateo are  better. That is saying a lot for me - a food snob extraordinaire. Sushi Zone is one of those rare places you cannot stop thinking about.  The wait is long, yes, but go across the street or next door to wait. It is worth it. Last time I went I waited two hours and I was soooo hungry but I was so thankful when we sat down, I stopped caring.  Plus the people that work there are super, super mellow, super friendly. The place completely lacks bullshit and serves amazing sushi.
author: Erin M.

description:
I went yesterday to sushi zone with Cristina M. and we were left feeling underwelmned. 

Everyone is right when they say the bakes mussles/bass is amazing, because they are. But I came to sushi zone for sushi not baked bass. 

We started with the Alaskan roll made with salmon, avo and scallion. the roll was huge, filled with way too much soggy rice, and avocado. The avo over-powered the rest of the roll.  I couldn't even taste the fish. 
That's ok we thought, avocado does over-power. Maybe it was just one roll. 

We then our striped bass and albacore nigiri. The fish looked like it had been cut by a dull knife with jagged edges on it's side, and to be honest it was subpar fish. It seemed like they remidied that by giving you a lot of it. The fish was hanging off the riceball reminding me that this was quantity over quality. 

The spicy hamachi roll came out out and it was tasty. The jalapeno and lime was a nice change but I can't emphasis how much the roll lost by having horrible rice and loose rolls. It was bittersweet, as if you morn a roll that could have been amazing but turned out mediocre. 

Next came a spiced scallion, and a yellowtail roll. The rolls tasted the same, the fish bland. 

When I see a 4+ star rating I know the sushi will melt in my mouth. What I was left with instead was buffet quality Sushi. Don't let the hunger that the long lines caused fool you. This place is worthless
author: Alex M.

description:
Hands down the best sushi place ever! I Its won't be the same again after trying Sushi Zone, I just can't like any other sushi place now. Baked bass and hawaian #2 is my two favourites. 
The only down side is that the place is so small, that sometimes the wait can take forever.
author: Elcin E.

description:
I've said time and again that once every so often, along comes a restaurant that creates a new standard for a specific food item, or cuisine.  
 
For example -  for brunch, I measure any restaurant serving breakfast items against my favorite brunch joint - Fifth Wheel in San Leandro.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/fifth-wheel-san-leandro#hrid:NdW9Y2eTUawSBQWl3cCmlQ
 
For gorging on meats, I measure it against my favorite red meat joint, Fogo de Chao.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/fogo-de-chao-beverly-hills#hrid:uk02t8IVKw4LXdXKQVXq4Q
 
When it comes to sushi - I measure everything against my favorite Ino Sushi.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/ino-sushi-san-francisco#hrid:Lyn6QgsDGQ4njA08juAGAQ
 
My old friend from high school swears by this place, so I made a true effort to try it out.  I am VERY reluctant to try new sushi joints as I am invariably disappointed when comparing it to Ino, but on this night, it was 9 pm and Ino was closed.
 
I thought Ino Sushi was small.
Sushi Zone is TINY.  I can see now why everyone is reviewing how long they waited -  my bedroom is larger than this restaurant.  Lucky for us, because we got there at 9:30 PM, we did not have a wait and got seated at the two remaining seats at the otherwise still full bar.
It's extremely casual (almost a dive, if you will) and doesn't have a Japanese feel at all, except the entire staff is Japanese.  As "hole in the wall" as it felt, it looked clean.
 
The staff was friendly, and the chef, while I don't believe it was Aio-san on this evening, was nice enough.
 
Let's get to the fish.
 
First - my friend recommended the Omakase here, but I was politely informed that they do not do Omakase because they are just too busy.  Perhaps they just do Omakase for my friend Kip and his wife - I am not sure, but even sitting at the bar, it was not chef's choice - we ordered what we wanted and said to include whatever is fresh and NOT COOKED at all  Read my Ino Sushi review and you will see how I feel about getting Omakase.
 
First came the maguro, sake, and hirame.  The tuna and salmon were totally underwhelming at best, the hirame was good.
 
The scallop nigiri was quite outstanding - as well as the hamachi-kama we ordered.  Both fish were extremely fresh.  
 
Having read some of the reviews, I knew I had to at least try a roll of some sort, and opted to order the hamachi spicy roll.  While I didn't find it spicy, I had  to admit this was a tasty roll - I loved the lime aspect of it and the hamachi was fresh.  Other items, like uni, were good.  Rob loved the tataki seared tuna - and I was not a big fan.
 
We ordered plenty of nigiri, and we were stuffed silly by the end of the meal.  
 
Now, I started to hear the theme song to Jaws, as we requested the bill.  The cost of the meal would be what would determine whether this was a 3 or 4-star experience.
 
Rob spends an astronomical amount of money on taking me out to dinner.  While we both enjoy a good In N Out Burger, we also both appreciate luxury dining at any cost, so long as the food and experience made it worthwhile.  
 
Having eaten at Sushi Zone - I knew what I was willing to pay for this experience.  I also knew at which price point this dinner would have become a waste of good money.
 
We received the bill and for $100 total - including tip - Grace and Rob were full (read: we ate our usual enormous amount of sushi).  This breaks down to $50 per person, including a small bottle of cold sake (which, by the way, was good stuff).
Now this was truly an economical meal.
 
Excellent sushi, I think not.
But we ate without crinkling our nose at anything or having to spit anything out, and more than once, we were impressed by the quality of SOME of the fish (though not all), and while the rice is not to my liking in taste or size (a bit too much rice), it was all in all pretty good.  
 
The selection of rolls, however, was impressive - and the one roll we did try was very good.  
This was also the first time in my life that I have entered a sushi restaurant and ended up being the only Asian party in the restaurant - which explains the popularity of the rolls at Sushi Zone.
 
For most of the food, I would only give it 3-stars overall.  The ambiance of the place, while cool in an eclectic sort of way, is also not what I want when I am opting to eat Japanese food - BUT, you factor in the price and Sushi Zone just kind of makes sense.
 
Will I be back?
I'm not entirely sure.  I am the type of person who'd rather spend double this amount and eat amazing sushi at Ino rather than eat "just good" sushi, but then again, Ino's last seating is at 8:30 pm (if that), whereas Sushi Zone seats until 9:30 pm.  
 
Most definitely, though - I am not one to wait 2 hours to eat here as many yelpers have claimed to have done.
 
No way, no how.
author: Grace K.

description:
Did I go to the wrong restaurant?  What I ate was nowhere near as good as these reviews.

Remember to write your name on the whiteboard and prepare to wait.  After about 40 min on a weekday, we were seated at the bar.  BTW, this place is super tiny.  I don't think any table can seat more than 4 peeps.  Food comes out pretty fast and service was great.

Chirashi was okay.  I'm not sure if his knife wasn't sharp, but the edges were stringy and jagged.  Hamachi kama was prepared in what looked like a toaster oven, but it was very meaty, tasty, and super fresh.  Sea bass with mango was aight.  Can I be honest?  It reminded me of something you'd get at a Chinese buffet, not a 5 star yelp establishment.

I may have overly hyped up Sushi Zone in my head.  If I walked in off the street and ate here, I might think they're a notch better, but not by much.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My sister and I were visiting from Seattle over Thanksgiving weekend and were hunkering for some sushi after a weekend of turkey and Chinese food.  After perusing Yelp while riding the BART into the city, we came across the reviews for Sushi Zone.  

First of all, people are not exaggerating when they say you will have to wait... and wait... and wait to eat at this restaurant.  However, if you have the time and the patience, I think it's worth it!   Sushi Zone has barely any waiting space (one small bench and a few seats against the far wall), so after writing your name on the list you are likely going to have to wait outside.  There were about 8 people listed ahead of us and not realizing the amount of time we'd have to wait, we stuck it out for 30 minutes.  Then we realized that there are only 16 seats (yup, we counted!), did some quick math, and decided to wait at a nearby bar for awhile.  We came back after an hour and still waited another 30 minutes before we were finally seated.  So total waiting time: 2 hours.  

You may at this point be wondering why I still gave Sushi Zone a 4 Star rating after such a long wait.  The answer?  The food.  

I cannot remember the exact names of the rolls we ordered, but I'll try to do some describing.   We both started out with miso soup and tea, which both came very quickly.  Then, after seeing table after table consuming these delicious looking baked something or others in shells, my sister and I decided we just had to try them.  After 30+ minutes of examining the menu, we deduced that they were baked striped sea bass with mango.  And they were as tasty as they looked!  There is a reason why everyone orders them and if you go to Sushi Zone, you should too!

In addition to the soup and bass, we also ordered a tuna roll (very fresh!), a hibachi (?) roll (yum!), and one more which I cannot for the life of me remember right now.  Just know that it was delicious and you can't go wrong with any of their rolls!  

To top off the delicious cuisine, a final element Sushi Zone has going for them... their prices!  The rolls are relatively inexpensive for how many pieces (6) you get!  The typical range is between $5 and $8, with a few more expensive specials.  The total for my sister and my bill was under $40 with tip!

So, to sum up this review... Sushi Zone is well worth the wait.
author: Suzanna F.

description:
This is the only restaurant I go to at least once a month.  The two hour wait is always worth it.  To pass the time, just order a sake and take your time reading the Zagat Survey for America's Top Japanese Restaurants located on the counter.  Or you can go to Pisco around the corner.

My favorite dishes:

*uni
*hawaiian #1 - the macadamia nuts are magical
*stuffed mussel (better than the stuffed mushroom or jalapeño; but they are good as well)
*hamachi - the regular cut almost tastes as good as hamachi belly
*spicy scallop handroll - you can ask for extra mayonnaise
*amaebi - like uni, so many things can go wrong with this dish but it's been consistently good
*unagi handroll - no wonder Japanese people have this for dessert

My least favorite:

*Mexican roll
*anything w/ mango in the sushi
author: jacalyn y.

description: The best sushi that I have ever had, period.  I also loved the seaweed salad and the baked mussels.  It was the highlight of a week of eating in the Bay Area.  I cannot wait to go back!
author: Julie H.

description:
For those of us sushi fanatics out there...This is the place to go!  The menu is short and sweet. The food here is so amazing its almost a shame there are like 12 seats and if you dont get there by opening you wont get seated for hours. You'll be sitting in the window like a sad puppy staring into peoples mouths drooling on yourself. I almost hesitated writing a review because it may attract even more people and make it more difficult for me to eat my dinner in peace.  I love the fact that the staff are all Japanese (no offense but c'mon it' s sushi).

*if u don't eat sushi at Japanese resaturants dont go here. They dont serve ramens or teriyaki or any of that other shit.(not saying i dont enjoy these things but right time right place)For sushi lovers only! Dont bring your meat and potato BF or friends with allergies who will simply be wet rags for the rest of us. Hahaha...
Sush Zone I love you...xoxo

D
author: Darina N.

description:
Decided to try this place after numerous recommendations . The food here is ridiculous! Some of the best Sushi I have ever had and easily one of the best restaurants in SF period. There's one problem...the place is the size of a large walk-in closet. Because of the Yelp warnings, I left work early and arrived at around 4:30 and there was already a line. Luckily, we were seated shortly after 5. 

I would give this place 5 stars, but I only gave it 4 because of the people standing behind you and the impatient glares while you're trying to enjoy your meal. Plus, I don't really enjoy eating dinner in the late afternoon or close to midnight. I do recommend everyone try this place at least once. It just seems to be a pain in the ass to frequent this establishment on a consistent basis.
author: R T.

description: Baked bass filled with mango !! Crunchy sushi with mango !!! By far best sushi experience ever !!!
author: Eddie E.

description:
I don't really understand the hype here... I went with a few friends the other night and had a very subpar experience.

I got the Chirashi which I get at pretty much every sushi joint I go to.  First off, it took about 45 mins to get our food.  I'm all about lounging, having a good conversation over beers and sake with friends, but 45 mins!?  We all got sushi so its not like they forgot to cook something in the kitchen and had to wait for it.  Anyways, after the food finally arrived I was very unimpressed by the amount of food.  There were 5 pieces of fish total (one of them being ebi, which I don't really even count so its more like 4 pieces).  Sake, maguro, hamachi, unagi over some rice.  Move along, nothing special to see here...
author: Miranda L.

description:
Two tables and a bar... it's a hole in the wall but it's awesome. If you want fast uninteresting sushi... don't come here. There's always a wait but it's always worth it! 

Tips:
Figure out what you want before you are seated it will shorten the wait ... and buy the chef some beer or Saki as a thank you and you'll be treated extra awesome!

Favorite items: 
Baked Sea Bass - OMG so good!
Hawaiian #1 & #2
author: Elisabeth G.

description:
Wow. lets just say i have been living in SF for two years and have been thoroughly dissapointed with the sushi that i have eaten in the city.  Some was ok (ebisu) but none come close to fresh, delicate, and delicious sushi that i had at sushi zone with my girlfriend tonight.

App: Baked Mussels with spicy mayo that were excellent

nigiri: amaebi (sweet shrimp) a specialty that i dont see very often, it was excellent and the heads were served deep fried

sake(salmon): extremely fresh and tasty

hamachi(yellowtail): the absolute best piece of fish i have had in so long.  It was like butter that just melted in your mouth.

albacore: my least favorite but still delicious

rolls: hawaiian #2, albacore, mango, avocado, diakon sprouts, scallions, and macadamia nuts on top. just perfect. every thing you could ask for in a roll.

spicy hamachi: hamachi, jalapenos, spicy mayo, and sprouts.  very good also.

plus super nice service and ambience and very reasonably price, i just found my go to sushi spot in SF.
author: Anthony F.

description:
Excellent sushi in a tiny hole-in-the-wall place. Service is just one woman, who is very nice and accommodating, and does her best to manage the line. Get there early!

Their sushi - the rainbow roll, the spicy tuna - is excellent. Sometimes I dream about their Baked Mango Sea Bass, no joke. The problem is that they're really popular and really small, so give yourself plenty of time when eating there. 

Also: a reminder that it's cash-only.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Wow- got there 20 minutes after opening and there was a waiting line- all locals- began to get a little weary...but then we were seated at the bar. The four workers moved seamlessly in their tiny space, the plum wine appeared, the food moved around...ah the food...thick sashimi, mackerel that melted, try the sea bass appetizer with mango, try the mussel appetizer, do not share. Everything is prepared before your eyes, and the mood is lighthearted and festive- service is efficient, aware, and the food is fresh, creative (mango, lemon and jalapeno in various rolls)- this is why we eat out- arigato!
author: Chui X.

description:
Sushi Zone is a restaurant (yes, it's hard to believe as you take in the size of this miniscule hole-in-wall, but let me finish) that rewards you if you've done your research.  I've been here a few times now, and each time has been fabulous despite the wait that you'll almost certainly experience.

Knowing that there is a wait, you can use that time to your advantage.  The bf and I came here yesterday right at opening (5:00 pm), put our name down on the whiteboard, and didn't get seated until 6:15 pm.  Pretty ridiculous, right?  But the waitress brought us beverages during our wait.  In the alternative, there's the Pisco Lounge right next door, and they serve delicious cocktails and wines to help pass the time.  Or the bookstore across the street.  My point is that knowing there's an ass-long wait to eat here, just be prepared for it and you'll be eating before you know it.

Once you get over it, the food is quite enjoyable here.  I'd pass on the run-of-the-mill Rainbow Roll and the Spicy Tuna Rolls - they're nothing too special.  However, you'll be blown away by the Baked Striped Sea Bass with Mango ($5.00).  This is served in a mussel shell, and it simply melts in your mouth.  Also, don't miss the Hawaiian Rolls ($5.75 each for HR#1 and HR #2), which come with your choice of macadamia nuts or not.

We were really full after getting all of the above (plus drinks and miso soup), and it only cost us about $55 tax and tip included for the two of us.  Everything about this place is reasonable, aside from the wait, of course.
author: Kira K.

description:
This is literally the best sushi in SF. Since moving from the city I now come here almost every time I do find myself in the neighborhood, with near religious devotion. Last time I was here I ordered 5 orders of my favorite baked mango / sea bass appetizer. The waitress was a bit surprised until we explained that I had moved to the country. "Oh, yes, I get that all the time," she said with a smile. LOL

This place has not  changed a bit in the last 10ish years I have been going. YUM. Can't wait to go again tonight. 

Don't come here expecting to find seating for a party of more than 4 people. Also, you should try and arrive as close to 5 as possible as there is usually a wait and that is the best time to slip in before the "rush" ... expect to wait a bit, it's worth it.
author: Erin H.

description: Had a great time in this little place! Sushi is freshly made in font of you and tastes great. You have to go earlier though as there will be queue, so don't go if you are in a hurry, but it worth the waiting.
author: Tony F.

description:
The wait here is crazy because there place only seats about 15-20 people. Be sure either to get there early- even before it opens.  But most good restaurants in SF have a wait anyway.  People line up anywhere from 15-30 minutes before it opens. I've been lucky a couple of times where the timing was right or if there was only two of us. 

Besides that, the food is fantastic.  I'm a big fan of just sashimi- not the rolls, the baked stuff, or even the rice- just fish, and it is delicious here.  There's a sashimi platter to share and it's well worth it.  There's a dish with thinly sliced yellowtail and jalepeno that is delicious.  As a filler though, I do enjoy the rolls that are topped with macademia nuts- adds a  little texture to it. 

Great food, good prices, and fun atmosphere- the only reason I didn't give it a 5 star rating is because of the wait.
author: Thao T.

description:
Two stars because the sushi was alright and the chef works his balls off.  No more because the wait was just about intolerable.

Biggest problem are tables crammed with 6 people who order 19 different rolls.  The chef obviously cares about what he's doing it's just that there needs to be about three chefs to make the wait tolerable.  From name on the board to final roll was about two hours.  We felt like baby birds mouths open waiting for something...anything.  We called for the check in advance because I just couldn't take waiting for anything any longer.

Hate to down a place for its popularity but it just ain't worth the time invested...
author: Steve F.

description:
Best Sushi ever.  If I could give it 10 starts I would.
Orgasmic melt in your mouth deliciousness.
I never knew sushi could be so good.

Must have:
Baked bass = heaven on a half shell
Spicy Mango Salmon = dill delicious
Seared Albacore nigiri = sublime
Fatty Tuna nigiri = better than in Japan
Salmon nigiri = unbelievable, holy molly
Hawaiian #2 = macadamia treat

Bring cash. Worth the 1 hour + wait. You will never think of sushi the same.  I can't eat sushi anywhere else.  I am sooooo addicted. 

Looking to kill the time while waiting? Go across the street to The Mint for some karaoke and cheap drinks.
author: A S.

description:
There's not much I can say about sushi zone without getting all emotional. So here it is.  This is my FAVORITE sushi place of all time.

Baked sea bass
Spicy Hamachi
Hawaiian #2

all equals a fantastic night, but get there for the early bird special or you'll be there all night.

Don't tell your friends, seriously, don't tell them.  I would only bring 1-2 people tops in order to make it in.
author: jessica b.

description: I can't believe I have never been here in my 7 years of living in San Francisco. This place was recommended by a friend, and I was skeptical. I went for the first time today with a friend, and truly enjoyed the quality of the fish and portions. Price to quality and quantity ratio is really high. The salmon nigiri and seared albacore were amazing. The only drawback is the long waiting time, so be prepared for 45-60 minute waits at prime time. It's cozy, high quality at a great price, you can't ask for much more.
author: Joseph C.

description:
This place is AMAZING.

My cousin and I went out last Friday to check out Sushi Zone.....when we got in the place smelled delicious and it was packed with people.  The place is TINY!  Only two tables and bar seating.  We waited an hour for a table, but it was all well worth it.  While waiting we got to chat with a few others who all had nothing but great things to say.

Highlights:

Sea Bass with mango!!!  My cousin and I decided next time we go back this is all we're ordering!  :)

Stuffed jalapenos.....yummy!!!!

Salmon Mango roll

The people there are great too, very nice and very attentive to your needs.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Jana S.

description:
For $60, my friend and I had loads of sushi and appetizers (the baked seabass in a mussel shell is to die for, I could order 10 of them) AND one large sake, small sake, and a beer. Really good prices! 

The fish is excellent, and I love all the mango rolls they have. Alaskan #2 is bomb with the macadamia nuts sprinkled on top.

It can take over an hour and i hear sometimes two to get seated. But, just put your name on the board and head into the peruvian bar next door for a drink while you wait.
author: ella a.

description:
Delicious fresh seafood. The uni was creamy and sweet, the baked muscles were sweet and savory, but my favorite were the scallions.

The place is next to another Japanese restaurant that is slightly larger, so do not get confused. The lines can get kind of long and if your full party is not there, then you will have to wait.  Also, remember this is a hole in a wall that is cash only. :)
author: Jason G.

description: Best sushi SF. You pretty much always have to wait 45+ mins for a table but it's more then worth it. There's some Mexican spot next door that you can grab a few quick beers at while you wait. Great prices too.
author: Michael B.

description: Must get more than one order of the baked sea bass. So good! But deduct one star for the terrible 2-hour wait, and another star deduction for waiting 20 mins for sushi. Prices are reasonable though.
author: Mary L.

description:
walked in around 6:30 and got a table by the window right away. Thank goodness because right after, people were coming in and out, crowding the door waiting for a seat at one of the two tables or a bar seat.so expect a long wait ..
Anyways,our 4 order of sushi took over 30 mins. I'm guessing it's because they had to put everything on one big plate to serve it all at one time. saving on dish washing soap?
Over all, loving the sushi + mango madness...

the Hawaiian roll is a definite must have...
sweet mango with a chunky layer topped with  macadamia nuts (and you all know those nuts aren't cheap.)

Another stand out was the baked sea bass with mango. 
But everything else was just ok. loved munching on the Amaebi's legs tho:)
author: Lynn T.

description:
Nasu nigiri, divine...
And the mango/bass gratin in a mussel shell it's still to die for.
Oh well, I know, long waits, laundry fee for your clothing smell but hey, Sushi Zone never disappoints....with that "Aishite Knight" vibe :)
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ai_Shite_Knight)
author: Dario B.

description:
Oy.  The wait times really kill this one for me.  If not for the long wait to get seated, the long wait to put in our orders, and the long wait to receive all of our food, I would have been happy to give this place more stars.

What everyone says is true:
- fish is fresh.  The honey and I had some really amazing, completely un-stinky, super fresh buttery sweet delicious uni here.  Incredible.
- the wait is long.  We spent an hour waiting to be seated, and an hour waiting for our food.  We had the bad luck of getting seated right after a group of 7 (crammed into one of the booths), and the chefs decide to make all of the food for one table at a time.  We spent close to three hours at Sushi Zone overall, waiting, waiting, eating, waiting, waiting.
- there is really only one server.  She is a nice lady, but she is very busy.  We watched our potential counter seats sit there uncleaned for close to twenty minutes, until she was able to wipe it down for us to sit down.  Our spot was almost poached by a single older dude, but the waitress is good about regulating the waitlist.  That was nice, because I'm not so nice when my blood sugar gets really low...

Overall, while some things were surprising and delicious (uni, watching the head chef mix together the rice just so, listening to Bob Marley on the sound system), I don't think I'd venture back.  This is more of a sushi-beginner place, with lots of rolls and a basic selection of fish.  It's a shame though, because I feel like the chef has the chops to do a lot with fancier cuts of fish...Most customers order lots of rolls and dunk liberally into soy sauce.  (All the more reason the uni was so surprising!  We ordered after we saw the chef put together an order for another table.)

This is a decent neighborhood spot, but not a sushi destination.  Since it's not in our 'hood, we won't be back.
author: Alicia C.

description:
This is my 2nd attempt to eat at Sushi Zone. Attempt #1 ended in failure after waiting for an hour with no table in sight. Weep not, dear friends, for we knew what we were getting into. To get into this place is like a mission in itself. 

Tonight we only had to wait for an hour before finally being seated. The place is small and packs in a few parties. We ordered some nigiri, seaweed salad and a few rolls. 

Seaweed salad - tastes as delicious as anywhere I've had seaweed salad. I've either been lucky or seaweed salad is always delicious. I do hope it is the latter of the two.

Rolls - the spicy mussel roll (with cilantro & lime) sounded much better on paper than it did on the tastebuds. Although I had just come down from an artichoke roll, so it tasted more vinegary than I would have liked. Shame. The california rolls had chunks of crab, and the spicy tuna was heavy on the wasabi but mighty tasty going down. 

Nigiri - have to say that this was the star of the night. We had salmon, tuna and yellowtail and all were fresh as they come - I see from other reviews that others were not so lucky, which is a shame, as what I had tonight was delicious. 

I have to admit that I am not sure I would be willing to queue up every night to go here, but I definitely enjoyed what i had here tonight. It is cash only, but there is an ATM machine a couple of doors up on Market that is within jogging distance. 

Oh yeah and when they say this place is on Market? Such a lie! It's more like Pearl than Market, so if you are like me, look up the side of Pearl and Market, and there shall you find the oyster.
author: Catriona C.

description:
*3.5-4 stars*

I LOVE the small restaurant atmosphere, I LOVE the sign-in, i LOVE the selection.

[THUMBS DOWN]:
I really don't like the sashimi.  I got the sake and tako; and for $10 for 4 pieces, I really expected it to be fresh and not have a bad lingering taste.

The spicy hamachi wasn't spicy..and fell flat on taste.  

The mango hamachi roll was ehh...i can barely remember how it tasted--that says ALOT!  

[THUMBS UP]
The spider roll was delicious!! I wish we got that first though--by that time, I was full and couldn't eat more then 2 pieces, and really wanted more...

[THUMBS IN-THE-MIDDLE]:
The hawaiian roll was ok--I really like the crunchiness of the mac nuts.  

Next time, I want to hamachi kama and salmon kama!
author: Jac T.

description: Once you try the Baked Bass, you'll become a sushi snob
author: Alejandro G.

description: dont go there starving because chances are that you will have to wait a long time before you can be sit. The place is small and there's only one waitress, one sushi chef and another guy who does the baking dishes, salads etc. so it is a small production but my God it's worth the wait! every single roll was delicious and fresh. the baked bass and baked mussels where amazing too. We ended up ordering more rolls than we usually do maybe because we were starving also the rolls are not huge but they are cheap so everything works out. the service is great. even though the place is packed and there are many people anxiously waiting the woman who is the waiter is always nice, helpful and understanding. so yay1
author: Vanderbird V.

description:
I don't know whether to rank this one star or five stars. 

I've waited three hours here but it's the best darn sushi in SF. Seriously, BEST SUSHI IN SF. 

PLEASE don't go to sushi zone. If I have to wait four hours for my head might expload.

Thanks.
author: SF I.

description:
Tips: NOT good for groups over 3 people. There are only two booths that hold 6 people max if you squish, so waiting for those are a huge pain (what our group had to go through...). Huge pain = 2 hours w/o breaking a sweat.

First Impressions: 3/5. I really did not like the name... but had high hopes because quite a few friends had been here and claimed they loved it (even the hipstery ones). The location was also pretty awkwardly hidden, but that's something that I knew i had to deal with regarding all places in SF. I did like how intimate the setting was though. It even felt casual & secluded when inside despite being so popular w/ its the roughly 800 reviews already written on Yelp.

Decor/Ambiance: 4/5. My first impression was a 3/5 because everything did look very average, but I could honestly see myself going to this place quite often at every chance I got, so based on my preferences of the ideal sushi bar, I added another star. It's cramped, but things seem all the more fun that way in the city I've found. The interior isn't sparkling new or anything, but I really appreciated the down-to-earth, humble feel. It's probably not what I'd recommend for a first-date kinda place (especially w/ the long wait on most times), but it's almost a great hole-in-the-wall discovery if SF weren't so hipstery to know about it already, haha.

Service: 4/5. Just from my first visit, I could tell everyone working there was old-staff. The way they communicated, greeted old customers... everything was very fluid and everyone was well-trained, so there weren't any mess-ups at all. There was only one waitress too, and she was able to spot that I was a newcomer and immediately guide me to their little whiteboard of sign-ins. Throughout our wait, she would also check on us from time to time and apologized for the wait even though they really didn't have to. I always appreciate service a lot more when the staff is still able to respect customers despite the unwavering stream of success. It's good karma if anything else! During dinner, the waitress was also experienced enough to tell us that we probably had not ordered enough food for the group, and she was right on the money. Had she just written our orders down and let the events fall as they would, we would've either left hungry or be forced to wait a while for just one more serving. I appreciated that she didn't force it on us, but casually brought up the idea to let us decide for ourselves. The staff at Sushi Zone definitely made me want to come visit again, support their business, and become a regular.

Food: 4/5.
Baked Bass Appetizer (Mango, Spicy Mayo, & Fish Eggs, $6.50): 4.5/5. This was definitely unlike anything I'd ever had at a sushi restaurant, and I've been to so many. The texture was so smooth and it was served in such a unique way... no wonder it cost so much!
Rolls. The only slight disappointment was that the rice didn't taste as fresh as it could've been, but for a busy restaurant, I understand this is all about timing sometimes. The presentation for most rolls was also a bit muted, but I know they're not looking to seriously WOW people with art and whatnot... that's not what they're going for and definitely not their first priority.
Spicy Tuna: 3/5. This was probably the 2nd most average thing ordered but a necessity for a few friends to order anyway.
Spicy Himachi: 3/5. Nothing too special... the 3rd most average?
Spicy Mango Salmon: 2/5. This was the most average thing we ordered, but we just chose it under pressure when the waitress hinted we didn't order enough. I wouldn't recommend this.
Hawaiian Roll #1 (Tuna, Avacado, Scallion, Mayo Sauce w/ Macadamia Nuts): 4.5/5. I loved this one! What a breath of fresh air it was to even be able to choose something seriously different and unexpected. Ok, maybe it's because I haven't been to Hawaii, but this was delicious. I'm definitely going to try the HR#2 next time I visit.
Papaya Unagi: 4/5. Also very unique and definitely worth a try too. It's amazing how complimentary papaya can be to bbq eel, flavor and texture-wise. It took me a while to wrap my head around this one in a good way!
Spider Roll: 3/5. This was a bit dry (rice & soft shell crab), and I was left with the unfortunate task of eating one of the end-roll pieces where the crab head and legs were sticking out. I have arachnophobia so this was a big feat (it seriously looked like a spider was crawling out of both ends...), but I took one for the team because I think everyone else in my party had arachnophobia, haha.

Overall: 4/5. While many of the rolls are just rated 3/5, I'd still give them another chance, and this says a lot because we waited for about 2 hours! Realistically, this place isn't worth the 2 hour wait, but on SF terms, I'd wait an hour for it assuming waiting 30min is normal for most restaurants during dining hours.
author: F C.

description:
Amazing. Delicious. Heart-stopping.

The sushi here is so incredibly good that I can't remember much else from the 2+ hours we spent around the tiny hole-in-the-wall on a Tuesday evening. We put our names down at around 6:30pm, sat down at the bar around 7:15pm and got our food about 7:50pm. Patience is a virtue.

But sweet Science, the food is positively, unequivocally and ludicrously excellent. The fresh tuna sashimi (maguro) was some of the best I've had in my life (and I've had a lot of sushi, though never been to Japan), the salmon was tender and savory and the wasabi doesn't mess around--completely clean sinuses and ample eye-watering on the first bite.

The spicy mango salmon roll was surprisingly wonderful and a welcome departure from the typical sushi fare. Even the old standby California roll (though with real crab) was very tasty and worth every penny.

Our waitress (the only one) was pleasant and friendly, chatting with us for a few minutes after things settled down a bit. There are precisely 8 seats at the bar (5 on one side and 3 on the other side of an L shape) and 4 seats at each of two booths, giving a grand total of 16 dining seats, which are constantly filled.

On top of all that, the prices are entirely fair for sushi--not nearly as much as we've paid for "nice" sushi elsewhere, but the quality is among the best. Needless to say, I *highly* recommend Sushi Zone if you have the time, patience and inclination to experience truly incredible sushi.
author: Brad F.

description:
I went here last week at around 6PM and found a place for two right away, which I guess its rare for this place according to previous reviews.
First of all, my friend and I were super hungry and were really looking forward to this place.
There is only 1 sushi chef, which is fine because I've been to other sushi places in the city with 1 chef and the food comes out quickly...or so thought. We order our food and it literally didn't come out till 45 minutes later.
Needless to say we scarfed our meal down. 
The sushi was just alright (California roll was runny, the other rolls were mediocre, the best thing I had here was the miso soup!) I have had fresher and faster sushi in the city.

So I recommend this place if you're not hungry at all and are willing to wait about an hour until you are to eat this sushi.
author: Brenda I.

description: This place is a total find. It is cute and tiny, with a small sushi bar and a couple of booths. Great service and staff.  Reggae and Latino music plays in the background. The food is creative and absolutely delicious. I highly recommend the tuna stuffed mushrooms. Also reasonably priced. The only problem is there usually is a long wait, so get there ahead of time to put your name on the list. It is worth the wait!
author: Mia M.

description:
Food: 4
Service: 3

We arrived at 4:45PM and stood in line for the 5PM opening. We didn't get seated until 6:15PM and didn't receive our rolls until 6:45PM. There are only two 4-person tables and 7 seats around the sushi bar total. Expect a long wait to get seated.

Good sushi rolls once we were seated. Didn't try the sashimi.  Fish and eel cuts were tasty and not drowned out by sauces.

Cash only. Cheap rolls with a little too much rice per roll.

You'll have a shorter wait and similar quality at a number of other locations. Food was good, but the long wait detracted from the overall night.
author: LookingAtCars L.

description: Always be prepared to wait for a seat at this place. Its very small with only two booths, and about ten seats at the bar. However, well worth the wait. Put your name on the board and walk down to the bar on Market to wait. This place is super laid back, but the sushi is absolutely divine. I'd have to say, some of the best in San Francisco, if not THE BEST. Just find some time and go, you won't be disappointed unless you're a prude. And they don't want you there anyway, so go someplace else with your prudishness personality. Try everything because it's all so, so very delicious and fresh and magnificent in every way! Muah!
author: John A.

description:
This place has scrumptious sushi! My favorite was the Hawaiian role #2 with mango, macadamia nuts, avocado, and tuna-- a little slice of heaven!
The owner/ waitress were so kind and personable!  The only drawback to this place is that it is discovered and the waits are long. We waited almost 2 hours for a table for 4 last night. But I have to say, the food was worth it. Super high quality fish!
author: Oona Q.

description:
Yum, yum, yummy!!!

It's not the most fancy sushi spot, but I guarantee you, the line is worth the wait. I was blessed to live in the same block from this hidden Gem on Pearl Street and Market. I was spoiled growing up in this neighborhood until I move back in 2005. 

Baked Mango Seabass umm...it's one of their specialties. The owner is super friendly which btw, is the main guy making your sushi. Their staff is always so hip and cute might I add. It's not the typical sushi spot...besides being delicious, it's trendy and hip.

Keep an eye out since this spot is easily missed even though it says Market Street. It's on Pearl Street, just the corner of Market but the place is not exactly on the corner.

Enjoy everyone!
author: Jules V.

description: Can I just say the best sushi I've ever had...so far!  Melt in your mouth goodness! My suggestions are the Hawaiian #2, mango hamachi, and stuffed jalepeno.  Well worth the long wait and their prices are reasonable for the portion size.  Next time I will try to get there right when they open to avoid the long wait.  Definitely coming back!
author: Janelle D.

description:
Best sushi place I've been in the States! Wait is long unless you show up half an hour before the restaurant is open to line up... But we always hop into the bar next door to kill some waiting time, which turned out not too bad.
Appetizers are very tasty - my favorites are the mussels and the mushrooms. Love that they put sprouts in sushi. all fish and seafood are fresh and well prepared. I small note is that the chef tends to like put lots of wasabi underneath the fish, so if you can't handle much (like me) tell them to put less!! (lesson learned... but sushi are still yummy)
author: Yao A.

description:
Good things come to those who wait!!!!

Just put your name down, order a drink and sit back and relax with your friends until you are eventually summoned to your table!!!!

I love the place and know what to expect when i go here and so prepare mentally that i will not be eating as soon as i walk in the door. 

The wait can break you sometimes, many a comrade has fallen to the side whilst waiting for food here. I believe as legend has it that Sushi Zone uses an old method of Japanese torture testing those who walk through the door, and for those who pass this laborious task will be greatly rewarded......

Good Luck!!!
author: jae f.

description:
YOU WIN MY HEART AGAIN.
wait sucks yes i know, but there is this cool travel book shop across the little street plus the waitress is nice and will let you order drinks while you wait even thought there is no bar.
author: Skye W.

description: You gotta, you really gotta try the baked bass. Jesus they are holy!
author: Ferra Lee D.

description:
At first, I nearly walked by and missed it because it doesn't look like your typical japanese sushi place - it feels more like an old school diner which is kind of cool. it is pretty cramped inside with just 2 booths by the window and an L shaped diner counter with stools facing the sushi chefs.  

we got the baked bass and the hawaiian roll#2 based on the other reviews and they were surprisingly good. i agree the fish is no longer the star in the roll because of the mound of crushed macadamian nuts on top.

the nigiri pieces were cut larger than other sushi places which i appreciated but it didn't sit well with me. for example, the lime on the sake nigiri that started to "cook" through the fish like ceviche, or the mint that was placed under the scallop nigiri. when i get nigiri or sashimi, i just want straight up fish and a little wasabi - i don't really care for the extra stuff on top - but experimenting with rolls is fine.
author: Annie c.

description:
If you are looking for an over priced sushi place with expensive decor and ambient lighting etc.etc.... This is not the place for you.
      It can take a while to get seated, and it can take a while to get your food, but it is totally worth the wait. Try the baked mango sea bass, and the Hawaiian #2 Roll.
author: V M.

description: Great little hole in the wall Sushi Bar, the tuna is always super fresh tasting and I love the rolls with mango. Get here early though, the lines are long and seats few, still there are a couple good bars around to get drinks at while you wait.
author: Zachary S.

description: It is hard to put less than 5 star to sushi zone. I have been there twice, it is always super frustrating to wait hours for a table but it is always worth it. Fish is super fresh, appetizers rock, maki are amazing.
author: Boris H.

description: It's not that great.....small ass establishment and ehh. I hella remember the mussels only came with 3 pieces smh....To be honest I barely remember what I ordered here cuz obviously it wasn't the best. I think I got the Hawaiian #1 and #2 rolls....didn't like the macadamia nuts on there with their sweet sauce, but if I had to pick one roll the mango hamachi was the only good thing that I got here.
author: Diane L.

description: This place is amazing. Expect to wait more than an hour. The place seats 8 at the bar and has 2 tables that seat 4. Once you are seated the sushi chef serves parts of orders to diners so there is a constant flow of food. Now these are not your usual rolls they are really big. I had 4 rolls and I thought I was going  to explode. But I enjoyed every bite.And the four gigantic rolls cost me $40
author: Pinner B.

description:
Yup, the wait sucks and if you want to complain about it and not come back, that is fine with me.  I live a couple blocks away and have been there so much, I can almost time the wait perfectly.   I kind of feel bad for the people who have been waiting for two hours when I walk in and immediately get seated.  :)  

Anyway, they finally fixed the menu board to clarify it's baked striped bass, not sea bass.  Of course it's awesome.  We tried the baked mussels, which was also good.  I also like the spicy hamachi roll and seaweed salad.
author: Brian Y.

description: I want to marry Sushi Zone and have a million of its babies. That being said, don't come here, the line is too long already.
author: Susie D.

description:
Let me tell you, a Yelper's picture of a luxurious dish served at Sushi Zone has been standing for months on my laptop desktop and it was unavoidable that I would have soon or late ended up there.   

Everything I had was excellent: vegetarian sushi with avocado and artichoke (only remark: the light flavour of the vinegar in which artichokes had been soaked was a bit odd in a sushi), albacore/ginger and hamachi/scallion/avocado maki rolls, halibut sushi pair. My gf's tuna/mango/mayo was original, but what's the use of putting mayo in it?  My friend's mussel/avocado/scallion maki roll was awesome.

Great place if you crave for some creative sushi but, be warned: your patience will be wildly challenged by the long waiting time, which is inversely proportional to the restaurant size and staff's pace. I haven't tried the dish in the above mentioned picture though :-(
author: Andrea L.

description:
Ok, I take it back -- this place wasn't overhyped, I just didn't order right the first time.  THIS TIME I read the Yelp reviews and noted what I should order.  And it was SUBLIME.  Thank you Yelp.  Thank you thank you thank you.

We had the baked mussels -- which, seriously guys, you MUST try.  Holy LORD -- the Hawaiian roll #2, salmon skin roll, salmon nigiri, and eel nigiri.  It was all AMAZING.  Especially the baked mussels and the Hawaiian roll.  Wait, let me say "baked mussels" a few more times.  Baked mussels.  Baked mussels?  Baked mussels!  Marry me, baked mussels.

Oh, the wait was still 45 minutes.  On a Tuesday night.  But this time I was prepared, and filled up with Girl Scout cookies beforehand ;)
author: Sarah B.

description:
2 people - 2 appetizers, 4 rolls: ~$30-40

This is your definition of hole-in-the-wall sushi place in SF. First of all, they open at 5pm and the entire place only fits about 15-20 people MAX. I arrived at ~5:10pm and the place was filled with a 45min wait time. Seeing as we came specifically to try this place out, we waited 45mins and were seated at the bar thereafter (do not come with more than 3 people ~ you will never get seated!) 

The menu is relatively small but the specials change all the time! (well they ARE daily specials! =P ) We got the baked mussels and baked scallops for appetizers which were DELISH as my friend likes to say. It's only 2 peices for ~$3-5 but it was really good. Also, they reuse the mussel shells that the appetizers are served on (eco-friendly!)... I still haven't quite decided whether or not that's a good thing. 

The actual rolls were ~$5-7 for 4-8 pieces. The ingredients are really fresh (ie. the fish) which made the sushi good which in turn made my taste buds ecstatic. The rolls taste more authentic than sushi house or little tokyo and the place feels really authentic (it's as if the 4 employees just came straight from Japan and found a small, rinky dinky place to rent and set up shop). 

I doubt you will find another place like this in the city so it's a must try. The rolls here were also unique (a couple used MANGO in their rolls which were REALLY GOOD; highly recommended). If you have time, come and try this place with 1 other person and preferably arrive before 5pm!
author: Brian L.

description:
Mango and macadamia nuts are sure to expand your sushi horizons when you go to Sushi Zone ... I loved the crunch that the macadamia added to the sushi. 

After waiting 2+ hours for this place, I'm certain it tasted good for two reasons:  the fish was extremely fresh and ... I was fucking starving?

I wish they had some spicier rolls. They had one with jalapeno which was pretty tasty. I wish they had some spicy mayo or somethin' to jazz the simpler rolls up!
author: Frances L.

description:
This place gets full *quick*. I figured that me and a friend could possibly get seats with little wait at around 5:30, we didn't get a spot until about 6:30 or so. That's 30 minutes after opening, you're already confined to the second shift of customers. So if you want a seat quickly, pretty much come before opening.

In addition, as there's limited staff (my night there was one chef, one assistant, and one waitress), it means you're going to have to endure another wait for your order to come out after you get your seats. I'm not sure we got our eats until about 7:15 or so.

But okay, you should know that small places always equal long waits. Is the sushi worth the wait? For me, the answer is a resounding yes. The menu here is a bit more experimental than the standard CA/Rainbow rolls you're probably used to. We tried their papaya/BBQ eel and their Hawaiian #2 (sprinkled generously with macadamia nuts) rolls, both of which worked well! There's no taste like experimental sushi done well.

Oh man, and the prices here! So reasonable. I was honestly shocked to see the bill at the end of the night, it was about 30 for a large beer + 3 rolls. That's a fantastic value.

I'll be hitting this place up more with my more patient friends.
author: Roland C.

description: This is definitely a restaurant worth visiting more than once. The lines can get incredibly long so showing up to wait before the store opens is a must, especially on weekend nights. If you are showing up with a group larger than six people (as I have before) it will be difficult to get seated at the same table at the same time, so smaller groups fare better here. Plus they refuse to seat groups unless your entire party is present. My vegetarian friends love the avocado and mango roll they make, and my Mom who is super picky about Japanese food absolutely loves this place. I make it a point to always order the baked mussels and either the plum wine or some hot sake with whatever rolls I am getting. This is an adorable little joint that is completely worth the wait but even better when you get seated as they open. Plus dessert is always close by if you don't mind going to the nearby Smitten.
author: Aileen M.

description:
I'm still in love with this tiny gem. 
Met up with one of my fave gal-pals here for a 
much needed chat and a bite. As always the wait 
was ridiculous. But, that allowed us time to catch up 
and gossip about boys, life, love, earrings and everything 
else under the sun. The saba was perfection, and of course 
you HAVE TO order the mussels when visiting Sushi Zone. 
Afterwards we walked over to Orbit room for fruity libations 
muddled by the cutest hipster-boy duo I've laid eyes on 
in a while. . . . 
*swoon*
author: Kia B.

description:
seriously, take the other yelper's advice and don't come here.  i don't want to wait any longer than I already had to...

in all seriousness, this is the best, no bullshit, sushi i've had since moving to the bay area.  you won't find any of the sauce drenched fru-fru, tiger/dragon/catepillar/(other animal) rolls here.  just good, authentic stuff.

its super tiny so not really ideal for groups of 4 or more.  the sushi chefs are all japanese which is a super good thing in my book.

but anyway, stop reading about how great this place is.  i don't need more people going.

thanks.
author: Sally T.

description:
We came here early to try to avoid the long wait most people here talk about. Ended up waiting about 2 hours for a table. 

Yes, I understand it's a small place. But no, the waiting continues. 

Sit down. Takes 30 mins for someone to even come by to take our drink orders. By then, we're ready to order because we're starving. We figure, we'll put some orders in and add on. 

1 hour later, food comes.  We noticed there was a moment where NO ONE in the place had any food in front of them. 

We're still starving but don't dare risking ordering more. 

I've been into places equal in size as this place, and it should not take this long. even simple nigiri sushi. i counted 3 "chefs" behind the counter. but where's the food? 

for all the positive reviews of this place, sorry... i don't know what your standard is for eating quality sushi with great service. and i've eaten at hole in the wall places here and in japan. i waited 2 hours to eat at a place in the tsukiji fish market... and when i finally sat down and ordered. it came in 10 minutes. the chef prepared it in front of me! 

you want to know why you wait so long for a table? because the slow ass kitchen doesn't know how to work efficiently.
author: Sean L.

description: KAKA KAKA, get some KAMA!!! Long wait, but the baked stuff was good.
author: Rainbowz R.

description: I was really surprised I found a good Japanese restaurant in San Francisco.  This is definitely one of them.  The place is really small so you have to be really lucky to get seated in a reasonable time.  I think the place has maybe 14 seats.  I basically ordered all the sashimi and nigiri and a couple rolls.  All the fish was fresh and cut well.  The seasoning was done right too.  And th wasabi paste will definitely help clear your nose.  You'll leave happy your wallet didn't get a big dent.  Cash only is a big negative.  The other big negative is the food comes out really slowly.
author: Byron L.

description: We were aware that there was a wait for this place so we came prepared. 6pm we put our name on the board, we were a group of 4 so we could only use one of the two booths they have. 1 hour goes by, no bigs. 2 hours, sure why not! We are monitoring our name on the list and knew we had to wait for one more table then it was us! We went over to the pisco bar next door for a drink. The entire time we sent runners over to keep an eye on our spot. We got the green light and ran over. It was 3 hours later at this point. We watch the table before us leave and wait for the hostess. While we were out we noticed the wait list was rewritten but my name was still at the top. However this other group walks in and said they were next. The hostess claims she 'remembers them'. They shove my friend out of the way and sit down. I was shocked. I explained we had been waiting for much longer than this other group who said they had been waiting for 2 hours. I showed the hostess my four square checkin that was 3 hours earlier. The hostess finally admits she made the mistake but still lets the other group sit before us. Watching the other group eat just made us more upset so we booked it out there. Never again.
author: Renata S.

description:
Undeniably THEE best sushi you can get in the city. It's fresh, it's made with care - it's delicious. What more could you ask for? Yes, I'm well aware of the wait, but believe me and the many other yelpers - it is WELL worth it. If you wait in line outside before the restaurant opens you can pretty much guarantee yourself a spot when the doors open and if not, put your name on the list and chill at the bar around the corner. 

The food, the friendly atmosphere, the cozy feel, the prices.. You really can't go wrong here. And even though I don't want to give away yet another 5 star review to talk about how awesome this place is in fear of the lines being even longer.. Everyone should really know about this treasure!

Just remember to bring cash and your smiling face. Cheers!
author: Tay R.

description: We were fresh off a flight from Japan and the first meal we wanted was at Sushi Zone. This place has the best sushi in the world! Gotta try the jalapeno ahi appetizer. Accommodates vegans beautifully. And you can watch the master chef at work. Limited seating but worth the wait. Cash only.
author: Travln B.

description:
How do I say this eloquently?

Hmmmm, here goes:

F You Sushi Ran.
F You Zushi Puzzle.
F You Godzilla Sushi.
F You King of the Roll.

You all suck big fat Unagi.

Sushi Zone makes me want to do a back handspring over the sushi bar and stick my face in some cold, wet Hamachi.

I cried a little bit during my first bite of Nigiri.  I wept softly when I slurped down my first baked striped Sea Bass with Mango from its beautiful shell.  I sobbed quite violently and scarily (although that probably had more to do with my current set of issues than with the actual food) when I sucked down my first Spicy Hamachi w/ Jalapeno roll.

That said, this place is panty dropping good... and as you know, I don't drop them like they're hot for just anyone.

Shut it, JT.

Disclaimer:

Sushi Ran, Zushi Puzzle, Godzilla Sushi and King of the Roll are actually all delicious establishments.  However, I can't be held responsible if you go and they are actually sucking big fat Unagi.  After all, sucking Unagi IS kinda fun... 

PS.  If you ever take Sammy S. to Sushi, be sure to make her drink hot Sake.  Her facial expressions are worth 5 stars alone.
author: Rachel G.

description:
SUSHI. I mean everyone has different standards and palettes for what constitutes for great sushi. Mine is really uncomplicated; fresh, simple and atypical food that is unpretentious. So I come to Sushi Zone for that. Place sites roughly 15-18 seats max. Opens at 5pm. Its in your best interest to get there for the first round of seating at that time otherwise you're gonna have to wait for another 45-75 mins before getting another seat, depending on how many groups are ahead of you and what kind of pace they're at for eating dinner. 

I always order the baked oysters. They're sooo good that I sometimes convince myself that this is how oysters really taste out the water so whenever i eat oysters and they ain't served like this I get mildy disgusted. I know, sucks for me... 

Another favorite that is sure to not disappoint are the Hawaiian Rolls. I mean the main combination of Tuna and Macadamia nuts makes me go crazy. Every bite is causes commotion in my mouth like when the green light hits at the Shibuya crossings in Tokyo. Madness coupled with ear to ear smiles. The sakes are pretty good too. They pretty much keep the same ones in stock so I usually get whatever the waitress recommends. 
Hats off to the Taisho that makes all the food. One man makes 90% of the food so you know its going to be consistent every time you go. This is how sushi is made in most intimate sushi bars in Japan anyways. One guy who keeps tabs on your pace and does his best to get the food coming in one course after the next is the customary norm for Nihon dining. I wish i lived on Pearl St so I can eat there more often.
author: Nick V.

description: Not the best sushi in town, but definitely worth a stop or two if you're into sushi. Dude needs to hire an assistant sushi chef. When this place is packed and it's always is, the old man is struggling!! U can tell by the look on his face !  Our food came out  sooooooo slow and in 5 or 6 different times . Our total time including waiting was over three hours!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Seriously come here within 30 minutes of opening, this place can kill ur entire evening.
author: Demanding T.

description:
I'm conflicted: 4.5 stars.

I ate here after a recommendation from a friend, and purposely set it after a day I had to take a big test. It was what I looked forward to for a whole week. 

My boyfriend and I got here at 4:30PM (we did yelp research coming here) but we were still the 6th and 7th persons in line. The restaurant smelled good even in line. We got seated at 5, and ordered: 

1. Mango Hamachi- Good.
2. Hawaiian #2- Good. Very generous with the macadamia nuts.
3. Rock 'n Roll- Good.
4. Nasu nigiri- Delectable. This dish alone attracted a lot of stares. Its aroma was amazing.
5. Baked Sea Bass appetizer- Forgettable. A little salty, and too little bass. 
6. Miso soup- is miso soup. 

Everything was good, but not as good as I expected. BUT, I couldn't stop thinking about their sushi afterwards. I think my unconscious is telling me that I secretly loved the place and was playing hard to get. 

We sat at the bar, and we loved how we got to see the chef prepare each order. He has amazing skills. There is only one main chef, so the orders took a while to complete. I think he has a patterned way of serving the tables. 

Food was fresh. Great place, great price. Place opens at 5PM and closes at 9:30PM. Small place, come early with small party if during peak hours. Have fun & ITADAKIMASU!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Really good sushi (I very rarely say this) -- coming form someone who's lived in Japan for nine months.  The service is rather slow, as they have only one chef.  Expect around two hours from the time you arrive to the time you have sushi plated in from of you.

Try their rock'n'roll, it's fantastic.
author: Bill T.

description:
Don't talk to me bitches! I'm in the Zone.

No you fools! Not The Zone weight lost program, because if I was on that The Zone, you better believe I'd consider YOU a "good carb" and eat your mother truckin ass fo breakfast.

K, I'm white, I'm Jewish and I don't work out....ever....so really, there is no need for me to talk like this. I'll just tell you straight up how it is.

Sushi Zone=oral sex in the hot tub while eating a dip cone good . Simple as that (nose plugs, invest). 

Baked sea bass with mango? Are you kidding me? I almost cried and "you know whated" (yes I'm a big fat prude) at the same time. Sorry mom and dad, but the only way to describe this shell of heaven is to relate it to mind blowing sex. The sea bass and mango are baked in a mussel shell, and for some magical reason that I won't question, it tastes like there is cheese on the top. I'm swooning, or actually, it's more like I'm being saved and I'm having epileptic fits like those women with the fans who speak in tongues at church.

Spicy Hamachi roll: orgasm 1
Albacore, avocado, mango roll with macadamia nuts sprinkled on top: Orgasm 2...all I'm gonna say is "bucking."
Salmon nigiri: like having your hair pulled by a bad, bad man
Albacore nigiri: legs quivering
Hamachi nigiri: I need a cigarette. And make sure it's a 100.

This review is shameless and wrong...who wants to go to Sushi Zone for dinner?
author: Sammy S.

description:
Sushi Zone has 2 small tables, a sushi bar, and a great reputation.  So you're gonna wait, but you're gonna love it.

Thorough some magic stroke of luck (I like to call it karma), we arrived at 6:15 on a Thursday night, and there was no wait.  Soooo happy!

We knew that the masses were probably on their way, so we got our order in quickly.  Luckily, my very savvy friend knew exactly what to order.  Soooo happy!

We had:  Spicy Hamachi Roll, Spicy Scallop Roll, Hawaii Roll #2, Hot Stuffed Mushrooms, Hot Stuffed Mussels.  All were fantastic!!  I especially loved the Hawaii Roll with the chopped macadamia nuts on top - very unusual.  Soooo happy!

There is one guy who makes the sushi, and one guy who makes the hot dishes.  One woman serves all customers including the sushi bar.  You can imagine how easily things can get bottlenecked.  We got our order in just at the right time, before any of the larger parties ordered and after the other customers had finished.  So everything came out quickly and we scarfed it down gleefully, with me making lots of nummy noises.  Everything was so fresh and perfectly seasoned.  Sooooo happy!

With drinks, we made it out of there for about $25pp, and in less than 30 minutes, so within plenty of time to see our 7:30 movie in Japantown.  

Soooo happy!

This is what I looked like upon leaving, as I made my way past the now-growing line:
:)
author: Liz S.

description:
My hotate, ankimo, and toro were expertly prepared and delicious, but I have to swim against the current on this one with *only* 3 stars.

We took every precaution:
Arrive early, cash in hand, knowing what to order ahead of time. We were seated immediately, with high hopes and great expectations.

It took over 45 minutes to get our food from the time we ordered. The fish likely took less time to get there from the ocean than it took to get from the cutting board to my plate. For nigiri.

Waiting 45 minutes for seating is fine. You can bail if your patience runs out. Waiting that long after ordering, with no attempt to refill water or tea, is inexcusable. 

I can't wait to taste what must be phenomenal when fresh. Literally. I can't wait.
author: Andy R.

description:
VLADIMIR:
    Words words. (Pause.) Speak. 
BOY:
    (in a rush). Mr. Godot told me to tell you he won't come this evening but surely tomorrow.

Not sure what is worse, waiting for Sushi Zone or waiting for Godot...
author: Dave G.

description: The food was great. Everything was fresh and delicious. Had the baked  muscles which were delicious. Spicy scallop was fresh to the point that it melted in your mouth! This place is teeny tiny and if your entire party isn't there...be ready to wait. So tell your friends if they aren't on time, they shouldn't bother hanging out there and should meet you after dinner. Just kidding! But all kidding aside make sure to have your entire party there and prepare to bring cash! They do not take credit!
author: Linda L.

description: Went here on my way home from a meeting, excited by the positive reviews. Place was okay but not up to the hype at all. My soup was just okay, edamame good and the.rainbow roll loose and skimpy for the high price. Place was tiny and noisy with everyone on top of each other, and they didn't take credit cards. I can understand the last part, if it's a cheap eatery but this want. Fail to see why they line up outside the door. Not horrible but simply not 4.5 stars.
author: Pachamama J. B.

description:
I went to Sushi Zone because EVERYONE I work with RAVES about their sushi. Up to that point, I'd only had sushi at Ino and Bistro and Red Box and Kitaro. I didn't realize what I'd been missing! Their food quality is UNRIVALED! Not only was I amazed at how fresh and delicious everything was, but the bill at the end was the best suprise of all! Everything is sooo reasonably priced!

The only caution I have is that the service is slow, so don't walk in famished expecting to get your meal within the next half hour. There was a 10 min wait between the time we were served the soup and the salad and then about a 25 minute wait before we received the entrees. But, don't let that keep you from going! The food was DEFINITELY worth waiting for!
author: Stanley K.

description: Believe the hype. This place lives up to its reputation for serving fresh sushi. Get there early to avoid a long long line.  Like with the Indian food in this city, Sushi is hit or miss. In Boston I felt like they were mostly quality, here you really have to choose wisely.  Sushi Zone sounds like a cheap name for such quality sushi, don't let that fool you.
author: Mark S.

description: Yummy sushi.  Everything is great here, especially the specials.  Minus one star for the almost 2 hr wait and teeny seating area (but cozy).  Get here early and remember to sign your name in--first thing! Grab a beer at the bar next door while you wait. :)
author: Kay T.

description:
You've got to have plenty of patience for Sushi Zone. And for those of us who do, this place is well-worth it! And you've got to have a plan.

After walking by this place and ALWAYS seeing it crowded inside with people (eating and/or waiting), and a crowd outside (waiting), we finally made the plunge and worked our way inside to get our names on to "the list." And that's the key thing to a successful dinner here, GET YOUR NAME ON TO "THE LIST." Do not be shy, do not be intimidated, don't hesitate and then let any more people get listed before you. 

Then for "the wait," try to get to some of the "waiting stools," or there is also a small bench by the door. Plant yourself and ask the friendly waitress for an ice-cold Japanese beer (I am loving Sapporo) and a bowl of Edamame. A nice way to make that wait not so painful (also a nice time to catch up on reading that novel or gossip rag). And you may have to wait outside, and if it's cold outside you gotta have something comfy and warm to wrap around you and your date.

Once we got to one of the 2 booths, we knew exactly what we wanted and got the order in lickety-split (that means quickly). We also got some recommendations from the waitress for the appetizers, and she dazzled us with some delicious dishes.

And then once the Sushi and Sashimi arrived, all was well with the world. All fresh, all delicious, can't say enough about how much we all enjoyed the meal.

And now I that I've got the hang of it....I will let my inner Sushi-Warrior take me again to Sushi Zone.
author: Mickey A.

description: So worth the hour wait. The Hawaiian # 2, seabass, and the scallop roll were absolutely yummy.
author: Parichehr M.

description:
Oh my gaaaawwwd Muriel, the wait! The wait! It's sooo looooowwwng :)

Despite my complaining inner Jewish grandma and the hour and a half wait for dead fish, I really enjoyed this place and it was by far one of the better sushi experiences I've had in "The City." The fish was super fresh. I mean, really really super duper fresh. Like when he was slicing the fish it almost looked sexy and erotic, it was that fresh. And once the pieces arrived on our little plates and made fast friends with our mouths, oh yes, that is some damn good sushi!

Highlights were definitely the scallops and the hamachi and the cooked sea bass and mango dealios on the shells. Yum! Wasn't all too impressed with the albacore and mango roll as it had waaaaay too much wasabi on it. Yikes, burnin my mouth!

As for the rest, the place is a shoe box and the only thing I'd like to put out to the masses who come here is, if you are two people sitting at a table for four, why not look around and invite another two some to share the table. It's tiny, the wait is forever and haven't you ever heard of a little thing called family style? Sheesh!
author: Stephy S.

description:
The whole time I was waiting in that fucking hilarious line of people in front of this place I was thinking, you wait in line and then they finally seat you after nearly three hours?  And then they make you wait another two hours to have dinner?  I call bullshit.  No way am I going to be able to enjoy a meal after waiting that long.  And there's no way sushi is that good, no matter how cheap it is.

Too bad I was totally right,
author: Honey L.

description:
The fish was really fresh and delicious. Absolutely no complaints.
