However, what kind of place is this?   Who has min 2 hour to waist in the line for food?

Waiting over two hours for food is ridiculous.  We got there at 7:00 and didn't get seated until 8:30... the wait took forever cause this spot is so tiny. Once we were seated, the waitress took our order and then it took another 45min for our food to arrive. Definitely won't be back,  I have better things to do with my time.
author: Kim C.

description:
I want to rate this down a star seeing that every time I come here, there's about a 1 in 3 chance that I'm going to wait that long to be seated. I spend that hour or more putting around, trying not to eat and restless in anticipation

And once I taste those delectable morsels of sushi, I fall in love again. Hamachi Nigiri, you have my heart and my devotion. 

This is my love-hate relationship with Sushi Zone. Just don't order a California Roll, the Sushi Gods will not have mercy on you.
author: Ryan V.

description:
It's all been said before, but I'll vouch for the rest in one sentence.

The striped bass with mango and some kind of cheese that they bake on the half-shell is worth the two hour wait to get a seat in this tiny little hole in the wall, where people line up a half hour before they open, and the sushi is all top-notch, but you can get sushi of similar quality elsewhere in the city for less money and/or less of a wait.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I originally thought it was unbelievable that people rate this restaurant as high as they do... but then I realized something about sushi restaurants, and how there is a uniform break from the common rules of rating. Everyone has had a moment---a special night at one time or another at a sushi restaurants that transcended a normal dining experience... in fact, it moved them, and goes on to permanently define their opinion of the place. In a way, the restaurant becomes like family: forever in your good graces, and forgivable, for even the most serious of indiscretions... at least on some level. So, now I understand how 5 stars get thrown around with the caveat of 'oh yeah you'll wait forever, but it's cool!' line in their text.

Sushi Zone makes you wait... they make you wait, and then they encourage you to drink beers or head across the street for liquor. You're probably buzzed now, because you've been waiting for an hour, and drinking on the street with your friends. Now you've waited close to two hours, and now your hammered, and oh! Now you're sitting down to eat.

"Oh my God, this is *so* the best sushi I've ever had in the city!" the drunk girl cheered sitting at the bar.

Listen to Dan V on this one, as the fish does come from the same source... it's not your taste buds fooling you, it's the booze glossing the sushi with that magic shine. Hit any number of other restaurants in the city for a similar experience sans the wild wait times. Nothing that special here.
author: Ankarino L.

description:
Now it's becoming a standard to judge the rest.  Love the ambiance, simple, no frills, friendly.  We got there early and sat at the bar.  Baked mussels, baked bass, few rolls and finish with the nigiri.  A perfect warm up for dancing at Yoshi's!
Thank you Sushi Zone...
author: brian w.

description:
I don't care about the long wait.
I don't care about the people breathing down your neck for you to finish your meal so you they can feast.
I don't care b/c Sushi Zone is the Best!

This is NOT the place to eat if you are starving. Go here if you have time to wait and are willing to seriously enter a Sushi la la land while you taste the most delicious concoctions around!

The last time I went here I feasted w/ my mom...  We went early (5:30ish) and only waited about 30 minutes.......we had:

-Unfiltered Sake.... cold....mmmmmmm
-Edamame: (must have, not over or undercooked and salted perfectly)
-Striped bass and mango: Yum. I could eat 10 of these.
-Stuffed jalapeno, I forget the fish, but it was really good. The jalapeno wasn't hot, but crunchy and fresh and a nice addition to warm fish.
-Hawaiian #2.... can't go wrong w/ macadamia nuts, fish and avo
-Albacore Nigiri
-artichoke roll
-Spicey Hamachi Roll

Understand that this is not all served at once. Because there are only 2 tables (good for 4, but often holds 2) and a bar that seats 9 at the most, they alternate who they serve. So you'll get a roll, they get a roll, they get a roll.... and so on. It works really well b/c you eat slowly.

It really is a Zone.
author: Ariel P.

description:
To enjoy eating at Sushi Zone, you must strive to be like a Ronin Warrior...

Strive for Ryo of the Wildfire's Virtue, and have the moral excellence to be polite to the others waiting with you and not rush the others already eating.
Possess Sage of the Halo's Wisdom, and know in advance Sushi Zone only accepts cash and the waits will be long and arduous.
Have faith like Cye of the Torrent's Trust, because your name will eventually be called and your food will eventually arrive all in patient time.
Believe in Kento of Hardrock's Justice, that the waitress will not seat a party lower than you on the white board before you.
And embrace Rowen of the Strata's Life, because there are few things in life as satisfying as a meal at Sushi Zone.

Dao Jin!
author: Mercutio k.

description: Insanely good sushi. For dinner, the wait is long because there are not many seats. Definitely come early, put your name on the list, and come back. Compared to New York prices and quality, this place was a delicious bargain. Tip: make sure to order a variety of flavors. We ordered too many rolls with the spicy mayo dressing and wished we had gone with more variety. Overall though, I highly recommend Sushi Zone.
author: Mark F.

description: This place is amazing.  I'll admit, the baked bass was a bit too heavy on the mayo for my liking (it was still great).  The fish quality was absolutely superb, the portions are generous, and the preparation is tip top.  I suppose I was lucky in that I didn't have to wait (although I was eating alone while in SF for business), but there was a line for parties of 2 or greater.  Would definitely eat here again on my next trip to SF.
author: steve f.

description:
Holy Mother, this place has ruined me.  If i could breathe sushi i would, but this place has got me critiquing every sushi place i've gone to since (trust me, that's a lot).  Please try ANYTHING with mango and macadamia nuts.  But don't show up half an hour early, so me and my bf can be the first in line again and get our sushi first mwahahahha :)

Rolls you MUST get:
Spicey Mango Salmon Roll
Spicey Hamachi Roll
Hawaiian
Hawaiian #2
Salmon Hamachi Roll (salmon, hamachi, and mango, OH MY)
author: Shunte Y.

description: Great sushi
author: David B.

description:
After a year of trying to check this place out, tonight was the night.
I stepped in and surprised to see how small this place was, seat probably 15-18 with 8 waiting.  It MUST be good.  
To help time go by faster we ordered some edamame and a beer.  After about and an hour wait, we finally get a booth, for two!   The wait for the food was pretty long too, but man was it worth the wait.  We had the Mussels (6 stars!), as well as the Stuffed Shittake mushroom (6 stars!), and I even tasted the stuffed Jalapenos (6 stars, and it wasn't even spicy, which I can't eat).  
Then for the main, we had the Albacore tuna, mango, and Macadamia nuts  (6 stars!!!!)  The artichoke and avocado...delicious!!!!
Everything was amazing!!!!!!!  (even the price!!!!)
Made me forget how long we waited.
author: Gemma P.

description: I discovered this place waaay back in the day when the original owner was running it. I've taken all my friends & everyone agrees AMAZING! Baked Mussels, Mango Hamachi etc... to die for. It's a small place & the wait is long but very worth it.
author: Meikee M.

description: My husband and I ate here the other night and we just had such a fantastic time - great food and great service!
author: carina g.

description:
I've written a few reviews now about lame-ass guys, so I think it's only fair that I deprecate myself a little as well.

Ways to Not Impress Your Date:

1) Arrive late. Then get lost. This is even more impressive if you were like hours late to the first date because you originally planned on standing him up in favor of doing your taxes. 
2) If there is one remaining chair in the entire waiting area, pour sake all over it instead of into your glass. Insist that you can pour sake into a glass, try again, and pour it on your pants and jacket.
3) Act like you know what edamame is and have plenty of experience eating it when you don't. Eat it whole. Really scarf it down because you've been waiting for food for a while. Suddenly notice you were supposed to be eating only the beans and not the shells.
4) If a sushi roll is very large, announce loudly that you can fit the whole thing l in your mouth because you have a huge mouth! (see photo for evidence) Make a mess in the process. In fact, just eschew all table manners entirely.

Ways to Impress Your Date:
 
1) Take her to Sushi Zone. I'm sure it depends on the type of girl you're dating, but I think this is an excellent date restaurant. The sushi was amazing. I usually just like sashimi, but the chef here had some really interesting rolls with ingredients like mangos, macadamia nuts, and jalapeno. The atmosphere is relaxed, and the room is ridiculously small. The wait could be annoying if you are hungry when you arrive, but in general I prefer my dinner dates to proceed at a leisurely pace, so it didn't bother me.
2) Don't appear to be alarmed that your hot Sushi Zone date is behaving like a rude 5-year-old.
author: Liz G.

description: Like the other reviewers, I have nothing but positive things to say about their sushi and therein lies the problem: the good word has spread and they just don't have the capacity to keep up with demand. Do not come hungry cuz you'll be famine-starving by the time you actually eat. 1-2 hour waits are routine and just not worth it for me! I don't plan to return until they move to bigger digs.
author: Jen H.

description:
You know, if you run a business, it wouldn't kill you to act like you're interested in having customers.

We just missed the first post-5pm seating thanks to parking issues.  We stood in the entrance for 10 minutes, trying to get the waitress to at least acknolwedge us.  We wanted to find out if we could be served at the little bar on the wall, or if we needed to just walk on since obviously everyone else had just gotten seated.  She wouldn't even respond to us!  Screw that for a lark.

We walked over to Sushi Delight and got immediate, friendly service, $1 oysters, and some of the freshest, most delicate hamachi sashimi I've ever placed on my tongue.
author: Sheila A.

description:
I don't believe all the long wait rumors.

Jonathan S. and I walked in here at 7:30 on a Saturday night and were seated immediately at a 4-top. Ok, fine, so it WAS a holiday weekend, but still :)

Everything was absolutely delicious, fresh, and beautifully presented. We started off with some edamame, glistening with a light sprinkling of salt.

The different rolls we had included: hamachi with mango, unagi with papaya, spider roll (with softshell crab), and the rock and roll (avocado, cucumber, and unagi). We also had sake and hamachi nigiri. All of the fish was fresh and the flavors were WONDERFUL. I loved the use of tropical fruits in the rolls. As Rachael Ray would say (a little too emphatically), "YUM-O!"

The entire bill was less than $40 and we were completely fulll and satisfied.

I can't wait for my next trip to the Zone!
author: Jill M.

description:
"They use the same seafood distributor as 80% of the sushibars in SF (Island Pacific), so don't let the hype fool your tastebuds."  Dan V.

Great comment...I mentioned it to a friend who added "yeah, but my uncle (who's korean) says Island Pacific gives the best fish to the japanese-owned sushibars, so he has his chef (who's japanese) handle getting the fish."  

So maybe there's a reason why my tastebuds love the sake with scallions best at Sushi Zone?  Maybe they know somebody who knows somebody?  I have no idea...I do know that I find myself not minding the horrendous wait.  My tastebuds seem convinced Sushi Zone is a cut above.
author: Mike R.

description:
I hold grudges. In life as well as with food.

We met Marcus at Sushi Zone at 6 pm on a Sunday night. By the time we paid the check and walked out the door, it was nearly 9 pm.

This is not fucking France. This is not a country where you hold a table all night long. And if it were fucking France, and you did hold a table all night long, you would damn well get better, more prompt, and certainly more satisfying service than we saw tonight at this hole in the wall.

Add it up: 

- An hour and 20 minutes before we were seated;
- At least another 30 minutes before our order was taken;
- 15 minutes before our drinks and my miso soup arrived;
- 30 minutes before our food arrived at the table.

That's two hours and 35 minutes before the first bite of fresh fish landed in our mouths. Was it fresh? Absolutely. Was it good? For sure. Was it worth waiting more than two and a half hours for? Are you insane?

At one point we flagged the waitress to ask her what was up. She shrugged, gave some vague answer, and walked away. I call that lousy service. I don't care if the waitstaff is not at fault, and it didn't look like the waitstaff was indeed at fault. It was the fact that they have a single sushi chef turning out grub, and tonight that just wasn't enough.

This is the Bay Area. Throw an incense stick and you'll find incredible sushi -- sushi for which you won't have to throw away your night and your evening plans, as the three of us eventually did. That pisses me off. No food is good enough to justify that, and Sushi Zone didn't even come close. Good thing for them that others are more forgiving than me.
author: Allison L.

description:
This was, by far, the best sushi I've had, but it comes at a price. As long as you know what to expect, I don't think you can go wrong.

For one, the place is TINY. It probably seats about 12 people if you count the bar and standing room (I guess that wouldn't really be seating...if you are standing). Anyway, expect to wait for at least an hour, no matter what time you go. My roomie and I went on a wednesday at bout 6:00pm and waited for about 1 1/2 hours.  But, I knew what I was getting myself into. In fact, I met a really cool guy named Keith while I was waiting and look forward to riding with him up at sears point.

Once you are inside, the service is attentive, but it takes a damn long time to get your sushi...so make sure you get an appetizer like the muscles...they are good and will be served quickly.  As for the food itself, I've never left without feeling almost elated.  I swear, they must put some sort of drugs in the sushi.  It has to be the single greatest food I have eaten. I was upset about something when I came into the restaurant (perhaps being hungry) and left having forgotten all my problems and happy as a lark. Now that is good sushi.
author: Eric C.

description:
I'm sorry Sushi Zone, even though I thought your salmon sashimi was buttery and delicious, I have to give you three stars because you gave me and my two dining companions horrible gas cramps for two days.  
  
Also, you charge too much for your seaweed salad and give too little!  I have to admit, I still like you though and it's hard for me to hold a grudge.  Maybe we will meet again if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
Make sure you get here early. Sushi Zone is small, only a couple tables and a small sushi bar.  We got here soon after it opened and still had to wait a little to sit down.  

We ordered a couple of the rolls with mango and macadamia nuts on them and they were good.  The fish is really fresh here and the combinations of fruit and nuts with sushi worked really well.  The hamachi here is very fresh and has a good fat content.  It was really melt in your mouth.  We also had some baked mussels that were quite tasty. 

Overall, Sushi Zone has some great fresh fish and rolls at a reasonable price.  The restaurant is small so get here early or expect to wait.
author: steve w.

description:
The first time I came here was when Regi K took me when I was a kid.  i remember it as Nori's too.  the small lil spot off of Market with a crazy wait if you get there a little too late after they seat the first wave of people.

The service has always been friendly and welcoming.  It's always fun to drink with the sushi chef too and they enjoy it too.  They lie, they can drink even after they say no, granted they probably might not be making your sushi as pretty, but why do you care, you've already pounded a few back yourselves. 

I've got to come back here sometime soon  I used to get the baked Mussels, hawaii rolls, and other new and interesting thing the chefs come up with.
author: Vincent K.

description:
They say much in life is about timing. The adage certainly holds true for this 20-seat jewel in Hayes Valley.

The evening we arrived, there were no others waiting who were not already seated, But looks can be deceiving. None of those seated were eating. We wound up waiting about 1 hour to get seated (a four-top was given to a larger party which arrived later; them's the breaks). We enjoyed some drinks on a small bar alongside the wall.

Any normal night, I would have gladly sat and enjoyed the cozy atmosphere. On this particular evening, though, I had a plane to catch in San Jose. After dropping off my friend. And returning a rental car. And checking bags.

After a showdown with the clock the likes of which would make any old western "duel" seem like a game of pattycakes, I decided that we were going to eat there, consequences (and departing flights) be damned! 

Upon telling the waitress our predicament, she was very kind and bumped our small order ahead of that larger table who was seated before us. We only had a chance to savor some items (mussels app, a sake sashimi dish with dill, capers and a delectable sauce; albacore tataki, hamachi, and a mango roll.)

The chef is a master at his craft. Everything was fresh and amazing.

Had I not had to catch that plane (which I made with roughly 2 minutes to spare), we would have stayed another hour and savored all the other fantastic dishes on the mental plate I had built in my mind.

If time does make fools of us all, then I consider myself lucky to have escaped this adventure with only a semi-full belly and my dignity intact.

I shall return, Sushi Zone.
author: Austin D.

description: Good sushi and awesome prices!  We really loved the baked mussels and baked sea bass.  The sashimi cuts were large and tasted fresh.  I still think Zushi Puzzle is better, but this place is much more affordable.  It's a tiny restaurant so the wait time can be long, especially since they don't take reservations.  Nevertheless, I wouldn't hesitate to go back.
author: K V.

description:
Meh.

Not bad, not great.

Too many flavors hiding the fish... and I don't like all that stuff on it.  I really just like fish and rice and the occasional mango and avocado.  Yes, it's cheap... but no, it's not worth the wait. I would rather pay and wait for really, really fresh fish.  Doesn't anyone do that anymore?
author: Tangerine L.

description:
This place is ridiculously good! I'm talking wait out in the rain for 20 minutes for a seat at the bar good. There are two booths and 9 chairs at the bar. It's pretty much always crowded, but the key is to get there early (5-6pm). Don't worry, you won't join the early bird special crowd, you'll have to wait for your food a little while. Get the specials written on the wall -- Hawaiian #2: salmon, mango, avocado and macadamia nuts. The spicy hamachi has jalapenos in it to add that extra kick. It's the winner in my eyes. I've had nothing better yet.

Head to the ATM before you go, it's cash only.
author: Defne A.

description:
The sushi is great. Absolutely no complaints. 

I give Sushi Zone two stars because I have actual self respect. Wait minimum an hour to be seated? Are you kidding? From start to finish, it's a three hour tour. It's not even a pleasant wait, being cramped in to a tiny place, shoulder to shoulder with both the other people waiting and the people eating. It's the food equivalent of sitting by the phone, eagerly waiting for a guy to call after a date. And you wait.. and wait.. and feel lousy. 

Go over to the sushi place next to The Mint, which is 2 blocks up Market. It's perfectly average, but you get 2 hours of your life back.
author: Julie S.

description: The wait is insanely ridiculous!  Is it the best Japanese restaurant in SF...no but sadly it is the best in the area.
author: Michelle M.

description: I love eating sushi here. The atmosphere is nice, the sushi are top-notch, and the service couldn't be any more better. All in all a really nice place to get families or friends together for a nice lunch or dinner. Try to come earlier or wait.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Before I start my review, first things first. Going to Sushi Zone is a night-long event. Do not be on a schedule. I recommend going here, putting your name on the list, go get a beer at your favorite local bar. Return after 45 minutes.

Now..I took my girlfriend to Sushi Zone for her birthday because Warakubune, her favorite sushi spot, was closed. I had read a lot of reviews online about it and had a good idea what I was getting into.

Well, all of the reviews were right on. We had a 45 minute wait to get 2 seats at the bar plus about another 15-30 minutes waiting for our order to go through. It is a very small place so it's not exactly romantic. So, if you're looking for a romantic date I'd go someplace else. However, if you are looking for a fun birthday place for excellent food... I'd highly suggest Sushi Zone.

The fish is extremely high quality. My girlfriend, who normally does not eat sashimi, fell in love with it.

Since my first time eating here I have returned very often with one or two guests for dinner. The staff is always the same. They know what they're doing. It's always very very good.
author: George M.

description:
sushi zone haiku(s)
***********************

be kind to yourself
order the mango sea bass
you'll lick the shell clean

the place is tiny
windows above booths open
my nipples froze off

the service is good
wait times are exorbitant
wish for bench outside

i sound like i am
complaining, but the food is 
worth any hardship

i have one secret
to spare you from the hardship
but i'm not sharing
author: Andy P.

description: Excellent sushi, friendly staff, a hidden gem.
author: Bruce H.

description:
A tiny hole in the wall that used to be a secret. But you can't stay on the DL if you serve the best sushi in San Francisco. 

Yummy nigiri with big cuts of the freshest fish. Perfect slices of sashimi by a true master. A nice selection of interesting and innovative (like hamachi with macademia nuts and mango) special rolls.

The food is 4+ stars, but I'm deducting a couple of stars for the long long long long wait for a table. Always an hour or more. Last time I came here with my girlfriend, we waited close to two hours.

If you perservere, order the baked striped bass with mango, served on a mussel shell. Amazing.
author: Shawn S.

description: Best sushi hands down!  And its next to 2Spirit tattoo. The best sushi and tattoo shop in one place. Can't beat it! It's a great atmosphere for a night out.
author: Matt B.

description: if I die I hope they serve sushi zone there, and I hope god equips me with enough cash.
author: Sara I.

description:
Next Muni? This place needs Next Table!
A 2 hour wait, 2 tables and no take out option?  
What kind of business is this?  What kind of customers have such a lack of self-respect that they put themselves through this?  

Sorry Sushi Zone, I have better things to do with my time than wait and watch others eat while unintentionally glaring, (I'm sorry guys, I was hungry!), and then feel that same unintentional glare of those who are unfortunate enough to be on the list after me.  There isn't a food on this earth that is worth waiting 2 hours for when you're hungry, especially when you are forced to helplessly witness the efficiency deficiency right before your eyes . 

If you're a party of two and want an intimate dining experience, do yourself a favor: cross your name off that list yourself,  get on the F market for a few blocks, get off at Noe St, and have yourself a romantical evening at Sushi Time.  You'll find about 7 times more seating in half the space with 100% more charm and great sushi to boot.
author: Marie S.

description:
I recommended this place to a sushi-loving friend of mine, and told him the deal:  you get there the *minute* it opens, or you'll wait forever.  Don't go with more than two people.  I spoke with him the following week:

[friend]:  Dude.  Four of us went on Saturday night at 8.  It took forEVER.

[me]:  WTF?  I told you to go early.  And FOUR people?  So you hate it, I suppose.

[friend]  No, dude.  We waited over two hours, but it was SO GOOD.  I'd have gone back later that night and waited ANOTHER two hours if I could have!

Seriously, though.  If you don't want to wait hours to eat, don't go after 6pm.  There's one chef, one waitress, and it's just the way it is.  Deal.

Great music, and don't miss the artery-clogging goodness of the striped-bass-and-mango appetizer.
author: kathryn a.

description: I love Sushi Zone! They are local, small, friendly, delicious! I highly invite anyone coming to the Castro to give them a shot!
author: Paul R.

description:
let me start off by saying that the sushi here is so fresh that it had a fish scale on it..  not sure if that is good or bad, but you can be the judge of that.  

so the food was good, but the fact that i had to wait 2 hours before i got to sit down to try it was rather unbearable.  probably not coming back here again until they decide to expand or move to a larger location.  do yourself a favor and get there before they even open.

p.s.  get the baked muscles
author: Derrick W.

description:
I feel like a sushi snob because I am only giving it 3 stars when everybody else seems to love this place. Yes, the sushi is definitely better than my last sushi foray out at Ozumo's, but still only 3 star worthy. 

The yellowtail sashimi was indeed extremely fresh and melted in my mouth.  Tuna sashimi was average.  The rolls seemed to have to much rice on them.  The edamame was good though. :)
author: Mamoon H.

description: The sushi was amazing.  Fresh big sashimi chunks, not no little half ass slices.  Chef definitely knows what he is doing.  Great rolls too.  Now the reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 is that damn wait and the fact that its cash only.  I waited for 10 min before I could even cram into the sushi bar.  Once I was there, it was almost an hour of sitting there watching everyone else enjoy their scrumptious rolls and mouth watering sashimi, before my first plate arrived. was it worth the wait? YES.  If youre in a hurry, dont eat here.
author: Brandon H.

description: This place is amazing. Freshness and quality. Be prepared to wait. But make sure you wait...it's worth it! I recommend the Spicy Mango Salmon and the Hawaiian #2 rolls. The Hawaiian roll has mango in it and is topped with macadamia nuts...tastes amazing. Also had the king California (with real crab meat) & spicy tuna. All taste fantastic.
author: Marissa M.

description:
Five stars are usually reserved for the best places , save for drunken reviews when I'm feeling generous or waxing nostalgic.

Now, it wasn't a perfect dining experience, but I can't blame SZ for that. First off this place is tiny, I think probably can't handle more than 25 guests, maybe 30 tops.  That is the start of a formula for waiting. We were warned, you'll have to wait 2hrs. I looked at the 3 people waiting outside and laughed to myself, there is no way this will take 2hrs. We'll have a bottle of sake and laugh at her in 30 minutes when we're eating! ha ha ha... ; (

Well, 2 hrs 18minutes, 2 large Asahi's, 3 bottles of sake, watching 25 people come strolling in and eating their delicious meals and we're about to be seated. Thankfully, the Universe is a wonderfully complex organism and has a built in reward mechanism for both patience and alcohol. I have never been so ready to eat, so warmly libated and so appreciative of food being prepared for me. 

Everything was great. Some was exceptional, specifically the Baked Sea Bass and Mango. I'm a big mackerel fan and the Saba did not disappoint. You probably can't go wrong ordering anything here. 
In hindsight, I would have followed Matthew R.'s suggestion and put my name in and gone off to a bar for a couple drinks. But know before you go and this will be a special sushi occasion.
author: Phil M.

description:
Itty bitty *CASH ONLY* Sushi Bar with one chef and every aspect of the operation open for your viewing. The waitress was nice but the service wasn't so hot; I'm thinking we went at an off time. The fish was spectacular melt in your mouth magic. I'm fairly certain it was the best albacore and tuna I have ever had the pleasure of having melt on my tongue (the salmon and eel were nothing to lift your nose up at either). The Hawaiian #2 Roll was sensational but by far the best roll we ordered. I would have been happier with us ordering 2 of those and the rest Nigiri. The mussel appetizer was very good but where some pieces of mussel were perfection others were rubbery. It was strange because the tables got all of the attention while us bar folk just stared longingly hoping for just one bite. It also seemed that everyone else around us was receiving their orders on a more regular basis (Example: if 2 people of the same party at the bar ordered 2 things they would get theirs at the same time while ours had a 20 minute minimum wait time in-between). 

Fantastic Sushi Rice and AMAZING melt in your mouth fish? = 5 stars

3 hours sitting at the bar waiting for all of our food to arrive (no we didn't order a crazy amount of food) = 1 star

We will definitely go back and see if it was just a random bad service experience or if it was just us. 

Oh also? Prices are awesome. And if you are like us and had no idea they were cash only there is an ATM up market just a tiny bit. 

Part of me wants to deduct more stars for the service portion of our encounter but..man that fish was just so good..
author: Natalie G.

description:
Be prepared to wait. The place is small. But DAMN good! My favorite: tuna, avocado, lime and jalapeno. Oh man oh man oh man....
Amazingly, their hot sake doesn't taste like rubbing alcohol as opposed to most places. And to top it all off, it's not too expensive. Love this place!!!!
author: Owen T.

description:
I love sushi.  LOVE.  But I often find that I stick to the familiar rolls that I love.  Not so at Sushi Zone.   While their offering isn't huge, their selection is different from the traditional rolls you'd find at other places, and are all super delicious.  The Hawaiian Roll #1 is absolutely amazing.  And the Spicy Hamachi roll is the perfect balance of spicy and fresh. 

As if that isn't enough, there's the Baked Bass.  Sea bass, mango, spicy mayo and magic all baked in a mussel shell.  It is to-die-for-incredible.

Minus one star only for the wait.  You can wait a while to sit.  And then once you sit, you wait a while for your sushi.  But I'll tell you, its well worth the wait.  

*** be aware, cash only ***
author: Julie E.

description:
This place has incredible sushi... too bad the service is slow and you may end up waiting 2+ hours for a table.

Honestly, I can appreciate the small hole in the wall vibe and decent sushi prices. But its just not THAT good sushi to wait this long for my food. Go up the street to Sushi Delight nextdoor to the Mint. You'll have more fun there.
author: Andy A.

description: I want this right now.  We got there right before closing time this weekend hoping for a shorter wait...no such luck.  We waited for a solid hour, maybe more, but it was WORTH IT!!  Drank our fair share of Sapporo while waiting, had 3 of the small cold sakes (so good) and some Edamame.  As for our meal?  AMAZING!!  We were instructed to order 2 orders of the Sea Bass Mango appetizer (for the two of us) and I wish we would have ordered 4.  IT WAS SO GOOD!  The Unagi was the best I have EVER had and we ended up ordering and additional roll with that in it, on top of the Nigiri we already had, and two more rolls.  Our bill was $52..... WWWWWHHHHHHHHHHHHAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAATTT?!?!?!?!  $26 bucks a piece.  I will be waiting in line many times to come.
author: Monica P.

description:
Waited about an hour, but it was totally worth it. The stuffed mushrooms were really good, but they only give you 2 per order. The Hawaiian Roll #2 is my new favorite roll. It has tuna, mango, & crushed macadamia nuts. The Papaya Unagi roll was also very good.

So far, it's the best sushi I've had in the San Francisco area. I'd definitely eat there again. Just be prepared to wait.
author: Eric B.

description:
this place isn't very big and there's only one sushi chef,  but every piece of sushi we ordered was fresh. the chef takes his time and pours his heart into each dish he makes. you can taste his hard work in each grain of rice, it's that good.

just be prepared to wait.
author: Shawn C.

description:
There is one thing that keeps me coming back to this place:

the baked sea bass with mango

It's amazingly delicious, and somehow makes up for the cash-only policy and guaranteed long wait for a table on most nights.

If I'm just looking to eat a sushi treat and not up for a long wait and hassle I'll usually go somewhere else... unless I hear the siren song of the damn baked sea bass mango.
author: Shannon W.

description: Finally was able to get in without waiting on line. It was a Tuesday night at 8:30p. We sat at the bar. Based on all the reviews and the guy next to us raving, we ordered the bass and the mussels  the bass is indeed tasty. Something about the mango and delicate fish and the creamy cheese/mayo topping just works. The mussels were good too. Chopped up and mixed with herbs and egg I think. Anyway, it's all very tasty. The rolls were good but I don't think the rice is packed tightly enough. Seaweed salad was the only disappointment. Small and uninteresting. All in al this place is good, but worth a long wait?? No. There's plenty of other good sushi places. And they only take cash so beware!
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Be there early or prepare to wait 2 hours and watch the couple, who beat you in line, enjoy the best sushi San francisco has to offer. This place will not impress you since it is the size of garage. Actually IT IS a garage! But the rolls are made with  the love of an Iron Chef. You will not be disappointed. This is not a typical meal. This is serious business here. No soy sauce or dipping sauce BS. That's like adding ice to your beer. Just open and enjoy.

This is the road to Hana...
author: My T.

description:
The sushi is so good here, the best I have had in San Francisco.  The fish was supremely fresh, and the preparation maximized the flavor.  They prepare sushi a bit differently than most places, adding watercress and small lemon or lime wedges to some of the nigiri pieces.  The Rainbow roll was excellent: they make a roll and then cut it into individual pieces and then add full pieces of several types of sushi.  I was particularly impressed with the halibut, which I don't normally like much but which was great.

I am conflicted about the size of the place.  It is the smallest restaurant I have ever been to, with only two tables and no more than 8 seats at the counter.  My group of 4 waited an hour-and-a-half on a Sunday night.  They actually didn't seat us until they were "closed."  And we were not the last group.  There is something cool about going to a restaurant with such attention to your order, but that is still a long time to wait.  On the up side, there is a Peruvian restaurant with a full bar around the corner (Destino), and they were perfectly willing to seat us for cocktails.  All in all, if you have the time, it is definitely worth the trip.
author: Bob H.

description:
wowsers.. Sushi Zone gets 5 stars.. 5 stars is what they deserve. Best sushi in town.. They have this 2 piece mussel dish with something yummy on top..I dare not ask what it is because I'm afraid I won't like it anymore afterwards... It kinda tastes like cheesy but I once heard the waiter say that it didn't have dairy in it..so it's not cheese.. secret sauce..

I would be specific about the rolls that I order, but I can't be because I'm all over the charts..I order everything.. Everything is soo damn good..

Ok ok so the wait is long.. but I learned my lesson.. NEVER go there on an empty stomach because there is always a wait.. Just put your name on the list them walk over to Destino for cocktail..  and then you'll live happy ever after.. :)
author: Monica S.

description:
Was looking for a sushi place to take my boyfriend to on his birthday.  We'd had Japanese twice that week (it's his favorite), one at an izakaya and another at a more traditional place, so I was looking for somewhere that was a bit more on the creative side.  This place was perfect.

I brought him expecting a wait, but we totally lucked out and were seated right away.  Our timing was lucky though, because by the time we got our first few rolls, there was a line out the door.

Anyways, the sushi here is good.  No, it's not upscale, and yes, there are a lot of rolls with mayo, nuts and/or fruit, but it's delicious and super inexpensive.  I don't know if I'd wait an hour to eat here, but I'll definitely be back.
author: Siobhan G.

description:
My girlfriends and I went here for my birthday. We arrived at 5:30 which was perfect because there was only one open table and the minute we sat down, there was a party of five that arrived and the line only got longer from there. One word of advice is be prepared to wait! Getting drinks took at least 15 minutes, and the food came to us about an hour into the dinner service. The wait is understandable because they only have two chefs and one waitress and the place is small so it's worth it. The rolls are incredibly delicious! They have really creative rolls and the sushi rice is fresh and nicely seasoned. We were so famished when the waitress finally took our order that we just about ordered half the menu and even had to question whether it was enough food. to that, the waitress said "wow, you guys must be really hungry!"

We ordered the following rolls:
Hawaii #2
Spicy Mussels
Spicy Scallop
Saba Nigiri
Ikura Nigiri
Eel and Papaya roll
Hamachi and Mango roll
Salmon and Avocado roll

I think we may have even ordered some other ones but I can't remember. And we polished it all! The fish was very fresh, the rolls prepared with a lot of care.  It was a really fantastic experience and I would really recommend this place to anyone that likes a little twist with their sushi!
author: Jade L.

description:
K, I'm going to sound like every other review about this restaurant, so I'll keep it short.

Best Sushi Ever

Rolls I REALLY liked:
Spicy Hamachi
Hawaiian
and any roll with mango

Sushi Zone is very reasonably priced as well.
author: Ramy H.

description:
If you don't get the hype, stay the heck away. 

There are easy ways to screw up coming here and ordering incorrectly. If you know what to order however, you couldn't possibly help but love this place. Every single person I've ever brought here has left pretty much in awe of the experience, the food, and the price. 

Hint: don't order like you're at a regular stupid sushi restaurant or get ready to be disappointed.
author: Jake R.

description:
Freshest sushi in the city. Waitstaff a little unattentive but that comes with being busy.

Will def return with my hubby (we're kinda foodies). My go to place during the week after the gym. Prepare for a wait on the weekends.
author: Connie D.

description: Brilliant, the best sushi I have ever had. Very fresh, perhaps the best eel and scallop nigiri I have ever had. Long wait, but well worth it. Prices are fair as well.
author: Stacy B.

description: Sushi here is fresh and tasty! The prices are all very reasonable and the atmosphere is cozy. The spot is small and always crowded. The super long wait will definitely keep me from coming back here on a whim. Plan for an early dinner here and ENJOY!  No, seriously - a very, very early dinner!  They open at 5 pm and expect a line just to get a seat, then wait another 45-60 mins for your food.  Long wait with yummy results!
author: Lisa R.

description:
I don't often write reviews, but this place has been on my mind for a long while because I've never been able to get beyond the impressions of my first visit.  A couple of years ago, my wife and I waited for 2 hours just to be seated after arriving not long after they had opened.  I can understand having some wait, given the limited amount of seating, but this review addresses my issue with the inefficient operations of the staff that made the wait longer than it should have been.

The sushi chef was really slow and took his sweet time between tasks.  This wouldn't have been such a bad thing if the place was larger, more comfortable, and didn't have tons of people waiting for a seat.  What's more, while we were waiting, this couple must have sat around for a total of 20 minutes between paying their check and passively wondering to each other whether the waitress was planning to come back with their change.  Additionally, for some reason, this same couple waited until after they had received their change, stood up, and put on their coats before deciding to chat the sushi chef up, even though they had been sitting in front of him the entire time.  And what does the sushi chef do?  He puts down his knife, wipes his hands, and proceeds to engage in idle chatter with them for more than 5 minutes.  You could argue that all the patrons might have already received their orders, but that wasn't true because I distinctly remember that it was only after their conversation ended did the sushi chef conspicuously snap out of it, hastily check his orders, and start hustling to catch up.  The reason this upset me was because either this is the speed he should have been working at the entire time, or he ended up cheating subsequent patrons out of the same quality he had previously put into his work (i.e. long wait AND hastily prepared sushi).  Also, the waitress could have went ahead and cleared the area and seated the next guests, since the couple was standing, but she waited for their conversation to end, as well, before preparing the counter.

Lastly, the background food preparer also did his share of contributing to the slow turnover.  I watched as he idly took his time preparing the appetizers (I think they were stuffed mushrooms), put them in a toaster oven, then just stood around until the cooking time was finished.  He then took them out, stared at his burnt appetizers for a long while, and proceeded to throw them away.  It was only then did he begin to prepare their replacements at the same slow, careful pace.  Why couldn't he have prepared more while the original batch  was cooking?  They're probably one of the more popular appetizers.

I've since been here a second time because my wife loves their sushi, which is admittedly delicious.  I got there 10 minutes early, and their door was open, but they refused to let me put my name on the waiting list or sit on the waiting stools because they weren't ready, then proceeded to close the door on me.  I don't remember being impressed by any improvements in their operations after being let in either.
author: Lawrence L.

description: I forgot why I haven't been to Sushi Zone in forever...the long wait. I also forgot how great their sushi is...totally worth it!
author: Loretta G.

description:
I had my second Sushi Zone dinner last night and was reminded how fanfuckingtastic the food is there.  We got to the restaurant at about 5:20 and the whole first seating had already begun, but we were first in line and it only took about 20 minutes to get a spot.  

It's a pleasure to watch the chef work at this place.  He has the easy manner of an expert; after rolling them up, he gives the maki nothing more than a single squeeze to get them loosely into shape.  The flavors here are light but heavily nuanced; mango, spices and marinades abound.  The waitress is achingly beautiful.  The albacore is effing delicious.

Sushi Zone is the kind of place you go with people who appreciate good sushi.  It may very well take a while to get seated, and once seated it might take just as long to get your food, but it's well worth it if you appreciate the craft and are prepared to have a drink or two while waiting.  Overall, among sushi spots I've experienced here in SF at least, Sushi Zone is probably my favorite.  You just can't beat food this delicious.
author: Oliver N.

description:
I have to add my voice to the choir of people complaining about the wait at this place. I was ready for the 45 minute wait to sit down and came prepared with brown bags and friends, but the 90 minute wait between our order and the arrivals of our rolls was too much. And after all that waiting with no updates or apologies our sushi came out WARM. I'm no sushi expert but I am pretty sure that it is supposed to be room temperature to cool. I suspect what happened was that they ran out of rice and had to cook more towards the end of the night, hence the wait and temperature but there was no explanation from the waitress.

That being said the sushi was innovative, cheap as hell, and really quite good despite the temperature. I may go back some time but the quality is not quite worth the wait although there is a certain charm to the small packed setting.
author: M L.

description: Inexpensive, super fresh, simple but delicious!
author: A L.

description:
Somehow this place got a Market Street address but it really is tucked down a small side street.  Despite being slightly off the beaten path there is clearly a loyal following.

The place isn't large and seats maybe 20 people and as a result the wait for us was approx 2 hours.  Don't be fooled by some of the other reviews, while the sushi is good it isn't 2hr wait good.  

Sushi Zone has a great and somewhat creative menu of Sushi and some excellent appetizers (Baked Sea Bass w/Mango is fantastic). 

Best Sushi ever...not a chance.  Best Sushi ever for the price....yeah, probably.  With most rolls under $6 it's definitely a good value.  The staff is hospitable and the patrons are passionate about this place.   I recommend sitting at the bar...the patrons who come here are very passionate about this place (crazy enough to wait 2hrs)...at the bar you'll definitely be engaged with the others around you and also with the chefs.

Give it a shot...you may not come back again but you won't regret it.
author: Joshua J.

description:
I love sushi! Thus, since I came up to San Francisco to spend time with my mom, I decided that it'd be a good idea to find a good sushi joint in the area. From searching through yelp, I discovered a ton of sushi places that not only have a high rating but also a ton of reviews. We settled for Sushi Zone because of its close proximity to the place we were staying at. 

The Good:
  The quality of the sushi was amazing. I've had better quality only at one other sushi restaurant and since I've tried a bounty of different sushi restaurants, this is definitely a compliment.  My mom and I ordered the Amaebi (Sweet Shrimp), Sake (Salmon), Hamachi (Yellow Tail) Nigiri, some roll that I forgot and the stuffed shiitake mushrooms. The Amaebi was good but definitely didn't have the fresh taste of a freshly killed sweet shrimp. Turns out they keep a bunch of dead amaebi in a box in the fridge. The salmon and the yellowtail on the other hand were as fresh tasting as if they had pulled the fish from the sea minutes before we sat down. It was that good. Not only did the fish melt in our mouths but the size of the fish they put on the rice is ENORMOUS.  The mushrooms were alright and the roll was pretty good...if only I could remember the name of it. 

The Bad:
  The wait is ridiculous. My mom and I got to the restaurant when the bar was full and we were the next ones up for a spot at the bar. It ended up taking us an hour and 10 minutes to get seated and then another 25-30 minutes before we got our food.  I looked behind the bar and the problem concerning time was clear as day...they only have 1 cook. The other 2 guys back there wait for dishes to come their way so that they can clean them or they wait for people to leave so that they can wipe down the tables. Other than that, they just stand around and watch people eat. Maybe this usually isn't the case but from my experience, it was pretty ridiculous. The chef also takes care of orders one at a time so if you want to get your fill, you better order a lot your first time around! Otherwise, if you decide to order some more down the line because you enjoyed the delicious sushi so much that you needed to have some more, your order will be put after the last order which could mean that you're not going to be getting your second order for a good 25-30 minutes after. 

All in all though, the food was delicious. The fact that the waitress explained to people who came after us that there would be an hour to an hour and a half wait and they still waited shows how good the food truly is here. I only wish that they would hire another chef.
author: Mitchell L.

description:
I kept hearing about this place for so long. Everyone was talking about it. How amazing it was. That it was truly magical. I needed to see for myself.

I noticed Lily T. mentioned that you lose some time, and you feel invested. That's how it was for me. After an hour of waiting, I said, "F this crap! I'm waiting! I am not losing an hour!" Well, that hour turned into three before we were seated.

Now here's the deal...the sushi was good. I'm not even going to try and sugar coat that little statement. Fan-f-ing-tastic! I think that everything that we ordered was delicious. I would definitely say it was one of the best sushi places around.

Why only 4 stars? Because when we stepped in and asked the waitress how long the wait was, she said "Not that long." Uhm...3 hours is not that long? Also, she wasn't very helpful when we asked if we could get some water or something to nibble on (appetizer) while we waited. And once we ordered, it was like she disappeared. Uhm...how do you vanish in a place that small?

People shall hate me, but here is the secret...step in, put your name on the list, and then go for a walk. Hit the Orbit Room or Martuni's for a few drinks, and then come back. That's the only real way to do it without going insane...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Great little casual spot for sushi. The only bummer of the night was waiting an hour to get a seat. I'm not gonna lie, I started getting really annoyed at people who were sitting and sipping on their Sapporos for 30 minutes, taking their sweet ass time when they could clearly see all these hungry people waiting to be sat. Damn squatters!

Anyway, the food was great. I liked the baked mussels and all of the sushi was fresh and yummy. I think we had the hamachi, unagi, seared tuna and saba. The nigiri was the perfect size. Loved it. 

I think the key is trying to find a time when there isn't a wait, if it's even possible...
author: Alli J.

description: This place is a gem. Living around the corner makes it so easy to go here often for wonderful, fresh sushi. They also have the best seaweed salad I have ever tasted. They open at 5pm, but people start showing up long before they are ready to open their door. The place is small, so you could have to wait for seating. It will be well worth the wait. Excellent service too! Love this place.
author: Buddy M.

description:
The baked sea bass (or striped bass) with mango is complete heaven! 

Sushi fish is great quality. 

There are lots of unique rolls with fruit and  nuts-- My favorite is Hawaiin #2 with macademia nuts. 

The seaweed salad is delicious and big enough for two. 

I heard a lot of people talk about the stuffed pepper, but I wasn't so impressed. 

All in all, this is my favorite sushi place, but the wait is always long. It's great to go here if you aren't famished and happy sitting down and enjoying sake for an hour or so before your meal. Then it's fantastic. I'm definitely a fan.
author: Erica G.

description:
Know this about me. I despise the places that are San Francisco institutions. That the San Francisco people line up outside day in and day out.

This is one of those places, but it is fantastic. Fresh fish, good vibe. Fair price. Best sushi I have had in the city.

Go during the week.
author: Sir M.

description:
I *LOVE* this place.

Those who are devotees do not come for the ambiance, wait staff, or decor.  We just plain love our sushi.  And although the prices are great, I'd definitely keep coming back even if it cost more.  To me, it's worth it.

But get your timing right, people!  You've read the reviews.  You know there's a wait... so plan accordingly!  Either get there early to be seated at 5, or place your name on the list and entertain yourself elsewhere for the hour or so that it takes for the folks to finish eating and the turnover happens (which is roughly every 2 hours).  

Feel free to tell your friends this place sucks or don't mention it at all.  We can all do our part to keep the crowds down so you and I can get a seat faster! (I'm only writing this review now, since I no longer live in SF... oh, how I miss it so...)
author: Gail S.

description: With this tiny little place, expect an hour or more wait.  But who cares, this place is WORTH IT!!!!   Just order a couple of large sake's and I'm all good.  It's hard not to order almost everything on the menu. Big fan of their baked seabass and baked mussels in half shell.  My only disappointment was the hamachi collar. Everything else was oishii!!!!
author: LeezaMarie A.

description: Great rolls, fresh nigiri and very reasonably priced. The trick is to arrive right when they open on a weeknight to ensure that you get seated soon. If you're aiming for a Saturday, it's wise to start lining up at 4pm. I once arrived at 5:10 on a Saturday and was disappointed to find a full house and a 2 hour wait.
author: Kadie C.

description: Unbearably long wait.  4 star sushi and our waitress was pleasant and efficient, but the solo sushi chef tested even my girlfriends patience, and she never complains. Our appetizers were there in 5 minutes but the two rolls took over an hour. No exaggeration, sat and ordered at 9:50, served the first roll at just before 11. No thank you!
author: Jan S.

description: I loved the stripe bass appetizer. They have the best tasting spicy rolls in the city. I suggest getting tuna or yellowtail. The wait was pure horror though...
author: John R.

description:
People, the hype is deserved.  No, i'm not talking about KFed's debut album.  The Sushi Zone Experience eluded me for years, but I finally sucked it up and camped out overnight, hoping to get a table by dusk. 

Showed up at 5:02, sat down at 6:15.  Yes, the wait is serious.  But the food is beyond serious - it's sublime.

Highlights..........

Edamame: perfect, fresh, nutty high-quality soybeans, with flakey sea salt

Hawaiian Roll:  Definitely falls into the "pseudo Cali-fancypants sushi" category, with macadamia nuts et al, but each bite was an explosion of flavors, textures, and was essentially, an epicurian orgasm.

Uni:  My benchmark.  9.5/10  (-.5 b/c there was just a little too much rice in the nigiri.  This is as good as i've had)

Spicy Hamachi:  Are those daikon shoots?  Delicious bitter greens, lime, fresh hamachi, avocado....really, reeeeeeally good

Also had papaya/unagi, and spicy mussell rolls, both of which were excellent, innovative, and fresher than Terry Gross

oh, they use REAL wasabi
author: Jon B.

description:
LOVE SUSHI ZONE!!!   my #1 all-time favorite sushi place!!!!  am so happy to see nori's sushi boom & flourish with a line outside the door starting @ 4:50pm, people willing to wait for a couple of hours and all these awesome reviews!!!!  nori would be happy!!!!

LOVES:
 - striped bass mango in mussel shell appetizer (signature appetizer)!!!!!!!!
 - stuffed mushroom w/ salmon appetizer
 - eggplant (nasu) nigiri!!!!!
- spicy scallop
 - spicy tuna
 - mango hamachi
 - unagi w/ papaya
.....there may be more but don't remember off the top of my head right now!!!
author: Cindi N.

description:
Actually 2 1/2 stars:

Its good... but not the best, to die for, mind blowing, I think I just saw God, I will name my first born after, better than orgasmic sushi experience ever as a lot of these reviewers are proclaiming.  

I've waited close to 2 hours (it may have even been more) for a seat here, and that was at 10pm when they cut off the waiting list... ridiculous! 

I will say the baked mango sea bass is delish!  But is that really sushi?  Both their Hawaiian rolls are good too, unique.  I wouldn't  go out of my way to patronize this place... but if I'm in the area I might stop in for the banked sea bass.  I'll just make sure there isn't more than a name or two ahead of me on the list because I don't think I'll be waiting around for 2 hours to eat here ever again.
author: Ms. M. M.

description:
I love this place.    I always come way before 6pm and ensure I'm one of the first wave of customers for the evening, otherwise you can expect to eat 2-3 hours if you come any later.  

I must have my own spicy tuna rolls.  That's just not one I can share.  I love the hawaii rolls, the unagi papaya, mango hamachi, eggplant nigiri,  the baked mussels, .....      I love all the fruity combinations, the liberal use of avocados, and the yummy fresh fish.   

I've been coming here since it was Nori's, and then when his best friend took the restaurant over and he kept the same menu... yippeee!!!!!
author: Regi K.

description:
I do not understand why Sushi Zone does not get 5 stars from EVERYBODY!!!
For us, Sushi Zone still is the one and only Sushi place outside of Japan! WE try out different places all the time, just because we want to be fair but... it is simply NOT possible for anyone to keep up with Sushi Zone!  The cosy atmosphere, the personal relationship you develop with the Sushi chefs and the waitresses, the selection on their menu! The Baked sea bass, the Spicy Scallop roll, the Sweet Shrimp nigiri... OUT OF THIS WORLD!!! Honestly, whenever I take a bite of anything they produce I can't help but close my eyes and sigh... HMHHHHHH!  
Does the wait bother me?! NO, it's part of it. Enjoy a few glasses of Sapporo while you wait and even more so... enjoy the anticipation!

Sushi ZONE... we'll be back, very soon :) :) :) !
author: Stefanie S. J.

description: Most awesom-est sushi place for a sushi fix ever, it'll get you hooked for more and more.  Can't actually believe it's worth a 2 hour wait just for one of the two tables for four, but it so is.  Just PLEASE do NOT steal whoever's name is on top of the list because you WILL be caught and you WILL run out of there with your head between your tail or your tail between your legs or whatever the saying is, because that is WRONG and no one who knows what they're waiting for will let it happen peacefully.  I hope the guys who did that when we were there get food poisoning from the ecoli infested spinach spreading across the country.  It is just so wrong.  The sushi is so good it brings out the worst in some i guess.  I am always sad for my loved ones who aren't with me when I get to go here and indulge in sushi delights.  It's really that good.  YUM
author: Today Y.

description:
The sushi was good but I probably won't go back. There are a lot of other good sushi places in town. The wait was so long!! My friend and I arrived at 5:30 pm and we were 3rd on the list. It took an hour and 10 minutes to get seated. This was enough time to get sauced at Martuni's a block away. It took another 35 minutes to get the sushi. And we never got the water we asked for. So I just kept drinking beer and kept my buzz going. 

And be prepared to be stared at while you eat as that is the only thing the people waiting to get a table can do -- STARE.

My very astute friend said this place should be called the "no sushi zone"
author: Frankie S.

description:
I am so disturbed to see the four and five star reviews of this place, because apparently no one in San Francisco values their time.

After hearing rave reviews of this place month after month (notably from a vegetarian), my boyf and I decided to check it out. We put our name on the list, which seemed not too long, and stood outside. And then we stood some more. And then we collapsed on the sidewalk in exhaustion.

It took TWO AND A HALF HOURS for us to get a table. Initially, the waitress indicated the wait would be about an hour, but we had to wait for the entire restaurant to turn over twice. Ridiculous.

And here's the rub: After you've waited for an hour, you can't leave, because then you've wasted an hour and given up. It's a no win situation. I found myself feeling guiltier and guiltier for losing more hours of my life that I could never get back, and still unable to move from my prime square of sidewalk.

And then they called us. And we ordered, and everything was speedy, efficicient, and delicious. It was almost closing time, so a few tables were actually empty and things moved along quite well. The hamachi kama was delicious, as were the rolls. The prices are great and the chef is friendly (although the waitress could barely look us in the eye after spending so much time looking at us apologetically, while never saying 'go somwhere else, you're wasting your time'). This would have been easily a four star sushi experience, if not for the excruciating period of time spend outside, lurking in wait. What total misery!

So, to recap:
Four stars for the sushi! Delicious (although most things are when you're faint from hunger).

No stars for the service or the misery of waiting. It is so not worth your while. For a wait of 2.5 hours, I want the chef to be out fishing for my dinner and then serving it himself.

+Hamachi kama
+reasonable prices
+tasty sushi
-indifferent wait service
-miserable wait times
author: Jessica H.

description:
Everyone here has already said the things that needed to be said about the best sushi in the city. So i guess i'll just talk about how good it was in the 90's, since I have this theme going on.

One of the things that happened back then with Sushi Zone, that doesn't seem to happen now (or atleast for me), is that the original chef (who died in a motorcycle accident) would call us while we waited for seats. we'd usually go to the Orbit Room, and have a cocktail. So the wait was never "oh my god, this sucks, this place is totally slow" to us.

When the chef died, I remember we closed down the place for a memorial, complete with the infamous mussels and the mango rolls.

I lived half a block away from sushi zone and i am glad I didn't take it for granted. I would go, and say, "this is the best sushi in the city", without even attempting to go to other  places, making me uninformed and biased.

But it's true. Best sushi. Now please, don't go.
author: Olivia W.

description:
Ugh.  Sashimi was good, I will admit that.  The rolls, horrid.  First of all the "spicy" sauce was just mayo, tons and ton of may and a bit of spice.  It was blahhhhh.  The spider roll was mushy and who's idea was it to add avocado and lime to soft shell crab?

Not worth the wait or the pain in the parking issues.
author: Alex S.

description:
Aside from fresh fish, the rice is what defines good sushi.  It's an art form. Sushi Zone has PERFECT sushi rice.  I get mesmerized as I watch them, not roll the sushi, but prepare the rice.  It's delicious.

Baked mussels are a necessity.  Go early or late so the wait isn't an issue.  If not, bring snacks cuz it's gonna be a damn long time.
author: michelle s.

description:
Three appetizers:
Miso Soup
Baked Sea Bass with Mango 
Baked Mussels

Four rolls:
Spicy Scallop Roll
Spicy Salmon with Mango Roll
Hawaiian #2 (albacore, macadamia, mango)
Unagi Papaya Roll

One Nigiri:
Ame Ebi

= Perfect amount of food for two hungry people

We arrived around 5:30 and waited around 45 mins for the table. Upon being seated, the food came in a reasonable amount of time.  
The size of the place is VERY comparable to Ume on Park Street, 2 tables and a fairly small bar. This was all expected, so doesn't really sway my rating. 

Hands down = Baked Mussels is BETTER than the Baked Sea Bass with Mango, which comes on the half shell and looks like the mussels.  Next time, we plan on a dozen of the  Baked Mussels. Freaking heavenly. 

Our favorite roll was the Hawaiian #2.  Generous with the expensive macadamia, appreciated.  The rest were good, but honestly, I would not say great. I wished we had gotten more nirigi, but we were dazzled by the rolls, though the ami ebi we had was pretty good.  

What does sway my rating, I suppose, is the hype.  I was not impressed by the quality of the sushi.  It was tasty, but not MIND BLOWING like a few other places I could rattle off.  The first two spicy rolls had an overly strong taste of watercress or shiso and I had to pick some out.  The rolls were not that well constructed and visibility falling apart upon presentation.  Given the high amount of pressure the staff must be under, can't say its unsurprising and we still still tipped generously.  

We WILL go back for the Baked Mussels and the Hawaiian #2.
author: Dulce V.

description:
This place is such a gem that I almost don't want to review it. We're talking top quality fresh fish here.  The place is small, seats about 13 in total, it's cozy, intimate, warm, neighborhoodly, and busy. 
They don't take reservations here and you WILL have to wait.  I've waited for 90 minutes on occasion but every time, I knew it was worth every minute of the wait when I finally got seated and started to eat. The chef makes daily specials and the mango mussels are not to be missed.  They're cash only so remember to line your pockets with some paper money before you come in.
author: Mystery X.

description:
I heard about this restaurant first from my pharmacy preceptor.  She told me it was her most favorite restaurant in SF.  I decided to look it up, and went during a weekday thinking that the lines shouldn't be THAT long on a Wednesday.  We tried getting there before they opened, thinking they opened at 5:30pm... We got there at 5:05pm, just 5 minutes after they opened... and all the seats were filled!!  The place literally seats 16 people.  There's 2 booths that can seat max of 4, and the rest of the seats are at the sushi bar.  The place is pretty cramped.  We ended up waiting like 45 minutes, and were seated at the bar.  Don't come here with more than 2 people.  You'll be waiting forever.  

Onto the sushi.  The sushi prices were really decent!  You can get about 6 dishes/sushi rolls for about $30-35.  The baked mussels were soooo yummy I wish I had ordered more.  You get 2 pieces for about $3.75.  Don't damage the mussel shells because they re-use them. haha Same thing for the baked scallops.  The sushi rolls were about $5-6/roll, depending on what you get.  Make sure you order everything ahead of time otherwise you'll have to wait a while for your sushi.  The sushi chef likes to get one table's orders out at one time.  

We tried a lot of the rolls, including the Octopus rolls.  The rolls come with about 6-8 pieces.  They aren't super special rolls like with tons of spicy sauce or the kinds you'd find at Sushi House or Little Tokyo... but there's a few special rolls.  The fish is reallllly fresh, and all the employees (all 4 of them) are japanese!  =P

If you decide to come here, make sure you go at 4:30 no matter what day it is! haha  AND it's CASH ONLY.
author: Diane L.

description:
Hi, my name is Honey. I am super important and a minute out of my life not being pleased should be everyone else's problem.

You are going to one of the more exclusive sushi restaurants in Northern California and then whine about it. Not exclusive as in high end chic, but exclusive in the sense you can't just cartwheel through the front door and scream your order. There is a reason you waited so long... it is an amazing, innovative, and surprisingly cheap sushi restaurant. But you were displeased with waiting... boo hoo pansy. If you can't enjoy anything you have to wait for I'm sure your marriage will be filled with happiness one day when you lean against a weak willed, financially stable putz and force him to put a ring the size of your ego on your finger. 

Thanks for making the wait longer for other people that will actually appreciate the beauty of such an original hot spot you can't find anywhere else. Seeing the dissatisfied look on someone's face when they can't just relax and enjoy the moment in such an incredible place is grounds to walk up and sock you in the boob.

Enjoy the rest of your sunshine, rainbow, hug, and panda filled life. 

This is some of the best sushi you can find in Northern California.

Good talk.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
Fresh is the sushi
Long is the wait
Groovy are the tunes
Low-key is the vibe
Fair is the bill
And Great is your reward
author: Reema B.

description:
My log tells me you are craving raw fish, served in a fine Japanese style. My log also says that you would not like to spend an exorbitant amount of money on California cuisine bs, in an Anime-themed douchebag chain restaurant. 

There is a reason why you shall see many people--include Japanese people--standing outside the Sushi Zone and waiting for hours to get in. My log tells me this restaurant is for people who know good sushi, and hold very high standards for freshness.
author: amity b.

description: I went here based on Yelp reviews. Our party of three had to wait an hour after arriving at 7 on a Wednesday night. We ordered the mussels and the stuffed mushrooms as appetizers, both pretty good. We ordered three rolls, all very good. The uni was the best I have ever had. The sashimi plate was really lacking, it could be that I prefer thinner cuts of fish. It was a fine, but not epic, dining experience. Its probably not worth the wait but you should  try it out once.
author: Lauren M.

description:
It's SO teeeeeny.

OK, now that I got that out of my system... Sushi Zone ROCKS and those prices are from 1981 or something, so cheap!

The pretty boyfriend and I devoured 4 orders of nigiri, 4 rolls, 1 large beer and 2 small sakes all for $51. INSANE. 

This no frills sushi joint is easily missed when you're walking along Market Street, but the quality and freshness of the fish was DEFINITELY worth it and we'll come here again for sure, especially since it's less than a 10 min walk from our hobbit hole. Our favourite roll was the spicy hamachi... not so memorable was the Hawaii #2 (bland).

If you can get there early enough perhaps there won't be a wait, but with 3 booths and maybe 8 counter spots you're guaranteed to wait (unless you get there during odd hours, or perhaps when they're closed).

100% recommended especially if you're in the area already!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
A hole in the wall sushi joint that has two tables that seat about 4 (six if you squeeze in), and a sushi bar that seats about 12.  Naturally you're going to encounter a wait of 45mins-2hours.  My friends wanted to take me here for my birthday.  Total wait for us (a party of 5) was about 2hours for a table.  The whole time I thought in my head "This better be worth it".

And finally we got seated.  I know the previous reviewer had issues with the service, but on the day I went (a Saturday night) there was the chef/owner, 2 sous-chefs, and 1 waitress.  So we were able to order right away, and our food came within 10mins.

Aside from all that, I must now mention the food.  I've been to many Japanese restaurants, and I've noticed that a lot of them share menus.  A california roll is standard, but everyone also seems to make "specialty" rolls the same way.  For instance, a Rock and Roll, a 49ers roll, a Dragon Roll.  There's probably a sushi roll convention they all go to in order to share these ideas.  Well here in Sushi Zone, it is drastically different.  They do have a Rainbow roll (delicous, by the way) but they also have two Hawaiian rolls, an Indian roll, and more whose names I forgot.  I've never seen the pairing of macademia nuts and tuna before, or papaya and salmon!  It was an amazing experience because the rolls were something I've never encountered before!

Is it worth the wait?  It depends.  If I happen to be starving and impatient and don't care what I eat as long as I eat, then no, probably not.  But if I'm hanging out with good company as I wait, (and the conversation is good) then probably.
author: Mary V.

description: Alright, so I've been to "the zone" three times now and it's not failed to disappoint.  There's often a wait, a really long wait, but good things come to those who wait.  The whole place only seats 16 at most so it fills up pretty quickly.  Don't go starving, but sit and snack on some edamame, sake, or sapporo as you wait.  Everything I've had has been so delicious.  I'm vegetarian and there's several delicious options.  Veggie or not, have the eggplant.
author: brion p.

description:
My new favorite Sushi place, lucky that we didn't have a crazy wait, but we did opt for an earlier meal.  

The specials are worth noting - mango oysters baked (or something like it) worth ordering a couple portions.  Amazing.  Friendly staff, though watch out for the chef.  He knocked a bowl of Miso on my date.  They bought us a fresh Asahi (as the first nearly finished round got a bit of Miso in it) and were very sweet.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I miss this place.  Went there a few times with ML and loved the sushi.  There was always a long line, so get there at least an hour or so before they open to claim a spot in line.  Once, a fight almost broke out because more than one line started forming.  People go nuts for this place.  And, there is a reason!
The place is tiny, two booths, and the rest are counter seating.  The fish is fresh and melts in your mouth.  The chef and the wait staff are on top of their game and very serious.  The food takes a while to get out, but it's worth the wait.  The prices are cheap, too!  I need to get around to going back soon.  I miss the baked sea bass so much.
author: Cino B.

description:
I have a theory that once a restaurant has more than 300 reviews, the rating will kind of peak off and subsequent reviews won't matter anymore. Still, I have to put in my two cents on this joint, which clearly has been ranted and raved about since the fledgling days of Yelp.com.

I came to this place a few times before. All those times, I had a really bad experience due to the horrendous wait. At one point, we waited 1.5 hours just to sit, and another 30 to 45 minutes just for the food to come to our table. 

Anyways, this review isn't about those previous visits. This review is about the latest I made to this restaurant, which you got to admit, has really awesome food for the price. My partner & I made it to this restaurant on a Saturday 20 minutes before it was going to open. The wait didn't seem that long, but soon after we arrived to stand in line outside, people kept coming up to the point that by the opening at 5pm, the whole restaurant was full. Regardless, the waitress who seated and served us was extremely courteous and quick to serve as usual. We were seated right next to the 2 people ahead of us on the bar. 

We ordered:
- Baked Mussels
- Mango Hamachi
- Alaska Roll
- Spider Roll
- Indian Roll

All of these were DELICIOUS! My partner is in love with the baked mussels (but what about me??!) and even though I'm not a fan of octopus, the indian roll was delectable and I can't wait to try out the other rolls next time!

We are going back, and I recommend everyone to visit this place...20 minutes before it opens on a Saturday.
author: Jason S.

description: decided to eat here while on vacation, hands down best sushi rolls I ever had, thinking of making a trip back up there just to fulfill my craving.
author: Art E.

description:
Ok! Here's the deal. Come early, bring friends, drink, relax and have an amazing time. 
Then.....TIP your server!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I'm actually having dinner here right now while I post this,(yes there is ample time between courses...but that's really ok), and I just witnessed a couple leave a $2 tip on a $40 bill. They had a boat load of sushi for that cheap price, and there is no reason to leave a 5% tip!!!! The servers here are so amazing, with so much responsability, and are slamed the whole night. Just because the prices are so cheap, I would suggest to tip a minimum of 20% and up for great service. And no I'm not rich, I'm unemployeed at the moment so, please think of this as a valid perspective. For most dinners people are prepared to tip $20-25. Why leave $2 when you know $6 or even $8 is justified? 

And beyond that, my absolute favorites here are Hamachi Kama, or Salmon Kama with a side of rice!!! $6-8! truly amazing baked fish. Best I've ever had. And in general, this place has the best hamachi sushi I've ever had. Come in and order everthing hamachi. You won't be dissapointed. 

Then... Please tip. It's really worth it.
author: James O.

description: Delicious. Affordable. Fresh. Generous portions. Such a teeny tiny little place you likely won't get in without waiting forever, or showing up early, or getting lucky. But it's worth a long wait if you're able to get in, because this is some of the best sushi I've had in SF.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
Update:   The stats say that there's take out, but I just learned that they discontinued takeout.   Damn.

Original Review:  

The lines, the lines, and then it's slow food, as in, s-l-o-w food, but I love it.  The seared albacore is killer.  I went to Sebo one night in Hayes Valley, and after 1 course with a $40 bottle of sake, we looked at each other, and cut-and-ran to Sushi Zone.  (It's perfect to eat a little first.  Preferable to getting sloshed at the Orbit Room while waiting 464 hours for your table.  I mean, I love the Orbit room, but sloshed + food = not the right mix.)
author: Laurel B.

description:
The Zone. 

 Third time in = three times I'm happy.

 The baked mussell appetizer, maguro are tasty fresh...and I'm having day dreams today about the spicy hamachi roll, with jalapenos, lime and avocado.   

Molly and I got there right at 5:00;  it's true that  we had to wait a bit because the restaurant filled up right when we got there, but everything was so good, so fresh and so worth the wait.  Good things come to those that wait, so we waited and it was truly good.

Following dinner, we wanted to have more saki, but decided to give up our prime real estate due to the wait behind and went over to Tokyo a Go Go. T-G-G does have an extensive saki list, which I can appreciate.
author: annie s.

description:
