If it wasn't for the truly ridiculously long wait, this place would get five stars.

Actually, I might even break out a sharpie and draw a sixth star on my monitor in that instance - but since the demand for greatness always outweighs its supply, I feel confident that this place will always have a ridiculous wait  to be seated.

Having said that, I've never waited for more than 40 minutes to sit down here.  Not to say that I haven't had the opportunity to wait for more than 40 minutes, but I'm a slave to my tummy and it's not that patient.  If the wait is too long, I just don't stick around.

If you're really smart, you can go when they're not busy.  I'd tell you when that was - but then, they'd be busy then too.
author: Nick T.

description:
By far one of my favorite spots to eat in SF. Great food and great service. 

The wait is long but it is most definitely worth it. Everything I have had here has been fresh and delicious. Try the nasu if they have it on the specials menu when you go it is amazing yummy goodness on rice.
author: Erin D.

description:
BEST SUSHI IN SAN FRANCISCO!

I used to only tell people I really, really liked about this place because it is such a bitch to get into.  

They make this amazing hot fish thing with mango that is YUMMY.  The Unagi is out of this world!  If Sushi Zone was a man, I'd make sweet love to him all day and all night long!

I line up before they open or I go way ahead to get in line and have my friends meet me in an hour.  It also helps to go with someone with whom you have a lot of catching up to do.

I LOVE SUSHI ZONE!
author: Sarah T.

description:
First of all, when my friend finds out I posted a public review of this place, I might be in trouble.  It's supposed to be our "secret place" b/c it's SO GOOD that he's afraid everyone will flock to it if they find out and we'll have to start making reservations 3 months in advance or some shit.  I disagree.  I say, tell the people.  Share the love. People will come and go as they please, and not everyone will have the same (RAD) tastebuds that we do, but whatev.  This place needs a review.  From me.  Now.

Sushi Zone is one of the best sushi spots in San Francisco.  I will lay down and let the MUNI run over me if you think I'm lying.  It's located in a tiny alley off of Market St. and you no doubt will have to wait a while (let's say 45+ minutes) to get a seat in this cozy place (2 booths and about 8 seats at the sushi bar), but when I go with friends, we usually grab the waiting booth or stand by the wall and order a nice cold nigori while we wait. Just put your name on the list and wait your turn, it's okay.  *pat pat*  You'll be handsomely rewarded and it's better than when you were a kid and mommy gave you a cookie.

What to order:  OK, for starters if  you look at the pictures posted for this place you'll see the menu.  It pretty much looks like that all the time and doesn't change.  So, if you scan the mouthwatering list pay close attention to these:  For your appetizer, the baked sea bass mango is...*S2*Ysf&(#Rd(%^...sorry, I just had an orgasm from the memory.  It's about $5 each, but SOO worth it when it melts in your mouth...all warm and mango-y...and lovingly placed in an oyster shell.  Get some nigori while you're at it.  I love the unfiltered coldness of this sake- I'm not much of a hot sake person.  

Next comes the main course:  Spicy scallop, spicy hamachi, spicy tuna (are we seeing a pattern here yet, people?  Mama likes it H.O.T.), and the Hawaiian #2 (albacore, mango, and crushed macadamia nuts) all together make a fabulous feast.

The staff is SUPER friendly and I can't help but want to jump over the counter and hug the sushi chef everytime I leave for making my tummy so happy.  I contain myself, though.  But, whew, does he ever get a make-out session in my mind.
author: Amber B.

description: Time to expand to a larger space? I was passing through on my way back from China and was craving sushi. Anyway, had a wait of about an hour on a weekend night. Went next door for a drink to kill the time. The staff of 3 was hustling! Service was good once sat. Sea bass and rolls were super. I can't remember the whole order since waited too long to do this review...but still felt the need to give them credit. Good value indeed.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I ALWAYS want to get into The ZONE... 
Two words for the owners of Sushi Zone: Don't change!
author: Jasmine W.

description:
By far the best sushi I've had in the city! Unique combinations of fruit and sushi such as spicy tuna mango, and spicy hamchi- with lime and jalapeno.
and the baked sea bass mango is probably the most amazing thing I have ever put in my mouth! Freshest sushi ever!
The service is excellent... both the waitresses and sushi chef are on top of it. I only wish they would expand their space, b/c there is always a huge wait. But I guess if they did get bigger, then maybe the quality of the service and food would go down. To me, this place is well worth the wait, just put your name down, and go do something and come back in an hour or so.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I have no problem waiting on line for a delectable culinary experience.  Unfortunately, I did not have that anticipated experience after waiting for two hours.  

The food was eh and the service was was eh.  If you visit, you need to sit at the sushi bar because those people clearly get served before anyone in the booths.  

I have been to better sushi places in the city that serve it up quickly with a much shorter wait time.
author: Matt T.

description: It was good. Really good. I won't deny it. That little hawaii role #1 was total yummers. But...to wait an  hour for a table, and then to be served so slow that the entire experience took almost four hours? We were happy we ordered edamame and miso unless we would have had to call out for pizza. If the service was a bit faster I would have appreciated it more...as it is...three. but only cus I love mango.
author: Danielle L.

description:
The wait. wow... so, in case you haven't gathered this yet from the 300 plus other reviews, this place takes a REALLY long time to eat at.  Check it; we arrived at 5:02pm and somehow managed to miss the entire first seating.  It took them until 6:40pm to seat our group of 4.

Given that it took them over an hour and a half to seat us, that gave me plenty of time to peruse Yelp Mobile and read the billion reviews on this place... We were ready to rock when we sat down.  Unfortunately for us, they weren't quite as ready.  It took another hour and 15 minutes to get the food.  All in, we're going on three hours here.

Now the good news; the sushi is really freakin good.  The baked striped bass app is awesome.  The spicy scallop roll, spicy hamachi, and hawaiian roll are all delicious and highly recommended.  The nigiri is fresh and well prepared, with the yellow tail being the standout for me.

The sushi is really good, but given the wait, im not sure I'd be in a hurry to go back.
author: Marc H.

description:
Expect to wait for some of the cheapest and best sushi in the city.  I would be here more often but I am usually too hungry to wait after the walk.  Love the macadamia nut encrusted Hawaiian roll, it melts in your mouth.  Be prepared for the possibility of sitting with total strangers if you want to eat faster...happens all the time.
Hit up the Mint for bad karaoke and strong drinks prior.
author: Jill D.

description:
the sushi was soooooo fresh and delicious, goodness :) the mango sushi is a must-try.

the only thing is that this spot is teeeny with one chef serving the whole place. make sure once you come in to write your name on the dry-erase board and be prepared to wait. this is more to appreciate the taste and the company of who you brought, because you are going to have long intervals between every order and you're probably going to still be hungry afterwards.
author: Mitch N.

description:
What I liked best about my experience at Sushi Zone was the atmosphere: it's small, intimate and non-pretentious.  And the prices were totally affordable!

The wait was long (an hour) but enjoyable.  I sat with my friend and shared a good bottle of high-end sake.

The fish was mostly amazing but not entirely (which disqualifies it from being my "best sushi in SF").  The cuts of fish were generous,  a little jagged around the edges and full of personality which makes it unique and unlike many thin, slick and perfectly cut fish.  I liked it.

The highlights:
The appetizer, baked sea bass and mango in a mussel shell, was absolutely amazing.  So was the Hamachi Nigiri, which I believe was the Hamachi toro (the fatty, belly part) for no extra charge.  The Maguro and Mango roll was also outstanding.  The wasabi was very fresh and super strong, a quality that you'll mostly only find in a small establishment.

The minuses:
We did find small bones in the Saba (mackerel), and the Hirame (fluke) was still a little cold and seemed like it hadn't been properly thawed.

Overall it was a very good experience, but certainly not "the best."
author: Shayna N.

description:
Everyone talks about the wait. My group's: 3 hours.But we had 6 people, so yeah. If you can't handle it stay away and make room for the rest of us you nay saying cry babies.

Was the fish good? The fish was so good I would bathe in it. I would literally immerse and dunk my head in the hamachi, sea bass, the scallops, and begin eating from the bottom up.

Yes it was worth it, it was all worth it.
author: Tom E.

description:
I went to this place based on Yelp reviews. It was good for the most part but I think the wait and the service is not so good. We got there around 5pm and waited for a table for around 40 mins, then waited another hour for our sushi - mind you, there are 2 booths and about 7 seats at the sushi bar...I counted one sushi chef tonight when we were there. 

I highly recommend the Eel Papaya Roll. It is definitely one of a kind. We also had the Rock and Roll, The Hawaiian (which was on special), the Tuna Avocado & Mango Roll among other things. They were all very fresh and very good. The price is great too for each roll (ranges from $4 - 9 per roll, with most averaging around $5.50). That is a great price for someone who is used to paying around $15 for a decent roll in the Midwest. I don't know what sushi restaurants are like around here normally but I found that even though the rolls were very tasty, it didn't seem like the best I've ever had. Certainly they have very original rolls but I felt that the menu itself was rather skeletal and that the specials had the better offerings. 

This is definitely a casual place. Parking can be hard to come by so be prepared to walk from a meter. I have to say that meters are expensive in SF! Almost $2 for an hour! Oy vey!
author: Johanna C.

description:
Do not make the same mistake that I did, which is coming here for a special event (birthday).

My party of four arrived @ 7:30 (on a Wednesday night) and didn't get seated until 10:30; they don't take reservations.  It's one of those things where the longer you've waited, the harder it is to walk away to eat somewhere else; as soon as you know it, it's been three hours.  We kept thinking, "we're going to be seated soon; just hold off for a little bit more."  But of course, the people who were seated have also waiting for a very long time, so they felt no guilt taking their time with the meal.

The food was good, yes, but I can't say I can base it on very good judgment, for by then I've already had too much Sapporo.  The rolls we ordered also looked smaller and not as good as others' orders; another thing about being the last ones there is the chef is probably tired from the day's work.  I don't care what anyone has to say; because of the three hour wait, Sushi Zone, you will never see me again .
author: Lily T.

description:
One of San Francisco's best kept secrets.  If you go early (at 5pm) or around 9pm, the wait is reasonable.  I went a few weeks ago and parked RIGHT across the street around 9pm--and then only waited about 10 minutes for a spot at the sushi bar.  

There have also been times where I have waited over an hour.  Let me tell you though...so worth the wait!  Put your name on the list and then walk up to the Orbit Room on Market @ Laguna for one of their amazing cocktails (Pearody)!  Or if you are afraid they might call your name while you are away, then order a Sapporo or Sake and munch on some edamame while you wait there.

The prices are really affordable for sushi and the fish is super fresh.  Try anything with mango and macadamia nuts!  

Zagat rates Sushi Zone as one of the best sushi spots in America...there are about 10-15 SF sushi joints listed & Sushi Zone is one of them!
author: Sara W.

description:
Not to rain on the parade, but this place is really just ok.

It certainly has that whole in the wall charm, and it's delightfully funky and fun, but the sushi is just ok, nothing more nothing less. And while cheap ok sushi is a great thing, when you attach a two and a half hour wait I just don't think it's worth it. If you are really strapped for cash, have abundant amounts of time, and desperately crave middle ground sushi this place is for you. Otherwise I can't see not just paying slightly more for a better product served within your lifetime (no joke, you will have to wait two or three hours for a seat at this place).

If you do endure the wait make sure to get the Baked Mango Sea Bass, it's the one truly  stand out item on the menu.
author: Alex D.

description:
Best sushi in the United States!

I have not yet found a better place. You San Franciscans don't know how lucky you are. But maybe you're used to this quality of fish and sushi.

Everything about this place is amazing. It's worth a flight from Chicago to San Fran to eat here and then hop a flight home. 

I didn't mind the wait. That's what happens when you serve mind-blowing sushi in a 20 seat restaurant.

Insanely fresh. Cheap prices and big rolls. Delicious. What more could you want in sushi!?

If you locals are ever in Chicago and want a comparable place go to Toro. It's ALMOST as good as Sushi Zone but SZ can't be beat.
author: Ben P.

description: Oh, this is the awesomeness. The fish with mango is a must. I don't mind the long line at all and recommended this place to a lot of friends from other parts of US.
author: Jj M.

description: This sushi stopped my Vegetarianism... straight up! Eating fish here propelled me into a new era of awesome.
author: Mike J.

description:
If, and this is a big IF, you can handle the wait, then Sushi Zone is absolutely fantastic, delicious, amazing sushi.

If you are in a hurry or super hungry or just impatient, maybe its best for you to try somewhere else for your sushi fix.

But really the wait isn't all that bad.  Go grab a drink at the Orbit Room or somewhere's nearby and come back--they'll even give you beer and or sake while you wait in the (tiny tiny) restaurant.

Once you're seated, be sure to try the baked mussel with mango appetizer thingy.  We also had the salmon stuffed mushrooms, which was pretty amazing, as was all the sushi. 

Also, my friend and I sat next to this really cute couple who looked like they were on maybe their third or fourth date and just starting to realize that they were like, REALLY into each other.  Not in a gross PDA way (like the old guy and his young trophy girl further down the bar) but in an innocent, hand holding, deep conversation (that we totally eavesdropped on, sorry kids) way that was really sweet.

AWWWWWWW!!

Anyway, back to Sushi Zone.  It comes down to three words:

Worth The Wait!!
author: Kevin H.

description: Amazing sushi and authentic environment (i assume).  There was less than 20 seats in the house, and everything was done in a single room (no back kitchen).  Very impressive appetizer made with Seabass, mango, and cream cheese, was incredible.  You can't miss out on that.  Sushi roll with Albacore, macadamia, and mango was probably the best sushi roll I've ever had.  There sashimi platter was a little less impressive when compared to the above bites, but I remember the Albacore being particularly great.  They had a special Sweet shrimp nigiri on the that came with a fried shrimp head that was pretty unforgettable.
author: Anupam S.

description:
SHIZAM! It is like a taste explosion in my mouth!!!

My buddy introduced me to this place and told me I had to try the striped sea bass and mango shooters. Oh.....my......god. I wish I could line up a dozen of them on the bar and pound one after another, they are that good!! And the mango hamachi rolls make me start salivating when I see them. they are onolicious!

Show up early or come after 830 or else you will be waiting forever.
author: Jesse M.

description: This place is the spot. First off, super tiny (literally 2 4-people tables and a small sushi bar). I went with one other person on a Thursday night and waited for an hour to be seated. But if you are in no hurry--- totally worth it! Secondly, the staff there is super friendly and in midst of a busy night never forgot about us nor do I have negative things to say. Their Hawaiian No.1 roll is to die for. It has plenty of cracked macadamia nuts all on top. This is one of about 15 rolls all under $6.50!!! 6 pieces per roll. I have yet to find a cheaper price than this. I highly recommend it hence why I reviewed it. Gotta give 5 stars!
author: Marissa P.

description:
If I'm not hungry but could imagine, at some later hour, eating sushi--but I don't want to spend a bunch of money, Sushi Zone is the spot. But if I'm hungry, I'll pass (more on that later).

Let me just say that in every aspect, this restaurant stands out among other susheateries as a beacon of fish and freshness, a paragon of things delicious and delicate, the envy of every sushi boat wannabe in every non Japanese city in the world! 

Great portions of fish, excellent rolls, amazing prices. Wonderful! As just about every review here testifies: you'll love the food and you wont' spend much (for sushi), I promise.

Just don't come hungry. You'll most definitely wait an hour, maybe more depending on the night. There are two tables and about five bar stools with one chef frantically preparing gems of deliciousness in between cigarette breaks. I've been told "30 minutes more" and 2 hours later, I'm starving, bellicose and petulant and shoved food in my mouth so quick, I didn't taste a thing. The best thing to do is have a snack before you come--I'm not exaggerating when I say don't come hungry! And bring CASH ONLY!
author: Mario T.

description:
Sushi Zone was everything stated here. Absolute top quality sushi and an hour long wait for one of the 12-16 seats.

The Hamachi was amazing. Buttery and just the right texture. I had the Tuna rolls with mango and they were the same: the flesh just melts in your mouth and the mango is perfectly selected to yield in exactly the same way. Good size hunks of each.

The one criticism I have was that the Uni was not of the same caliber. Great Uni almost fizzes in your mouth, mediocre Uni is kind of brackish. This was the latter. I am not going to dock a star for one dish being off for an otherwise amazing meal.

The price was also quite reasonable for what you are getting. Highly recommended.
author: Tony D.

description:
I feel lucky to have experienced Sushi Zone like others haven't. One evening I simply walked in and sat at the bar with a friend. Normally I'd seen people waiting outside of this small, restaurant, no bigger than my bedroom. We order and had some sake. Everything was fine. We enjoyed the cozy atmosphere. It was like eating dinner at a friend's house. Our sushi was delicious: toro, salmon, and some fancy rolls.

Whether it's the hidden name of the restaurant (by overgrown trees), discrete location, or its small quarters, Sushi Zone embodies the "hole-in-the-wall" sushi hot spot that is coveted by foodies and those against the gastronomic status quo.
author: Tim B.

description:
Secret:  Arrive by 4:40PM to wait in line because the restaurant opens at 5PM.  

This restaurant has two booths (seats up to 5) and 8 bar stools, one server, two sushi chefs.  

If you don't get seated after the first round of seating, expect to wait one hour.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I'm a big sushi fan. Since I travel a lot, I've eaten my fair share of sushi all over the country. I am willing to pay $$$$ for top of the line sushi. So, when my friend I visited during a business trip in Mountain View mentioned Sushi Zone, I was game! A search on yelp seems to validate what she heard. Average of 4-5 stars. I was pretty excited so we decided to line up 30 mins before it opened so we can get guaranteed seating and not have to wait. Sure enough we were the 2nd in line and we got the last table. Okay, so far so good. Everyone else who were seated at the bar or the other table were still pouring over the menus so when the waitress came by to asked us what we want do drink, we decided to order.

Things went downhill from there. 

Even though we were the first ones to order, we didn't get our miso soup until after everyone else. That totally irritated me. Yes, there's only one waitress so I should be patient right? Nope. The place is small enough, she shouldn't have trouble forgetting. We had to remind her. After the reminder, she served the people waiting for a table their beers first before we even got our drinks and soup! Definitely a no no.

Then the sashimi came. All in all, it was okay. The fish was not bad, but it wasn't as fresh either. It was just okay.

Then the nigiri and rolls came. From what I've read through yelp, their specialty seems to be the rolls so I was pretty excited to try that. When I tried it, I was extremely disappointed. It was bland and I couldn't taste the fish. All I could taste was the sweet mango that came with it. Oh and they gave us the wrong roll. I didn't want to wait longer so we just ate what they gave us.

Then I looked at the nigiri sushi. I thought, okay, this must be why people are raving about this place. Each piece is humongous! I've never seen a cut of sushi that big before! Not only were they huge, they were cheap too! I took a bite and was instantly disappointed. Fish, when really fresh, is supposed to melt in your mouth. If you have to chew really hard, then it's not good fish. I don't know if it was too big, but I found myself chewing a lot before I can swallow the sushi.

So to summarize:
Pros:
-Cheap sushi
-Big cuts of fish

Cons:
-The pace is too small
-The wait is long if you don't get there before it opens
-rolls are okay, borderline bland
-forgetful waitress

All in all, if you want a cheap sushi place, then you should go here. But if you want quality I suggest you go somewhere else. The amount of time you have to wait is not worth the price.I'm not from SF but if you're ever in LA, try Mori sushi, Sushi Zone, or Urasawa. I guarantee that you will not be disappointed.
author: Jill A.

description:
I almost feel bad reviewing Sushi Zone on Yelp because I want to keep it all to myself. But I feel like the secret is out of the bag - at least that's what the 2 hour waits tell me!

This fishy little nook is as unpretentious as they come. Nothing flashy or fancy about these guys - just hands down good sushi. And the oft impressive waits are because there are only 2 tables and seats at the bar, and each morsel of food is given attention and care.

The reason the food takes awhile to come is because there are only three people running the place on any given night - dedicated sushi chef, charming little waitress and silent sushi sous chef (?). There is literally not room for any other staff.

Their sashimi and nigiri is always expertly sliced, with solid, meaty chunks of delight. The rice-to-stuff ratio in their rolls is also near perfection. And speaking of rolls, they really do a great job with concept and execution. Be sure not to miss Hawaiian #1, Hawaiian #2 and Spicy Mango Salmon. Mmmmm. Also a must have are the stuffed oysters. Maybe they are not stuffed. Actually maybe they are mussels. I'm not sure, but they are soooooo good!

Do know that they accept cash only and that the sushi chef will always accept a beer! I love this place, have been a million times and will definitely be heading there again soon!
author: Melanie D.

description:
there is nothing like sushi zone....sorry, peeps.  Nothing.  This place delivers pure oral pleasure and delight.  And the owners are so sweet.  And, the prices are reasonable.  I can barely express my passion for this place....

thank you sushi zone for making my life more joyful
author: Pamela W.

description:
My ABSOLUTE FAVORITE sushi joint in SF!! I cannot leave Sushi Zone without having the Hawaiian #1 and #2 rolls, mango hamachi roll,  and mussels.  

I have waited 2 hours more than once to be seated but I expected that. And yes, there is only 1 chef, assistant chef and waitress so you must be patient. For those of you who complain about this....deal with it or leave so that Sushi Zone lovers can take your place.

Also, please be considerate and do not sit for hours on end so that starving people waiting in line don't have to watch you eat and drink copious amounts of sake. Thank you!
author: Michelle T.

description: I brought my mom and a group here for a family dinner.  The sushi was really fresh and wonderful, it was well worth the wait.  For our group of 4 it was perfect, but I am not sure how they could accommodate a larger group if you wanted to sit at a table as opposed to the sushi bar.  Its a small place and it had a good crowd on a Monday night.  Yay for being open on Monday!  The owner also makes Sushi at the High Sierra Music Festival where I first met him.  I was happy to be able to support another live music lover and to have a chance to eat some top notch sushi.  Don't miss the Hawaiian Rolls and anything with mango or papaya is really good  They don't have chicken terriyaki or anything so this might not be the best place to take people who don't like sushi...
author: Greg K.

description:
One of the best "Hole in the Wall" places to get great fresh sushi, taste interesting special rolls and drink tasty sake. Get there early, or be prepared to wait. The restaurant seats about 15-20 people at it's maximum capacity. If you're up for getting a few drinks while you wait - Destino is around the corner on Market St, and the Orbit Room is just up about a half a block on the other side of the street.

If you have the time to spare and people to keep you entertained while you wait, this is definitely a unique spot.
author: noelle m.

description:
Much has been said about the long wait - to this I'll merely observe that there must be a reason, and it's not just because of the high demand for good sushi, and the low supply of seats.  I think the wait serves as a necessary hurdle to filter out those who are impatient, or who didn't bring cash, or who prefer instant gratification, or who don't know any better.  It's probably not a good idea to bring people who are used to super fast service, or who are deliriously starving.

Sometimes I just can't make it to Sushi Zone because logistics prevent me from (gasp!) blocking out an entire evening for dinner.  And that's ok - going without one night makes me appreciate it the next time.  But there are ways to deal with the wait to make it tolerable so you can partake in this gift to San Francisco - no, to humanity itself.  I suggest:
* enjoy a drink at Martuni's
* put your name on the list right after work, then go home for an hour (and do whatever you can do in an hour) and come back
* have a good conversation with your friends
* take a walk through the Castro

But please - don't glare at those who are lucky enough to be eating - they had to wait, too, and they usually know enough to not take any longer than they have to.  We're all in this together.

The fish - whether in the maki or nigiri - has never been less than pristine for me.  My standards were set in Tokyo, at the Tsukiji fish market - I know.  My only quibble is that there is never any fatty tuna on the menu - sometimes I like to splurge.  But that's ok - the bare necessities are what make Sushi Zone shine.

What I have enjoyed over and over:
Sea bass mango - what a friend calls 'sea bass crack' - is so fucking good... get it as an appetizer.
Spicy hamachi maki - julienned jalepeno, lime, and avocado - amazing!
Salmon skin maki - salty goodness!
Saba nigiri - my very high mackerel standards are always met here
Salmon (sake) nigiri - always great (best with slice of lime)
Hawaiian #2 maki - like a party in your mouth and everyone's invited
Spicy mussels maki - like its hamachi brother above - amazing
Spider maki - probably the most expensive thing on the menu, and worth it
Baked salmon w/shitake - I've only had this when I'm sure I won't go without the sea bass crack - very tasty

I've always had excellent service here - and by that I mean courteous, pleasant, and happy to see you.  If you can get there early, great.  If not - it's gonna be ok - sit back, relax, and enjoy the best sushi in SF for the price.
author: Marty F.

description: The only waiting I will ever do for sushi is for Sushi Dai at Tsujiki Market in Japan.  Otherwise, absolutely not worth the wait.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I've been to a million sushi resto's in my lifetime and I'd have to say that Sushi Zone is TO DIE FOR! Be sure to show up at the door at least 20-30 min. before opening time of 4:30p, or be prepared to wait for 1 of the roughly 15 total seats to open up. This is the smallest operating food establishment I have gone to; it's about the size of a very small studio apartment -- 10 x 20 ft at most (including the bathroom).

The whole place is ran by a three man team, a hip waitress, lieutenant sushi chef, and the MOST BAD-ASS LOOKING SUSHI CHEF you've ever seen. He wears this bandanna to keep his bangs from flopping over his eyes. The look on his face while he "creates" your sushi dish makes you feel like you're watching a ninja work... very focused and disciplined.

Although the lack of space may knock some cool points off of this joint, I'd have to say that the food certainly makes up for it. While you are busy sipping on your green tea or sake, you choose from a variety of items on a menu posted on the walls. With the fish so neatly displayed in a refrigerator on the bar, everything is freshly made. For dishes that are heated/toasted, they have just one Hamilton Beach-like home toaster oven. Dishes are all handwashed (I'm guessing a method to maximize space). 

If I didn't know this was a restaurant, I would thought I'd walk into a Japanese person's kitchen.

PROS:
- Best, fairly-priced sushi I've tasted in Years (Average $30/person)
- Quick, efficient service
- Ninja Sushi Chef

CON:
- SPACE
- SPACE
- No reservations
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
What can I say that has not already been posted about this place...

Even with many people waiting, they never rush and try to provide the best service possible.  I guess that is why people are willing to wait for hours sometimes.

Great sushi, reasonable price, personable service... I love this place
author: Jae C.

description:
In response to Sean L.'s review, the wait is long not because the kitchen doesn't know how to work efficiently, but because they really only have one sushi chef,  one who assists when not cleaning or preparing, another who makes the baked goodies, and one waitress. First come, first served. 

This place is pretty damn orgasmic. Be sure to write your name and party size on the white board located near the furthest booth from the entrance. If you don't have the patience to wait or don't like the sush here, I'd hit you with a chopstick, but I won't. Less people means less of a wait. I contemplated writing a review for Sushi Zone. No matter how much I want to share this goodness with the world, wouldn't it be nice to keep this place a secret?

First time I came here it was 630pm, put our names down and waited, and waited, and waited till we couldn't wait anymore! FYI, don't come here after 5pm and hungry. It's torture to watch one person or two enjoying their sushi while everyone else is waiting for theirs either sitting or waiting to be seated, and there you are knowing you won't be able to eat for another hour or two. Thank goodness for Hunan Garden next door. Read review on Hunan Garden.

Second visit, I came here around 5. This time I stayed, and waited about an hour to eat. OMG!!! Sooo gooood! I can understand why people are willing to wait patiently even though the wait isn't so pleasant. I come here religiously and always before they open. Now if I can only do the same with Catholicism. Get here at 5, and there's a line. You could  always put your name down, grab drinks around the corner and come back in an hour. Don't forget the cash!

Everything's pretty dang delish. The Baked Striped Bass w/ Mango comes in 2 pieces- I'll bet you can't just have one! Same goes with the Stuffed Shitake w/ Salmon and the Stuffed Jalapeno w/ Albacore (which I wish were spicy). The Spicy Mussel roll is good but again, not spicy.  The Spicy Mango Salmon, Spicy Albacore, and Spicy Hamachi (I like the slice of lime in this roll) are really good. A popular roll and definitely a favorite is the Hawaiian #2- Albacore, Mango, Macadamia Nuts. 

Omg, I'm having withdrawals and it's only been 3 days since I've been here last.
author: Audrey B.

description: Talk about a hidden gem! There isn't much to add to all of the other 5 star reviews, but a quick rehash of my experience was amazingly fresh sushi at very reasonable prices, a baked mussel that was a taste sensation and attentive service. One thing I was surprised about was the fact that although this place is tiny, they didn't seem to rush you, and when I ordered an additional sushi roll (2 actually) after my first order they were more than happy to oblige. Two things of note, their oven is a tiny easy bake oven looking thing, which really doesn't matter, but it just makes me laugh. Secondly, if you walk to their listed address you will think the place is closed because a different restaurant has that address, but do not fear, just turn the corner and you cant miss it. Enjoy!
author: Nick C.

description:
Had a *great* sushi experience here.  As others have said.. best to get there at 5pm or a little before if you want to minimize the wait, it's a small place.  That being said.. have some patience and you'll be duly rewarded.

Eating here was the first time I really decided to go for it with sushi and venture full force into raw territory.  I'm so glad I did and I'm so glad I did it here!

Highlights:
-Amazing spicy hamachi roll with jalapeno, avocado, lime, and sprouts (the lime flavor comes in just when you think your flavor trip is over and puts you into sush bliss)

-They have great musical taste (something you don't usually find at most restaurants) playing really good latin music.. might sound a little weird for a sushi place but it works.  I wanted to steal.. er borrow their cd collection.

-You just have such a good vibe eating there on a sunny evening, nice music, amazing sushi, and don't forget the sake!

-I had afterglow the whole night! :-)
author: Engelbert H.

description:
This place has really fresh, authentic and tasty sushi.  The price is also very reasonable.  The only bad thing is the waiting.  If you don't get there at 5, be prepared to stand around for at least an hour.

The baked mussels on half shells are really good too!
author: Bird A.

description:
Okay so I give them one star for the hour long wait I had to endure... ( I have ADD and I hate waiting) After I got over the waiting part and got to sit down to eat I had no more complaints. The food was delicious. I'm usually not a very adventurous sushi eater but this place opened my mind and mouth to some scrumptious new options. Try the baked mussels, they were great. I went with a friend and felt a little embarrassed at the end when the bill came because they are a cash only joint. oppsy should of hit up the ATM first. 
Actually don't come here... then there won't be room for my selfish butt
author: Sunshine S.

description:
I've just been back for another visit, and had to update my review to five stars.  

The sushi here is INCREDIBLE.

I just had the best spicy hamachi roll of all time.

And again, the albacore is unreal.

I think I've met my regular sushi joint.  Hel-lo!
author: Jessica H.

description:
This is my absolute favorite sushi place in the city, or even in the east bay for that matter... and by  how long the wait is to get a seat, I am sure I'm not the only one thinking so.

There's one chef, one server, and a world of wonderful flavors.  The sushi chef is SOOO DOPE, and so creative, and the fish is so fresh... it's worth the wait.

If you get a seat at the bar, get some Sake, and offer the chef a shot....

and remember PATIENCE IS A VIRTUE, bitches!
author: Bone D.

description:
The most terrible thing about Sushi Zone: this restaurant will *completely ruin* all other sushi experiences for you.  I cannot go to any other sushi place, as I already know it will never measure up to the luminous and infinite goodness that is The Zone.  Truly the apotheosis of sushi, the Platonic pinnacle of raw (and in the case of that mango hamachi mussel shell niblet of heaven, cooked) fish.

So it is freakin tragedy that the establishment that would so render all other sushi establishments superfluous (if not an affront) basically makes you a zombie slave to its infrastructural limitations.  Like everyone else has said: it's TEEN-EINTSY (two tables for four and maybe 6 or 7 at the bar), has a staff of three (one waitress, a chef, and a diswasher/rice maker/mussel baker/and more), and a waitlist system that causes endless amounts of anxiety ('course, that could just be the hunger talking).

I understand the frustration that others have expressed about the wait--which is utterly ridiculous and entirely unavoidable--but we regulars put ourselves through this bcs, again: zombie slaves.  It is the best fucking sushi EVER, and some of us love sushi that much.  So here are some rules we've come up with to better manage the experience:

1. Eat something before you go.  Seriously.  It will be two hours before you eat again, so pick an appropriate meal for your digestive pace.

2. SZ opens at 5 pm.  You need to show up sometime around 4:40 pm to secure a place in line that will assure you seating among that first batch of diners.  Do not be surprised if there is already a queue when you get there.  Use that information to assess how much earlier you have to arrive next time.
     NB: if you miss first seating (this is not an actual term, it's just how I think of it), you *might* be able to pare down your wait time if you arrive some time around 6:45 and get your name on that list pronto.  I've never tried this strategy, but it's one I've thought about after watching the ebb and flow of the dinner crowd.

3. If you got seated at 5 pm, you will eat around 6:30.  Yup.  Hope you had that suggested meal.

4.  Although you may not be able to help the hunger-induced cross-eyed grimace on your face, try not to glare at those seated.  Likewise, I *completely* understand the urge to linger at your table--finally getting seated feels like a darwinian victory--but just try not to be too gloaty about it.  Someone might eat you, and you could hardly blame them.

I disagree with the reviewer who said SZ becomes more and more inefficient as the night wears on.  On the contrary, given their staff and space constraints, I constantly marvel at the well-honed efficiency of the organization.  The three of them NEVER STOP WORKING, and working HARD, and yet they are always pleasant and courteous and the food and drink come out just as fast as they can.  (90 minutes?!?  Um, again, remember the constraints.)

It's true that The Zone is not for everyone, and you really have to be ready to take in ALL aspects of that dining experience.  But if you know what you're getting into, and can prepare for it, you will be rewarded with sushi nirvana.  Get the spicy tuna, mango hamachi, and the Hawaiian #1 (oh god yess, the Hawaiian #1) and tell yourself your evening would have been a boring one anyway.
author: V. m. g.

description:
was delicious!!!! tried this place for the first time about 4 days ago and i have to admit, seeing the cost of items on the menu before coming here, i thought this was one of those overhyped sushi places rated by people high on hallucination drugs. but, honestly, this place is delicious. the small place is a stroke of genius for them - makes ppl want to eat there more bc its intimate and if ppl are waiting outside, this place must be good rite? it sure is. there are literally two booths that can sit a max of 6 people per booth, and about 8 bar seats, althoguh they will add an extra stool at the bar for a party if needed.  We came 40 min before opening time, at 420. we were the first ones in line and food came promptly because of this. when the resturant opened at 5 there was already 4 more parties behind us. they take orders and serve based on order arrived, which is very fair if you're the first party, not so very "fair" if you're the last person in line ^^. 

during my family and I's one hour eating time, 6 more couples signed up on the clipboard list, were told there would be an hour or more wait, in which they walked out the door....to wander around the neighborhood for an hour or so before their table was ready. theres a lot of mango related items on the menu, and like others before me recommended, be sure to try the baked mussels and seabass, both of which are served in large mussel shells. the baked mussels and seabass are both topped with a delicious creamy mayo-like sauce and little cut up pieces of mango. the baked mussels are just pieces of cut-up,mussel chopped up, with a delicious sauce on top and the delicious, delicate flavor of mussel juice which you can slurp out of the shell along with the mussels themelves. sorry did that sound weird? in my head it sounds delicious. dont order sashimi (which is plain raw sushi slices with no rice or toppings) b/c in my opinion the price isnt worth it;it tastes like sashimi at every other sushi place in sf - without the heavy price tag. be wise and adventurous and try their unique tiems. we got t 4 rolls - the only name i remember was the hawaiin roll b/c of the unique topping of macademia nuts on top - a generous portion of crushed macadamia nuts. im generally not a fan of mac nuts but the rolls were GOOD. i would definitely come back if not for the price - i dont like spending a lot of money on food.

 one star was taken off for the prices - but i would definitely come back here again.

UPDATE: came here again. this place is no joke. Fairly cheap (for japanese food) if you know what to order. once again, Dont order sashimi unless u have a real craving for it. triples your bill and you can get sashimi elsewhere. Would order the baked seabass and definitely their salmon nigiri. mmm mm mm
author: Vicky T.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've ever had.

Everything was fresh, the flavor was excellent, and the atmosphere was tons of fun. We waited quite a while for a seat, but that's part of it.

Can't wait for next time.
author: Amber H.

description: This little restaurant is very good. The major downfall was how long it took us to get a table- almost an hour maybe more? People were waiting there for 2 hours! However, it was worth the wait. I love super small sushi restaurants because they are more intimate and cozy. The waitress let us drink some sake while we were waiting, so that helped speed up the process! The rolls were delicious as well as the seaweed salad. I'm definitely going to return, but maybe try and make a reservation first?
author: Sonya D.

description:
Sushi seems to lie on two different poles in San Francisco.


 You've got the expensive, serious sushi, where fresh fish is flown in from international fish markets on a regular basis, the presentation is an art form, and you have to take out a mortgage if you want to indulge in a complete dinner.


 Then you've got the cheap places where you stick to the rolls, order up a few sake bombs, and pray that you consumed enough alcohol to kill whatever bug might've been in the cheap fish.


 Very few places bridge the gap, occupying the veritable neutral zone in between these polar opposites of the sushi scene. The aptly named Sushi Zone fills it admirably.


 While one would to best to avoid rolls (maki) and go for the good stuff at high-end sushi restaurants, and avoid nigiri and stick to California rolls and Dynamite rolls and Caterpillar rolls on the low-end, Sushi Zone has a unique niche by specializing in rolls comprised of fresh, less commonplace combos.


 Papaya unagi. Mackerel and ginger. Mango and striped bass.


 Traditional? Barely.


 Delicious, fresh, and prepared by an entertaining middle-aged Japanese man with amusing stories? Most definitely.


 The downside, of course, is the well-documented wait. It can be eternal. Infernal. Downright perpetual. Another downside is the small size. Not only does it contribute to the wait, but if you happen to be seated near someone with no sense of voice modulation, you may well spend an hour involuntarily listening to someone's boring, insipid stories.


 But dammit, I love the mango and striped bass. And hence, I love Sushi Zone. Loudmouth-annoying-girl-with-boring-stories-sitting-behind-me and all.
author: Omid T.

description:
Ok, so i don't know that anyone is really addressing the issue of the ritual of sushi zone.

The fish: it's fine. Always fresh, perhaps cut a little too thickly, and certainly with a Cali twang that only satisfies the equal opportunists of the sushi world. Are you a purist? Don't come here.

The scene: it's tiny. i love the petite stature of the place, and the waitress, who is always there, is the cutest thing EVER. She'll remember you by the second time you've been there.

The ritual: You have to put your name on the list. Look how many people are on the list before you and peeer around to see where others seem to be in their meals. If there are at least 4-5 people in front of you and everyone is in various stages, or just the beginning, get ready to wait. 

The waiting is fine. Move on down to Martuni's and grab a stiff one //mind out of the gutter//. A drink. A manhattan even.

Go back, check on your place and head out to the orbit room. Get a shot and a beer or one of the pint sized mojitos.

Then go back, and no matter what, wait. You don't want to be slobbering drunk, now, do you?
author: Brer R.

description: my friend told me about this place Excellent sushi and the prices were suprisingly affordable,I love this place! The wait is long, but it is worth the wait
author: Nicole R.

description:
DEEEEEEE-LISCIOUS!!!!
However, keep track of how much sake you drink! It can be a bit of a wait and by the time you are seated you may be HAMMER TIME! So proceed with caution! I didn't think I'd like the Mango/Macadamia nut roll because I'm a bit anti-Hawaii at the moment (a story that is neither here nor there) but I loved it! Also the oyster appetizer thing is also really good too! The hamachi sashimi - smooth like fucking butter - yes, it was that good! Can't wait for payday - I'm going for seconds, thirds, fourths....
author: Alexis D.

description:
Yes, the sushi was good.  There are also some really interesting side dishes that I saw other people get that I want to try next time.  

But I don't know that I will live long enough or have the patience and understanding to have a next time.  My culinary experience was grossly overshadowed by the 2 hour long wait, which should have been just less than an hour long wait.  The waitress said that we had to be requeued because we were not there when she called, DESPITE her original statement that we would be seated as the next party if we came in after our party was called.  When it finally came turn for us to be seated, she ended up seating a party who came after we got requeued because she did not see our name on the list.  

Waiting to order and waiting for the food also took excruciatingly long.  One of our rolls was not delivered to us, when we brought this up, the sushi chef (owner?) implied that we were lying.  Despite all that, I still tipped the "obligatory" 15+% because I'm spineless.

So I'm conflicted on rating this.  Food, I would give a 4(the official rating), service gets a 0.5 for social ineptitude.
author: Linda Y.

description:
This is by far THE best sushi in San Francisco, and I am talking about reeaal sushi.. The last time I ate here was a year ago... yes one year ago!..., But I can still remember how the fish melted in my mouth (+ my memory)... It was a blast! The whole dinner took 4 hours, including the waits: one for the table, and one for the snail service.. BUT, it's still worth it!

Been trying to coming back, but had to give it up after 45 mins wait. Maybe next time when I have 4 hours to spare for dinner.
author: Andy W.

description:
zOMG zOMG!!! the mussels!!! the sushi!!! the line......

The wait time is what stopped me from giving this fantabulous place a perfect score...

Waiting in line for what seemed like days, cold and famished, we finally got to eat our mussels and hawaiin rolls! MMMMMMMMM.....eating those just gave me a warm and tingly feeling inside. 

The Mussels are highly recommended as well as any sushi roll that combines raw fish with mango!!!

My advice, try and get there at 5:00pm when it opens, otherwise be prepared for a looonnnggg wait
author: Calvinn W.

description:
I'm not sure what all this "best sushi in the milky way" thing is all about.  Zone definitely has fresh quality sushi, and the tiny place is very cute.  What's the big deal about that?  That being said, the sushi is very creative and yummy, although they seem to rely a bit too much on mayonnaise as a flavor enhancer.  I tend to dislike too much mayo involvement in my sushi experience, however Zone does a solid job with it.  
We got there very early (around 4:45) and waited until they opened so we could sit right away.  It was a fun time, and I will go back again!  But gosh people, be a little more judicious with the 5 stars!
author: Mr. G.

description:
Well, It's like this. I never liked sea food nor did I ever think I would. My extent of sea food was fish and chips maybe once every 2 years. And that a generous myriad of time. Buy my lady friend Paola forced it down my food pipe. And now... I like I. Plus Sushi Zone was my first real dive into sea food. Loved it. And still testing the waters. Both figurative and literal. Thanks Pay-pay.

Get the baked sea bass with mango. It's Bananas! But it's mango.
author: Lou Z.

description:
I was told the baked mussels is the specialty dish here so I tried it and it was delicious! I do not really like mussels, but the ones here were the best I've ever had. They melt in your mouth.

The sushi was interesting too since they add mango and macadamia nuts to some of them. The quality is fresh.

The place is small (only 2 tables and a bar) so the wait can get really long. Personally I would not wait again (should go early around 5ish) but there were many people lined inside and outside the restaurant who didn't seem to mind.
author: Stephen S.

description: Delicious Sushi.  Great tiny place.  Long wait worth it.  Fantastic Salsa music plays while you dine, what else can one ask for?
author: Ana E.

description: The consensus seems to be that everyone has to wait a long time to be seated at this restaurant, here's a tip, make the waitress see you, or else you will be ignored just like my bf and I were last night, pretending we weren't there cost them a star, the sticky table and the almost 45 minutes to get our food after ordering cost them another star. I will say that things did look up after getting the baked mussels, they were great, warm, savory, a little kick to them, perfect. The rainbow roll was enormous, each piece was fresh, buttery, and required 2-3 bites each. The spicy hamachi was by far my fave, it felt like a cross between sushi and ceviche. To wrap it up, the place is tiny so you better not have somewhere to be, cause you'll be late, generous portions, decent prices in a somewhat loud setting.
author: Chunker N.

description:
Yes, the wait is horrendous.

Thankfully, I live a block away and can scribble my name on the white board and go home to wait it out.  Sushi Zone takes planning and patience.  DO NOT SHOW UP HUNGRY.  You will be sad.  And your belly will be angry.  If you want to eat sushi here, plan ahead and get your name in early.  There are several bars in the area that can keep you occupied for an hour (or more).  

All that said, the sushi is the freshest I have had.  My favorite rolls are the spicy himachi, the Hawaiian #2 and the papaya-unagi.  They also do the edamame up right.   And last, but certainly not least, it is SO cheap.  My hubby and I can kill miso soups, edamame, 3 or 4 rolls, beer and sake for around $50.  Can't beat that.
author: Leah W.

description: Sushi Zone is so good, for food and value.  Their rainbow roll and sea bass with mango appetizer are delicious.  Their rolls with fresh mango are very tasty and satisfying.  The food leaves your stomach feeling warm and fulfilled from all the good food.  The quality of the sashimi is great, and I have not had one thing on this menu that I didn't love, so you can't really go wrong with it.
author: Nadine K.

description: They do a happy hour special with sake and rolls, have large portions for all their dinner plates/boxes, and have super yummy chicken katsu. I'm a fan. Plus, you can eat really well with rolls, apps, tempura, and prob even a dessert, for less than $22 a person. Bonus that you can watch the people doing karaoke next door at The Mint on a projection while you wait for takeout :)
author: Jenz y.

description:
Fantastic place, however let me warn you this place is SMALL (think Tokyo Ramen shop small) and the wait is pretty long esp if you get there late.

The food however is great. I'm not really a sushi person (odd considering I'm mostly Japanese right?) But the spicy salmon rolls and spicy scallops are phenomenal. The owner/chef's quality control is rigid and it is inspiring to see someone who takes so much pride in his craft.
author: Takeo E.

description:
I'm glad I live a block away from this place!  For anyone deciding to go to here to eat, please prepare your zen like patience as you could be gearing for a 2+ hour wait. However, some days are better than others.  

Every time I had to wait, it was well worth it.  Its a little more convenient for me as I can just put my name down, hang out, and then give my taste buds some serious treats.

The Hawaiian # 2 is my absolute favourite with Albacore tuna, avocado, green onion, fresh mango, and topped with crushed macadamia nuts.  Truly one of the most creative and delicious sushi i have ever tasted.

With regards to the sea bass appetizer, you might need to get multiple, as its very difficult to share.

Anyways I should probably give 1 star so no one can find out this hidden gem.
author: Steve O.

description: If you like fresh fish at reasonable prices then Sushi Zone is the place for you! The hamachi sashimi was awesome with generous portions. I would stick to the more traditional sushi/sashimi choices since the rolls tend to taste more like rice than anything else. It's a small place so get there early or expect to wait!
author: Helen Y.

description:
One of our favorite sushi places in the City. Good luck getting a table. There are only about 16 seats in this place, so you really just have to get lucky and hope that the group ahead of you got bored and left or got too drunk next door. My wait times have been from 5 mins to near 2 hours and usually it is worth it in the end.

Sushi is fresh and the rolls are a unique mix of fresh island mixes like tuna, macadamia nut and mango. Most stuff is pretty damn good here. The baked oyster mixes are amazing. It's always just one man working the sushi bar, one on the baking station and a busy waitress. The wait always leads us to order too much, but that's not really a bad thing. Food wait is awhile after seating, but only because it is a one-man show. If the sushi chef is in a good mood and not overwhelmed he is a very cool guy who will talk your ear off about his favorite bands. Even though it will just add to the waittime, I highly recommend this place, it's too hard not to give them cred.
author: Nick V.

description: What an amazing dining experience! I was told to get there right when they opened or else it would take a while to get seated, so my party enjoyed an early dinner. We enjoyed some big boy Sapporo's after ordering. This ended up being a good move since the food did take quite a while to arrive. This is probably because there is only one (awesome-looking) sushi chef at the whole restaurant. When the food finally arrived, it was well worth the wait. The nigiri is so fresh, it melts in your mouth. We ordered a few rolls with spicy mango, which I had never had in sushi. After traveling in Thailand, I learned never to pass up an opportunity for mango + rice! This strategy proved once again to be the right move. We also had an awesome roll with fried soft-shell crab, which was also bomb. My only gripe with the food was I felt like the rolls fell apart easily when I was using chopsticks, although the multiple sapporos may have contributed to my decreased coordination. Overall, this was a very unique dining experience with some of the best sushi I have had in SF.
author: Evan S.

description:
MAN. I heard so many great things about this place that my expectations were way too high. I'm not sure what it is, but I'm just not that impressed w/ this place. Fish is fine, good even - but I love sushi. The snobby part of me, though, says boo to the yucky display of fish that is very visible from the bar seating. I don't expect a fancy display of fish but I believe raw fish should look appetizing and reflect cleaniness vs. just piled in a disorganized mess of hamachi, sake and saba. Sushi is an art as much as it is a meal, right? I don't know about you but looks do count.

Nigiri/fish quality - 3.5. star
Service - 3 stars
Ambiance - 2.5 stars

There are too many solid no-fuss sushi places like Kazu, Wayo and GrandeHo to make a trip down Market to Sushi Zone. Sorry....
author: Deann M.

description:
THE BEST sushi joint in THE CITY.  One of my favorite places. 

My brain doesn't automatically think of  this restaurant whenever I have a toro craving because it's such an ordeal of planning out approximate bus routes, boxing out the couple on their first date, and hurdling over old ladies. ORDEAL.

I mean, the food is REALLY worth going for. Even if I have to sign up early and spend an hour taking tequila shots at Mint. Well, its a good thing I love Karaoke. 

Win-WIn. 

I really wish I lived a block away. Or seeing a guy that lives a block away so he can sign up for me. Its all about real estate. Sure, a view of the Alcatraz or the Golden Gate  is great but access to this list, is priceless. 

Hmm....if you live near Sushi Zone,  email me and name your price.
I think I might be on to something here.....
author: Cin H.

description: I'm the type that only writes reviews when something is particularly exceptional or offensive. Sushi Zone has really good sushi at really good prices, though the wait is insane, even for cosmopolitan standards. If you are told about an hour wait, expect over two. Which is fine if you want two hour wait sushi, but this place is not that by any stretch. Also, pray you aren't seated past 10:00 (their closing time) or you will be vying for attention while the sushi chef bleaches the rice cooker and your waitress is counting the money for the night. Honestly they don't need to pay attention to you because there will be hundred SF residents lined out the door the next night who think they've found the next underground sushi joint in the city. I'm happy to say I am one of those people no more.
author: Tim O.

description: You might notice that most people love the sushi, but hate the wait. Come early (before 4:30p if possible), or be prepared for an hour+ wait. Fresh, quality fish, and generous cuts for very reasonable prices. This place is tiny, with only two small tables and bar seating, so it is not good for groups. There is a creative selection of tasty rolls, but they don't go overboard with schmansy varieties (i.e., weird ingredients or excessive mayo drawings on your plate). The sushi chef takes his time to prepare quality sushi and sashimi, so don't go too hungry, as there will likely be a solid wait for your food. There is only one sushi chef, one waitress, and one assistant/dishwasher, however service is friendly and attentive. Bottom line is if you can either come early or be prepared for the wait, you will enjoy the food and will not be disappointed.
author: Nancy F.

description:
I have to thank fellow yelper Danny D.  for bringing me here.   After 1 experience I felt it would be possible to die on the spot, very happy.  Three things:
 
(1) Get there early and do not under any circumstances, leave your spot, unless you've got friends holding it for you.  We almost came to blows with another couple who didn't take too kindly to our claims that we were the second in line ... 10 minutes ago.  They were eventually placated with hot sake, but you get the picture.  Yes! Sushi Zone is worth fighting for!
 
(2) Yes to anything with macadamias.  Yes to the freshfreshfresh fish and particularly to the sake (salmon) nigiri with wafer-thin slices of lime. Yes to the amazing prices for the quality of food. 
 
(3) Set your expectations early.  Do not expect to be "in-and-out" super-quick.  Plan on spending at least a couple of the best gastronomic hours of your life either sitting at the sushi bar or at one of their Two tables for 4.  And drink while you're waiting for the food.  It helps the time go by a bit faster.
author: Claudine C.

description:
I think i agree with most people that have Yelped that the wait here is Ridiculous.   Either get there early so you can skip the wait (they open at 530 i think) or sign up on their wait list and grab a drink around the corner.  

The place is small.  There are two tables that seat 4 and seating around the sushi bar.   While you're waiting for a spot, I highly recommend the Nigiri Sake, a chilled sake with about 4 servings in it for 6 or 7 dollars.  We went as a group of four and consumed probably 7 of these.

The sushi is divine, we had both types of Mango Sushi, Baked Scallops, some Sashimi and we let the waitress make suggestions.  Everything we had was delicious.  If you can endure the wait, I highly recommend this place.
author: Myke H.

description: Small little cozy place with great fresh sushi! Went on a Monday night and the wait was ~30 minutes, but worth it. Travel a lot for work and this was one of the best sushi places I have been to. You have to order the baked mussels, I actually ordered them twice it was so good!
author: Aaron W.

description:
I like many others have lost faith in finding good sushi in the bay area...until I found SUSHI ZONE!  The food here is fresh, great portions, and reasonably price. 

During one trip here, 4 friends and I had 2 bottles of sake, 2 bottles of Asahi, seaweed salad, 3 orders of baked stripe bass and 6 rolls.  The bill came out to about 12 dollars a person.

Side notes: 
- Be sure to sign in on the waitlist. 
- The restaurant is just a sushi bar and 2 booths that seat about 4-5 people each.
- Be patient. There is only one sushi chef, one assistant, and one waitress.

 Mmm...I could probably eat here every day, if mercury poisioning wasn't an issue =P

P.S. A little beer and sake makes the wait seem shorter
author: E C.

description:
There are three key aspects which make Sushi Zone a complex, frustrating, intriguing, and incredible spot.

1. The Wait. You will have to wait at least 20 minutes here, unless you arrive at 5pm. Once I arrived at 5:30 and still had to wait. As has already been mentioned, after waiting to be seated, you will also have to wait to be served. I guarantee that you won't be here less than an hour and a half in total, so plan accordingly. I recommend a light salad before coming so that you don't start drinking the chopsticks. Because, ouch.

2. The location. You'd never know this place was here. I like secrets.

3. The sushi. Frickin amazing. The rolls are generous, fresh, and inexpensive-- the best deal in the city, as far as I can tell. They don't skimp on anything, be it flavor, size, accoutrements, or freshness. Everything is exquisitely prepared and delicious. The appetizers are phenomenal, particularly the spicy mussels. I'm not a fan of the macadamia nut or cream cheese weirdo sushi stuff, so I can't really comment on that, but their rainbow roll is probably the best I've ever had. 

They could definitely add more dining seating in the back by the mirrored counter where people tend to sit and wait to be seated at the bar or in booths. And, I agree with another reviewer--was it Toro E.?-- who remarked that it would speed things along to have an apprentice. But if you want fresh, satisfying, unpretentious, and affordable sushi in the Hayes Valley/Market st. area, this is the place to go. Just don't go starving.

(They'd get a fifth star if they would shape up a bit and get real about seating/wait time!)
author: Molly A.

description:
I LOVE this place.  I almost want to give it zero stars so it's not as popular and I don't have to wait as long.  

Yes, the lines are long, but it's a small, authentic sushi hut in the middle of San Francisco - with very reasonable prices.  They could improve the name, I suppose - but it's a great atmosphere and I get to practice my Japanese there.  The waitress is cute and very friendly.  And most importantly, the food is YUM! - check out the stuffed jalapenos!
author: Tommy O.

description:
To eat here you must have: 
1) Patience and lots of it - There are literally two tables that seat 4 people each and then a sushi bar area that can fit 8-10. There are a total of three employees (a chef, a waitress and an assistant). You have to be ready to wait for your seat and there's nothing you can do about it. I suggest that you arrive when you're not quite hungry yet. The hunger will be sure to build as you watch others eat.

2) Cash - They don't take credit card, so come prepared. 

3) Love of sushi - The space is small and so is their menu selection. They only serve sushi and a small selection of other items (salad, etc.). They DO NOT serve bento boxes or teriyaki so if someone in your party does not appreciate raw fish or the art of sushi, maybe you should dine elsewhere. 

4) Comfort in tight spaces - They've maxed out any available space for the dining patrons so while you wait for your table, you may find yourself squished in a corner or standing outside. Again, patience is a virtue. 

Although the above may deter you from dining here, it shouldn't. All good things are worth waiting for and this is the prime example of why. Once you finally sit, the sushi is fresh and the rolls are inventive and mouth-watering. Ever had sushi with mango or papaya or macadamia nuts? If you are patient enough to venture here, you will and it will be awesome.
author: eileen b.

description:
Per Johanna C., the wait is definitely "not so good."  In fact, it sucks butt.  Seriously, why does anyone wait in line for over a half hour in SF when there are so many sushi joints?

Frankly, it's the baked sea bass with mango served piping hot in mussel shells.  Sometimes my dining companion and I have to order one apiece so that we can each savor the yummy combination of the fresh chopped mango and sea bass twice.  Makes my mouth water just thinking about it.

This is a teeny tiny restaurant so if you're not one of the first ones waiting in line for the restaurant to open, don't bother waiting.  Come back post-dinner crush time.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
Who knew such a place existed?!  The types of rolls they offer and the quality of fish are amazing.  I love ordering the baked mussels for my appetizer - they are really yummy (and after waiting about an hour - these little morsels definitely satisfy your hunger).  

Definitely be prepared to wait a while if you are unfortunate enough to be on the LONG waitlist - but it's definitely worth it .
author: Cherlyn M.

description: This place has very good cuts of fish that are very fresh. The flavors of their rolls are insanely good. I will definitely be a regular. The only negative is the size of the place. I wish they would expand or change locations to accommodate their ever growing patronage.
author: An Marie M.

description:
my husband and I came here starving one day, after hiking on the coast sand dunes, waited only a few minutes and slid into a couple of seats at the bar as they became vacant. mmmmm, plum wine, mmmmm sapporro, mmmmmm, spider rolls. It was all so delicious and fresh! We love this little place.........specials! ......get the specials on the board!.........
 
we had our twins with us in packs, and rolled out of there laughing so hard we almost peed our pants, because we kept dropping bits of rice on the baby's heads as we attempted to eat sushi with chopsticks while carrying them! I twas the most fun day ever!
author: Marisa A.

description: The best sushi in the city, certainly. Worth the wait, especially since you can just go around the corner and wait in Pisco, or across the street to Orbit room. Best thing on the menu is the baked bass, without a doubt. The hawaii rolls are also amazing. Go right at 5pm and you won't have to wait at all!
author: Sophie K.

description:
Holy crikey. Sushi amazing. Sake delicious. Wait long. Worth it.

One of my favorite sushi places of all time. It seemed to thin out after 9:30pm (on a Monday night, at least), so that might be a good time to go.
author: Blake E.

description:
Fresh and tasty.  Long waits, slow service and no reservations, but who cares because this place is awesome.  The prices arent cheap, but better than most of the larger sushi restaurants.

Get there early and dont forget to write your name on the chalkboard on the back wall.  If you come after 630pm, expect up to a 2 hour wait to sit and another 30 mins to get your first course.
author: Rob U.

description:
My friend's and I refer to it as "the zone". The owner/sushi chef places traditional Japanese fare against creative South American fusion. It's well worth the wait - and with two tables and a small counter, there often is one. If your food takes a while, buy the sushi chef a beer - it's a surefire way to get it sooner than later.

Best item on menu is their appetizer: grilled striped sea bass on a bed of mango's.
author: Chris I.

description:
We were waiting for it to open and managed to be the first one to get a table. Waited another 15 minutes before the server took our order, and our food arrived after at least 1 hour. That is ridiculous! The spider roll was the worst sushi I ever had, burned with bitter taste of course. I tried the spicy mango and also Hawaiian 1 but nothing special about those(was recommended by the server)-too much avocado and small portion.

Honestly, Nara Sushi at Polk Street is better! I will certainly not go to Sushi Zone again. Waste of my time, and very NOISY!
author: Myra T.

description:
There's plenty to complain about when going to Sushi Zone. The service can be slow, and combined with the wait for a coveted seat, it can be almost unbearable at times. But as soon as you get your food, the anxiety will melt away. 

The one thing Sushi Zone does right is sushi, especially fat rolls filled with everything from mangoes and limes to their own take on the spicy tuna roll. Big slices of raw fish ensure you won't leave hungry.

A few tips: 
- Get there as soon as they open their doors if you want to eat right away.
- Don't go if you are already hungry. Be prepared to wait.
- Order appetizers as soon as you sit down.
- You have to order everything at once from the waitress, so be careful not to let your hunger overshadow your judgement. On the other hand, if you want to order just one more thing later on, you will be put back in the queue, so it's best to think your order through carefully.

My favorites include: stuffed jalapeno, maguro sushi, and the spicy tuna roll. But most anything on their menu is great.
author: Timothy P.

description:
There are two types of people in this world:

#1 - Those who already know (or immediately recognize) that "The Zone" is unrivaled in it's class. Pants Down. 

and

#2 Those who just don't get it, don't care to get it, and probably never will get it. The rest of us hope you never get it. The line is long enough as is.

The fish tastes so fresh here that it's almost like it just swam to your plate. And where else can you actually afford to eat yourself into a sushi coma?

While waiting to eat at "The Zone", veterans experience a certain zen-like weightlessness, detachment, and freedom from expectation, seldom found in a dining experience. They are also usually happily getting drunk over at the Orbit Room or Martuni's while they patiently wait for their name to come up on the "list". There are rules to follow. There are things you must know. This is true. 

Which reminds me. It's about time for another pilgrimage.
author: Frank Y.

description:
Currently a favorite sushi spot for me.  The service is very friendly and the chef is amazing.  You will get a sizeable cut of fish for your sashimi or nigiri and they have some other small dishes that are pretty spectacular.  The baked striped bass with mango in particular is a must order any  time I go here.  Try some different things and you'll find favorites as well.

Sushi Zone is very small (only about 15 people can eat at any given time) so go here when you have some time and expect a wait.  To make this less painful, you can sign up on the little whiteboard and head out for a drink or two then come back.  They normally won't erase your name so you get your place in line back when you return.   You can also get there right when they open and try to be in the first wave for seating.  

It's a good spot.
author: Zach J.

description:
I don't care what anyone says, it's still the best-sushi-EVER...IMHO. And it's oh-so-worth the wait. One could call it fantastic and down-right delicious. I do. But that's just me. And the others I've recruited to the Zoneatology.

I make it my once in a while treat. I go knowing I'll wait an hour or two....Go with one more person or a small group. Go to Zeitgeist or to Orbit Room, get a cocktail, drink the time away. Trust me, it works every time. 

Oh and their price for what you get, can't be beat! Cheap! Cheap!

Do be warned....if you're with a giant group, in a rush, grumpy, hungrier than hungry, or just plain lame, don't bother. We don't need you there anyways.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I guess I never reviewed sushi zone because I figured it's all been said and there are really only five words to say about it anyway...

baked. sea. bass. and. mango.

I guess, on second thought though, I could say a few more... 

1) be ready for a wait.  put your name on the list and go have a drink at Martuni's.  (I'd suggest the Orbit room except the bartender there takes almost as much time to make a cocktail as the wait does at Sushi Zone.. which I guess can work out but by the time you get your drink and down it you may have lost your spot on the list at the zone)

2) bring cash.  it's cash only, but it's ok because you won't need much of it.

3) use the specials menu on the wall - everything you need to know in life is there.  which leads me to the next point...

4) hamachi kama.  somehow, they sell prepared hamachi kama for pretty much the exact same price it costs to buy it at the store.  and it's amazing.  get it.

5) when you order the sea bass and mango to start, go ahead and get the stuffed mushrooms as well.  they're also awesome.

that is all.
author: Bill B.

description: Hands down, the best sushi in SF, and possibly outside of Japan. Just like the reviews say, expect a long wait. So don't go there, get pissed off you are waiting too long and come back on here and write a negative review. Your reviews should be rated on FOOD only, especially since you were forewarned many times before even stepping into the place. You can go have your special sushi rolls that have elaborate, albeit creative names, sit at a table that was made from pure mahogany, be seen and observe the ritzy clientele and the sushi would be a 10. Then you can come here, without children and eat sushi that sets the standard for raw seafood lovers everywhere with a chart topping, off the scale Spinal Tap 11. Hey, if you are tired of waiting, go around the corner and have a drink @ Pisco.
author: Brandan P.

description:
hands down the best sushi i've had.  not only are the prices and portions more than generous, but the quality of the fish is AMAZING.  the only bad thing i have to say is that it has completely ruined all other sushi restaurants for me.  i find myself always paying more for less at other places and the quality is never comparable unless i'm at a super expensive restaurant.  i recommend any of their sushi (nigiri) particularly the salmon and the uni, and even though i'm not big on rolls, the spicy hamachi roll is fantastic and a must. atmosphere is small and cozy and staff is extremely friendly. i guarantee you will never find a place that is better at this price, anywhere in the world.

one tip... get there about 15 min before 5 or you may find yourself waiting up to two hours or more for a seat.
author: Kia P.

description: I tried sushi only a handful of times before I discovered Sushi Zone because I didn't think I liked raw seafood (to be honest).  One night, emboldened by the safety score rating of 100 I spied posted within their establishment and encouraged by praise my boyfriend heaped on the place, I enthusiastically ordered a variety of sashimi.  Awestruck by just how fresh the pieces were, together with the minimalistic presentation, I could say the experience was almost spiritual, it was just so mouthwateringly delectable, and I realized I had really been missing out.  Sushi is probably my favorite cuisine now, and no other place I've tried could compare to Sushi Zone.  Furthermore, the intimate, family-owned space with mid-century-like booths is charming, genuine and hip, even romantic.  Lastly, the waitress was attentive, welcoming and polite.  I love this restaurant, and it epitomizes the best of unpretentious but top-quality SF-city dining for me.
author: Lisa V.

description:
Plus 6: Supa FRESH fish! Great combinations & great price! Nondesript location and interior! 

Cons 1: Cash only & the wait (over an hour)

Plus 1: Martuni's down the street!

Do the math!
author: Lionel D.

description: The sushi and all the items on the menu are absolutely delicious. Owner and chef makes all the sushi and the food. The price is very affordable for the quality and service you get. The wait is totally worth the while. Thinking about the Hawaiian Roll #2(?) is making my mouth water.
author: Gin B.

description:
