This restaurant is hidden on Market Street. Be sure to have the number of the place just in case you get lost. 

Trekking through rain on Market with a few friends was worth the trip. The ingredients are fresh with filling portions. My friend got salmon sashimi, which she said was very tender. Her husband a few sashimi dishes in addition to some rolls. He said that this is one of the freshest places that he has had since moving to SF for this job. 

I got some soft shell crab rolls that were so fresh that you can taste the sweetness of the crab. 

The price is right for what you pay for. 

The wait takes a while because there aren't too many seats in the restaurant. But it is worth the wait.
author: Maryann K.

description: This place is incredible!  small, yet funky and fun. the food is unique and fresh and made with love by the owner himself.  It is one of my favorite sushi/japanese food restaurants in SF.  Plan to wait for seating and then take your time enjoying creative, delicious food.
author: Diana M.

description:
I almost want to give the Sushi Zone a bad review just to get the wait back down to when I started going there seven years ago. Back when the chef/owner had no wait list and played samba all night. But it's way too late. There is more to sushi than the fish, and I've always had a great experience there.

Get there 15 minutes before they open to get immediate seating. I'll be there a few minutes before you. There are about 16 seats. Each seat only gets about three seatings a night. So if you miss the first wave, expect to wait over an hour for the second or third. If inside, you can order sake while you wait. Outside, grab a cocktail from the spanish restaurant around the corner.

Be sure to order the two items they serve on mussel shells. It's heaven. The waitress once explained the secret ingredients to me but I forgot them almost immediately. Also, the salmon here is better than other places in SF. The rest of the fish is great.
author: Esso E.

description:
Expect to wait a while.

The sushi is worth it if you plan ahead and find a place to get drinks while you wait for a table.

Order the Mango Sea Bass!
Price was totally reasonable.  Made up for the long wait.
author: Matt H.

description:
Sushi Zone was where I first fell in love with sushi so it has a special place in my heart ;)  I once waited for 3 hours for a table with my girlfriends. Was it worth it? Well, we knew we had a long wait ahead of us, so we went to a local bar to have a drink (Martunis or Destino). 

I love their Spicy Hamachi roll with jalapeno and lime, and the Hawaiian Roll with tuna, mango (or avocado) and macadamia nuts. Last time I was there, too many rolls we ordered had some type of mayo. I am not a mayo-lover, so I could totally do without those again. 

Arrive before 5pm for a table, otherwise plan on waiting an hour + for a table.
author: Amy J.

description:
Sushi Zone is sushi heaven, but stick to the following protocol:

-Don't go if you are starving
-Don't go if you are in a rush, you'll want to relax here
-Get there before 6:30
-After you let the hostess know you are there, head across the alley to Get Lost books and begin planning your next vacation.
-Try the "hero special". Not on the menu, but tres delicious!

All in all, one of the city's best for sushi. Big Ao has never let me down.
author: Raoul D.

description:
Just OK-maybe that's because my co-worker raved about it forever!  The good: fresh fish and somewhat creative rolls.

The bad:  EXTREMELY small-plan on waiting at least an hour.  Mayo-since when did mayo become such an integral ingredient in sushi?  I don't get it but more importantly, I don't like it.  I won't be heading back anytime soon-I'll stick to Zushi Puzzle.
author: Alexis H.

description:
eh, I didn't mind it.

That was what I said to my dinner date after wards.

I went once, won't miss it.  Can't say why, it just felt like food.  The quality was fine, the portions fine, the service fine.

It was fine.
author: Ken p.

description:
I can't believe all of the stupid haters on here.  Yes, the Zone is a long wait.  You have to factor that in when you are deciding to go here.  Yes, the Zone only takes cash.  Don't be an idiot douche-bag and just bring actual paper money.  

The Zone is a completely perfect place to bring a date you are trying to impress, a friend you haven't caught up with in a long time, or just about any other one to two people you want to spend a good amount of time with while you are waiting.  Sit on the stools or on the bench and start ordering beer and sake, and you'll be surprised how quickly the time will fly once you are here.  Plus, I've actually met people sitting at the sushi bar and had great conversations with strangers.  Try it, you'll like it!  

BAKED STRIPED BASS.  I am going to come here one day and try to eat nothing but the Baked Striped Bass appetizer.  Once you've had it, you'll know what I am talking about.  Also, the hamachi here has ruined me from ordering it from other sushi places.  As well as the stuffed jalapeno and the spicy tuna.  

Listen, if you are starving, don't bother coming here, or eat a snack beforehand like people have suggested.  I promise that if you give Sushi Zone a chance and you aren't an egotistical ass who thinks the world should revolve all around you, you'll find it doesn't get much better than The Zone.
author: Julie B.

description:
This is a good place to come to with a couple good friends whose company you enjoy, because you will be spending a lot of quality time with them while you wait to be seated.  We waited about 2 hours and then spent about 2 hours eating, so you better like the people you're coming with.  Fortunately I liked the company I was with, so I had a great time at Sushi Zone.

We had a pretty even balance of nigiri and rolls, but I think I was most impressed with the Spicy Mango Salmon roll.  Many of the rolls have mango, and there was even a unagi+papaya roll on the menu.  I would recommend the rolls here, and leave the nigiri to other places that have higher-quality fish that you can really enjoy as nigiri (I've been so spoiled by Kitsho).  Things I hadn't had before: Hawaiian rolls had macadamia nuts on top and sake nigiri had lime on top.

I've uploaded some poor-quality photos of my food.

It's a tiny establishment, with 2 tables seating 4 each, and about 9 seats at the bar, where you can watch the chef prepare the food.  The price wasn't too bad, I don't remember how much it was a person, but I remembered thinking it was pretty reasonable after 2 carafes of sake plus a ton of sushi.  I was definitely stuffed afterwards, which is hard to do cheaply at a sushi place.  Cash only, though!
author: emilie k.

description: The wait is hell, but once you sit in your table you'll be in heaven. Trust me.
author: Ato B.

description:
i was resisting writing here for a while because i sometimes already wait over an hour for a table at this place so i'm not about to let this place attract others. however, this place is sooooo good that i can't help but tell the world. i've tried many great sushi places in the city, places that are highly rated, but sushi zone is still the best one. AND its not as expensive as others. the vibe is totally chill, not a scene, service is great. 

sea bass with mango is something that you can't leave without trying. TRUST ME. Hawaiian II is one of my favs, as well as the spicy hamachi. actually everything that i've tried here is ridiculously good. 

if you don't wanna wait, stake out at 5pm when their doors open or expect to wait at least an hour for a spot. i don't usually end up spending more than 20 bucks here whereas i can drop 30 easily at other places that aren't as good.
author: Marcia O.

description: This place has good sushi for a very good price. The place is small, so get there EARLY! Otherwise, you will join the crowd of patrons waiting outside for a table. They have a baked mushroom appetizer that blows my mind. Sushi is very fresh too. YUM!
author: Helen L.

description: Hands down the best Suhi ive ever had. The spicy mussel roll made me want to kiss the chef and the 6.50$ price made me want to dap up the owner. Make sure to come with some time on your hands because the place is small and the demand is high. This will be the first place I eat the next time i'm in the Bay.
author: Elliot A.

description: Best sushi in the Bay Area!
author: Brad D.

description: Some of the best sushi in SF hands down!!! Japanese style, small and cozy. i have tried everything in the menu except for the shrimp because I'm allergic. Get there early cause the wait is 1-2 hrs! Seriously! But once you sit down, get served and take a bite you will forget your crankiness and go into sushi orgasmic bliss!
author: Fredo L.

description: went with a co worker of mine, the place was small but the sushi was great I am a vegetarian and they made the sushi in front of us while were drinking sake, one of the best exp ever! simply loved it
author: Parikshit T.

description:
Adorable little place that makes you appreciate a random night with a friend, emphasis on "A" friend.

The only reason why I did not give this place 5 stars is because of the wait, which was worth it. Only 3 people were working: a sushi chef, an assistant chef and a waitress. The restaurant probably seated only 24 people at a time, and you are able to see the entire "kitchen" on the other side of the L-shaped sushi bar. 

I have never had mango in my Japanese food but my roommate and I shared the spicy mango roll with mango, salmon and avocado, and in addition the half shell bake with a mayonnaise base, striped bass and mango. They were absolutely amazing and both under $6 each. We also shared two other relatively standard rolls that were also under $6 each and made deliciously. We did notice though that the entire ordeal took 2.5 hours, so don't come with a big group especially on a Saturday.
author: Vivian Q.

description:
It's absolutely worth the wait to get one of the few coveted seats at this tiny place. Everything here is super good and there are always cool and interesting specials. Just plan ahead so you aren't starving. Or come a bit early. 

Besides, they serve you sake while you wait, and time flies when there's sake involved.
author: Amy K.

description:
My favorite sushi place of all time.  I used to live about six buildings away on the street.  Six buildings away from my favorite food in the world!

Their baked mussels and hawaiian rolls are out of this world.  And if your into the little details, their miso and edamame are very favorful, better than other places. But if you don't get there really early you are in for a really long wait.  I have waited about an hour an a half before, but that's what I'll do when I have a hankerin' for their amazing sushi.  

And everyone who works there is really nice.
author: Biggie M.

description:
A friend and I went here for dinner having heard of course that it has amazing sushi.  If nothing else it was certainly an experience.

The well documented wait for a table was in effect.  I'm willing to suffer for delicious food but this one was close. We wanted to see a movie afterward but long after the movie started we were barely eating. 

The food: I may be biased as i love rolls and I love mango, but I thought the food was very good, though perhaps not authentic. I love the idea of authentic, but you also have to love innovative.  It was all well made, and tasted very ... clean and crisp. 

While it's not good for a quick bite, or maybe not for very regular dining, part of me really enjoys the slow way of eating here.  The long wait, of course could go, but the slow way that the sushi chef makes each roll and sends it out one at time makes you really slow down and enjoy it consciously.  The excessively drawn out meal here felt like a sort of ritual.  A delicious one. 

Next time I'm going early. 

Side note: Found out the hard way Sushi Zone is now closed on Mondays.
author: jason N.

description:
This has to be quite the experience.  An extremely long wait to be seated and then another excruciating wait for our food to arrive.  The build up has got to be a part of the hype, but the food is damn tasty when it finally arrives at our table.  

The sashimi was fresh and the albacore melted like butter, the rolls were yummy, but the wait definitely made my tummy shrink.  I'd compare this experience with waiting in line to get my Wii.  When I finally got it, I was excited and I couldn't complain.

P.S. Try it if you have 2 hours to kill on a Tuesday night.
author: Kenny Y.

description:
Best Sushi place in the bay area -hands down.

Not only is it the greatest sushi, but it is also the greatest value, two people (stuffed), with beer for under $50.

Yes the waits are rediculously long, I would say about 1hour on average, so I would recommend this place only when you have lots of time on your hand, I would say three hours start to finish.

The combinations of flavors are on par with some of the finest resturants I have been too (nobu comes to mind) but it's so cheap!
author: Justin D.

description:
Everything they say about this place is true. Terribly long wait if you get there at the wrong time. Relatively inexpensive sushi. Friendly service. Amazing fish.

After drinking sake and beer through my 2 hour wait, I could barely eat by the time we got our food. But I THINK it was delicious.
author: m t.

description:
Damn, this food is good... despite the 90 minute wait at 7:30 on a Tuesday night.  

There is a mango theme here, but its a great take. The baked sea bass is excellent. However, I saw someone get 6 orders of it, which is pretty gross. I'm a big fan of the albacore.
author: Brendan L.

description:
I went here for the first time this week. I tried different kinds of sushi with my friend and they were all good although I wasn't really a big fan of the ones with mango in 'em. In my opinion, there's too much mango that it overpowers the taste of the fish.

The wait was bad though--an hour and a half although I can't really complain about that since I knew it was gonna be a long wait coming in. The only thing is I can't justify that long of a wait for the sushi. I honestly would rather just go to Sushi Delight, which is a block away. It's not as good but comparable and I don't have to wait to be seated...most of the time.

Overall, great sushi, good service.
author: Joselito S.

description:
I dont care what others say this palce is so worth the wait, if you can hang in there. put your name on the list and go get a drink down the way (orbit room is across the street), then come back when it gets closer to you. This is no quick date place. go here with someone you want to spend a long time talking to and hanging out with, someone who's company you enjoy. 

besides the long wait. this place has never failed me. The fish is oh so fresh and buttery, amazing. great flavors in sushi rolls and new things i have never seen at any other sushi place.
hawaiian 1 and 2 
little "bakes" with see bass and yummy yummy ness. 
spicy hamachi roll
unagi papaya roll....the list goes on.

i usually pay about 40 to 50 bucks for drinks dinner and a joyful time with the person i have gone with...totally recomended.
author: .Strapped ..

description:
My favorite sushi spot in SF!

It's a tiny hole in the wall place that does seat more than 16 people in total.    There's always a long wait.  But the appetizers and sushi are AWESOME.   I highly recommend the stuffed mushrooms and stuff peppers - best items on the menu!  all the sushi is fresh and delicious as well.  prices are very reasonable and cheaper than most high quality sushi places.
author: jeff l.

description:
Ate there after a long morning of watching footie, followed by an afternoon at Zeitgeist...so, drunk. We got lucky and arrived just before it opened (at 5), which is a very good thing because any later and we would have had to wait about an hour I'd say to get in. 
The sushi looked amazing, prepared by the owner right in front of us. Being veg, I ordered the artichoke heard and avocado roll...SO. GOOD. I do have to admit that the baked seabass with mango that my friends ordered looked damn good! It even made me miss eating fish a little bit! 
There's pretty much one guy preparing all the food, so be prepared to wait. And if you have to wait for a table outside, I'd suggest not scowling at the people eating inside. You'll get your turn, and it might make some patrons annoyed enough to hang out longer just to spite you! (We did NOT do this, we ate and left, though the scowling was a little unnerving.)
I will definitely go there again, I can't stop thinking about that damn roll!
author: Susie D.

description: A-M-A-Z-I-N-G sushi, but you gotta go before 5pm and wait in line.
author: TVAT T.

description:
This place is awesome, except for the wait. 

The place is small and the lines start at least 30 mins prior to opening, so you really need to know when you'll be hungry or risk an hour or more long wait starving to death. 

All that aside the sushi is great. They have creative rolls and fresh fish, which are both pluses when it comes to the sea of sushi joints in SF. The Hawaiian rolls are awesome with the mango and they never hesitate to give some extra mango on the side when I ask. 

5 stars on the food. Not knocking them for being popular and having a wait associated with good sushi.
author: Ted L.

description:
This place sucks! 

I don't know what all the hype is, it's just another sushi restaurant. 

Good points: 
Restaurant is run by REAL Japanese people, not Juan Carlos and the crew. 

Bad Points: 
Waited 2 hrs, finally got seats in front of the sushi chef. Watched him make a Hawaiian #2, then realizing he mad a mistake, he scrapes off the saucy fish and throws it back in to the fridge. NICE! 
After about 1/2 hr, we finally get our food order going. 

Mango Hamachi - really?..Hamachi roll w/ mango - 1 star 

Spider Roll - Possibly the worst Spider Roll I've ever had. I don't even think they put a batter on the crab. Crab tasted burnt and was mainly on the end pieces, hardly any filling the middle. - 1 star 

The Hawaiian #2 - Macadamia nuts and mango pieces w/ saucy fish. I looked at the fish and it seemed familiar...ya! the shit the sushi chef scraped off earlier and put back in the fridge is now I'm my mother fuck'n sushi! WTF! 
Nothing special about this roll either. - 1 star 

I will never go back to Sushi Zone again. Just because you put mangos, papayas, or macadamia nuts in your sushi doesn't make it special or taste any better! 

Overall - I give it a big 1-star on my middle finger! FUCK YOU Sushi Zone!
author: Wilson T.

description: I decided to go there after work but I wasn't able to try the food because they said they were "too busy"!! How lame is that!?! I couldn't believe it... I wanted to get some unagi to go and the lady told me that they were too busy. I said, I could wait and she said they couldn't do it. I was sooo pissed because she was really rude about it! I know it was a hole in the wall(my room is bigger than the whole restuarant) but there was only 7 people in there!
author: Brittney M.

description:
pretty good. seems to get busy quickly as it is very small

only cash, no to-go orders
author: Captain B.

description:
This is a great place to practice patience and mindfulness meditation...First of all, the sushi is fine - nothing spectacular.  The prices are really good.  But the wait is pretty mind boggling.  I skimmed the reviews before going and wrongly concluded that 'the wait' applied to waiting for a table.  In fact, the 'wait' also applies to getting your food after you get a table.  

I stopped by after the gym on a random week night at around 5:15 and got the last seat at the sushi bar.  I was feeling pretty lucky and psyched to try this place. Well the excitement started to subside as I waited nearly 40 minutes before I got my first bite of fish.  In fairness, I was promptly served my miso soup and the waitress was pleasant.  The guy next to me actually offered me some of his sushi, as I think he felt sorry for me.  My whole dinner lasted 1 hour and 45 minutes - I ordered a few pieces of sushi and a roll.  It was pretty comical. I only wished that I had brought a book or my iPod.  

The sushi is good but nothing special, and not worth the wait in my humble opinion. I doubt I'll go back, so good news for the devotees!
author: Eric C.

description: The thing about Sushi Zone is that it basically IS as delicious as every person you know said it was. But the problem is that we waited for sixteen million years and died hundreds of thousands of times and were reincarnated as every animal and then became beings of light and transcended our earthly bodies entirely and left our dying solar system and were incorporated into a single God consciousness before our food came. But they didn't just make us wait until our hanger meters were maxed and then lay some fish on us. Instead they slowly distributed the food over 2 hours of hellish food torment. It was like the Japanese sushi version of Chinese water torture. Or the food version of Waiting for Godot. There is one guy making the sushi and he looks like a Japanese version of Cheech, which is neither here nor there, but I'm just saying, bring a sandwich.
author: Nathaniel L.

description:
i dream of this place but have nightmares of the wait. 

i only go here with one person. my sushi partner in crime and eat sushi til i can't eat no more. it is so good.....
author: Jen S.

description: Loooong wait, but worth it!  Go early, put your name in- run some errands and come back! Baked Mussels and Hawaiian Roll #2 is a MUST!!
author: mochiBrownie I.

description:
Fabulously fresh, well presented special rolls were worth the wait. The Stripped Sea Bass with Mango(served on half-shell!), as noted elsewhere, is absolutely divine. 
I went on a Friday night with two friends. We were on the wait list by 8:15 p.m. or so but didn't get seated until after 11 p.m. The chef and staff were as friendly as could be, but the place is that small, the food that good, and the ambience nice enough that those already seated were taking their sweet time. Highly recommended, though perhaps ordering to go might be an excellent choice as well (if time is of any concern).
I will definately be returning (though will try to get on the wait list a bit earlier next time)
author: Ted S.

description:
It is the very best sushi in the city and has the very best prices.
It also has the longest wait for a table and also for your food.
Don't go when you're hungry, you'll be hungry by the time you eat.
Eat the baked mango seabass. Eat the Spicy Tuna and you MUST eat the Hawaii #2. YUM YUM YUM YUM!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Heather B.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars, if it weren't the fact that it only seats 17 people and eating there really is a whole-night affair after the wait for a table and the wait for sushi.  Unless of course you get there at 5 right when it opens.

But aside from the amount of time it takes, they have creative rolls that are very tasty (like the hamachi with mango topped with mac nuts, and unagi with papaya).  Prices are pretty good too for what you're getting.
author: Karen L.

description:
I didn't want to write this review.  Why not?  Because I'm tired of waiting 2 hours while the newbies who found this place on Yelp take their sweet ass time at the bar,  meanwhile I drink myself silly waiting for a seat.

This place is all about the rolls.  The nigiri is great too, but seriously, check out the rolls.  If you read my Zushi Puzzle review, you will find nearly the opposite statement.  Why?  Because Sushi Zone is in Bizarro World.

Here is what I order, every damn time I come, with very few alterations.  Order the same and you will be in heaven, just like me.  Well, anyone waiting 2 hours to eat will be in heaven after all that time, but sometimes you get seated right away, and its still just as good.  

Baked Striped Bass with Mango
Baked Mussels
Spicy Mango Salmon
Spicy Hamachi  (love that lime and jalepeno!)
Hawaiian #1 (w/ no mayo, but she always asks if i want mayo on everything else, which I do)
Spicy Scallop
author: Dave K.

description:
This place has the best fish I've eaten in SF, and if you get a spot at the sushi bar, you feel like Queen of All Sushi. 

Unfortunately, the wait is sort of prohibitive. Either you have to get there at the crack of dawn and stake out your place first in line, or you have to be prepared to wait at least an hour. And be really hungry and wait some more once you're seated. 

At least the Orbit room is across the street, serving up stellar drinks. Mmmmm.... sushi and orbit room....
author: Jen B.

description:
Okay, I was arguing for Ryokos, Zushi Puzzle or Hamano, but my friend Derek said I had to try Sushi Zone if I wanted to experience the best sushi in the city. Okay, Derek, you're right. The incredible (and yes I mean as in unbelievable) hawaiian sushi is worth waiting for, bring your lover or whoever you really want to pamper, you won't forget it, it will start appearing in your dreams, and of course you'll have to come back. I like the one rolled in macadamia nuts and I have to get multiple mango sea bass because I guess it's now my favorite thing to eat. period. I say it's the dessert, but then i have to start with one too. Addicted! 
I am often by myself and then the wait is relatively short for a seat at the bar! Cheater! Otherwise, come around 5:45 for their 6 pm opening or just be with someone you like so you can hang out while you wait.
author: Suzanne J.

description: Go early or expect a wait. Amazing sushi. You'll love it. Great crowd. Make sure to get the sushi sampler and the baked mushrooms. So great. Again, don't hate on the wait.
author: Brandi S.

description:
Loooooooove the sushi. it's a little hole in the wall local secret sweet spot. tiny little place off of market, one small room with a couple benches and a sushi bar. enough room for a waitress to help everyone and barely any room for waiting... and there will be waiting. 
but man, that sushi is worth the wait. once you get a spot, as another reviewer points out, you won't be hurried out by the staff. they're attentive and happy to serve. your beer comes cold, your food comes fresh, and you'll be satisfied. 
speaking of the food, appetizers are great, and the fish is sooooo fresh and tasty. you'll notice there's no fake fish anything (they use real jumbo lump crab w/o mayo if you're into california rolls). the salmon is so buttery smooth and delicious, and the spicy tuna roll... the BEST i've ever tasted. seriously, so good. plus they use interesting herbs in their rolls and it gives it a little more "umph" that'll leave you wanting more. it's so great. 
didn't try it, but there's some sort of baked mussel dish, or could be the sea bass, that everyone surrounding us seemed to order. next time i think we'll try it due to the popularity.
ok so you get it. basically, 5 stars for delicious food and generous service for the caliber of restaurant, minus 1 for having to wait and get stared down by other patrons... never fun...regardless, if you go and can handle a wait w/o much room, it'll be well worth it.
author: N F.

description: Get there at 4:45 to get a table in this tiny, tucked away scary good dinner stop.  More stools at bar than seats at tables.  Sea Bass starters are sushitastic.  Assorted nigiri astounding.
author: Matt S.

description:
"The more things change, the more they stay the same."
We recently went back for the first time in @ 3 years, and I am pleased to report that Sushi Zone has hardly fallen.  The spicy hamachi and Hawaiian #2 were still great.  The physical space was still really small (I saw my first child/toddler there . . .  needless to say, somebody nearly trampled her while she was waiting for her table). 
The only noticeable differences were that (i) all the sushi are now served in rolls (previously nigiri and slight drop in quality) and (ii) the wait was not as long as it used to be (a good thing).  Maybe we were lucky, but we managed to walk right in and grab a table (trans: no wait - on a Saturday night nonetheless!).  But we did notice some folks waiting up to 25 minutes, but that is still less than the 60 minutes that used to apply.  
Over all, it was a great dinner, and we were glad to go again.
author: Eddie S.

description:
Albacore Nigiri - check 
Baked Seabass and mango - double check 

I agree with the rest of the city, yes it's very tasty fish.  But, could it be because while you're waiting 90 mins for your sushi (after seated) you're downing Asahi after Asahi and practically near starvation?  Tg for the bloody at ****** Zuni prior.  

A line a 5pm on Sunday?  If you don't make the cut, you better try later at around 6:45pm.  Otherwise "you better forget about it"


Overall yes, it's as good as everyone says...
author: Jennifer B.

description: Oh MAN, longest wait of my life. We are talking levels of absurdity higher than anything I was prepared for. The food delivered though. I was astonished. Its some of my favorite sushi in the city, for both the rolls and fish. Im bringing a snickers bar next time and not having as many beers while I wait.
author: Justin B.

description:
Holy crap . . . that's good sushi!!

The place is tiny (2 booths, maybe 9 seats at the bar).  If you don't want to wait, shoot to get there around 4:45pm.  They open and 5pm and the place is almost always packed.  How ever long it takes to get a table, it's well worth it.  I waited almost 2 hours the other night and was happy to do it, the sushi is that good. 

Prices are reasonable and the fish is fresh.  Plus, they've got some of the most interesting rolls I've ever eaten.  You have to try Hawaii 1 and 2. 

They've got an app served in a mussel shell - some bass and mango thing that is out of this world.  

I spent the meal in constant amazement at the flavors and when the bill came, I was amazed at how reasonable it was.  

Love it!!
author: Andrew L.

description: The best sushi I have ever had.  He is the Jiro of San Francisco.  The wait is worth it.
author: Mari E.

description:
Not too thrilled to be forced to go to a small place with a horrible name.  (I still think Sushi Zone is a horrible name BUT what a place)  I was also scared to go after reading all the Yelping about the wait.  We arrived at 4:55 and were the first ones there.  Extremely small place with 1 sushi chef, 1 waitress, and 1 helper.  Ignore the obvious and just go.  This place was fantastic.  Every dish was great, especially ANY of the shiro maguro items and the spicy tuna roll.  I will stop judging places by their packaging.

My only (small) negatives were sitting next to someone who liked smelling like an ashtray (just like Japan!) and the music was shite but they redeemed themselves with Bob Marley as we were paying our bill.  Go here and expect a wait and you will be just fine.  Prices were also reasonable.
author: Des S.

description:
Love the sushi. 

Hate the wait, so plan to go at least 2 hours before you really want to eat. Recommend waiting it out at Martunis until your table is ready. Restaurant is small, recommend going as a party of one or two. The roll with the macadamia nuts is the bomb. Staff is friendly.
author: Phill and Molly O.

description: Over the top in deliciousness for sushi, especially at the price. You have to be strategic in arrival time, or else you are completely screwed, but there is a cool bar up the street (Orbit Room) if you have a long wait ahead. Seriously, top top TOP sushi experience. Owners are big music fans, which is nice, too =)
author: Wonder P.

description:
the baked striped bass & mango on mussel shells and the original baked mussels rock!  This place seats about 14 people so grab a beer and prepare to wait, it's worth it!

Nori R.I.P.
author: Kevin D.

description:
come early, really early, and come prepared to wait.  and when you get inside, you'll wait some more.  and when you get a table, you'll still be waiting for your food.

sometimes i think i'm bucking the system by letting my friends come early and do all the waiting.  i dream of waltzing in late, into a seat at a table with a waitress ready to take my order.  but much as i try, i've never been late enough to bypass every previous step of waiting.   i think the cosmos is punishing me for being selfish, but really, i think the restaurant is just small and slow.

but when you get your food, you will be happy.  or exhausted - who really knows by that point?
author: Amy H.

description:
we got there at 5:15 (open at 5:00) they said it'd be a 1hr wait for our table of 3. so we hit pisco for a 30min drink.

at 6:15 we were still waiting.

at 7:15 we were seated. while we were waiting a menu was given to us so we'd be ready to order the moment our butts hit a seat. we ordered off the menu and the whiteboard specials.

8:10 our food showed up. 8:15 our food was gone.

granted the bill wsa $57 for 3 people including a large sapporo, i don't think it was worth the 2:55 that we spent standing around. unfortunately i can't tell if the food was amazingly delicious or just okay due to my state of mind after waiting for so long.
author: Ameer N.

description: Delicious and freshest sushi i have ever had.  Its a small little place, but the food is the amazing!!  I had so many tasty things, I can't even remember which was which.  I do remember having the Hammachi cheek, which was the most delicate and tasty fish that melted in my mouth.  I would go here again and again.  :)
author: Jezebel U.

description: We walked in and sat right down at 7:30 on a thursday night... Granted it was  like a sauna... our waitress stated most have left for Burningman and the heat were to blame for such luck to have two empty seats. With that said, i can go on and on about how delicious and AMAZING the sushi was!!!! We had the sweet cold sake (lg) one glass of plum wine, a lg Sapparo, and 4 rolls. $48 pre tip. I recommend trying the Hawaiian!!!!!!! we will be going back on a weekly basis!
author: Tiffany L.

description: The only reason I'm giving 2 stars instead of 1 is because we liked our waitress.  It's a shame she had to suffer the consequences with a mediocre tip.  I went into Sushi Zone expecting a wait.  But nothing, NOTHING, is worth waiting around for 1 hr 45 min when you're a party of two.  We sat watching the other patrons linger over their Sapporos and ordering more rolls.  Etiquette, people, etiquette.  When there are 15 people in line after you, you do not have the right to a leisurely meal.  Once we finally sat down, we waited another half hour before we saw our food.  The sushi wasn't bad, but it wasn't worth it.  And my friend found fish bones in one of her rolls.  Sorry, nice waitress, but we will not be going back.
author: Christina D.

description:
Sure we had to wait about two hours (maybe longer, I was delirious at that point) to get a seat.  It's our own damn fault for putting our names down shortly after 7.  I think we were pretty patient though, to wait for our sushi until 10 pm.  At least they made plenty of money serving us yummy unfiltered sake and Asahi until it was time to feed us.  
The kitchen is about the size of my own and I'm just PISSED that my kitchen didn't come with it's own sushi chef to prevent me from having to wait this long while watching others moan in mouthgasmic pleasure right in front of me while I gnaw on my knuckles to stop myself from going zombie and eating the first person to pass too close to me.
The wait is ridiculous.  If I was hungry, someone would have gotten hurt.  Luckily the Girl Scouts have been giving me plenty of fat and calories to keep me busy, so I maintained.
The sushi was excellent, even if the spicy tuna was a little over mayonnaised for me.  I don't do mayo kids, but I ate the hell out of the spicy tuna, mayo be damned.  It was excellent.  And if there is Sushi Zone food in heaven, it will most surely be the striped bass & mango special they were serving.  I might be okay with never having sex again if I could have more of that special.  Okay, that's a stretch, but HOLY STRIPED BASS it was indescribable.  All I can say is that if you see it on the menu, for the love of all things swimmy, order seven.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I only knocked off the last star because of principal.
We waited FOREVER for this meal. Arrived at 6:45 and put our name down. Went to a local bar for wine and cheese. Came back by 8 (we were told to expect about an hour-and-a-half wait.) Finally sat down around 8:30-845, ordered almost immediately (from the very nice and helpful waitress), and then ended up waiting another 40 or so minutes for the actual food.
Although we ate quickly and still left the restaurant just after 10 (no exaggeration), the food was TOTALLY worth it.
Definitely up there as one of the best sushi meals I've ever had. Everything was basically perfect. And SO cheap. The four of us left totally stuffed for only $100 total with tip.
I have a tendency to consider everything about a restaurant other than its food peripheral. That tendency would lead me to give Sushi Zone five stars. But acknowledging that it's pretty ridiculous to have to wait about two and a half hours for one's food and that most people don't similarly feel that food is by far the most important aspect of a restaurant experience, I'm chopping off that fifth star.
Though the food really was phenomenal.
author: Sasha K.

description:
great experience. it's so tiny and warm feeling-it's really a special place. you will wait for awhile, but that is bc it's so small and they do not hurry you out. you can sit and really enjoy the AMAZING dishes and a cold extra dry Asahi beer (or two). It's really the best gastronomique experience i have had in awhile. 

recommend: spicy hamachi, striped sea bass nigiri, sea urchin nigiri (amazing!), and hamachi nigiri. Also, the baked mussels were super indulgent.

watch out: the fermented soy bean sushi was super authentic. This could be amazing for people who like it, but if you are a timid eater- you might not.
author: SJ P.

description: 5 years ago, this used to be a all time fave sushi restaurant. I would not post a review because I didn't want more people to know about it. Super fresh sashimi, awesome/unique rolls with large fish pieces, low prices. Even though I waited over 1.5 hrs for food, it was ALWAYS worth it. Over the years, the rolls have less fish and the pricest have gone up slightly. I still like their rolls because they have a good/unique flavor but I need to order more sashimi to satisfy my fish craving. Still a good place for sushi but sometimes it's not worth the wait these days. If the wait was shorter, I would give it 4 stars.
author: Veronica C.

description: The wait time to to be seated was longer than I'm usually willing to do, but it was worth it because prices were cheap and the service was good.  The spicey hamachi, salmon, spider rolls were excellant. The unagi roll with papaya was ok, the papaya was a little too sweet. The albacore nigiri and tataki (sp) was awesome. I did care for the sumomuno salad with octopus because it was bland.
author: S G.

description:
First thing's first: I love sushi.

Now that that's out of the way, let me say this:

I really love Sushi Zone.

I hate the sometimes interminable wait, and I hate it when the tiny space happens to be partially occupied by bellowers, but I do love the sushi so very, very much.  It's exquisite.  Uber-fresh, molto delicious.  My very fave place for sushi bar-none.
author: Alice T.

description: If you've had sushi in Hawaii this is very comparable.  Luckily I went on a slow night and we only waited for 25-30 minutes, not sure if I would wait 1-2 hours to eat here another gem in SF.
author: Rachel C.

description: I'm super excited to have found this place, thanks to Yelp!  After trying at least half a dozen other sushi restaurants in SF that were overpriced and / or underwhelming, I am happy to say that Sushi Zone lived up to its very positive Yelp reputation!  The fish is fresh and prices are reasonable.  The only negatives were that the wait was horrendous (2hrs on a Fri night!) and we could smell the oil from the fryers (we assume) on our clothes for hours after we left.  Nonetheless, best sushi I've had in SF so far!  Hamachi, good.
author: Kristina L.

description: DON'T GO HERE! I heard it's haunted! This one guy went here, and they never saw him again. All they found was bones and teeth. Also, sometimes, the sushi chef will just stab you in the head for no reason. And there have been a lot of explosions there; many people killed. And instead of fish, I heard they use human flesh. OMG please whatever you do stay away from this restaurant!
author: Tim S.

description:
My friend introduced me to this place and it has the BEST sushi. 
So delicious and yummy! As other's have said it is a little hole in the wall with only 2 tables and the bar, but the food is totally worth the wait and the setting. 

My favourites were the appetizers which has the seabass! Melt in your mouth! and the Hawaiian with macademia nuts!

See my blog for some pictures!
http://travelladybug.blogspot.com/2010/07/sushi-zone-in-san-francisco-best-sushi.html
author: Lynn S.

description:
came here with people i didn't really dig!  fortunately the sushi was fresh and yummy!  i like all sushi, sashimi and rolls but love it when they have anything with mango in it!  place is small but you'll be transfixed with the food...or was that the sake that got me?

overall a satistying spot for sushi!
author: Tony S.

description:
I have loved sushi zone for many years and have patiently waited my turn in line for their delicious rolls and amazing little toaster oven baked appetizers. Unfortunately, my love has turned to hate and I will not be returning! I have had it! 
The wait to get in is truly insane, minimum 2 hours if you are not the first one in line when they open at 5 (c'mon!) but then you will wait another 1-2 hours til you actually see any sushi on your table. 
The rumors are all true, sushi zone has gone from bad to worse and has no clue on how to turn tables or make customers happy. Their server girl is rude as hell and has no intention of accommodating a party of 4 by moving the 2 sitting at the booth to the open bar seats (this happened to me last night and the worst part is, they have a sign posted above the wait list that says they will do just that!).
 And don't even dream about walking across the street to orbit room for a drink while you wait, the sushi zone crew still hasn't gotten it together by offering a courtesy call to patrons when their table is ready. (and orbit has offered to reciprocate!!!) they just cross you name off the list, and you sink into the abyss...no matter you've been waiting for hours and going back and forth every 30 mins to check the wait. 
 IT IS NOT WORTH IT FRIENDS! TAKE YOUR PRECIOUS TIME AND LOVE OF SUSHI SOMEWHERE, ANYWHERE, ELSE!!!
author: summer r.

description:
i don't trust most reviews of sushi places i read online.  no offence to any yelpers, but i find that most people in this country don't know what makes good sushi.  you put enough wasabi on it and it all tastes the same, so who cares about quality of fish, etc.

so when i went to sushi zone, i was totally expecting to be able to rip this place apart.  it has a ridiculously high rating, and from the outside, it really doesn't look like much.

but i am unable to do that,  the sushi was really good. the nigiri pieces were pretty large, although i thought they needed a bit more rice.  the fish was very tasty.  the rolls were creative and very tasty as well.

the staff is extremely friendly, but the 1hour+ wait loses this place a star.
author: Steve S.

description:
NO place can be so good that you are willing and able to wait over two hours to get seated.

This is a tiny place that we have long since given up on trying again.  The first and only time we tried, we sat around for a long time while patrons lingered and sat around long after their food was gone.  Even more maddening, we had ordered and finished a large Asahi from the waitress to drink during our wait.  When we finally had given up long after most sane people would've been long gone, she was a lot more lively and proactive in making sure we paid for that Asahi.

With so many other good sushi places in SF, I can't imagine why anyone would brave the unwashed mass of lemmings to come here.  Sure, it's relatively inexpensive, and I'm sure a good value... if you don't value your time that much.  I do, so I'm done with this place.
author: Dave N.

description: eat before going. parties of 2 only. Good once (if ever) getting a seat, but only good because you are so hungry anything tastes delicious.
author: Mitsi M.

description: Sushi Zone is a great place for sushi if you can really wait for it! My gf n I waited over 2 hours just for 5 rolls of sushi and a large Sapporro. The sushi here was delicious but I'm not willing to really wait that long for food. If you really want to try this place out I'd recommend coming around 5:00-6:00. We came around 7:30 and stayed there until after closing. It's a really small place and only one guy makes the sushi but he is super nice and the waitress is very attentive. This place was great but I don't think it's 100% worth the wait. May try here again sometime if I feel hungry for sushi and it's early!
author: Elton N.

description:
update 7/3/2007

i took two stars away from sushi zone today.  it was a sad day.

but i really can't think of any meal on earth that warrants a 2 hour wait.

unless MAYBE if it's FREE (and tasty)!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
wow.  

this place may have just secured the number one spot on my "favorite sushi in sf" list.

everything was fresh and delicious.  really, that's all needed to be said.

the only reason it's on the cusp of number one - the wait took forever cause the place was so tiny.   we may have had rock star parking that night, but totally used up all our good karma, hitting a wall at 8pm.  no one budged for a full hour!

i don't think there is a magical hour to arrive.  be a good person, share love and peace, listen to your mother,  and perhaps the wait list gods will shine upon you when you enter sushi zone for what could be "the best sushi in SF."
author: Josie M.

description: This sushi is damn good and ridiculously cheap.  You must order their salmon sushi (nigiri!) - it has a subtle dill/lemon flavoring to it, and the salmon just melts in your mouth.  (Please forgive my pretentious food critic tone.)  Also try Hawaiian rolls #1 and #2 - you can't go wrong with the flavor combinations of tuna, mango, papaya, and macadamia nuts!
author: Dwigt S.

description:
This place is right in my neighborhood and it was excellent.  I was dining alone as I just moved back to town and the chef at the counter was super sweet to me and kept me company while I ate.  What  a great place to go to.  The pricing was very good and everything I had seemed fresh, fresh fresh!

I can't wait to go back again.
author: sheila G.

description:
so, "curiosity" didn't kill us after all.....

last saturday, as we were walking from market & 4th street towards the castro, we saw this line forming in front of a tiny joint that has a "closed" sign and we were wondering what the heck this was all about!?!...this place must serve the best sushi in town!!!!

therefore, last night, we went to check out the ZONE and guess what?! we were seated right away.... we didn't wait!!! we were LUCKY!!!

we were delighted with our orders of TUNA SAHIMI: it was fresh, the kind that softens, diffuses once it touches your palate!!! also, it was a GRADE A slice.

the PAPAYA UNAGI, CALIFORNIA , SPICY TUNA & SALMON SKIN ROLLS were just remarkable! delectable mixture of fruits, spices, condiments, fish & crab were nicely incorporated to an amazing maki.

moreover, they have two kinds of cali roll: fresh and imitation, and we surely went for the fresh one! however, the spicy tuna wasn't spicy. i noticed that he put more green onions than the "hot" stuff that a spicy tuna roll should have.

as for the expertise or where the chef did his apprenticeship is not my business, as long as he did a great job slicing those sashimi and rolling those maki & nigiri is appropriate for me to rate him as an excellent chef.

consequently, our inquiring minds were not destroyed by the cramped space and extensive wait ( for the food, in our case).
author: Nelle A.

description:
This place is all about the experience.  First you wait for about 3 years until you don't care about life anymore.  Then you walk into a place the size of a small closet.  I think they are used to only doing raw stuff b/c whoever does the oven has a hard time with getting smoky particles everywhere so after about 1 minute you are blind and can't taste anything.  The positive aspect is it takes so long to get your sushi you are completely blind and non-sense-aware from the fumes so it tastes pretty good.  

Another positive is that while you wait forever you can make jokes like "What's taking them so long to cook my food".  It never fails to not get a laugh.
author: Dirk C.

description: I was recently there for the first time.  I grew up in Japan so I know what real sushi taste and look like, and I have to say their sushi was pretty close!!  Most importantly, they know how to make the sushi rice.  Sushi rice is very important part of sushi and many sushi restaurants in Bay Area don't know how to make the rice.  Unfortunately, their sushi selection was small, but they are fresh and reasonably priced.  I would like to come back when I have a chance.  Though, I am not sure if it is worth 2 hour wait time...
author: M S.

description:
just moved to the deco ghetto from lower haight, and i am soooooo sooooooo excited to have sushi zone within spitting distance of my place.  i mean, i am beside myself with glee.  ok, no i won't spit on sushi zone, i "heart" sushi zone.  what would make me even more crazy happy is if the zone took over the chinese restaurant next door, bashed down the wall separating the two, and made the sushi mecca even bigger.  yes, it's true, every time i've gone here, i've had to wait, but it is worth it to me, seriously.  but now that i live so close, i can just peek outside to check out the line, go at off times, or call in an order and pick up on my way home from work.  

yummy fresh raw goodness and interesting rolls for a good price.  HAI  !!!

UPDATE 6/21/07 - they no longer do take-out!  BOOHOO.
author: Suzanne A.

description:
Oh my God!

This place is outstanding, I think the salmon sashimi changed my life.  Hands down the best sushi I've had so far, plus the staff was incredibly friendly, they gave great recommendations and explanations of the menu including what was literally out of the ocean fresh.  

NOTE: this place is tiny, maybe room for like 12 guests at once. Seriously, it's that small.  Plus, there really isn't anything spectacular about the decor, this is just a serious foodie restaurant with mind blowing food.  Check it out, but maybe bring a snack with you to eat before dinner :)

Wait in line for the place to open, grab a table or stool, and then patiently wait until the server comes to your table to get your order.  Then, wait for your food.  This is some serious waiting to get dinner.  Guess what? It's worth it.
author: S B.

description: Horrible, don't go, waste of time and money.  I went because it is recommended by so many and on the bargain bites list.  So not a bargain!  It is a hole in the wall joint, two tables and sushi bar with seats.  Love hole in the walls but no treasure to repeat here.  It took two plus hours to get seated even though I showed up 15 minutes after opening.  I was determine to sit and try the talk.  The bill doubles the $30 or less for two to be stuffed quota.  There are so many better hole in the wall places than this place.
author: Mayah C.

description: I think I have to knock a star off all my other sushi reviews after eating at Sushi Zone.  No other sushi place even comes close to the beautiful pieces of gastronomic delight that were produced by the chef at the Zone.  Yes, we did wait an hour and a half.  Was it worth it?  Hell yes, it was.  The salmon stuffed mushroom caps and baked mussels alone were worth it.  Add to that the freshest, most buttery pieces of sashimi and rolls so flavorful they practically explode in your mouth.  And to top it all of, it's probably the least expensive sushi place I've been to in the city.  Yes, it's that good.  The only problem is that no other sushi will ever compare, and with that kind of a wait, I definitely won't be frequenting Sushi Zone, so I think I've just set myself up for disappointment.
author: Erica G.

description: Yes, it is worth the wait but the wait is c-razy and it is the smallest restaurant in the world. Everything I've had here has been delicious and so reasonably priced it's insane. But you have to have the patience of Gandhi and Mother Theresa combined to make this night work for you. Consider yourself warned!
author: Shira G.

description: The sushi is mouth watering and well worth the wait. Probably the freshest fish I've ever had. If you come around 5:30 on a weekday, you can usually get seated instantaneously, otherwise it's a 1-2 hour wait. Their specials are phenomenal and the service is always friendly. Four stars instead of five because I do hate waiting so long!
author: Robin L.

description: Sushi Zone is delicious.  I judge a sushi restaurant on the freshness and quality of their raw fish.  Unlike most Americans, I do not judge a sushi restaurant on their sauces and ridiculously concocted rolls.  We ordered the Nigiri combination plate which contained 12 pieced (6 different types of fish) of fresh quality Nigiri.  We also partook in the spicy scallop roll which tasted like heaven if you like a little kick to your sushi.  I love that this place is back to the basics of sushi....no silly "mango cucumber terryaki chicken rolls" or "peanut based spicy coleslaw"....just sushi, delicoius sushi.  Thanks for making it a great night!
author: Nick T.

description: I HEART SUSHI ZONE. My FI and I went on a random Wednesday night and only waited about 5-10 minutes for a seat at the bar.  Baked sea bass = heaven. Spicy Hamachi = bliss.  The list goes on...  But before you go, two words to remember: CASH ONLY.
author: Joy B.

description: Pretty good...went here with my boss before a show...she said the rolls had too much rice...i have to agree. But the fish was delicious.
author: Sara B.

description: The best sushi in San Francisco.  ALWAYS the freshest fish and large portions for the price.  If you don't get there for the first seating, put your name on the list, go to Octavia bar for two drinks and then come back an hour or so later.  The specialty rolls are great.  A friend couldn't enjoy sushi since a trip to Japan but he said Sushi Zone restored his faith in American sushi.
author: Jason G.

description: The hour-long wait is worth it. The mussels on the half shell and the stuffed shiitake mushrooms are the highly-recommended appetizers. Cash only.
author: Rob T.

description: we waited over an hour on a friday night to get seated but it was sooo worth it. i can eat a million orders of the baked bass. every roll we got was delicious. i'll be back for sure! with better timing of course.
author: Angela D.

description: Great place for wonderfully fresh sushi and cozy atmosphere.  The salmon and tuna rolls melted in my mouth. I arrived at 7pm on a Monday night and I was able to get a instant seat, however I recommend to come early if you don't want to wait for a seat.  Though the wait for food is slower than most sushi joints, I find the quality is worth the wait.  I can't wait to try their more exotic rolls....
author: Rodel B.

description:
yeah, we came because long lines usually mean something impressive at the end of that wait... but i have to shrug and say naaa...

sorry-i know everyone loves this place, but to me it's all mayo.  just lots of mayo in every roll and people are raving about this stuff.  i could remind you that mayo makes everything taste good.

now that said, the fish is very fresh, the jalapeno appetizer was memorable... but i'll never go back.
author: Lily A.

description: Agree with other reviews.  You have to get here early if you don't want to wait an hour+.  We generally get there about 15 minutes before 5PM.  There's usually a line already.  The key is to be within ~15 in line otherwise you will still wait because it is TINY.  The service is a bit slow because there is one waitress and two guys making the sushi. However, the food is spectacular especially the rolls with fruit in them.  Everything is good. I know this because my friends and I have pretty much ordered everything on the menu and the specials.  The best part - it's CHEAP!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Let me put it this way, I've never been to a sushi bar where I've looked longingly at a table as I sat at the bar. 

I don't know why all the sushi bars up in the bay area find it to be taboo to talk directly to the chef. All the sushi places in Los Angeles, the entire point of sitting at the bar is ordering directly from the chef. It's like having the honor of sitting at the bar of the fanciest, hippest alcohol bar around, you want to talk to the guy who's preparing your consumables, ask for a tweak here or there, a lil something special perhaps. Somehow this idea did not translate here in the SF Bay and it's driving me nuts!

Okay, so, I ranted for a moment, and it had little to do with Sushi Zone, other than the fact that sushi bar patrons are somehow treated like crap in this city! Well, after a half hour wait, I was feeling blessed by the sushi Gods because I had heard that this place was a monster to actually get seated at. Also, by the looks of it, two tables and eight stools at the bar, it could potentially be forever until sitting down, let alone eating here. 

I was so wrong about being blessed. The sushi was wonderful, don't get me wrong. The fish was not really showcased in the rolls, but the Nigiri was fabulous, and the Hawaiian #2 was unique and delicious. Where the Nigiri was concerned, it was some of the freshest, meltiest fish I've ever experienced. 

Where my problem arose was the service. I was sitting at the bar, three feet from the one and only chef in the house, and I could not talk to him, request one thing, smile at him even. On top of this fact, the waitress was trying to be kind and attentive, but was far too overwhelmed. A large party sauntered in just before we did and sat at a table, ordering gargantuan amounts of sushi and appetizers. A couple was then seated just before we got the bar at the second table. As I watched the chef whip up some incredible looking rolls, Sashimi, and Nigiri, I became quite excited for my order to begin heading my way. Half an hour into sitting at the bar, I watched over a dozen rolls leave, placed at each table in large groupings, and then, finally, one roll, out of about six items ordered, was delivered to me. One roll at a time, one couple at the bar at a time, was delivered, as more and more plates filled with delightful sushi left the bar, to end up at the tables. It was as though the chef's patrons at the bar were an afterthought, a hiccup, in his serving the tables. Three hours later, I had finally finished my last bite, the sun far gone from the sky, my day basically blown, and my dreams of Sushi Zone magic shattered.

Oh, by the way, CASH ONLY. As a note, there is an ATM just up the street on Market, going toward Castro, for those like myself, who missed the boat on this one.

***Update 10/20/07
I went back. The service was still kinda slow, but nothing near as bad as it had been that first night. Knocked an hour off of my time spent. I still feel like that "undeserving" shunned child in the corner, looking longingly at all the food going out to the loved children, but not quite as much. Also, the food was exceptionally good. So, I've bumped up to four stars, 3.5 overall, but worthy of that solid 4 for the food alone.

***Update 2/4/08
Yeah, so, I come here regularly now. It's just so good, I suck it up. Last night I was blessed by being seated right away, and being served all my food at once at the bar. Also, the Spicy Hamachi roll is one of the most brilliant I've ever had. Cheers! 4.75 stars for the food (I've had one or two pieces of fish I didn't particularly care for, out of dozens, and dozens).
author: Shannon F.

description: Best Sushi I've ever had in the US.  Super small place with a super long wait, but it really was the Best sushi I've had in the U.S.  The hamachi sashimi was especially good.  This was the only time I actually like mackerel sashimi -- most places it's not fresh enough and tastes extremely fishy.
author: Maria K.

description: Good food, long wait. Three of us arrived at 10pm on a Saturday night, waited 20min to get seated, then (nearly) another effing hour to get our food -- even when the whole place had cleared out and the three of us were the only ones left behind. I'm not sure why it took so long, we assumed they went out back to catch our fish. The food was good, but probably not worth the wait (luckily, nobody was in a hurry). We were out by midnite. On another note, the crowd was uber-hip (and quite hot), but expect to be stared at from head to toe when you walk into such a small place.
author: Eric P.

description:
Okay....Everyone has been talking about this place.  With all due respect, TWO HOURS for the sushi was really not worth it.  The food wasn't "Mind blowing".  The staff despite their service limitations due to high traffic is surprisingly good. The prices are great, but the sushi is really average.  From the way everyone talks about it, you'd think you get something sooo good you'd cry after one bite. NOPE.  It tastes good because your starving your ass off for two hours.  Anything tastes good after you sit and watch people eat for that long and while being hungry yourself. NONE of the seating or stools are comfortable. 
 Trying this place was important to me because he's one of the very few Japanese Sushi Chefs in San Francisco. As for him, he's very humble, friendly, and accommodating. 
My wife and I left a really good tip, but really don't plan on coming back there anytime soon.
 98% of patrons who frequent there seem to be very "laid back" rather than the usually obnoxious and excessively disturbing behavior for non-San Franciscans. (*this is very important to me.)

  To me, the fish didn't seem very fresh at all. Most of the Tuna variants were pale in color, but cut very well.  As for the Hawaiian #2 Roll and that Mango deal? Good stuff, but not really impressed. 
The food is certainly not "UNRIVALED".
*Ino, Redbox, and Kitaro!??!!  C'MON!!! Those places BLOW.

I'd recommend Ryoko's at Taylor and Post St.  
Thursdays thru Saturdays is usually up to a 45 minute wait.
Native Japanese Sushi Chefs 
Open late
Funky ass Decor
VERY friendly and increased number of Waiting staff
Service has always been consistent, slow on food delivery at times, but YOU CAN'T RUSH ART!!!
Prices are pretty high, but worth it.
Fish is REALLY  fresh.
They often offer unique specials (fish from all over the world).
The home made Gyoza is a must.
Tempura is like what you'd find in Japan.
Lots'a cool rolls
*I do get irritated by the management.  they seem to lack manager experience.  It's pretty tacky to "RAG" on your staff in front of customers.  

Murasaki on Clement
Native Japanese Sushi Chef
*Chef seems to be mean, but he's actually really cool.
Has a posted Sushi Chef's license from Tokyo older than me.
Good "First Date" spot
FRESH fish - 
he offers a unique version of his Salmon Nigiri prepared in a Wine sauce.
Service is great.
author: Jubei K.

description:
if it were within the realm of possibility and not in my magical fantasy wonderland, i would put the incredibly adorable waitress, the sushi chef god of deliciousness, and all the incredible sashimi, mouthwatering baked mussels, and deliciously inventive yet simple rolls into my pocket and keep them with me forever. 

i absolutely love this place. unfortunately, so does everyone else. put your name down, go up market to orbit room and get a cocktail with freshly and lovingly squeezed juice, and come back in an hour to eat some of the freshest yet somehow magically not that expensive sushi you will ever have.
author: Mei L.

description: I'm downgrading my rating because I don't have the patience to wait the time it takes to get a table at this joint anymore.
author: Vijay S.

description: I love love love sushi zone! It is so delicious and one of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF. Their rolls are pretty affordable for sushi and I love their specials. The owner is really cool and plays awesome music. They have limited hours since they are open only 5-10p and is pretty much a hole in the wall. But if you get there BEFORE 5pm you are set for a great meal!!!!! I love their striped sea bass with mango and the stuffed jalapenos! YUM!
author: Heather B.

description: This place is the end all be all, staple in the city for great sushi in San Francisco.  If you are in a hurry for sushi look for the next place, unless you get there when they first open.  There is always a wait and they will kindly let you know this when you first walk in.  This is because it is a one man sushi rolling show. But if you like great sushi and enjoy the comfort of funky little toys to play with at the sushi bar, look no further! Oohh...the baked mussels are a must.
author: jonathan b.

description: So I should caveat this review a little bit. I am a person who cares mostly about the food, so my reviews reflect this. I will admit you will likely have to wait a while to get a seat at this place (2 hours is not uncommon) and you will probably not get served right after you sit down, which is fine to me, just plan around that, you can always get a drink at one of the local bars while you wait, Pisco is great. So back to the food... the mango seabass baked in a mussel shell is awesome, a must have. The rolls are interesting and very flavourful. The fish is really fresh and its definitely sushi worth appreciating. I think this is one of San Francisco's gems and is a real treat if you are a sushi lover who doesn't mind the wait. But overall an awesome place worth taking out of town guests and a great place if you feel the need for a sushi fix.
author: Brent F.

description: Alright everyone!!! Here it is! I have been a sushi connoisseur for some time now, and this place is certainly not the best place. Let's think about it really, can you really all say that sitting around for over an hour to get this sushi is worth it? Yeah, i now i sound like a nay sayer, but let's me realistic people, if you can't find a better place in SF you really are not looking hard enough (Sushi Boom on Geary and Stanyan is a good substitue.)...There is only soo much time in a day ya know!!! Personally, I think people here are just trying to get on the "it is always busy that i have to get there" band wagon!!!
author: Ivan E.

description: This place is a small spot, so even after 9PM, you should expect a wait to be seated on a weekday. The rolls were delicious, but my boyfriend kept track of time, and the first roll took about a 20 minute wait, and every roll after that took about 10-15 minutes.  We ordered 4 rolls and we were there for a long time.  The prices were reasonable and customer service was decent.  We would come back again because of the price.
author: H. A.

description:
I want to give Sushi Zone ZERO stars so everyone can stop going, and I can START going again.  

The first time I ate here, was back in 1999-2000.  It was busy then, just as it's busy now.  The wait was a total biyatch.

The last time I ate here was in 2004.  Again, it was the usual 2-3 hour dinner.  Wait was a total biyatch.  Sushi was excellent.

I've tried, unsuccesfully, to return, only to see a whole gang of sushi fiends swarming the restaurant as if it were a starbucks.

The sushi chef is slow, not because he's autistic, but because he's a sushi nazi.  If you watch him, he plucks out all the bones, cuts off the not so pretty fatty/tendon like parts of the flesh, and is just fanatical about the way he cuts the fish.

I suggest getting his baked creations, like the baked striped bass on a half shell.  I also like the hawaii roll, toro nigiri, salmon skin roll. 

You never get anything that comes to your table that looks dry and 'dead', cut with a chainsaw, or about to completely fall apart the minute your chopsticks picks it up.  Everything comes out right, or it doesn't come out at all.  Thats the impression I got from the Chef...nazi (in a good way).
author: james c.

description: I've been here 3 times already.  Not really sure what the rave is about.  Yes, the sushi is cheaper here but I'd rather pay more and get good fish.  I also don't like larger cuts of fish that are more chewy which this place seems to have.  The sushi should be bite size so you can eat it in one mouthful.  This is more of an "american" spin on sushi in which I think you'll find most non traditional sushi eaters agreeing that it's great.  We went right when it opened so we were seated right away so we didn't have to wait.  The wait here can be terrible sometimes, over an hour.
author: Mitch A.

description: Best. Sushi. EVER. Seriously the best. Worth the wait. We had sashimi, it melted in my mouth! Stuffed mushrooms, and a plethora of rolls. Amazing.
author: Lauren M.

description: So I went to Sushi Zone on Friday, got there a couple of minutes after 5 (opening time) and the place was packed as expected.  My date and I put our name on the list and went to another place to grab a drink.  Worked out perfectly because by the time we got back it was almost time for our places at the bar.  The service was great and the mango striped bass was amazing, but the rest of the specials we ordered were just too big.  Yeah...totally something my date and I never expected to say...a sushi place that made their sushi too big consume without it all falling apart on you.  But I have to give them 4-5 stars for the freshness of the fish.  Size docked points for my review.  Never would have thought I'd say it, but bigger was not better.
author: Jolsna J.

description: Sushi Zone in my opinion is the best sushi place I've been to. Everything is so fresh and the taste is so flavorful. The restaurant is real small and they only serve sushi and no bento boxes or dinner combo specials or watever youre used to at other japanese restaurants. If good sushi is what you crave this is the place for you. The only thing is that the wait is long and unless youre a veteran you know what times are good to go. Make sure you get your name on that little white board! My recommendation is the Hawaiian #2 and the striped sea bass mango for an appetizer. Everything else you really cant go wrong because its so fresh. Patience is key!
author: Jon T.

description:
The Emperor's New Clothes #2.

Sushi is good.  But not THAT good.  Not worth the wait.  It's pure snob value.
author: Ritch G.

description: This place is so overrated.  The sushi is just OK and when you factor in the long wait its really not worth it.  My theory on why people like this place so much is that by the time they get seat they are so hungry they'll love anything you feed them.
author: Rob P.

description: Plain and simple great sushi.  Staff was super friendly.  Walked out with a full belly and didn't dent the wallet either.  Big fan of the Spicy Hamachi and Spicy Tuna Rolls.  Not a fancy interior but who cares when you get good food.
author: Bhavesh M.

description: Oh wow, definitely some of the best sushi I've had in the city. We went at an off time, so the crazy wait times didn't apply to us that evening, but wow the unagi was perfect and the yellowtail and tuna nigiri melted like butta'. Cool little atmosphere, great tea and some excellent edamame before the meal.
author: Michael E.

description:
had to try it b/c of the stellar yelp rvws & so close to my work, but it was just aite when i went. 

FOOD: ~the BAKED MUSSELS were the BEST, So Goooood. mussels=happy! so those were worth the rep.

~seaweed salad was better than avg. 

~yelp rarely steers me wrong, so i was surprised to discover that the SUSHI was pretty MEDIOCRE. i think it was the rice that nite--overcooked & not enuf flavoring (lacked sugar?) so it felt mealy in my mouth. also, the best sushi has barely any rice, & they were packing hella (unflavorful) rice in there. the rolls kept falling apart, another failure. & i never saw such unevenly cut maki in my life--looks homemade like i made it myself. 

~the spicy hamachi had good, alright flavor. 

~artichoke roll nothing special, a little disappointed there but credit for trying. 

~not enuf tempura on the ama ebi heads, & the ama ebi itself wasn't crazy delicious. i do like how ur encouraged to try the specials, some panisse ethos in there.

SERVICE: long gaps b/w svc, but i understand she's busy by herself. we waited forever for our rolls. they should alternate tables' orders so u @ least have something to munch on after the long wait. instead, we sadly watched other tables' huge sushi platters go by time & again.

BATHROOM: weird b/c the whole restaurant can see u, but it's clean.

DECOR: plain & simple. i liked the fish painting that jumped out of the frame onto the wall.

OVERALL: i've had way better sushi elsewhere! but the BAKED MUSSELS are to die for--amaaaaazing. i'd go back & try to get some of those to go or something b/c i sure as hell am not waiting 2 hrs to eat here.
author: miss b.

description:
low stars for:
1. ridiculous wait (1hr 15 minutes) & an additional 20 minutes after we were seated to have our orders taken.  yes, i think i'll need that extra 20 minutes to decide what i want to eat because 1+ hrs just isn't enough.
2. lack of service (basically took our order and handed us the bill.  didn't even serve us the food, and we had no water or tea or drink refilled).
3. poor quality sushi

the soft shelled crab had this really strange taste to it that made it terrible.  i don't think it was the quality of the crab but how it was prepared.  anyways, i did not enjoy it.

had their hawaiian #2 roll (white tuna, mango, & macadamia nuts).  my albacore was the same grade as "spicy tuna."  you know they use the worst cuts of the tuna for that because it's all mashed up and super spicy so you can't taste it.  well, this all mashed up albacore was lacking in quantity too.  all i could taste was mango.

all their other rolls where typical of anywhere else (alaskan, yellowtail, rock n roll, etc etc), and none of it tasted any different (except the spider roll).  definitely not worth the wait.
author: H. L.

description: Sooo Delicious!  Prepare for a long wait.  I'm a big fan of the baked striped Sea Bass with Mango, spicy tuna roll and salmon roll!  This is an inexpensive and tasty hole-in-the-wall restaurant. This is the best sushi I have had in the Bay Area.
author: Linnette E.

description: Very small place, so if you go there you should probably expect to wait a bit.  The sushi is very fresh and they have several very cleverly put together rolls.  I'm a fan.
author: doug s.

description: Hands down, the best sushi in San Francisco!  Fresh and creative, he knows what he is doing.  Believe it or not, it is a bargain!
author: Michael W.

description: If you don't mind waiting an hour and a half for a table, this may be some of the best sushi in the bay area. Or is it just that you end up so hungry after the wait? I'm not sure but either way it's fucking bomb. Their unagi is some of the best I've had. Everything is delicious. My mouth is watering thinking about it. I'm going to cry.
author: tuttle h.

description: The wait is ridiculous. No. Really ridiculous. And I was already annoyed, as I was tagging along a friend of mine who spoke highly of their 'mango-riden rolls.' I waited an hour and a half for mango madness that I was sure to hate, run back home and bitch about on Yelp. Instead what I got was  quite possibly the best maguro and sake nigiri that I've had in SF. Really. But honestly, the wait? It's ridiculous. 5 stars less 1 star for the wait.
author: D'arcy N.

description:
There are so many things right about this place - it's unpretentious and let's the quality and preparation of the food speak for itself. I had been read multiple reviews about Sushi Zone and was most notably warned that lines start to form outside before the restaurant opens. Molly and I arrived at 4:45pm on Saturday evening and got in line behind the 5 people who were already there. By the time the doors opened at 5:02pm, there were at least 10 people in line eager to get a seat. The restaurant is small and simply, but tastefully, decorated with a background of classic rock playing. I think the sushi chef was singing along to most of the songs. There are two small booths in the window (that can each seat 4) and a sushi counter with 8 or 9 barstools. We were seated at the bar and quickly scanned the specials board and menu. The kitchen is minimal and consists of a small hot plate and toaster oven just to the side of the suhsi counter. There is one man who makes the hot dishes (soup and a couple baked items, etc.), one waitress and one sushi chef.

We placed our order and were glad to be towards the front of the line-up. Since one sushi chef makes everything, you can't be in a huge rush to get your food. We started with a miso soup, sunomono salad w/ octopus, hot tea and a large unfiltered sake. Slowly our food began to arrive. We started with baked sea bass with mango. It isn't something I would normally be drawn to order, but we overheard a woman outside while we were in line talking about it. The sea bass, mango, butter and some creamy topping are all placed in a large mussel shell and baked in the toaster oven until the top is lightly browned. This dish is amazingly delicious and if i didn't think it would eventually clog my arteries, I would want to eat it everyday. We ordered two rolls; a spicy hamachi roll with avocado, jalapeno and lime, and a soft shelled crab w/ avocado roll (spider roll). I have to say that the spicy hamachi roll may be the best roll I've ever had. The hamachi was left in pretty large chunks lightly covered in a spicy mayo, the jalapeno was flavorful but not too spicy, the avocado fatty and sweet and the lime brightened all of the flavors. We also ordered 2 orders of maguro, 1 hamachi & 1 sake. Everything was superb. The fish was fresh and buttery and the sushi chef cut and prepared everything perfectly. Our meal took and hour and a half and there were a steady stream of people coming in and waiting. I will definitely be back, but do fear the lines a little bit.
author: Ariel D.

description: Ok so you might have to wait like 10 hours for a table..but the food is well worth the wait!! Very small place with only 2 tables, yes only 2 tables, and the bar area. If you get there before they open, expect a line outside. The specials are amazing with unique combinations like mango and papaya. Delicious! Oh did I mention how cheap it is..
author: Palak P.

description: This place is part of a "sushi showdown"/"sushi faceoff" that my friends and I are having this week.  My entry - Grandeho Kamyeko. The competiton - Sushi Zone.
