After reading the reviews on Yelp as well as citysearch, I was very trepidatious(yes thats a word) that this place would kick Grandehos butt.  We  went here on a monday night, the wait wasnt that bad, and the sushi was terrific.  The one observation that my girlfriend made, that stuck in my head, was that this was sushi with a hawaiin influence...because of their use of mango, papaya, and macadamia nuts in some of the rolls.  I dont know how much truth there is to that, but it was an interesting point. The fish was delicious and fresh, and the wait is well worth it. Does it beat Grandeho? Well, youll just have to wait for my wednesday update.
author: Gautham H.

description: So, I notice that everyone has the same complaint. The wait is ridiculous, but  when you have a tiny whole in the wall resturant with about ten seats, what do you expect? The sushi was the best I have ever had! The Hawaiian # 2 is the best choice every time. They get five stars for their originality, always playing great music, and always being apologetic for the long wait.
author: lisa f.

description: Al is the best. Fresh, cheap sushi lovingly prepared.
author: Christen D.

description: After you get over the name, it will blow you away. 12 seat restaurant, at home ambiance.
author: Nick D.

description: Be patient, worth the wait. Really good sushi - and innovative ways to serve it. The restaraunt is very cozy, I wouldn't exceed a party of 4.
author: melissa h.

description:
no one should ever have to wait 1 hour 20 minutes AFTER they sit down, to get their bloody food! yes the sushi is good, but I've had as good elsewhere (shogun in santa cruz, sushi ran in sausalito, niko niko in silver lake...). go elsewhere unitl the guy (the one guy owner/chef) get's a clue on how service should be done!

(yes I've been here before, 3 times, never had to wait as long as the 4th though)

(no take out)
author: marcus d.

description:
This is my favorite sushi restaurant in the city. Bring a flask and mentally prepare yourself for a wait, because there will be one. You should expect nothing less from a place that serves *very* fresh, delicious sushi, in good portions, and dirt cheap.

Get the sake sashimi (fresh salmon). It's like butter.
author: J P.

description:
yes, the wait is long. very long. we put our name down at about 7 PM thursday night, and didn't get seated until about 9 PM. but the sushi and most definitely the ambiance is well worth it.

maybe the ambiance is not for everyone- but for that great, mom and pop sushi place where once you are in, you're IN, you must take the time to try sushi zone.
author: Melissa G.

description: My favorite sushi spot in the city.  The prices aren't bad, but the wait sure is.  If you don't get in by 5:30 (they open at 5:00), count on a very long wait.  Even once you get to your table, you'll be waiting awhile to see your food.  There are only three people working: the sushi chef, the waitress, and the dishwasher.  They add a lot of flavor to their rolls that you won't find elsewhere.  You'll be happy that you waited.
author: Megan T.

description: best sushi restaurant ever. period. those baked mussels- amazing (and i usually don't like mussels).
author: andrea p.

description: Wow...people weren't kidding when they said there was a long wait.  Not 30min...not an hour...try nearly a two hour wait time from entering the door to actually getting your sushi...was it worth it?  I'd say yes. The prices were cheap and the fish was amazingly fresh...definitely the best quality I've had...and I know my sushi!  Not recommended for groups larger than four, don't go there if you're hungry to start with, and make it a whole night's event unless you go early (5-6pm).
author: Tanger T.

description: Please stop reviewing Sushi Zone! It can be our little secret ... No one else need to know ...
author: Katie B.

description: This place is small, and you may need to wait in line to get a table. But if you like innovative, top quality sushi, this is the best place I found in SF. Try the tuna with mango, or the spicy tuna with macadamia nuts.
author: Three M.

description: We arrived at about 6:30 on a Sunday, and waited a good hour and a half. I guess that's acceptable for a place that only serves about 16 people total. They do have some stools in the back, which allow you to sit down while you wait. Once we were seated, however, the quality of the sushi made up for the long line. The unagi nigiri was excellent, and the salmon nigiri was perhaps the best I have ever tasted. Everything was so fresh, and masterfully put together. The green tea ice cream was also great. The service is a bit slow - you get your entire order at once, so it takes a while to prepare it all. The bill came to about $51 for three people - and that included 6 orders of maki, 3 of nigiri, and miso soup.
author: Dana L.

description:
Please don't go to Sushi Zone for dinner... The wait is long enough without you in line...

One word about the sushi: WOW.
author: Edwin B.

description: so our roommate (who's been living here for several years) and has top favorite places to eat, told us of 3 great sushi places. this one, he said, was the cheapest and probably the best. he was right! TINY place, ONE amazing chef and knife, soo many tasty rolls to choose! we arrived at 5:30, put our name of the board, got a bottle of sparkling wine, hung outside the spot and around 6:30 we were given a spot at the bar. everything was so fresh and delicious! favorite roll- spicy hamachi. absolutely must have. in total: two rolls for me, and a combination plate for him, several sake later, and $65. THATS IT!
author: Abigail W.

description: Yes, the wait is bad but it is a known quanitity so you can plan accordingly. Those that wait are rewarded with amazing fish. Be sure to check out the white board on the wall for the specials. What I liked about the whole experience is that the sushi chef just gives you a small part of your order at a time rather than putting everything on one big platter and giving it to you all at once. I found myself slowly savoring each piece of nirgiri when served in this style.
author: matt m.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in the city.  I recommend you take a good conversationalist with you, as the wait can sometimes be up to 1.5 hours --- but the price at the end of the meal and the quality of the food is worth it.  (Cash only; be forewarned!)  I'm hesitant to share my love for this place as it's packed already, but it gets packed already, so here goes.  My favorite "dishes" are the spicy hamachi roll (jalapeno + lime, what!) and the ultimate I-will-have-four-orders-please special nigiri striped bass & mango.  I dream of that stuff.
author: Susan L.

description: Don't go here... Ever.  Stay away!  I had a hard enough time getting in here before all of you started coming here... now my wait has gone from an hour to 2+.... find your own sushi palce with the best sushi in the city and leave me to mine.
author: Darren R.

description: Sushi Zone is worth the wait...especially for the warm mango sea bass. Toss your name on the waiting list and head over to the Orbit room for a seasonal drink and you're set for the night!
author: Bridget W.

description: This is my favorite sushi place. I give this place 5 stars for the sushi, but minus 1 star for the long wait. Unfortunately, they only have 2 tables and some counter space. My advice get here early or be prepared to wait. If you can hold on, it'll be worth the wait.
author: Fil L.

description:
how have i never written a review for the 'Zone.  i love this spot.  living a block away is definitely a huge selling point for my apt. 

Fresh and tasty sushi.  cute, small quarters.  sure there can be a long line, sometimes hour waits or more, but this place warrants it.

spicy hamachi, hawaiian #1 (or 2), indian, spicy salmon and mango.. just a few of their specialty and truly amazing rolls.  don't forget the baked mussels.  and their miso soup is "souper" tasty.  

Hideko, will you marry me.

i love you sushi zone!
author: Andrew r.

description: i LOVE this place. worth the wait and not to mention great service. They only do raw food... except for unagi. This is what sushi should taste like. Im not keen on sushi places that sell everything "Japanese" under the sun. They only do nigiri/sashimi and rolls. simple and perfect. If only more places like this exists we wouldnt have to wait 90 minutes to eat.
author: Marcia B.

description: This is the best Sushi I have ever had.  The prices are low and the company is great.  It's so small that it is a unique experience sitting in this little restaurant.  Even though the wait can be long, it's worth it.  And if you time it right, you can dodge the wait.  I am now super spoiled by this place.  Everywhere else I go for sushi doesn't compare.
author: Walter B.

description: Yeah!! This placed lived to its reputation! The best sushi I've ever had in my life. So fresh and tasty. Got there by 6pm and no line like I've heard about. It is a whole in the wall, but well worth it. The stuffed jalapenos with tuna are to die for. The hawaiian tuna rolls were my favorite. And its cheap! I can't wait to come back again.
author: Caroliina F.

description: Simply amazing - the best sushi place I've ever eaten at.  Waited almost two hours for a table for 3 (the place is tiny - two booths and about 8 seats at the sushi bar), but it was well worth it.  The Rock & Roll was awesome as was a roll that had jalapeno and lime (can't remember name).  Also some great appetizers.  To top it off, most rolls are under $7.
author: s v.

description:
So Sushi Zone gets 5-stars, for the relative quality of food vs. low prices, but definitely not for the decor or the wait.

Sushi Zone is probably the best sushi restaurant in the Castro area (better than Barracuda by miles, better than Underground Sushi in terms of quality and service, better than Eiji and way better than Osaka).  

Good:
- the food is great.  Spicy tuna roll, sashimi combo, etc.  Everything I've had there is well priced and delicious
- prices.  cheap

Bad:
- the wait.  You may have to wait for hours, as in multiple hours.  Best trick is to go early and sign up and then go do something else.  When you come back you are at the top of the queue since they don't kick you off if you're not there when they call your name. 
- cash only.  It's 2009.  Cash only!?  But at least there's an ATM around the street.  It will charge you a $2.50 surcharge to get cash.
- small.  few seats, and you may smell a little like the kitchen when you're done eating

If you have time, go eat at Sushi Zone.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Seriously great food ... The fish is fresh, the rolls are yummie, the baked shells are to die for (yes, I am trying to figure out how to make them at home), the only problem is that the place is so small that  you wait for table and then food for a while ... a long-long while ... a very long while ... but it's worth it! And the best part - it's not expensive!

Wait - why am I typing all this?  This place is horrible - don't go! ;)
author: julia p.

description: Best sushi I've ever had.  Yes, the wait it ridiculous, but if you expect it, then its not a problem.  I would say on average I wait about an hour and a half to 2 hors.  Go get a drink nearby or something.  Their waiting list is a little nerve-wrecking - it seems as if no one is really watching or keeipng track, but I've had no problems.  The Hawaiian is amazing.  I can't wait to go back!  I would suggest no groups since there are only 2 booths.
author: Lauren P.

description: I love this small sushi spot off Market, near the Castro. The fish is very fresh and the staff gracious, but as with what everybody else has said, go early or be prepared to wait a little.
author: Nish N.

description:
sushi ZONE = bad
sushi TIME = hell yeah

don't confuse these two places, or do and stand in line for mediocre large sushi pieces.

the service is very nice, so nice in fact that they seem to build business on charm not quality.

if you like jive ass rolls, american-style slices (read too freaking big) and therefore don't want real Japanese sushi, this is your mecca. When the fish is so big and clunky like that, you can't concentrate on nice flavors and certainly not on nice presentation. so basically you're eating slabs of raw fish not sushi.

I bet Nobu K doesn't even give them the time of day, but tons of hipsters and yupsters do, all day. Yes this is a Japanese restaurant, but I highly doubt that the chef had real sushi training. and who am I to judge, you ask? a die-hard sushi lover who has worked in 2 amazing sushi restaurants.

this is not worth the wait.
author: G Z.

description: The baked seabass with mango is one of the best things I've ever eaten. And I've eaten a lot of things.
author: Louis E.

description: I like sea bass with mango a lot. But the line is always big.
author: Zoe C.

description:
food 5; service 3; value 5; wait -10

We arrived on Saturday at 4:59  (the open at 5) and were told that we would have an hour wait... we went next door to the bar and had great drinks so not that big of a deal... except the hour wait was really 2 hours.

food was really good - esp the baked sea bass and the sake sashimi but no place is worth a 2 hour wait.

very good value if you're willing to wait - we stuffed ourselves for $58.
author: Stacy N.

description: This place it's my favorite sushi in town ! It's totally worth it the wait which is usually at least an hour, because the place is so small.However they are some good bars around to kill the time. The baked mussels appetizer is to die for !!! I usually get it for desert as well :P
author: Geri M.

description: I'm very picky with eating Japanese food, especially sushi. Sushi Zone has reasonable prices. The restaurant is actually smaller than most restaurants, but it's designed just like the ones in Japan. I suggest going there before they actually open and wait by the door because it's usually a 2 hour await. All the sushi is delicious. Try everything. Their Hawaiian Rolls are my favorite though.
author: Lori M.

description: Tiny little place with magnificently delicious sushi.. Some of the best sushi that I've ever tasted, but I'm not exactly sure if it was the quality of the sushi or the fact that I almost died from hunger after my two hour wait...  They should really swap places with the chinese restaurant next door cuz that place is empty...
author: Dennis Y.

description: Really fresh fish... really great sushi.  Everything was super delicious except for our Spider Roll.  Everything else, our salmon sashimi, our various loads of nigiri, was great.  My only gripe was the incredibly long wait... but with a great friend to wait with and fresh fish it was worth it!!
author: Melissa G.

description: Waited atleast 2 hours to get seated, waited atleast another half hour to get food, ran home to get cash after realizing we didn't have enough, never got enough attention from the service....but It was completely worth it!  Unfortunately, it's not every night that I have a large timespan I can kill to wait for sushi.  I can't wait to return on an off night if there is such a thing.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
pretty good place. I am not a big fan of sushi, but my girlfriend drags me to different sushi places all the time. I like their rolls, especially the one with the macadamia nuts. The food is awesome here, but there is a warning, you have to go early. I had to go 30 minutes early just to get a table. If i went there when it opened i would have waited at least 45 minutes. 

--- food is awesome, but go early!
author: Michael H.

description: Some of the best sushi in town, if you can get in to enjoy it. Very small place, has anyone else noticed how small and difficult it is to get into Sushi Zone? They should call it Sushi Alcove.
author: Colleen B.

description: Well I did get to have some pretty good sushi but only after waiting almost 2 hours, partly because of the waitress.  We put our name on the board then walked around the corner to check out a bar and came back to find out that we would have to wait for another hour.... On a Monday night.  The waitress was serving her boyfriends table and didn't have much regard for people waiting, which I thought was rude. Once we sat down and ordered the food took forever and during our meal the waitress never asked us once if we needed anything, water, drinks, more food, nothing.  Again, the food was good, not worth the ordeal.
author: Malcolm K.

description:
I've been to Sushi Zone at least 12x in the past year. Could be more but I eat a lot of sushi...

My favorite things to order are the baked striped bass mango, the spicy salmon mango roll, and the rainbow roll. I also love all of their nigiri. 

Although the menu is not extensive, there is a great emphasis on quality of fish. And the prices are so affordable! The wait is long but the fish is amazing. Please don't give this place a two star because of the wait. All the ratings spell it out for you already!
author: Q C.

description: Damn all of you for letting the best kept secret in San Francisco out! Sushi Zone is a little, and I mean little slice of Hamachi heaven. The sashimi is some of the best in town and you have to try the Stripped Sea Bass with Mango, a velvety mix of bass, mango and a secret mayo sauce. Sushi Zone is so small that the wait can be up to an hour and a half. The trick is to put your name down, leave your cell number and go to the Orbit Room and have a tasty cocktail while you wait!
author: Matthew R.

description:
On visit here in San Francisco my friend took me to 2 sushi places, this was one of them. It is a small sushi place that is run by Japanese people and the chef is actually Japanese, which is good!
There is only one sushi chef though so orders take a while to get to you but if you sit at the counter at least you will be a little entertained by watching him prepare the sushi. 
I can't say it was anything spectacular but it was good normal sushi.
we tried the Uni ( Sea Urchin) and the Mackerel roll.  I have tried better Uni elsewhere so my taste buds were not as impressed, it is a tough one to find at its very best though and by no means was it bad, it was just average in comparison to what I've had before. The  Mackerel roll was good and didn't have a fishy after taste like some do. This restaurant did have a few signature items that seemed interesting to see on the menu listing involving macadamia nuts, papyas and such... though we did not get to try them :( maybe you can try them if you get the chance.
They didn't have too much in variety when it came to fish choices, but they were nice. The rice was freshly cooked and the atmosphere was welcoming.
The green tea ice cream was good as well and they give you a good amount so you can share properly unlike most Japanese restaurants that just give you a single small scoop.
author: Mdel R.

description:
baked sea bass is amazing....so is the stuffed jalapeno
there  can be a wait, especially on weekends
but due to price and quality of fish its worth it.
author: Lindsey Marie O.

description:
best sushi i think i've had.  the mussels are what keep me coming back every time though.  yeah, there's generally a wait.  i've found a bit of a way around the wait though... either get there as close to 5pm as possible, or you send someone to put your name down a good 45 minutes before you actually want to eat, but make sure there are at least 3 peoples names ahead of you if you do this, otherwise you'll show up past the time when your name is called and lose your place in line. 

the sushi chef has always been great and the fish has always been orgasmically good.  i've actually waited 2 1/2 hours just to sit down.  yes, i realize this borders on being pathetic, but really, after you've already waited one hour, it kinda feels like the point of no return, and you may as well just keep drinking sake  while you wait.   i generally do not make it out of sushi zone without spending $100 or more.  

I'll admit, i'm a sushi whore and i can eat way too much of it in one sitting... if i'm in the mood to gorge, i either go to sushi hunter or this place in berkeley on telegraph that looks like it used to be an ihop (the name of the place alludes me at the moment..), but if i need a pick me up, charge up my dopamine levels, over the top fantastic sushi, i go to sushi zone. and when i need that, no other place will do (at least none that i've tried so far)
author: Raynn M.

description: Best sushi in SF!  The only problem is the small space and long wait line.  Chef master owned..so he makes each order. Just wished they took reservations.
author: Dana O.

description:
you expect to wait here. you just know it will happen. but the quality of the sushi is completely worth that wait.

on that note, i went yesterday, a wednesday evening, with a coworker. we arrived at about 630 to a full restaurant, but no one in front of us waiting. we were seated at the bar in about twenty minutes. the people started lining up about forty minutes after we were seated, so we got lucky. there's one sushi chef, one waitress, and one assitant, so the service is slow, but personal. so even if you're seated immediately, there is waiting to be done. as we were at the bar, we got to interact with the sushi chef more than had we been at a table. it's a good feeling when he rolls the sushi in front of you and then hands it over, as if the restaurant's entire reason for being is serving you.

everyone has different preferences for what they call their favorite sushi, for me it just so happens to be unagi (eel), but going to sushi zone requires you to order the sea bass with mango. i have never enjoyed sea bass as much as i did yesterday. the chef seems to prefer exotic fruits with his sushi and he pairs a bed of fresh mango with the baked sea bass, covered in melted cheese, and resting in an oyster shell. it's a little slice of perfect.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: Sushi was good. Service was great. Wait was super long. Arrived at 530pm had a difficult time searching for this place. It's not actually located on market street. It's located on pearl street which is a one way street. 1815 is actually a Peruvian restaurant. If u walk on market, turn on corner , pearl st., you will find sushi zone. So back to the wait, wrote name on board sat & waited approx. 1 hr for our table. Ordered our food immediately. Waited another hour to get our food. Ate our food for about an hour. This whole event at sushi zone took us 3 hours. It was a very long wait, but the food was cheap, good quality, and delicious. I would go back but not on an empty stomach. The place is super small. Occupancy approx. 30. Be prepared for a scorching eye burn from the spice they use. Overall I came here for sushi not much for the atmosphere. I liked it. Nothing I would go goo goo gaga for because I hate waiting for over 1 hour to be seated.
author: Mimi S.

description: 2.5 years later and it is still my favorite sushi joint. I have been to countless other "best sushi place in the city" restaurants, and each one serves to confirm the Zone as the absolute best.
author: Cara H.

description: I'm afraid to even mention this place, because the wait is so long.  But it's so good, and I feel like it's only right to share it.  Two words...DAMN GOOD!  Yes, there is a wait.  Why?  The place is tiny and there is only one chef.  So you'll have to not only wait for a seat, you have to wait for everyone's order ahead of you.  But as you can see from the loyal fans crowding this place, it's well worth it.  The chef really makes sushi-making an art.  The sushi is fresh, and the service is great.  But if you're impatient...go somewhere else so that I can get my sushi.  The place is open 7 days a week, from 5-10p.  There's usually a line at 4:45, and there's no stopping the crowd until they turn off the lights and brush away the groupies from the sidewalk who are waiting to eat there the next day.
author: Mark D.

description:
I like this place overall.  Good portions of good (not great but never fishy) fish and all food is prepared in a tiny little area.  The "kitchen" consists of the sushi bar, a sink, a gas burner and a couple of toaster ovens.  I think that's cool.  It's also reasonably priced and they do a pretty good job of "dressing up" their average fish selection with creative ingredients.  Some work,  like the salmon nigiri with thinly sliced lime and the baked spicy mussels (from the toaster oven).  Some don't work like unagi and papaya roll-not good.   I do appreciate the effort though.  

I don't like one major thing about this place.  As many have already said, the wait is ridiculous.  It's not even just the wait for a table.  I wouldn't mind so much if I got to eat once I sat down but that has never happened.  You can easily wait 40+ minutes after you sit following the hour or more you already waited for a seat to get ANY of your order.  They don't stagger orders like most sushi places do where they give one group a few things, move on to another ticket and make the rest of the first group's order a little later.  They complete an entire ticket before moving on.  With only one guy behind the bar, if a party of four or more gets their ticket in before yours, prepare to wait A VERY LONG TIME.  Dinner here can easily take 3 hours not including the wait for a seat.  It's kinda like a chicken or the egg situation here.  Either way, it totally sucks.  Come early or late (like 20 mins before close because any later and they won't let you in even if you're on the list before 10). 

If you're looking for good cheap basic unpretentious sushi and have lots of time to kill, Sushi Zone is perfect.  If you're looking for unique top quality fish or you have limited time, Sushi Zone is NOT for you.
author: M M.

description: Love this place for sushi! Be prepared to wait at least an hour if you don't get there when it opens. And even once you're seated, it will take time to get your food. Only one sushi chef!  But very well worth the wait. Sushi is fresh, staff are friendly.  I love their baked mussels, albacore tataki, and tuna and mango rolls!  Hits the spot every time when I crave sushi.  And best of all they are consistent every time with their food.
author: Amelia L.

description:
Ao wants all his customers to have a good experience at his restaurant. After encouraging me to visit Sushi Zone again with gift certificate, I went with a few friends and we still experienced the wait time that many of the other reviewers mentioned, but this time around I actually got to try the sushi.  The Hawaiian number 2 is amazing as is the sea bass baked with mango appetizer.

Very enjoyable, but still uncertain about whether or not the wait is really worth it unless you have people to wait with you that will provide good company for 2 hrs.



____________________________
Heartbreak and an empty stomach. 

My friend just flew in from MI and was craving sushi so I had heard how great Sushi Zone was and immediately took her there to try it out.

We arrived at 8:30 pm with only 3 parties ahead of us. We waited patiently and were seated at 9:30. So excited about sitting at the bar and seeing the amazing looking food being prepared an served.  

We placed our order at about 9:45 and were ecstatic that we only had to wait a few more minutes to wait intil the deliciousness began.

We enjoyed our seaweed salad as we counted down the parties ahead of us to be served.  Then we saw out neighbors being served the baked sea bass and mango and we salivated.

Our amazing stuffed mushrooms came out and we were glowing with the great decision that we made to try out this restaurant.  Then at about 10:30pm the sushi chef made the heartbreaking announcement that the rice was undercooked and that he couldn't serve us anything that we ordered but could prepare us sashimi if we wanted.

My friend is relatively new to sushi and was uncomfortable with the idea of sashimi so we were heartbroken and hungry.

It was almost 2am her time and all I could do is make her a grilled cheese sandwich when we got home.  

A pitiful end to the night... after 2 hrs of waiting and only a little seaweed salad and 2 stuffed mushrooms.
author: Christine L.

description: When I lived around Hayes Valley/Mid-Market, I loved frequenting this hole-in-the-wall... and I still go back sometimes for the delicious fish. Though it can be a pain-in-the-ass to wait if you have more than two people, it's worth it as long as you're not completely famished. The stools are little tough on the hemorroid-prone, but sushi is fresh and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Be N.

description: It is really good, although had to wait an hour for a table. So get there EARLY like before 5pm to eat there. They have delicious and different kinds of rolls, which is cool. Also, make sure not to go there with someone who is high maintenance about waiting, because they will not be happy with the food. But it is really really good!
author: Gina R.

description: This has to be on my top 5 list for Sushi in all of SF. It really is a hole-in-the-wall kind of place. The wait is long, but the fresh fish and friendly service definitely made up for it.  Expect at least 2+ hours from the moment you put your name on the waiting list until you walk out feeling satisfy and drunk as hell...
author: L K.

description:
I don't know whats so good about this place besides the baked mango seabass. We ordered the spicy hamachi which tasted like eating a tree. It wasn't spicy at all. The spider roll just tasted strange. How can you go wrong??? That was the worst spider roll ever. It had this weird curry taste to it. The real california roll had some imitation crab in it i think that was pretty good. The waitress took a long time to get our order I had to eventually ask her. This place is lame, I won't be back. Another letdown by the hype of yelpers. sigh...

And to top it off they gave us one less dollar in change when our change came back! I just took that off their tip they were gonna get...
author: Crum B.

description: Wonderfully fresh fish, and perhaps the smallest dining room in the city.  Go early, and expect to wait...you won't be dissappointed.  This sushi is fresh, and made with love!
author: Sarah D.

description: Believe every word of every review here.  Outstanding, shockingly cheap sushi but unbelievable wait.  I think I once waited three hours after signing my name to the wait list to get my sushi, but I got mighty lit at Martuni's during that wait, so everything seemed just fine.
author: Jenn S.

description: Unquestionably the best sushi in the city.  Unfortunately, you'll have to wait at least an hour for a seat.
author: Napoleon R.

description: After reading all these reviews, I was expecting to wait for the whole night, but the wait actually wasn't too bad.  I think it was about 45 minutes, but keep in mind it was a Thursday night.  The place is teeny tiny -- 2 tables and 8 sushi bar seats.  We got the stuffed shitake mushroom caps stuffed with baked salmon and some delicious sauce thing.  My favorite roll was the spicy hanamachi (sp?) roll which had tuna (I think), jalapenos and bits of lime.  The lime really did it for me.  I can't remember what fish it was, but the combination of everything tasted so good, it didn't really matter to me.  We also got the salmon skin roll (always a goodie) and the Hawaiian roll number 2 (mango and tuna with macadamia nuts on top, genius!).  MmmmMmmm.  The only thing I wasn't so nuts about was the miso soup.  I can overlook that though because of that lime/jalapeno combo!  Slam dunk.
author: Sobrina T.

description: Most wait a long time to eat here. Luckily, I snagged a bar seat right before the crowd arrived. The menu is limited but still creative. I'd give the sushi a 4.5 but had to rollback to a 4 star rating simply for the fact that this place is not easy to eat at. There are only 2 tables and about 6 bar seats at this whole place. I think it's smaller than my bedroom! They only have room for 1 sushi chef, 1 waitress, and 1 busboy - need I say more. What really makes the sushi awesome here is the rice. They perfectly season it and take the time to dry it properly (paddle drying each kernel). The sushi was so good that I kept eating and didn't realize until I got home how full I was. Very satisfied and want to go back!
author: Josephine H.

description:
11/18/2007
I wanted to be happily fed for my redeye.  P and I arrived at 4:50pm (we were the 4th party in line), got seated at the bar at 5pm, and ate by 5:30pm.  Mission accomplished without too long of a wait.

6/28/2007
Yes, you must endure a wait, but for those who endure, they are rewarded.  S, who had introduced me to Sushi Zone years ago, was in town.  She can't get good sushi in DC and was craving it.  She got there around 6:45pm and bet me that we would eat before 9pm.  She was close.  We ate around 8:45pm.

Some tips:
1. Just because you get seated does not mean you will be eating anytime soon.  So don't curse the hardworking lone waitress who hasn't cleaned up the empty seats yet or stare down people who have finished but are dawdling because IT WON'T MATTER.  The sushi chef prepares the food IN ORDER, so he still has to create the 25+ rolls the 10 people who sat down before you ordered before he gets to you.
2. Appetizers like salad and the baked mussels or sea bass are prepared by the assistant/dishwasher.  Yes, that sounds weird, but no matter, order some when you are seated so that you do get some food in you before the main course.  And the baked mussels are good!
3. Have backup plans in case the wait is too long.  No need for fainting spells in the restaurant.
4. Know that if you arrive around 8pm, chances are you won't get to eat.
5. Order the spicy hamachi.  You do not know what GOOD is until you have the chef's version of spicy hamachi with hint of jalapeno and lime.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
i can't decide what rating to give this place. 

like everyone says, the wait was really bad. and it's not like you can have some sake and sit down and chill while you wait for your table; you have to stand there in the doorway, cramped and awkward, getting bumped into. my little party of two waited for over an hour and 15 minutes on a tuesday night. the decor is boring, the lighting is lame, and the neighborhood sucks. 2.5 stars. 

but when the sushi came it was REALLY good. we got something with jalapeno peppers...fuck...probably the best sushi i've ever had. and the guy was workin' it back there. 5 stars!

our bill, for two, after edamame, 4 incredible rolls, AND a small sake, was a whopping 33 bucks. 5 stars, baby!

my water smelled like fish and i had to send it back. 2 stars...

again, amazing sushi. 5 stars. 

but i keep thinking about that 1.5 hour wait in a city with thousands of incredible restaurants. net net, 3 stars....
author: jean w.

description: This place is great and I'd really like it if they moved to Seattle so I could go more often.  I loved it when I was working in the Bay Area, but I miss it now.  The sushi is delicious, low prices, good quality fish, and friendly service.  The place is small and you often have to wait for a place to sit, but it's part of what makes Sushi Zone so great.
author: Josh B.

description:
sooooo awesome! amazing sushi! great service!
takes awhile though... only 2 tables and a few seats at the bar so there is ALWAYS a wait! 
well worth it though!
author: Chelsea H.

description: Great little place, delicious food, friendly staffs. The downside is the wait times but definitely coming back and recommend to friends
author: Jennifer G.

description:
really really good! not sure i'd ever be willing to wait 2+hrs for dinner again... 

on the upside, waiting while having drinks at the comet club at the corner of market/laguna was a nice way to kill time, slightly inconvenient though since even if you're on the list, if you leave, they'll give your table away... you gotta keep checking back in at the restaurant to make sure you keep your stake in line. 

once we were seated, the waitress took our order and then it took 35min to get our miso. 35min? apparently she forgot to put in the order for miso. ok, but then our appetizers (yummy mussels) never came. she forgot those too. 

by the time our food finally came, we were very very ready. it was reaaaalllllyyyyyyy amazing sushi (props for the macadamia covered hawaiian rolls and the avo/mango roll). 

downside: having to wait 2+hrs for a table (we arrived at 6pm btw) and then having to wait almost an hour for our actual food. otherwise, amazing. 

try going really early, like right when they open, and it'd probably be dandy.
author: lisa w.

description: I love this place!  The wait is long, but it IS worth the wait.  The place really needs to expand because it is way too tiny.  I love the baked striped bass mango, spicy hamachi, stuffed jalapeno, spicy mango salmon, and their tataki tuna is off the hook.  They give you a generous portion here and the fish is so fresh and delicious!  Some places just have their fish already sliced, but not here.  He slices as he makes 'em.
author: M. T.

description:
been there 3 times.....the first time was GREAT....i love thier mango salmon...there nigiri were pretty fresh

second time waited over 2 hours before seated and the food was still pretty good....

third time....got there a little earlier and waited for hour an half.....foood was not as good as the first two time...

overall i would recommend this if you are willing to wait for more than 2 hours....the sushi is well worth it tho.....
author: C L.

description: Waited 90 minutes on a Wednesday night with three friends but it was worth it!   I still can't believe how GOOD and CHEAP this place is!!!   I can't wait to go back and get more more more more.......
author: Erick Z.

description: I love Sushi Zone! My favorite is the Spicy Salmon Mango roll! Yummy! There can be a long wait, but if you go with your husband/boyfriend or best friend it gives you the opportunity to talk together and just take a minute to slow down and spend quality time with each other! I also love watching the Sushi Chef while we are eating too. It's really affordable too! It is hands down the best sushi I have ever had!
author: Aimee M.

description: My old housemate Byron brought me here for my birthday one year, and the sushi was absolutely EXQUISITE. It's a small place, usually a long wait  . . WORTH THE WAIT.
author: Kali D.

description: Finally...finally, my bf took me here last weekend. He's always telling me this is the best place to get sushi. I admit I can't really argue with him on that point because I don't eat fish. Yes, I'm a vegetarian. So, we were lucky enough to be seated at the sushi bar after about an hour wait (yes, expect a long wait time to get seated). Overall, the experience was good but I'm still partial to my fave sushi place in my hood. Ummm...so I would tell you what we ordered but after a few large sake's, I can't really remember what we ate, except that we had a lot of food!
author: Lola D.

description:
why people don't mind waiting in line for this tiny neighborhood restaurant...  

i've been to sushi zone twice.  on the first day, there wasn't a long line.  luckily, i was promptly seated as i walked in.  tiny place of probably 8 seating sushi bar and two tables.  that was it.  no music, no decoration, one sushi chef, one helper who does kitchen and dishes, and one waitress.  

second visit...  staff's different except for the helper.  again, one sushi chef, one server and a helper.  long... long waiting list.  

it didn't matter how many people were waiting in line.  there is NO RUSH!!  no hurry in whatsoever about the service.  just relaxed..  and everyone's enjoying their meal.  except for the sushi chef who is busy with keeping up with orders.  he does it one table at a time.  after all table's order's out and no new table open up, finally, the sushi chef had a moment of rest..  and he began a small chat with customers.  

the magic of waiting works like wonders.  people are hungry, and usually devours food faster.  and as long as you're seated, nobody rushes you out of the table.  such charm, i believe, reduces the table turn rates in unexpected rate.  despite the long wait, i think table turn rate is less than an hour... or a little over that.

food of course, is the major factor for drawing people to this place.  fish is always fresh.  rice, little more than some fancy ones..  it will fill your stomach.  price..  will not frighten you at the end of meal.  

fish selection is limited...  but they do have creative rolls.  i tried the one with macademia nuts on top with mango filling...pretty good.  

i heard that a small business with 3 employees.. have a lot of tax saving benefits..  especially the benefit of not paying some type of insurance and so on....  
i think they are doing their business smart with limited staff and capacity they can accomodate with that many staffs.  
with that in mind...  such a cute restaurant how it functions....  

is it worth the wait?  yeah.  if you live in that neighborhood and have a sushi fix on your regular work day, and want a pleasant time chatting with your friend without having to worry about breaking your bank, an excellent choice.
author: E P.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to eat at Sushi Zone based fully on it being the 2nd highest ranked place that came up when I searched "sushi bars" and was within my spending budget. After gathering a few tips from previous yelp reviews, we set off in search of the hole-in-the-wall, hour-long-wait sushi bar. We arrived around 6:30pm and, after we wrote our name on a little white board, we were told we had around an hour wait. There was a few bar stools for us to wait but they were all occupied so we walked around the area. Sadly, everything closed by 7pm so we were left to wander through laundermats until we thought it would be in our best interest to stay in the restaurant to listen for our name. By 7:40pm, we were seated with our orders placed.

We chose two appetizers: Baked Mussels and Baked Sea Bass. Both of which were delicious but the winner was the Baked Mussels. The Baked Sea Bass had warmed mangos at the bottom of the mussel shell that it was baked in that didn't rub me in the right way.

For the meal we decided that the Hawaiian #2 and Mango Hamachi sounded most appealing from yelpers. I don't normally eat raw fish (I know, what am I doing eating sushi) but I decided that I really should eat these rolls that were getting rave reviews. The Hawaiian #2 was VERY good. Like, kind of amazing. I always thought that eating in one bite was just something I did out of convenience, but the way the ingredients worked together and pretty much NEEDED each other in this roll made me appreciate sushi that much more.  The Mango Hamachi was good as well but the Hawaii #2 took the cake for the raw rolls.
The we ordered the Rock n' Roll and the Artichoke and Avocado rolls. The Rock n' Roll usually never goes wrong (and it didn't) and it's not raw so naturally, I wanted to order that. It was very good but not really unique to this place. The Artichoke and Avocado was very... different at first. But after 3 pieces of it, it really kind of grew on me. I can't say it was my favorite and that I would order it again, but I did think that it was interesting.

The waitress and chef were both very curteous and welcoming and we got through the meal without ever getting pressure from them to leave. We finally left close to 9 and there were still lots of people waiting so don't try to wait out the crowd, just get there earlier than you plan to eat and your chance will come.
author: Virginia C.

description: You can't make reservations and will wait an hour and a half to sit if you have a table of 2 (don't even try it if there are more of you), but I would gladly wait 3 hours.  The food is wonderful and the atmosphere seals the deal -- I f!ng love this place
author: Chris G.

description: Hands down the best sushi I've ever had.  Go there with people you don't mind spending an evening with because, as the other people who've reviewed this place can atest to, the wait time is extremely long.  Ordering the beer while you're waiting is also pretty key in not getting fustrated.  For the extra treat, order the grilled mussels as an appetizer...Not on the menu (at least it wasn't last time I went), but soooooo good.
author: Peter Z.

description: This is defintely the best sushi you'll find in San Francisco. There are weird hours and a long wait because they only have 2 tables and a sushi bar that seats 10. I've waited for 2 hours just to eat here and every time it was well worth the wait. Owl, the main sushi chef that works there is a machine! I highly recommend everything on the specialty menu. The sea bass with mango are the best appetizers you'll ever have so get at least 2!
author: Sal B.

description: I think it's all been said already---some of the best damn sushi I've ever had.  Yeah, there's often a long wait, but you know that going in so don't whine about it. I went a few weeks ago with some friends and realized it had been way, way too long since I'd been there, I don't know what was wrong with me.  This is one of those I'd eat there every day if I could places.  I'm still dreaming about the striped-bass-and-mango appetizer.
author: Jen S.

description:
nothing compares..
great scene , superb sushi .. has never let me down!
-moderate prices and NO JOKE..the freshest fish and the largest pieces ever ever ever...i dare anyone to go try it out and tell me otherwise :)
author: CadoBaby P.

description: Not a review but a question for Michael: How about letting us know where the "far better sushi" is in this city? It's pretty hard to find, so please tell us.
author: Sandy R.

description: FANTASTIC SUSHI!!  It's a tiny place, and there's usually a long wait, but the sushi is worth it. Excellent food, reasonably priced.
author: Godot -.

description: Insanely good salmon despite a horrific wait time during peak hours.  Seriously folks, the place is good, but you have to go when it's not busy or you will wait in desperate hunger.
author: Richard P.

description: Good sushi, not enough sake (choices) and crazy music (some resemblance to modern rock). This place could get 4 stars only for the sushi. I didn't like the ambiance much, they could do much better and a smile from the sushi bar does go a long way!
author: Praveen K.

description: Finally went here tonight after not going many times because of the long wait. I won't wait 90 minutes again between writing our name and getting the food, but I was not disappointed. The spicy mango tuna was fantastic. I'll go back, but during the week and early.
author: Nicolas K.

description: love this place when it was nori sushi and still love it! RIP Nori you will definately be missed! Sushi here is the best in the city, and the baked mussels are to die for! The wait is worth it, just make sure you go there on a semi full stomach because you will wait 1.5 hour for a table. If your super hungry its not worth it (cranky)!  CASH ONLY!
author: lil d.

description:
The Bad:  Over rated, long waits (always), and bad service.
The Good:  Great sushi.

The poor waitress is harried and unattentive.  The suhi chef is slow--he likes to talk so try not to engage him or you may never get served.  You would think the place would comp a drink or two for waiting one, two, or sometimes three hours to eat.  There are better places with less hassle.  Don't fall for the tiny, out of the way vibe thing--it may sound cool, but after waiting forever...those are hours you'll never get back.
author: James W.

description:
1 word: amazing

a few rules:
1. don't go here with more than 4 people. the place is tiny and there is no room for more.
2. this place opens at 5. get here at 4:30 and wait outside until they open. thank me later.
3. enjoy!

what to get:
1. spicy hamachi
2. hawaiian #1
3. hawaiian #2 
4. tuna mango

i used to live in the city and would frequent this place often. every time i head back to sf i make sure to stop here.  best sushi in the city and it's  pretty cheap.  make sure to tip your chef.
author: J B.

description:
Seriously, bring a book--- or do what I do and get slightly hammered on sake while you wait. I think we put our name in at 6, and ate at 8:30... 

Very good FRESH sashimi. Hella pricey, but worth it. They give you double what most places serve. MMMMMM....

Dear Hawaiian #2 roll: I thought I hated macadamia nuts... but your nuts, those were damn tasty. (that's right.) Mango-ey, tuna beautifulness. You make me forget that I could turn into Jeremy Piven. Note: ask for less mayo and mas red spicy sauce. It makes it actually spicy. 

Get the sake in the white bottle with the gold? trim at the top. Subtle, green and nutty.
author: ascheras g.

description: Great sushi but go early to avoid the line.  Get the spicy hamachi hand roll!
author: C P.

description: hands down 5 stars for the sushi.  the entire menu is my favorite.  wait the sea bass in the muscle shell is the best than the rest of the menu comes second.  the only negative is i'm a family of 5 and if we bring a friend than we need a table of 6 to 8.  well, sushi zone fits about 15 people at one time.  don't be discouraged, i promise it will be the best sushi experience of your life.  the last tip i have for you, is to order everything you want from the beginning.
author: Dave And Teenz Q.

description: Great, low-key, good value sushi place near Hayes Valley.  The best dish on the menu is by far the mushroom dish under the appetizer section, better than the jalapenos that others on yelp recommend.  The value is very good, with most appetizers at around $5 and the sushi at an affordable price of $6 or so.  The one drawback is the wait --- sometimes it can run over an hour.  But I am definitely a huge fan.
author: Jesse C.

description: I love this place.  The sushi is yummy and inexpensive.  I especially love the strange sea bass in a shell made in a toaster, its a perfect start.  The Hawaiin #2 is also great, tuna with macademia nuts and mango, I mean come on.  The wait can be long but the food is worth it and what do you expect from a restaurant with 2 tables and a sushi bar.  The best thing to do is put your name down and go down the street have a drink and wait your turn.
author: Lauren H.

description: Best sushi joint I've been to. Went with a friend who knew the place and the chef. Had to wait a very long time because their dining area is tiny, but man was it worth it. We got seats at the bar and ordered dish after dish from the chef and it was seriously, bar none, better than any other sushi I had had. Worth the wait.
author: Christopher X.

description: Loved, loved, loved it! My ever-so-wonderful boyfriend recently took me to Sushi Zone for my birthday. Being in the know, he made sure we arrived about 30 minutes before they opened so that we'd be part of the "first wave" of diners. We started off with the mussels which were prepared in a way I'd never experienced before. The mango/clams were to die for and the rolls and scallops were scrumptious. The atmosphere was wonderfully casual, if not quirky. This place is right up my alley.
author: June M.

description: it is simple, jerks. grab a 6 pack from the convenience store down the street and porch it with your pals for awhile.
author: erik s.

description: Some of the best sushi in SF.  Inexpensive.  Long wait.  It's worth it.
author: Elton D.

description: I was going to give it one star, just to throw people off. It's better that people think its a dump and dont come. Because It is by far the best fish in town and i'd rather keep it a secret.  You can cry about the wait all you want but if you enjoy real, good sushi not some shit from mas sake, then you'll be impressed and will leave dreaming about the hamachi.
author: Bowie L.

description:
Happy Monday all ,

had an opportunity to check out Sushi Zone last week and the food was excellent as well as the service.

The seaweed salad was tasty and not to salty. You can not go wrong picking any of the fine sushi offerings I personally recommend the mango salmon but all were excellent !

Get there early for the first seating or prepare to have a cocktail across the street to pass the extended wait time.
author: Wayne n.

description: I woulda given it five stars if not that "loooooong" wait. We went to there at 6:30pm Sunday night, and had our butt sit till 9:00pm to get out first bite of that fantastic fish. My hubby was really upset cuz he went from "I am not that hungry" to "I am gonna eat that bench leather at the entry" during the 2.5 hour wait. But its worth waiting... people behind me kept saying. Well, it was! When it was our turn, we ordered spicy hamachi, mango hamachi and spicy tuna, baked mussel, five orders of different nigiri. I have never had fish that fresh I didn't bother to eat with ginger (which I usually pile up on top of the fish to cover even 1% fishy taste while eating at  this price range japanese restaurant) Hamachi is the highlight of this sushi bar, We end up spending $55 plus $10 tip, and we totally dont mind to wait again.
author: mushroom L.

description: you'll wait. and wait. for this much waiting, there's far better fin fare.
author: Brett W.

description: You've probably heard it before from everyone but this place is the best sushi restaurant in the city. Hands down. period. The wait for a table takes forever (people actually line up outside before it opens) and there are only two tables and eight counter seats but totally worth it. I've been eating here for seven years and I come back every time with a smile on my face. Try everything here and if you like Saba (mackerel) it is the freshest I've ever had. Seriously, try this place.
author: Robert S.

description:
had dinner here with my friend yesterday.
i had never been here, but luckily she had (she was the one who suggested this place) and told me that we would have to be there at 5pm when they opened or else we'd have to wait... we're not the type of people who wait to have a meal.  we want to eat when we want to eat cus we're hungry.  nothing is worth waiting for cus there's always somewhere else you can go.
we arrived at 4:50pm and it was still closed.  we saw the staff of 3 busteling around the little restaurant getting everything ready.  a few minutes after we got there, two other people came to wait for opening.  at 5pm, the waitress opened the door and told us that they were running behind a little and would open the door in 5 minutes.  
sure enough, in 5 minutes, she turned the sign over in the window to 'open', opened the door for us and asked if it was just the two of us.  we sat at the sushi bar right by the cash register.
there are two booths that fit 4 people in the restaurant, and i think the sushi bar can fit up to 10 people.  the two people who were waiting outside with us supposedly had one more coming so they had to wait until everyone in their party arrived.  so keep that in mind if you're coming here.  it doesn't matter if some of you are there already.  you won't get seated until everyone in your party is present.  
the restaurant was full within 20 minutes of being open...
my friend suggested a few signature items i should try.  like the striped bass with mango and some creamy stuff served on a seashell... that was really good.  it's served warm from their little toaster oven.  my friend also ordered the hawaiian roll 2 which had macademia nuts sprinkled on top of the rolls... very good.  i ordered a papaya unagi roll and a roll with hamachi, avocado and fish eggs.  both rolls were delicious.  
be prepared to wait a while for your orders.  everything won't come out at the same time, so it's really better to just order everything to share since the dishes most likely will come out one at a time as the lone sushi chef seems to make one item of each ticket at a time.  the other guy prepares the non roll items such as the striped bass in the seashell.  
the place seems to have a bigger selection of their rolls.  a few nigiri, and sashimi is a choice of just one kind or chef's choice.
the staff is really friendly and attentive.  they never make you feel rushed even if people are waiting in line.  that might be the downside if you're the one standing in line, but this place doesn't seem to believe in the quantity of people they serve each night... rather it's about the quality of service for their guests who are sitting down having their meal.  so... if you chose to wait for a spot to have a meal at sushi zone, then don't be mad at the restaurant if guests decide to linger at their tables.  the staff is not going to drop off the check until the guest asks and the staff is not going to try and make them leave to seat new guests.
when we were done with our food, the waitress asked if we wanted anything else so with that indication we asked if they had desserts and she said they have green tea ice cream, so we shared a scoop of that in the end.  when we were done, we asked for the check - it's cash only so bring cash.
i'd definately go back - but again, i'll make sure to be there right before 5pm
:)
author: charlotte s.

description: The Best Sushi I Have Ever Had.  Consistently.  So yes, if you get there more than half an hour after they open, you can expect to wait anywhere from 30 minutes to two hours, but what do you expect?  They only have two tables and a handful of bar seats.  One server/host works with one sushi chef and one prep cook/dishwasher on busy nights, and they can only handle so much volume.  The upside to keeping such a small restaurant is phenominal quality control.  The sushi here is the best I've had, and I've been whoring myself at sushi joints all over the Bay Area and South Florida for at least six years.  Get anything with mango.  Get anything with macadamia nuts.  Get anything with thinly sliced lime.  Particularly, I recommend the Hawaiians 1&2 and the Spicy Hamachi.  So just remember: get there early.  Sushi Zone is the place to start a night.  Fill up on the most delicious sushi you've ever had for less than $20 a person (including a beer or few) and then head out on the town.
author: Danny D.

description: Basically, the question comes down to this: are you willing to wait a while for sushi that is better than the majority of places in SF?  I feel this restaurant experience is pretty predictable - you will eat really fresh sushi, but will have to wait a while.
author: Michael C.

description: i dont understand the long wait and high ratings for this place.
author: LT B.

description: I have been to many expensive restaurants that are great. This is one of very few that are great and inexpensive. The food is awesome. If you are a sushi lover, you must try this place. Four stars for me, only because the space is uncomfortably small.
author: margret j.

description: i love. love. love this place... and for a long time i did not want to tell too many people about it because i knew if i ever saw them in line before me... i'd possibly start growling at them. sushi zone is small. very small, and if you luck out you might eat a 1 1/2 after your name hits the board... but usually not.  the sushi is the best in SF hands down but shhhhh... don't tell anybody.
author: miss m.

description: I love love love the sushi from this place. Developed a bit of an addiction to their Hawaiian rolls. But the last time I was there it took 4 hours to get food! Normally you spend 1 to 2 hours waiting on the sidewalk, but 4 hours?!? I haven't been back since. Nothing is that good.
author: Ona R.

description:
Well after all the hype on here about how amazing the place is even with the absurd wait I had to try it out for myself.  let me start by saying that thank GOD I didn't even attempt going to this place on a Friday or Saturday night.  Although I can't imagine my experience last night (Sunday) being any WORSE on those days.  After showing up literally at 5:04pm (or 4 minutes after they opened) we were added to the list (2 of us and two parties ahead of us).  We were told by the waitress that the wait would be 45 minutes.  Crazy since we walked in when it opened but not bad enough to walk out.  What made it tolerable was she said we could sit inside and get edamame and drink sake.

The place is small.  It has two tables (each seats four although most of the night two were occupying them) and about 10 seats at the counter, and thats it. 

Now I'm going to speed this up.  First, I was not at all impressed with the "specials", or lack thereof.  I consider myself a sushi snob in every sense of the word and I'm sorry but any place that doesn't have fresh toro is not going to score many points with me.  Secondly, the chopstick situation.  They recycle their WOOD chopsticks.  Disgusting.  Now to get right to the point, it took us TWO HOURS to get seated.  Yes, we got there when it opened and had just two people in front of us.  just after 7pm we are seated.  For two hours I stared as the one chef behind the bar worked at a SNAILS pace.  Now I've been to my share of sushi bars and not for a second does snails pace, make me want to jump over the counter and roll some shit up myself, equate to better sushi.  Roger at Zushi Puzzle is all you need to experience to prove that theory wrong.  The bottleneck is probably 20% lack of seating and 80% Chef Snail-san behind the bar.

Once we sat down we gave our order and the waitress informed us that "you might want to get some appetizers because its going to be a while".  THREE HOURS from the time we walked in when it opened, we were finally served out meal at 8:02pm.  UNACCEPTABLE on every level.  At this point after wasting three hours of my life it would take a miracle to make it even remotely worth it.  Guess what?  It wasn't.  The sushi was GREAT.  Very fresh, huge pieces of Nigir.  The rolls were flavorful.  But the rolls were also poorly made with them breaking apart mostly due to the fact the rice was ice cold.

So long story short, I will never EVER come back here.  NOTHING is worth that wait and for a MUCH better experience I highly recommened going to Zushi Puzzle which has easily 3 times the specials, just as fresh fish, and an experience to remember.

You guys need to figure out that there is absolutely no reason to run a business that has a three hour turn around time and absolutely NO sense of urgency.  Get a second chef, a bigger place, and bump the cheap prices up slightly to compensate.  It will be well worth your while.

I am still puzzled why so many people would rate this place so highly.  Yes the sushi is good, but the selection leaves much to be desired and the wait makes the whole experience utterly horrible.
author: Emm B.

description: okay okay calm down people. i heard stellar things about sushi zone but we had to wait for a REALLY long time for our sushi even though we were like the 3rd table of the night to order, which we ordered in two installments on purpose but which came all together, and while the maguro and hamachi nigiri were very fresh and delicious, i thought the rice was not too flavorful. definitely tasty, don't get me wrong, the smaller your restaurant is the more likely i am to think it is awesome (i like to delude myself into thinking i am like the cristopher columbus of bay area restaurants) but i dont envision myself giving up another 3 hours and $90 in this establishment anytime soon...
author: Lisa M.

description:
we got there at 745. we walked around, came back around closing time (945p).  restaurant closed at 10p.  got seated at 1015p.  received our first sushi at 1045.  left at 1145.    this was a thursday night.

someone ahead of us noticed we looked mad/sad while we were waiting and convinced us that it's an "experience" so we wldn't leave.  

i'm glad we stayed. it was really good!  my favorites
1.  striped sea bass w/ mango - baked on a mussel shell w/ some sauce on top.  this was really good and we shld've ordered more.  we didn't know it was an appetizer when waitress told us it was the last call.  
2.  spicy hamachi - the slice of lime made this a really distinct sushi roll.  there was a slice of jalepeno, but i didn't taste it.

fish was fresh, staff didn't rush (or anyone while we were waiting), sushi chef seemed friendly and was very precise (i watched him, shape the rice perfectly, make each roll, then wipe the area, til he made the next roll).  he made sushi making look like an art (it probably is)

sucks when u have big groups in front of you (we were a party of 2).  he makes the whole order for the whole party, then gets to the next one.  didn't take a look at other orders to see if anyone else ordered the same thing...

was worth it, and wld come back again.  just be patient.  eat a meal before you go there, and you'll get hungry again by the time your  food is ready.  and leave if there are big groups (3 and up) in front of you.
author: rien d.

description: the wait is worth it, people! ok, maybe if you're starving already, not the best idea..but, if you plan ahead and want to go out for a dining experience, and in my opinion, the best sushi i've had in this city(and i'm a hapa) then this place is SOOO GOOD!! and it's not at all expensive. get there early, put your name on the list, order some sake and brace yourself for some awesomeness. it's like the whole pavlov experiment for my best friend and i, we hear sushi zone and both of us immediately start drooling, and fantasizing about what we would order. my recommendation for an appetizer..the BAKED SEA BASS AND MANGO!!!!! orgasmic!
author: Angie B.

description:
this is the thing...i live right around the corner from this place so we can literally be there before its open.  if you can do that and minimize the wait for this place i'm sure it would get 5 stars.  but most people can't...

the first time i went there we were there 15 minutes before it opened and there was still a line, we luckily got the last table but watched as everyone was serverd their food while we played hangman and tic-tac-toe to pass the time.

when the food arrived, it was good. but its not worth the wait.  you can go around the corner to sushi delight and have just as good, if not better, and not have to think of games to play to pass time.
author: Vinyl J.

description: Tasty sushi, I really liked the artichoke roll (vegetarian), but the fish was also delicious.  It is a tiny restaurant (2 tables, and maybe 8 or so seats at the sushi bar) so this is not a good place for groups - best for 2.  Cash only, no reservations - put your name on the white board.
author: Sara S.

description:
+5 stars for fresh sushi in wholesome and palatable portions. the baked mussels are to die for!
-1 for the unpleasant realisation that i must be some sort of pseudo-intellectual jackass to be a true denizen of sushi zone.

fine, i'll endure the wait for a table. fine, i'll cast obnoxious glances at the befuddled couple who decide that the best way to order sushi is one plate at a time, 20 minutes apart. however, i'll put my foot down when i wind up surrounded by patrons who find it most appropriate to enjoy sushi by cluttering the table with their heavy texts on theory, or shouting above the general milieu that ORGANIZED RELIGION IS FOR MISGUIDED ZEALOTS. no, i don't care that your new goal is to write a script per day, or whether the prose on your crumpled lined paper evokes the right amount of pathos. bite me. or better yet, shower and reconsider the semi-dreadlocked coiff.
author: Mia L.

description:
mmmmMMMMMMMMmmmmm
amazingly made to perfection!
crazy long waits but worth every bite.
author: Laura K.

description: came here with a friend on a monday night around 6pm...there was no wait at all, which was nice. she and i were seated at the bar immediately. the atmosphere was interesting. i know a restaurant cannot be responsible for the quietness or loudness of another party BUT i found the loud music in combination with loud diners to be distracting.the food was reasonably priced but in my opinion, the menu was a bit limited. when the food came out, the rolls were very loosely rolled with the wrapper coming off in places. thats probably nitpicky BUT part of the experience of food IMO is in the presentation. plus when the rolls are that loose it can be harder to eat the food. the food itself was pretty good, although the uni didn't seem to be as fresh as i've had at other places. all in all, it was good. not earthshatteringly delicious. my mouth didn't explode into million tasty pieces each time i bit into a roll. i'm definitely glad i didn't have to wait because i would have been disappointed.  there are other places that are better, with a more intimate atmosphere.
author: doggie d.

description: Best-tasting sushi in San Francisco. Hands-down.  The drawback is obviously the inevtiable long wait to get seated, but there's a bar across the street so it's not so bad.  The spicy hamachi roll, spicy mussel role, and hawaiin #1 are my favorites.  But everything is delicious and the value is great.  If you don't mind waiting a while for a table, you can eat until you are stuffed and get out of there for about $30 / person.  You'll definitely leave satisified.
author: Dave D.

description: i'm half tempted to give this place 1 star to keep everyone away.  but with 140 perfect reviews..... why bother?  secret's out - this place is amazing.  prepare yourself for a loooong wait, 'cause it's about the size of a phone booth.  but put your name on the board, grab a drink at the bar next door, and settle in for something special.  make sure you get the hawaiian role #2 and the mango sea bass.  oh, and cash only but very reasonable - $25 including beers (or saki if you so desire).
author: Jonathan B.

description: After a few years, I finally wrote a review on this place, well more of a praise but same difference. Best freaking sushi you will ever try in your life! I am not kidding. Forget about all the hyped out sushi places like (sushi house and fuji etc.) However, more and more people are finding out about this place as the years pass. Their rolls are not pricey at all for the quality and proportion that you get. The rolls are very original and different from what you will get from other places. I have to mention the baked mussel and seabass mango are freaking heaven. Nevertheless, I still think this place is highly underrated compared with other places. Although it is small and packs up quickly (get there around 4:30 to ensure a spot) it is truly the best sushi place I have ever went to. Everytime I go there, I leave satisfied and full (well the bill was around 70 dollars for two people, but that's because I'm a fatass.
author: Herb L.

description: Great little place. Least commercialized restaurant ive ever been to. Friendly staff, great sushi.  Be ready for a wait.
author: Jon H.

description: Great food, great atmosphere, LONG WAIT. We were told it would be over an hour wait when we arrived at 8 pm on a Friday night, but we didn't get seated until just past 10 pm. Just so you know, the restaurant seats approximately TWELVE to FOURTEEN people. The chef is great, and we enjoyed sitting at the counter chatting with him. Totally worth the wait, but just know that it will be a LONG wait.
author: Katherine L.

description: There's a treacherous wait and like seating for 16 or so. We put our name in and then went to the Orbit Room for drinks. At about 10 PM or so, we returned and grab seating at the bar. We told the sushi guy to make us whatever he thought was good, which to me is a blank check. I don't think a lot of people request that so he had to think for a little while. But after some processing, we got served a steady stream of rolls, in pairs. WOW. They were awesome. I don't know if I was just famished because it was now 10:30 PM or if I was in heaven, but the sushi was some of the best I've had in the U.S.! (I still put my sushi breakfast at the Fish Mkt in Tokyo up on a pedestal). Sushi guy did wonderful things with mango and eel, and all sorts of other delectables. I haven't been back there since, mostly because my friend and I don't seem to be talking now, but need to think about a return to the Zone soon!
author: Janet C.

description: so good!  you definitely need to go at least an hour before you think you'll really be hungry, and even then be prepared to devote at least three hours to the waiting, eating, waiting again, and then eating of your meal, but once you taste the creations coming out from behind the tiny bar you won't doubt that every bite was worth it.  the baked sea bass with mango is amazing (and comes out fast!) and i also got to sample the hawaiian #2, spicy hamachi, and alaskan rolls, all of which i enthusiastically recommend.  every plate that passed in front of me looked delicious and fresh (despite the torture of them always being destined for a different table) and most special rolls are still only around $5.  my mouth is already watering in anticipation of going back!
author: ali l.

description: After living in sf for just about my whole life i never knew about this great sushi hot spot. This restaurant is about the size of my living room..literally. There are two tables and one long counter top space which could house about 20 people max. There is usually a long wait for this place if you don't come at the right times because it is so small. Come at 5 when it opens and then every hr and half thereafter to avoid long waits. Since my friend is a regular there he knew the exact time frame we should arrive so we didn't have to wait at all. There is only one sushi chef so the food can take some time to prepare. We ordered a few appetizers to start but I could only remember the shitake mushroom with salmon because it was mui excellente!..and I'm not being bias because i am a salmon lover. As for the sushi rolls - we ordered the Hawaiian (raw tuna and mango), rock and roll, spicy tuna and a roll with unagi and papaya. There was nothing spectacular about the presentation of the sushi because it seemed like every roll looked the same. But the freshness of their fish and fruit is what makes Sushi Zone special. If you love raw fish then this is the sushi go to spot for you if you have the patience to wait. I will have to come back again to try their other entrees.
author: Bonnie Y.

description: Excellent sushi. We did wait for awhile outside but were able to drink a glass of beer outside :) The interior of the restaurant is very cramped with only 2 real tables. But the quality of the fish made it worth it to sit at the bar.
author: Sarah W.

description: Right off the bat, this place is Japanese owned which is definitely a plus as the waitress and staff were very polite and the food was presented in very neat and clean fashion.  After putting our name on the list for 2, we waited roughly 50 minutes to sit.  This place does has pretty limited seating and it is a bit warm and stuffy.  We finally sat at the sushi bar on the stools.  We placed our order and received our beverages, soup, and stuffed jalapeno appetizer in 15 minutes.  The Jalapeno appetizer was alright, I was expecting a little punch and you only get two small peppers with a little albacore for $5.50.  Our sushi took another hour and twenty minutes.  The sushi however was quite tasty and the fish was very fresh.  We noticed the sushi chef took a whole half of a hamachi (yellow tail) fish skin on and took time in trimming it making sure all the inedible bits were clear for perfect nigiri presentation.  The Hawaiian Mac Nut #2 roll had a very nice flavor combination.  The spicy hamachi roll was also quite tasty but again, it lacked that spicy punch.  The albacore roll was very good, nice quality fish.  Octopus roll was OK, the flavor and make up was just like the albacore roll so it tasted like the almost the same except with Tako.  The Suzuki (Striped Bass) was delicious!!!  It came with a ponzu dipping sauce.  The overall waiting experience was like a marathon and I am not sure I would do it again.  The overall food experience was very good, the quality of fish and flavor of the sushi made the wait somewhat worth it.  Make sure you get a snack before heading over and have lots of patience.
author: Petri Y.

description: tasty creations and very fresh sushi.  the best hamachi i've ever had!  just be sure to get there early (before six) or be prepared to wait anywhere from thirty minutes to a couple hours.
author: Vic A.

description: holy moly. this is great sushi. the veg ones are unique and i even (oh my) dared to eat some fishy ones!! they were just so tasty!! the wait is long (so they say..we were lucky) the food is made to order so it takes a while for your food to come over as well. it's a small place and you wouldn't even know where it is. but it is just spectacular.
author: Anita C.

description: wow, the most fun I've had people watching and eating sushiin a hot minute :) Fresh, fresh fish adn glorious unpretentious combos of flavor...amazing.
author: Season F.

description: Great hole in the wall spot.  Its definitely one of those little "sushi club" spots in the city.  You put your name on a board, drink about 3 beers since the wait is always about an hour, and then you get to dine.  The fish is always fresh and some of the dishes are quite creative.  The atmosphere is more of a low key sushi joint, and I think that they like it that way.  Its not meant to be one of those trendy sushi bars with "great house music," and its definitely worth checking out a few times if you're a serious sushi fan.
author: Marc G.

description: Mushy, pieces of shit sushi. I came here with 3 other people extremely hungry and waited over 2 hours to sit down. I was so pissed off that I had to wait so long on an empty stomach that I turned into a total bitch disregarding the company and just wanting to leave. But I could not leave. This guy that brought me there has some serious guns in his closet, and despite my misery I was afraid to leave in fear of being shot. So I thought to myself, just wait it out- it can't be that bad. But it was. After sitting down, it took another hour and a half for the Mexican sushi chef to make those shitty rolls. I desperately kept looking at the clock and it was like watching paint dry. Right next to us there was a couple vigorously making out and then I realized why this place has 4 stars. When you come here, the wait is so dam long that you go to the bar across the street and you get fucked up. By the time you are ready to eat, anything tastes good. Fuck you Sushi Zone; you have no respect for my time. I would rather be eating pigs balls than waiting that long.
author: Marta A.

description: in an effort to ditch the last remaining baggage of something i once held sacred, i too shall jump on the yelping bandwagon for how amazing this little sushi joint is. phenomenally good sush, probably the best i've ever had.  the chefs are super nice and can get creative with the toaster oven. yes, toaster oven. magical little devil. who knew that could make this experience so complete.
author: julia r.

description: Thank you Nicole for taking me here!  I could eat the baked mussels and the spicy hamachi roll everyday.
author: Gabriela P.
