description: simply the best sushi in san francisco.  a sixteen seat restaurant, the zone is small yet sublime.  a line usually starts forming twenty minutes before opening, and yes it can take an hour to be seated, but ablolutely worth it.  hawaiian roll #2 is genius.  BBQ mussles?  i'll take two, please.  this is the place that i take any visting friend for perfect sushi.  every single person who i've turned on to the zone has become a regular.  it's awesome.  a gal pal went to cambodia, thailand, and china for five weeks and EVERY single email she sent ended with her craving for the zone.  needless to say it was our first stop from the airport!  check the specials board...always something good popping up.
author: church B.

description: you have to be patient for a table, otherwise your date turns into an orangutang and the idea of a quick bite vanishes from your mind. monkey or no, it's definitely a commitment worth having - with a mango hamachi roll to boot.
author: Domenique B.

description: god, this place is delicious. excellent rolls, and fresh, fresh fish!! i tried this hawaiian roll - something with tuna, mango and macadamia nuts-it was beyond delicious!! well worth the wait.
author: eve l.

description: love love love this place!  i have been going to SZ for over 6 years.  they are consistantly fresh and delicious and cheap!   the one downside...the wait. it  is really bad.  we usually go right when they open at 5.30 and there are people lining up outside at that time too. open. open .open. crazy i know but it is better than having to wait for an hour or eat really really late.  get anything with macademia nuts. jalepenos. and of course the baked mussels.  yum!
author: Caroline S.

description: get there at 4:30, even though they dont open till 5, wait 30 min and you wont be disappointed!
author: Jeshua B.

description: If the stars align and you don't have to wait for 2 hours, then you are the happiest ever!  However, if you are like me & my boyfriend, who I was DYING to take him to Sushi Zone for Hawaii Rolls #1 & 2, we decided to get there early, around 6pm, thinking no one would be eating that early.  Well, we just missed the table cut-off (the people right ahead of us sat down immediately) - and you know how that happens, when a place with very little seating, gets everyone seated right before you get in line....well, let's just say, we didn't sit down until 8pm.  We saw couples come and go, writing their names on the dry erase board and leaving for hours - "but we got here at 6! there's no way it will take more than 45 minutes...right?"  In any case, we waited the full two hours, sat down, and had a lovely meal (even though we had to sit at the two corner bar stools by the door (which can be really uncomfortable because the stools have no backs, and it can be freezing when people stand in the doorway).  But, the sushi is that good that I would do it again...once my memories of the REST of the experience fade a little, or I somehow end up with a lot of extra time on my hands.
author: Leigh c.

description: Wow!  Great sushi at a diner.  The hamachi kama was excellent and only 10.50!  The mussel nigiri and saba were mind blowing!  You gotta be there at 430pm for the first seating or around 7p for the 2nd.  No reservations, people but money, bro.
author: Diparshi M.

description: worth the wait!!11!! best damn sushi i ever had in my life!!
author: Paola W.

description: one of my faves in SF.  but the wait sometimes just isn't worth it.  if you do try to go  be prepared for a long experience.  at least 1 hour waiting for a seat, possibly 90 min. then another hour before you get your food after you've ordered and you're seated.  but they'll always get you some beer or  sake and some edamame if you're dying while you're waiting.  get 2 spicy hamachi rolls.  just trust me.
author: a g.

description: this place was great.  i went here with a japanese guy that i met in the hostel, and we had a delightful time.  probably the best sushi i've had, which isn't saying much because i'm from minneapolis BUT STILL!
author: Benjamin C.

description: This place is awesome.  Some of the best sushi I have had in the city.  The only negative is the wait.  Small seating area and one person making sushi for the whole crowd, but it is unbelievably good.  Just plan on spending 1-2 hours waiting to eat.   Rainbow roll is a must.
author: reza f.

description: best sushi place.awesome spicy hamachi and sashimi! do NOT go there famished though, the wait would seem eternal....
author: aj s.

description:
best sushi i've had in san francisco.

i waited for three hours, but it was so good that i forgive them for that.
author: annabel l.

description: fresh hamachi and albacore that melts in your mouth. the nigiri is among the best in SF, and even LA. spider rolls were ok. could use more creative dishes but what they have is almost worth the wait, put your name on the list, then run errands for a couple hours.
author: H K.

description: The only reason this place didn't get 5 star is... as you all know, the WAIT!!.  We got there at 7:30 and didn't get seated until 9.  This place is small, and waiting out in the cold is not condusive to a very pleasant experience.  I don't know if it's due to the hour and a half wait or the sushi, but it was good.  One of the top 3 in my list.  But dammit, if it wasn't for the wait, i might patronize this place more often.  Here's a bit of advice, wear comfortable shoes and a warm jacket.
author: gummy j.

description: This is my favorite sushi restuarant in SF.  The only drawback is the wait time for seating and ordering.  super fresh fish...Generally takes about 3 hours to complete a meal here...but its worth it!
author: Michelle F.

description: the best.  period.  plus, GREAT music.
author: E C.

description: Been going there for years.  I got hooked on this place via word of mouth.  My favorite roll is the spicy tuna.  The green mussels were also delicious.  Worth the wait.  Just don't be in a rush.  This should be the time you spending getting to know your partner or date.
author: Mara O.

description: i have been having a sushi challenge with 12beer and i have to say that my sushi place just won tonight cause i got special rolls since i'm such a regular but this is not to say that i didn't totally love the sushi zone. i will have to come back more but it is not as convenient. we arrived at a bit after 5 and waited til like 6:30, which is fine cause i figured it would be that way. their miso soup was very good and had lots of fried tofu bits in it. their stripped bass was delicious!!!!! my favorite by far. in general the fish was very fresh, they have some unusual rolls and put shiso in many things which i love.  i'd certainly go back! i saw lots of people eating rolls with radish sprouts in them that i want to try! they also played some good musics to dine by. but since i live in the east bay, and you have to plan at least an hour and a half wait my return may not be any time too soon.
author: celiac j.

description: danny d has the right recommendations (hawaiian role #2) and matthew r has the right idea of going to the orbit room while you wait the 1+ hours, and while i was happy with the sushi here, i still think kabuto has better hamachi and sake if youre looking for that pure unadulterated melt into your seat, roll your eyes back, groan in ecstasy experience.  the nigiri is a tad too big to put in your mouth whole, and attempting to bite any nigiri in half is always a dicey proposition, especially when youre on a date.  nothing is as inelegant as having your nigiri crumble into your wasabi mix.  Sachio is still the best in my opinion.  i think the appeal of sushi zone is in its personality (small cozy neighborhood alleyway), exclusivity (the place is SO small that when u DO get a seat, u feel like you EARNED it, and it makes everything THAT much better), quality, and price.  we had four people with beer for under $100 with tip.
author: Curtis Y.

description: after all of these years, the zone is still my most favorite sushi restaurant ever. there was a time when the wait became too much, so i tried to find a replacement...but failed miserably. it's really in a league of its own in terms of freshness, quality, innovation and price. so long as you commit to a several hour affair and aren't in a hurry, it makes for the best night out. pisco, next door, is a great place for a few cocktails while you're waiting for your table. i'll continue to show my devotion to sushi zone and stuff myself silly (salmon negiri is the BEST) as often as possible.
author: julie b.

description: sushi zone is not your typical sushi.  its anything but traditional, but that's what makes is so great.  the inventive rolls are nothing short of delicious, especially if you like things like mango, shisho leaves, and macadamia nuts in your sushi.  and yes, they do use mayo in some of the appetizers and rolls - get over it.  it tastes SO good it really doesn't matter.  unfortunately, there is no way around the wait. . .even if you go early, there is already a line wrapped around the corner by the time they open their doors.  thus, its best to go with a friend you haven't seen in a while, so you can catch up over some sake while you wait.  i'm surprised to read all the bad reviews, complaining about things like the wait or the fact that they make "american style" sushi. . .if you know what you're getting into, and are open to a san francisco twist on the japanese classics, sushi zone can't be beat.
author: Erin C.

description: yummy yummy....long wait, get there eary and be prepared to wait fort a great meal. you should not go hungry.....or you can get some nachos by the safeway to keep you while you wait =0 )
author: alda c.
